Chandrakirti summarizes the good qualities of a first-ground Bodhisattva by comparing him or her to an eighth Superior of the Hinayana. Because the good qualities of Hinayana Superiors are relatively easy to attain they are also easier to understand, and so Chandrakirti uses them to illustrate the good qualities of a Bodhisattva Superior.

As mentioned before, when Buddha taught the Hinayana path he explained eight levels of Hearer Superior from approachers to the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer to abiders in the accomplishment of a Foe Destroyer. This is the order in which the eight types of Hearer Superior are usually explained. Chandrakirti, however, explains them in reverse order, referring to the first Superior, an approacher to the accomplishment of a Stream Enterer, as an ‘eighth Superior’. His meaning is that just as an eighth Hearer Superior has already attained many good qualities and will now go on to accomplish all the good qualities of a Hearer Superior, so the first-ground Bodhisattva has attained many good qualities and will now go on to accomplish all the good qualities of a Mahayana Superior.

Emptiness and Liberation

THE GOOD QUALITIES THAT OUTSHINE OTHERS’ CONTINUUMS

This section has three parts:

1 Outshining Hearers and Solitary Realizers by way of lineage on this ground

2 Outshining Hearers and Solitary Realizers by way of wisdom on the seventh ground

3 An explanation of the meaning established by this teaching

OUTSHINING HEARERS AND SOLITARY REALIZERS BY WAY OF LINEAGE ON THIS GROUND

[I.8abc] Even when abiding on the first view of the mind of complete enlightenment

He defeats those born from the speech of the Powerful Able One and the Solitary Buddhas

Through the power of his greatly increased merit;

The Bodhisattva on the first ground has good qualities of both wisdom and method. His good qualities of wisdom are his wisdom directly realizing emptiness and so forth, but since Hearer and Solitary Realizer Superiors also possess these qualities he does not outshine these other holy beings by way of wisdom. However he does outshine them by way of method. His good qualities of method are his realizations of great compassion, bodhichitta and so forth. In dependence on these a Bodhisattva accumulates a vast collection of merit and enters the uncommon Mahayana lineage. Because Hinayana Superiors do not possess these minds or the great collection of merit that they generate the Bodhisattva on the first ground outshines these other holy beings by way of lineage. Here, the root text refers to Hearer Superiors as ‘those born from the speech of the Powerful Able One’ and to Solitary Realizer Superiors as ‘Solitary Buddhas’.

In Perfect Liberation of Maitreya Sutra Buddha says:

Son of the lineage, it is like this. For example, immediately a prince is born, because he bears the name of a king he outshines the entire retinue of elder and principal ministers through the greatness of his lineage. In the same way, immediately a novice Bodhisattva generates the mind of enlightenment, because he is born into the lineage of the Tathagatas he outshines Hearers and Solitary Realizers who have been practising pure deeds for a long time, through the power of his compassion and bodhichitta.

Son of the lineage, it is like this. For example, immediately it is born, the offspring of a garuda, the king of birds, possesses good qualities such as strength of wing and complete clarity of vision that other older birds do not possess. In the same way, immediately a Bodhisattva generates the first mind of enlightenment and is born into the great lineage of the Tathagatas he surpasses others through the strength of his wish for omniscience and the complete purity of his superior intention. Even all the Hearers and Solitary Realizers who have been practising renunciation for a hundred thousand aeons do not possess these qualities.

Because this passage refers to a Bodhisattva on the first ground we should understand the phrase ‘novice Bodhisattva’ to mean a Bodhisattva who has newly attained the first ground and references to generating the mind of enlightenment to mean generating the first ultimate mind of enlightenment.

Question Does this mean that Bodhisattvas on the paths of accumulation and preparation do not outshine Hinayana Superiors by way of lineage?

Answer No it does not. These Bodhisattvas also possess uncommon realizations of great compassion and bodhichitta, and so they too outshine Hinayana Superiors by way of lineage.

OUTSHINING HEARERS AND SOLITARY REALIZERS BY WAY OF WISDOM ON THE SEVENTH GROUND

[I.8d] And on Gone Afar he surpasses them in wisdom.

When a Bodhisattva reaches the seventh ground, Gone Afar, he develops a wisdom that is superior to that of Hinayana Superiors, and so he then surpasses them in both merit and wisdom. Some say that the reason a Bodhisattva on the seventh ground surpasses Hinayana Superiors in wisdom is that on this ground he or she is able to abandon obstructions to omniscience for the first time. However, this explanation is not correct because a Bodhisattva on the seventh ground does not abandon obstructions to omniscience. Obstructions to omniscience cannot be abandoned until all the delusion-obstructions have been abandoned, and a Bodhisattva does not abandon all the delusion-obstructions until he or she has reached the eighth ground.

According to the present system, the Bodhisattva on the seventh ground surpasses Hinayana Superiors in wisdom because he or she possesses a special quick wisdom and special powers of concentration. These enable him to enter into and rise from absorption on the perfect ultimate cessation, or emptiness, in an instant. On the first ground, when the Bodhisattva gains a non-conceptual realization of emptiness for the first time and his mind mixes with emptiness like water mixing with water he finds it difficult to rise quickly from that meditation. By the time he reaches the seventh ground, however, his mind can enter into absorption on emptiness and rise again in the duration of one finger snap. Hinayana Superiors do not possess this quick wisdom.

Bodhisattvas on the paths of accumulation and preparation can rise from meditation on emptiness with relative ease because their mind does not mix with emptiness like water mixing with water. Similarly, those at lower levels of practice experience no difficulty in rising quickly from meditation on emptiness! Thus the ability to rise quickly from meditation on emptiness is not in itself a special quality. However, for those who have accomplished complete absorption on emptiness, where the mind mixes with emptiness like water mixing with water, such an ability is a sign of powerful concentration and a special quick wisdom. Because Bodhisattvas on the seventh ground possess these qualities they outshine Hinayana Superiors by way of wisdom.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE MEANING ESTABLISHED BY THIS TEACHING

This has three parts:

1 The teaching of Sutra on the Ten Grounds that Hearers and Solitary Realizers have the realization of the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena

2 The sources that prove this

3 Rejecting arguments against this teaching

THE TEACHING OF SUTRA ON THE TEN GROUNDS THAT HEARERS AND SOLITARY REALIZERS HAVE THE REALIZATION OF THE LACK OF INHERENT EXISTENCE OF ALL PHENOMENA

Sutra on the Ten Grounds and Perfect Liberation of Maitreya Sutra both clearly explain that Bodhisattvas on the first six grounds do not surpass Hearer and Solitary Realizer Superiors in wisdom. This indicates that Hearer and Solitary Realizer Superiors have the same wisdom realizations as Bodhisattvas on the first six grounds. Since Bodhisattvas on these grounds realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena, it follows that Hearer and Solitary Realizer Superiors also have this realization. Indeed, if they lacked this realization they would have no means of attaining liberation.

Objection According to the teachings of Treasury of Abhidharma by Vasubandhu and Compendium of Abhidharma by Asanga, it is possible to attain liberation and become a Foe Destroyer by meditating on the views of the Sautrantika and Chittamatra schools, neither of which asserts lack of inherent existence. Both authors quote Buddha’s Sutras to support this view. They say that in some Sutras Buddha says that by meditating on the selflessness that is the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person it is possible to attain the path of seeing and abandon intellectually-formed self-grasping and all the other intellectually-formed delusions, and that through further acquaintance with this selflessness it is possible to attain the path of meditation, abandon innate delusions and attain liberation as a Foe Destroyer.

Moreover, some Mahayana Sutras explain how to attain liberation by meditating on the view of the Chittamatra school, while others explain how to attain liberation by meditating on the view of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school. Since none of these schools propounds lack of inherent existence it seems that it is not necessary to realize lack of inherent existence to attain liberation. All these scriptures state quite clearly that to attain liberation it is sufficient to meditate on the selflessness that is the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person. Therefore your claim that Hearers and Solitary Realizers would not be able to attain liberation if they lacked the realization of the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena contradicts these scriptures.

Reply It is true that these scriptures explain how to attain liberation in dependence on the views of the lower schools. However, Buddha gave these teachings for the benefit of disciples who were unable to realize the subtle view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school; they do not reveal his final intention. Since these teachings were given according to the capacities of the disciples rather than Buddha’s final intention they are teachings requiring interpretation, not teachings of definitive meaning.

In those Sutras referred to by the authors of the two Abhidharmas, where Buddha spoke of a path of seeing, a path of meditation and liberation, he was not referring to actual paths of seeing and so on. These are explained only in Sutras that reveal Buddha’s final intention, such as Sutra on the Ten Grounds and Perfect Liberation of Maitreya Sutra. According to these Sutras we can attain the path of seeing and so on only by realizing lack of inherent existence. These Sutras clearly state that all Superior beings and all Foe Destroyers realize lack of inherent existence. Thus the meaning of this present teaching is that it is definitely not possible to attain liberation by relying on the views of the lower schools, and that those who have a sincere wish to attain liberation should strive to realize the lack of inherent existence revealed by the glorious Madhyamika-Prasangika school.

This is also the intention of the great Bodhisattva, Shantideva. In Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life he says:

... the scriptures explain that without the path of wisdom realizing this emptiness,

It is impossible to attain even the small enlightenment of self-liberation.

This means that without the spiritual path that realizes the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena it is impossible to attain the enlightenment of a Hearer, a Solitary Realizer, or a Buddha.

The self-grasping explained in the two Abhidharmas, grasping at a self-supporting, substantially existent person, is not actual self-grasping and so by abandoning it we do not attain actual liberation. Grasping at a self-supporting, substantially existent person is gross self-grasping and the delusions that arise in dependence on it are gross delusions. Actual self-grasping is the subtle self-grasping conceiving an inherently existent self. This is the root of all other delusions and therefore the root of samsara. Since the two Abhidharmas do not explain this self-grasping or the delusions that arise from it those who follow these systems do not strive to abandon them. Therefore, they cannot abandon all delusions and attain liberation. The most they can achieve is a temporary abandonment of the delusions explained in those texts – the gross delusions – and a temporary abandonment of gross delusions is not a state of liberation. Actual liberation is permanent freedom from all delusions, including grasping at an inherently existent self and the delusions that arise in dependence on it. The only way to attain this liberation is by realizing lack of inherent existence.

Moreover, to abandon subtle self-grasping of persons and attain liberation we need to abandon not only grasping at an inherently existent self but also grasping at inherently existent aggregates. Thus we need to realize the lack of inherent existence of both persons and phenomena other than persons. In other words we must realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena.

THE SOURCES THAT PROVE THIS

This has two parts:

1 Mahayana Sutras that prove this

2 Treatises and Hinayana Sutras that prove this

MAHAYANA SUTRAS THAT PROVE THIS

There are many Mahayana Sutras that establish that Hinayana Superiors realize lack of inherent existence. One most commonly quoted is Sutra Requested by those with Superior Intention, in which Buddha gives the analogy of a man attending a magician’s performance. The magician creates an illusion of a woman and the man on seeing her develops strong attachment. With his mind ensnared by attachment he becomes anxious and embarrassed in the company of his friends. To overcome his attachment he leaves his seat and goes off to contemplate the unattractiveness, impermanence, suffering, emptiness and selflessness of the woman. ‘What do you think,’ asks Buddha, ‘Is that man behaving correctly or incorrectly?’ His disciples reply that anyone who strives to realize the unattractiveness and so forth of a non-existent woman is obviously behaving incorrectly. Buddha continues, ‘You should view similarly those monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen who consider unproduced and unarisen phenomena to be unattractive, impermanent, suffering, empty and selfless. I do not say that these misguided people are meditating on the path, for they are practising incorrectly.’

In this analogy the man sees the magician’s creation as a real woman and then goes off to contemplate her impermanence and so forth. This is similar to those practitioners, including the proponents of the lower schools of tenets, who hold the four noble truths to be inherently existent and then meditate on their aspects such as impermanence and so forth. Buddha says that they are not meditating correctly. Such a mind is a wrong awareness and therefore not a path to liberation. Thus, this Sutra clearly explains that to attain liberation it is necessary to realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena, including the four noble truths.

Question Since all proponents of lower tenets believe phenomena to be inherently existent does this mean that they cannot meditate correctly? For example, because Chittamatrins believe the body to be inherently existent it would seem that whenever they meditate on the impermanence of the body they are meditating incorrectly like the man in the analogy.

Answer This is not necessarily the case. If a Chittamatrin conceives his or her body to be inherently existent and then meditates on its impermanence, he or she is obviously meditating incorrectly. However, if he simply focuses on the mere body without considering whether it is inherently existent and then meditates on its impermanence, his meditation is perfectly correct.

Ordinary beings apprehend objects in two ways – one mind apprehending the mere object and another apprehending the object as inherently existent. For example, when we apprehend our body there is one mind apprehending the mere body and another apprehending an inherently existent body. The first is a valid cognizer and the second a self-grasping mind and wrong awareness. Usually, these two modes of apprehension function simultaneously and until we have some experience of emptiness we cannot distinguish them clearly.

The problem with the man in the analogy is that he holds the woman to be a real woman and tries to contemplate her impermanence and so on. Had he simply observed the mere woman created by the magician and then meditated on her impermanence his meditation would not have been mistaken. Thus, proponents of lower tenets such as the Chittamatrins are capable of correct meditation. This is obviously the case because Atisha’s great Teacher Lama Serlingpa was a Chittamatrin who realized bodhichitta, and he could not have gained this realization by aspiring to become an inherently existent Buddha!

However, although it is possible to meditate correctly on impermanence and so forth by relying on the views of the lower schools it is not possible to attain liberation by relying on these views. This is because the lower schools do not assert the lack of inherent existence of phenomena.

It is not only this Sutra that teaches that liberation is impossible without a realization of the lack of inherent existence of phenomena. The same point is made in many other Mahayana Sutras, including the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and Vajra Cutting Sutra.

TREATISES AND HINAYANA SUTRAS THAT PROVE THIS

The need to realize lack of inherent existence is established not only in the Mahayana Sutras but also in various treatises and in Hinayana Sutras. As an example of the first, Chandrakirti cites Precious Garland, where Nagarjuna says:

As long as there is grasping at the aggregates

There is grasping at I,

And wherever there is grasping at I

There is karma and rebirth.

With these three paths in mutual causation,

Without beginning, middle or end,

The wheel of samsara

Turns like a spinning firebrand.

Because this is not obtained

From self, other, or both in any of the three times

Grasping at self is extinguished

And with it karma and rebirth.

The meaning of the first verse is that for as long as we grasp at inherently existent aggregates we also grasp at an inherently existent I. Due to this self-grasping we create karma that causes rebirth in samsara. This shows that the minds conceiving an inherently existent I and inherently existent aggregates are the root of samsara and that if we want to attain liberation we must abandon both of them. Since Hearers and Solitary Realizers do attain liberation it follows that they abandon these minds, and they can do this only by realizing the lack of inherent existence of both the I and the aggregates.

The second verse explains how living beings wander in samsara in dependence on the three paths of delusion, karma and rebirth. Under the influence of delusions they create the karma to take rebirth in samsara. In each rebirth they generate more delusions, which cause them to create more karma to take more rebirths, and so on. With each one causing the other, these three circle in mutual causation without beginning, middle or end. If we twirl a lighted incense stick we create an apparently uninterrupted circle of light. In the same way, in dependence on the mutual causation of delusion, karma and rebirth living beings revolve in samsara without break.

The third verse shows that the only way to break this vicious circle is to realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena. Once we have extinguished grasping at an inherently existent self all our delusions cease and we no longer create the karma that causes rebirth in samsara. Without realizing the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena, however, it is impossible to stop taking samsaric rebirth and become a Foe Destroyer.

Buddha also teaches the need to realize lack of inherent existence in Hinayana Sutras. In Sutra Expounded to Hearers, for example, Buddha says:

Forms are like bursting balls of foam,

Feelings are like bubbles of water,

Discriminations are like mirages,

Compositional factors are like plantain trees,

Consciousnesses are like magical illusions.

Thus the Friend of the Sun [Buddha] says.

The first line teaches that the aggregate of form lacks inherent existence by comparing it to a bursting ball of foam. A ball of foam may appear substantial but when it bursts it disappears into empty space. Similarly, forms such as the body appear to be substantial entities, but their ultimate nature is emptiness.

The second line teaches that the aggregate of feeling lacks inherent existence by comparing it to bubbles of water. If we examine a water bubble we will never find its essence. Similarly, if we examine our pleasant, unpleasant and neutral feelings we will never find an inherently existent essence.

The third line teaches that the aggregate of discrimination lacks inherent existence by comparing it to a mirage. When we see a mirage, something that is mere appearance to mind is seen to be real. Similarly, though they appear to exist from their own side, our discriminations are also mere appearance to mind without even a trace of inherent existence.

The fourth line teaches that the aggregate of compositional factors lacks inherent existence by comparing it to a plantain tree. No matter how much bark we peel from a plantain tree we never find a core. Similarly, no matter how rigorously we analyze our compositional factors we will never discover an inherently existent phenomenon.

The fifth line teaches that the aggregate of consciousness lacks inherent existence by comparing it to a magician’s illusion. Sometimes magicians conjure up the appearance of an animal or a person, but though these phenomena appear to mind they are mere illusions with no existence from their own side. Similarly, all our consciousnesses are manifestations of lack of inherent existence with no existence from their own side.

Explicitly this Sutra teaches the lack of inherent existence of the five aggregates but implicitly it reveals the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena. Since this is a Hinayana Sutra, we can know for certain that Buddha taught the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena to Hinayanists.

Another Hinayana Sutra in which Buddha teaches lack of inherent existence is Instruction to Katyayana. Nagarjuna quotes this Sutra in Fundamental Wisdom, where he says:

In Instruction to Katyayana

Existence, non-existence and both

Are refuted by the Blessed One,

The Knower of things and non-things.

Nagarjuna is saying that in this Hinayana Sutra Buddha explains the middle way by refuting the two extremes – the extreme of existence (that phenomena are inherently existent) and the extreme of non-existence (that phenomena do not exist at all).

It is clear from many sources, therefore, that Buddha taught the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena to Hinayanists. By meditating on the meaning of these teachings both Hearers and Solitary Realizers can attain liberation from samsara and become Foe Destroyers.

Question Previously it was said that it is not possible to attain liberation by relying on the views of the Hinayana tenets of the Vaibhashika and Sautrantika schools, so how is it possible for Hinayanists to attain liberation and become Foe Destroyers?

Answer It is important to distinguish a proponent of Hinayana tenets from a Hinayanist. Within the four Buddhist schools, the tenets of the two lower schools – the Vaibhashika and the Sautrantika – are called ‘Hinayana tenets’ and the tenets of the two higher schools – the Chittamatra and the Madhyamika – are called ‘Mahayana tenets’. However, this does not mean that proponents of the lower tenets are necessarily Hinayanists or that proponents of the higher tenets are necessarily Mahayanists. A Hinayanist is someone who is motivated by a wish to attain liberation from samsara for himself or herself alone. A Mahayanist is someone who is motivated by a wish to attain full enlightenment for the benefit of all living beings. Thus, the criterion of whether we are a Hinayanist or a Mahayanist is our motivation, not the tenets we propound.

There are many cases of Mahayana practitioners propounding Vaibhashika or Sautrantika tenets and of Hinayanists propounding Chittamatra or Madhyamika tenets. If a practitioner has bodhichitta motivation but holds the view of the Sautrantika or Vaibhashika schools he or she is a Mahayanist propounding Hinayana tenets, but not a Hinayanist. However, even though such a practitioner may have renunciation, bodhichitta and tranquil abiding and even though he may be adept at meditation on the four noble truths, he does not have a complete path to liberation because he lacks the path realizing the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena.

Conversely, a practitioner who has only the motivation of renunciation but who holds the view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school is a Hinayanist propounding Mahayana tenets but not a Mahayanist. Even though such a person has a Hinayana motivation, he nevertheless has a complete path to liberation because, being a Madhyamika-Prasangika, he has the view of the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena. Thus, anyone who holds the view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, regardless of whether they have a Hinayana or a Mahayana motivation, has a complete path to liberation. On the other hand, those who subscribe to any other school, even if they have bodhichitta and even if they have tranquil abiding and many other good qualities, cannot attain liberation.

In conclusion, there is no contradiction in saying that proponents of Hinayana tenets cannot attain liberation whereas Hinayanists can. Hinayanists definitely have a complete path to liberation because they have the path realizing the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena.

REJECTING ARGUMENTS AGAINST THIS TEACHING

There is a debate between two of Nagarjuna’s disciples – Buddhapalita, who is a Madhyamika-Prasangika, and Bhavaviveka, who is the founder of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school. In his commentary to Fundamental Wisdom Buddhapalita explains that Hinayana Sutras teach lack of inherent existence. Bhavaviveka objects to this, saying that if that were the case there would have been no point in Buddha teaching the Mahayana Sutras because he would already have taught lack of inherent existence. Chandrakirti dismisses Bhavaviveka’s objection in his Autocommentary to the Guide. He gives two reasons why Buddha taught the Mahayana Sutras even though he had already explained lack of inherent existence in the Hinayana Sutras. First, the Mahayana Sutras reveal all the stages of the vast path from the cultivation of compassion through to the attainment of Buddhahood, and these are not taught in the Hinayana Sutras. Second, Mahayana Sutras explain emptiness much more extensively than Hinayana Sutras. Mahayanists strive to attain great enlightenment and this entails abandoning not just the delusions but also their imprints, the obstructions to omniscience. To accomplish this they have to attain very special wisdoms on the patience stage of the path of preparation and on the seventh and eighth grounds. Since this requires elaborate meditation on emptiness using countless forms of reasoning, Buddha gave a comprehensive explanation of emptiness in the Mahayana Sutras. Hinayanists, on the other hand, are concerned to abandon only the delusions, or obstructions to liberation, so that they can attain the peace of nirvana. Since this can be accomplished with a relatively brief meditation on emptiness, Buddha did not teach emptiness extensively in the Hinayana Sutras.

Besides this objection and its reply explained in the Autocommentary, there are many other arguments and counterarguments raised on this point. These are explained by Je Tsongkhapa in Clear Illumination of the Intention, but fearing that they will take up too much space I will not elaborate on them here.

Asanga

The Perfection of Giving

THE SURPASSING GOOD QUALITY OF THE FIRST GROUND

This section has four parts:

1 An explanation of the giving of one who abides on the first ground

2 An explanation of the giving of lower bases

3 An explanation of Bodhisattvas’ giving

4 The divisions of the perfection of giving

AN EXPLANATION OF THE GIVING OF ONE WHO ABIDES ON THE FIRST GROUND

[I.9] At that time giving, the first cause of the enlightenment of complete Buddhahood,

Becomes surpassing for him.

That he acts gracefully even when giving his own flesh

Is a reason for inferring the non-apparent.

When a Bodhisattva reaches the first ground his or her practice of the perfection of giving becomes surpassing. This does not mean that he practises only the perfection of giving – Bodhisattvas practise all ten perfections on each of the ten grounds. The meaning is that on the first ground he attains a degree of force in his practice of giving that he has not yet attained in his practice of the remaining perfections, moral discipline and so forth. Thus, whereas a Bodhisattva on the second ground has abandoned all faults discordant with pure moral discipline, the Bodhisattva on the first ground has not yet done so, but he has abandoned all stains of miserliness and attachment that are discordant with the perfection of giving. Therefore his practice of the perfection of giving is said to be surpassing. He is now completely free from the stains of miserliness and feels no sense of loss when giving away his wealth, his possessions or even his body.

If someone were to ask a first-ground Bodhisattva for some of his flesh he would give it gladly without his joy diminishing or his physical demeanour altering. This is a conclusive reason for inferring that he has attained very special realizations of giving that are not apparent to ordinary beings. If there is a fire inside a house someone on the outside will not be able to see it directly but they can correctly infer its presence from the smoke issuing from the chimney. Just as the smoke, which is apparent, indicates the existence of the fire, which is not, so a first-ground Bodhisattva’s external behaviour indicates extraordinary inner realizations that otherwise remain hidden to ordinary beings.

The definition of giving is a virtuous determination to give. We engage in the practice of giving when we give to others and when we simply generate or increase our determination to give. There are three types of giving – giving material things, giving Dharma and giving fearlessness. If possible we should practise all three. If we lack the resources to give material things we should still try to practise the other two, and if we cannot give Dharma we should at least practise giving fearlessness. This is defined as a virtuous determination to protect others from fears and problems. It includes such practices as protecting the lives of insects and animals, helping those who are lost, helping friends and neighbours when they have problems and bestowing peace of mind on those who are troubled. There is no one who cannot practise this type of giving.

The definition of perfection of giving is any giving maintained by bodhichitta. Although anyone, whether Mahayanist or Hinayanist, Buddhist or non-Buddhist, can practise giving, only those who have generated bodhichitta and entered the Mahayana path can practise the perfection of giving. There are two types of perfection of giving – the transcending perfection of giving and the transcendent perfection of giving. An example of the first is a Bodhisattva’s perfection of giving and an example of the second is a Buddha’s perfection of giving.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE GIVING OF LOWER BASES

This section explains the giving practised by ordinary beings who are not Bodhisattvas. It has two parts:

1 Attaining samsaric happiness through giving

2 Attaining the happiness of nirvana through giving

ATTAINING SAMSARIC HAPPINESS THROUGH GIVING

[I.10] All these beings strongly desire happiness

And humans cannot be happy without enjoyments.

Knowing that these enjoyments come from giving,

The Able One taught giving first.

All beings desire happiness and humans cannot be happy without basic enjoyments such as food, drink, clothing and shelter. If they lack these they experience the miseries of hunger, thirst, cold and so forth. Knowing that the basic enjoyments that alleviate these sufferings are the result of the practice of giving, Buddha taught giving as the first of the ten perfections.

If our enjoyments were the result of this life’s endeavours alone anyone who strove to become rich would succeed, yet there are many people who work hard at business with no success while there are others who seem to accumulate wealth with almost no effort. This is because wealth is the result of giving in former lives. If we have strong imprints from previous giving we will accumulate wealth with little difficulty, but if we lack such imprints we will never become rich no matter how hard we try. Seeing the benefits of giving and seeing that all enjoyments come from giving, both Buddhists and non-Buddhists value this practice.

Whereas humans depend on physical resources for their happiness, gods of the form and formless realms do not. They never experience the sufferings of hunger, thirst and so on, but abide continuously in the peace and happiness of meditative concentration with no need of food, drink, clothing or shelter. They do not even suffer sickness and ageing, although they do experience the sufferings of birth, death and pervasive suffering.

Question Do all humans depend on material comforts for their happiness?

Answer Within the human realm there are some pure Dharma practitioners who, through the power of their spiritual realizations, experience continuous peace and happiness even though they may lack many worldly enjoyments. When Chandrakirti says that humans cannot be happy without enjoyments he is referring not to such practitioners but to ordinary humans who have little or no experience of Dharma.

Question To receive results such as wealth and resources, is it necessary to practise giving as part of a spiritual practice?

[I.11] Even for those with little compassion and very rough minds

Who pursue only their own interests

Desired enjoyments that cause the alleviation of suffering

Arise from giving.

Answer No. Giving is a virtuous action and so it is always beneficial, even when it is not part of a spiritual practice. For example, people engaged in business understand that it is necessary to give away a little to receive greater returns in the future. There are many people with little or no compassion who are concerned only with their own interests and whose minds can be very rough when dealing with others, yet even they receive worldly enjoyments that temporarily alleviate sufferings such as poverty as a result of their giving.

Usually the results of giving are experienced in future lives, but there are some people who experience them later in the same life. For example, someone might give generously when they are young and as a result experience prosperity towards the end of their life.

ATTAINING THE HAPPINESS OF NIRVANA THROUGH GIVING

[I.12] Even they on some occasion of giving

Will soon come to meet a Superior being.

Then having severed the continuum of samsara completely

Those who possess this cause will go to peace.

Even those who have little compassion but who are happy to give will practise giving continuously and one day, in some cases quite soon, meet a Superior or other realized being as the object of their generosity. That holy being will then help them to develop renunciation by explaining the faults of samsara. As a result they will practise Dharma purely and eventually sever the continuum of samsara and attain the peace of liberation. The initial cause of this peace, meeting a holy being, is itself the result of the practice of giving. Thus, by practising giving we can attain not only samsaric happiness but also the happiness of nirvana.

AN EXPLANATION OF BODHISATTVAS’ GIVING

Having explained the benefits of giving practised by ordinary beings who are not Bodhisattvas, Chandrakirti now explains the uncommon characteristics of Bodhisattvas’ giving. This section has four parts:

1 The uncommon benefits of Bodhisattvas’ giving

2 The instructions on giving are fundamental for both bases

3 The great joy a Bodhisattva obtains from giving

4 Whether a Bodhisattva experiences pain when giving away his body

THE UNCOMMON BENEFITS OF BODHISATTVAS’ GIVING

[I.13ab] Those who hold in their mind a promise to help living beings

Immediately experience joy from giving.

Everyone eventually experiences happiness as a result of giving, but Bodhisattvas experience immediate joy. This is the uncommon benefit of Bodhisattvas’ giving and it leads them to practise giving with great enthusiasm. Ordinary beings, on the other hand, do not experience the results of giving immediately and so they have little enthusiasm for it.

Most people do not like being asked to give, and sometimes they even respond with resentment or anger. Moreover, when they part with something, they do not immediately experience joy from having given but usually feel a sense of loss or regret. Even a Hinayana Foe Destroyer, because he or she lacks great compassion, will not immediately generate joy at the prospect of giving, or rejoice in the satisfaction of the receiver. The first-ground Bodhisattva, however, has promised to help all living beings by bestowing on them temporary and ultimate happiness whenever he or she can. His compassion for those in need is like a mother’s love for her children, and so whenever he is asked to give something he immediately experiences great joy just from hearing the word ‘give’. Delighted with the opportunity to practise giving, he feels as if he has discovered a precious treasure, and as soon as he sees he has satisfied the receiver he spontaneously generates supreme joy.

THE INSTRUCTIONS ON GIVING ARE FUNDAMENTAL FOR BOTH BASES

[I.13cd] Therefore whether one is compassionate or not

The instructions on giving are fundamental.

Whether one is a Bodhisattva or not the practice of giving is very important because, as already explained, it leads to the temporary happiness of samsara and the ultimate happiness of liberation. Therefore, we should regard the instructions on the practice of giving as fundamental. In Friendly Letter Nagarjuna offers the following advice to King Udayabhadra:

There is no better friend for the future than giving –

Bestowing gifts properly

On ordained people, brahmins, the poor and friends

Realizing enjoyments to be transient and essenceless.

Ordinary friends can help us only in this life, but giving brings us enjoyments in many future lives. Therefore we should regard the practice of giving as our best friend. Je Tsongkhapa also praises giving in Condensed Exposition of the Stages of the Path:

Giving is the wish-granting jewel that fulfils the hopes of living beings,

The supreme weapon for cutting the knot of miserliness,

The action of the Conquerors’ Son with a courageous heart

And the basis for proclaiming his fame throughout the ten directions.

Knowing this, the wise rely on the excellent path of giving everything –

Their bodies, their enjoyments and their virtues.

I who am a Yogi practised in this way;

You who seek liberation, please do the same.

Also Milarepa says in Songs of Speech:

Since you have to depart alone leaving everything behind,

It is more meaningful to leave everything now.

When we die we have to depart from this world alone, leaving our bodies and all our possessions to others, but leaving everything behind without any choice is not a practice of giving and brings no benefit. Therefore Milarepa says it is better to give away our possessions now while we still have the choice. Only in this way can we derive some meaning from having owned them. In the Sutras, Buddha says:

The rich who do not practise giving

Are as if guarding other people’s treasure,

And the wise who do not keep their commitments

Are like rotten, hollow trees.

THE GREAT JOY A BODHISATTVA OBTAINS FROM GIVING

[I.14] If from hearing and contemplating the word ‘Give’,

The Conquerors’ Son develops a bliss

The like of which is not aroused in the Able Ones through experiencing peace,

What can be said about giving everything?

Because they are completely free from the sufferings of samsara Hinayana Foe Destroyers experience extraordinary peace and happiness, but this happiness does not begin to compare with the bliss experienced by a Bodhisattva when he or she is asked to give something. Whenever a Bodhisattva is asked by others to give he experiences extraordinary bliss just from hearing the words and contemplating their meaning. If Hinayana Foe Destroyers do not experience a bliss that compares with this, how can we begin to describe the bliss experienced by the Bodhisattva when he gives away everything, including his body?

WHETHER A BODHISATTVA EXPERIENCES PAIN WHEN GIVING AWAY HIS BODY

Question Although a Bodhisattva develops bliss when he is asked to give and when he is actually giving, does he not experience pain when he gives away his body?

Answer This depends on whether he or she is a Superior Bodhisattva or an ordinary Bodhisattva. A Superior Bodhisattva will experience no pain and no sense of loss when parting with his body, even if he were slowly to cut it into many pieces. There are two reasons for this. First, because he has a direct realization of the lack of inherent existence of the I and the body he does not experience pain. Second, because he has completed the practice of exchanging self with others he is utterly without self-cherishing and so there is no basis for suffering to arise. In Question of Gaganganja Sutra Buddha says that just as a large tree experiences no pain and no sense of loss when its branches are cut off, so a Superior Bodhisattva would experience no pain and no sense of loss if someone out of malice were to cut off all his limbs. He would feel only joy at having the opportunity to give away his body for the sake of others. Also, in Commentary to Valid Cognition Dharmakirti says:

He is said to be separate from attachment,

As with sandalwood and axe.

If one person were respectfully to anoint a Superior Bodhisattva’s body with sandalwood while another angrily attacked it with an axe, that Bodhisattva would not feel close to one and distant from the other, but would have equal compassion for both. This is because he is completely free from attachment to his body.

An ordinary Bodhisattva, on the other hand, does experience pain when his or her body is cut. However, he is able to use this experience to strengthen his practice. The root text says:

[I.15] Through the pain from cutting and giving his body

He sees from his own experience

The suffering of others in the hells and elsewhere

And strives with great effort to eliminate it quickly.

If an ordinary Bodhisattva cuts his body and gives it away he uses his own experience of pain to contemplate the suffering of other living beings such as hell beings, hungry ghosts and animals who are trapped in lower realms. Seeing that their suffering is infinitely greater than his own, he thinks only of them and strives with great effort to attain enlightenment quickly so that he can eliminate their pain.

Those who have taken Bodhisattva vows have a commitment to train in the practice of giving everything including their virtues, their possessions and their body. However, Buddha warned us not to give up our body if we lack the motivation of great compassion, if we cannot bear the pain or if the sacrifice would serve no great purpose, for to part with our body with a narrow or unhappy mind would be a great hindrance to our practice. At our stage we should simply cultivate the intention to gain the ability to give our body.

To appreciate fully the extraordinary qualities of the first-ground Bodhisattva’s giving we should contemplate them repeatedly. When as a result of our contemplations we develop a feeling of rejoicing in the Bodhisattva’s good qualities we should hold this feeling as our object of placement meditation. Finally we should dedicate our merit with the prayer, ‘May I quickly attain all these good qualities.’ Rejoicing in the good qualities of the first-ground Bodhisattva helps us to develop an aspiration to attain them ourself.

THE DIVISIONS OF THE PERFECTION OF GIVING

[I.16] Giving with emptiness of giver, gift and receiver

Is called a ‘supramundane perfection’.

Where attachment to these three is generated

It is explained as a mundane perfection.

Chandrakirti briefly explains a twofold division of the perfection of giving into supramundane and mundane. A perfection of giving maintained by the wisdom directly realizing the emptiness of the three spheres – the giver, the gift and the receiver – is a supramundane perfection of giving. A perfection of giving in someone who does not have a realization of the lack of inherent existence of the three spheres but who still conceives them to be inherently existent is a mundane perfection. Mundane perfections are practised only by ordinary Bodhisattvas, supramundane perfections only by Superior Bodhisattvas and Buddhas.

CONCLUSION BY WAY OF EXPRESSING THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

[I.17] Thus, abiding high in the mind of the Conquerors’ Son,

Beautifying with light this holy base,

This Joyful is like a water crystal jewel

For having dispelled all heavy darkness it is victorious.

Chandrakirti summarizes the excellent qualities of the first ground by comparing it to the moon. In the scriptures the moon is sometimes called the ‘water crystal jewel’ because its light is cool and the sun is sometimes called the ‘fire crystal jewel’ because its rays are warm.

The first ground has three points of similarity with the moon:

(1) Just as the moon abides in a high place, so the first ground abides in the mind of the highly-realized Bodhisattva

(2) Just as the moon beautifies the sky with light, so the first ground beautifies the holy mind of the Conquerors’ Son with the light of wisdom

(3) Just as the moon dispels the darkness of the night, so the first ground dispels the thick darkness of confusion obscuring the view of emptiness, and is victorious over the intellectually-formed delusions.

This concludes the commentary to the first ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Stainless

THE SECOND GROUND, STAINLESS

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the second ground

2 Explanation of the second ground

Introduction to the second ground has four parts:

1 How the second ground is attained

2 Definition of the second ground

3 Divisions of the second ground

4 Etymology of the second ground

HOW THE SECOND GROUND IS ATTAINED

Even though the Bodhisattva on the first ground has abandoned intellectually-formed true-grasping, he or she still has innate true-grasping. There are nine levels of innate true-grasping – big-big, middling-big, small-big, big-middling, middling-middling, small-middling, big-small, middling-small and small-small. These are gradually abandoned by the Bodhisattva on the next seven grounds.

While still on the first ground, the Bodhisattva continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains a wisdom that functions as the direct antidote to the grossest type of innate true-grasping, big-big. This wisdom is known as the ‘uninterrupted path of the path of meditation of the first ground’ because when the Bodhisattva attains it he or she advances to the path of meditation but remains on the first ground. In the next moment of the same meditation he attains the released path that has completely abandoned big-big innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the second ground. Thus, he advances from the first ground to the second while in meditative equipoise. Whereas the first ground begins with an uninterrupted path, the second and subsequent grounds begin with a released path.

DEFINITION OF THE SECOND GROUND

The definition of the second ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned big-big innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of moral discipline from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE SECOND GROUND

The second ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the second ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the second ground and the exalted awareness of the second ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the second ground, the uninterrupted path of the second ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the second ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the second ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to middling-big innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two is any meditative equipoise on emptiness between these two. This and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

ETYMOLOGY OF THE SECOND GROUND

The second ground is called ‘Stainless’ because a Bodhisattva on this ground is completely free from stains of degenerate moral discipline and uncommon Hinayana attitudes.

EXPLANATION OF THE SECOND GROUND

The second ground will now be explained extensively under five headings:

1 The completely pure moral discipline on this ground

2 A praise of moral discipline

3 An illustration of separation from that which is incompatible with moral discipline

4 The divisions of the perfection of moral discipline

5 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

THE COMPLETELY PURE MORAL DISCIPLINE ON THIS GROUND

This section has four parts:

1 The excellent moral discipline on this ground

2 The completely pure qualities that depend on this

3 This moral discipline surpasses that of the first ground

4 Another cause of completely pure moral discipline

THE EXCELLENT MORAL DISCIPLINE ON THIS GROUND

[II.1ab] Because he possesses excellent moral discipline and pure qualities

He has abandoned the stains of degenerate discipline even in his dreams.

Because the Bodhisattva on the second ground possesses excellent moral discipline and many pure qualities he is not polluted by the stains of degenerate moral discipline or its imprints even in his dreams. Most ordinary beings, including those who keep pure moral discipline while they are awake, break their moral discipline in their dreams. For example, there are some who are very careful not to take life while they are awake but who sometimes dream of killing. Similarly there are those who never commit sexual misconduct while awake but who do so in their dreams. Such dreams arise from the imprints of faulty moral discipline that remain in the mind even after we have begun to practise pure moral discipline. Because the Bodhisattva on the second ground has abandoned these imprints his mind is always pure, even in his dreams.

The definition of moral discipline is a virtuous determination to abandon non-virtuous actions and faults. To practise moral discipline we must have an intention to refrain from non-virtuous actions, otherwise we would have to say that stones and trees practise moral discipline because they never do anything wrong! To practise moral discipline we contemplate the disadvantages of non-virtuous actions, generate a strong determination to abandon such actions and then conscientiously avoid committing them. If we wish, we can make a promise in front of a holy being but this is not essential. It is sufficient simply to make a strong inner determination and then to practise purely. If having made such a determination we then commit non-virtuous actions, we incur moral faults.

Some actions however are naturally harmful and should be avoided at all times, regardless of whether or not we have decided to refrain from them. These are – killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, divisive speech, hurtful speech, idle chatter, covetousness, harmful thought and holding wrong views. The moral discipline of refraining from these ten non-virtuous actions is fundamental and should be practised by everyone. Whether we are a Superior being or an ordinary being, a Mahayanist or a Hinayanist, a Buddhist or a non-Buddhist, we always need to refrain from these actions.

There are three types of moral discipline – the moral discipline of restraint, the moral discipline of gathering virtuous Dharmas and the moral discipline of benefiting living beings. There is also a threefold division from the point of view of vows – the moral discipline observing the Pratimoksha vows, the moral discipline observing the Bodhisattva vows and the moral discipline observing the Tantric vows.

The definition of perfection of moral discipline is any moral discipline maintained by bodhichitta. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of moral discipline and the transcendent perfection of moral discipline. The first is practised by Bodhisattvas and the second by Buddhas. Another division of the perfection of moral discipline is given below.

THE COMPLETELY PURE QUALITIES THAT DEPEND ON THIS

[II.1cd] Because his conduct of body, speech and mind is pure

He accumulates all ten paths of holy actions.

The Bodhisattva on the second ground has many pure qualities that arise from his or her moral discipline. Because his conduct of body, speech and mind is always completely pure, without even a trace of defilement, he accumulates all ten virtuous actions. There are three virtuous actions of body – abandoning killing, abandoning stealing and abandoning sexual misconduct; four virtuous actions of speech – abandoning lying, abandoning divisive speech, abandoning hurtful speech and abandoning idle chatter; and three virtuous actions of mind – abandoning covetousness, abandoning harmful thought and abandoning holding wrong views. Chandrakirti calls these actions ‘holy’ actions because they protect us from lower rebirth and lead to happiness in both this and future lives. If we practise the moral discipline of abandoning the ten non-virtuous actions our conduct of body, speech and mind will gradually become pure, and we will acquire pure qualities similar to those of a second-ground Bodhisattva.

THIS MORAL DISCIPLINE SURPASSES THAT OF THE FIRST GROUND

[II.2] For him all these ten virtuous paths

Are perfected and so extremely pure.

Like the autumn moon he is always completely pure.

Pacified and radiant, he is beautified by these.

Question Does a Bodhisattva on the first ground also practise pure moral discipline?

Answer Yes. Bodhisattvas on the first ground practise the ten virtuous actions purely, but for the second-ground Bodhisattva these actions are perfected and so completely pure. Therefore the second-ground Bodhisattva’s moral discipline surpasses that of the first-ground Bodhisattva.

Just as the autumn moon relieves the pain of heat and fills the sky with pure white light so the second-ground Bodhisattva’s realization of pure moral discipline pacifies his mind by relieving the painful heat of the delusions and generates a mental lucidity and radiance that beautifies his body. Atisha once told his disciple, Jangchub Ö, ‘Always keep pure moral discipline, for it leads to beauty in this life and happiness hereafter.’ If we follow Atisha’s advice we will also come to possess these special qualities. In Condensed Exposition of the Stages of the Path Je Tsongkhapa says:

Moral discipline is the water that cleanses the stains of misconduct

And the moonlight that relieves the painful heat of the delusions.

Resplendent as a great mountain amidst all living beings,

All beings bow down to it without threat of force.

Knowing this, the holy protect as they would their eyes

The discipline that they have vowed to observe.

I who am a Yogi practised in this way;

You who seek liberation, please do the same.

In many Buddhist countries there is great respect for monks and nuns, not just because they wear robes but because they observe pure discipline. Similarly anyone, lay or ordained, who keeps the moral discipline observing the Bodhisattva vows or the moral discipline observing the Tantric vows is held in great esteem. Shantideva says that simply by generating bodhichitta we become worthy of veneration by humans and gods, so how much more respect is due to those who take the Bodhisattva vows and keep them purely?

ANOTHER CAUSE OF COMPLETELY PURE MORAL DISCIPLINE

[II.3] If we keep pure moral discipline with the view of inherent existence

Then because of that our moral discipline is not pure.

Therefore, he is always completely free from the wanderings

Of the dualistic mind towards the three.

If we refrain from non-virtuous actions and practise virtue we are practising pure moral discipline, but if we view our practice as inherently existent it will not be completely pure. A Bodhisattva on the second ground never views his practice as inherently existent and so he attains complete purity of moral discipline.

Question Since proponents of all the lower tenets view phenomena as inherently existent, does this mean that they are incapable of keeping pure moral discipline?

Answer No. For example, there are both lay and ordained Chittamatrins who keep very pure moral discipline. If a Chittamatrin is practising the moral discipline of abandoning the ten non-virtuous actions we cannot say that he is not observing pure moral discipline, but because he views himself, his practice and the objects of his practice as inherently existent his moral discipline is not as pure as that of a second-ground Bodhisattva.

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, moral discipline is completely pure only when it is conjoined with the realization of lack of inherent existence. The main purpose of practising moral discipline is to attain liberation or enlightenment, but a moral discipline that is strongly viewed as inherently existent is the cause of rebirth in samsara because it is motivated by the ignorance of self-grasping. Since moral discipline is a virtuous practice it can never be the cause of lower rebirth but it can be the cause of rebirth as a human or a god. However, even though we may still have self-grasping, if we practise moral discipline with the motivation of renunciation it will be a cause of liberation, and if we practise with the motivation of bodhichitta it will be a cause of enlightenment.

In Condensed Perfection of Wisdom Sutra Buddha says that practising virtuous actions while regarding them as inherently existent is like eating delicious food that is laced with poison. If we were to eat contaminated food our initial experience would be pleasure, but that would soon give way to suffering as the poison took effect. In the same way, if we practise moral discipline contaminated by the view of inherent existence, the initial effect will be a clear and happy mind and a radiant body, but the long-term effect will be further suffering from having taken another rebirth in samsara. In Collection (Heap) of Jewels Sutra Buddha says:

Kashyapa, some monks possess moral discipline in so far as they abide within the restraints of the Pratimoksha vows, observe excellent rituals and spheres of activity, view even the slightest transgression with concern, perfectly assume and train in the bases of training and have completely pure livelihoods due to their very pure actions of body, speech and mind; and yet they propound a self. Kashyapa, they are the first of those who appear to possess moral discipline but who have faulty moral discipline . . .

Furthermore, Kashyapa, some monks perfectly assume the twelve qualities of training but they view them with apprehension, abiding in the apprehensions of ‘I’ and ‘mine’. Kashyapa, they are the fourth of those who appear to possess moral discipline but who have faulty moral discipline.

In another Sutra, Buddha says:

If you practise moral discipline while viewing these spheres as inherently existent, that practice is not pure.

All actions have three spheres. In the case of moral discipline they are the non-virtue that is abandoned, the person abandoning it and the being(s) with respect to whom it is abandoned. A mind that conceives these three spheres to be inherently existent is a dualistic mind because it falls into the two extremes. The Bodhisattva on the second ground has completely abandoned the wanderings of this dualistic mind and so his or her moral discipline is completely pure.

There are many causes of the complete purification of moral discipline, but realizing the emptiness of the three spheres is the main cause. Although the Bodhisattva on the first ground also has this realization his moral discipline does not become surpassing until he reaches the second ground. Therefore the complete purification of moral discipline is given as a quality of the second ground.

A PRAISE OF MORAL DISCIPLINE

This section has five parts:

1 Enjoying the fruits of giving in fortunate realms depends on moral discipline

2 Enjoying the fruits of giving continuously depends on moral discipline

3 It is extremely difficult for those who lack moral discipline to escape from the lower realms

4 Why the instructions on moral discipline were given after the instructions on giving

5 Praising moral discipline as a cause of both high status and definite goodness

ENJOYING THE FRUITS OF GIVING IN FORTUNATE REALMS DEPENDS ON MORAL DISCIPLINE

[II.4ab] If enjoyments that result from giving arise in a lower rebirth

It is because that being broke his legs of moral discipline.

It has already been explained that if we practise giving we will experience wealth and resources in future lives, but if we want to enjoy these fruits in the human or god realm we must combine our practice of giving with the practice of moral discipline because moral discipline is the cause of higher rebirth. If we practise giving without practising moral discipline we will experience the results in a lower rebirth, for example as a pet dog in a wealthy household. There are many cases of animals enjoying comfortable conditions just as there are many cases of humans experiencing deprivation. The former are the result of practising giving without moral discipline and the latter are the result of practising moral discipline without giving. Moral discipline is like legs. Those who have strong moral discipline will be able to travel to fortunate rebirths but those beings who break their legs of moral discipline will fall into the lower realms. Therefore, while we still have this precious human body we should use it to practise pure moral discipline and thereby ensure that we take a fortunate rebirth in our next life.

ENJOYING THE FRUITS OF GIVING CONTINUOUSLY DEPENDS ON MORAL DISCIPLINE

[II.4cd] If both the interest and the capital are spent

No enjoyments will arise for him in the future.

If the fruits of giving ripen in lower rebirths they are consumed without fresh seeds being sown because beings in the lower realms have no opportunity to practise giving. For example, a dog born into a wealthy household experiences relative luxury and comfort during that life, but it uses up its good fortune without creating the cause for more. This is rather like a businessman spending both the interest and the capital, or a farmer consuming his harvest without sowing fresh seeds; there will be nothing for them to enjoy in the future.

On the other hand, if as a result of practising moral discipline the fruits of giving ripen in a fortunate rebirth we experience both prosperity, which is the environmental effect of giving, and a disposition to practise giving again, which is an effect that is a tendency similar to the cause. With both the resources and the disposition to give we will naturally practise giving again, thereby creating the cause for even more prosperity and an even greater disposition to give in the future. This in turn leads to even more prosperity and even more generosity and so on. Thus practising giving and moral discipline together creates the cause to enjoy the fruits of giving continuously in life after life.

IT IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT FOR THOSE WHO LACK MORAL DISCIPLINE TO ESCAPE FROM THE LOWER REALMS

[II.5] If, when living in good conditions and acting with freedom,

We do not act to hold ourself back,

Once we have fallen into the abyss and lost our freedom

How will we raise ourself from there in the future?

In samsara there are only two types of rebirth – rebirth in the higher realms of humans and gods and rebirth in the lower realms of hell beings, hungry ghosts and animals. The principal cause of rebirth in the higher realms is the practice of moral discipline. If we do not practise moral discipline we lack the cause of higher rebirth and so when we die we will definitely be reborn in the lower realms. There is no alternative.

Right now we have a precious human life and the freedom to control our actions. If while we have such good conditions we do not protect ourself from falling into a lower rebirth by practising pure moral discipline, once we have fallen into the abyss of the lower realms and lost all our freedom, how will we raise ourself to the higher realms again? It seems almost impossible.

The reason it is very difficult for beings in the lower realms to escape is that they cannot practise moral discipline, which is the main cause of higher rebirth. We have only to look at animals to see how difficult it is to practise moral discipline in a lower rebirth. All animals instinctively commit negative actions. Cats, for example, are never free from non-virtuous minds; day and night they have the desire to kill. They do not need to be trained to kill or to steal. It is almost impossible for animals to practise virtue. We can train a dog to catch balls, protect property, round up sheep, apprehend criminals and excel at various sports, but if we tell a dog that it can attain enlightenment by reciting just one mantra it cannot even understand what we are saying. Since it is so difficult to practise moral discipline in the lower realms, once we are born there, there is a great danger of our taking one lower rebirth after another. Therefore we should practise moral discipline now to protect ourself from falling into lower rebirths in the future, and we should develop compassion for those who are already trapped there.

This verse is extremely important and we should contemplate it repeatedly. Many of the great Kadampa Geshes used to begin their meditations by reciting this verse and reflecting on its meaning. If we do the same our mind will naturally turn towards Dharma.

WHY THE INSTRUCTIONS ON MORAL DISCIPLINE WERE GIVEN AFTER THE INSTRUCTIONS ON GIVING

[II.6] Therefore the Conqueror taught moral discipline

After he had taught giving.

When qualities grow in the field of moral discipline

The fruits will be enjoyed unceasingly.

If we practise giving in conjunction with moral discipline its fruits will be enjoyed unceasingly in fortunate realms, but if we practise giving without moral discipline the results will be wasted in the lower realms. Because it is unwise to practise giving without considering the kind of rebirth in which we will experience the results, Buddha taught moral discipline immediately after he had taught giving.

PRAISING MORAL DISCIPLINE AS A CAUSE OF BOTH HIGH STATUS AND DEFINITE GOODNESS

[II.7] There is no cause other than moral discipline

For the high status and definite goodness

Of ordinary beings, those born from the speech,

Those definite in self-enlightenment and Conquerors’ Sons.

There are two types of happiness – the happiness of high status, which is the happiness of humans and gods, and the happiness of definite goodness, which is the happiness of liberation and enlightenment. Ordinary beings who have not yet entered spiritual paths desire the happiness of humans and gods, Hearers and Solitary Realizers desire the happiness of liberation and Bodhisattvas desire the happiness of great enlightenment. None of these desires can be fulfilled without the practice of moral discipline. Although there are many other causes of happiness, such as the other perfections, they cannot produce happiness if moral discipline is lacking. Therefore Chandrakirti says that there is no cause of happiness other than moral discipline.

AN ILLUSTRATION OF SEPARATION FROM THAT WHICH IS INCOMPATIBLE WITH MORAL DISCIPLINE

[II.8] As with an ocean and a corpse together,

And auspiciousness and misfortune together,

So too this great being controlled by moral discipline

Has no desire to remain with that which is degenerate.

If a corpse is thrown into an ocean it is usually washed ashore. We would say that it is brought ashore by the waves, but according to some Buddhist texts it is thrown ashore by nagas living in the ocean who do not wish to share their abode with such an unclean object. Just as an ocean and a corpse cannot remain together, so auspiciousness and misfortune cannot remain together because when conditions are good there is no place for misfortune. These analogies illustrate how the Bodhisattva on the second ground whose mind is completely controlled by moral discipline has no desire to remain with faulty moral discipline.

The Bodhisattva on the second ground abandons both gross and subtle moral faults. Gross moral faults are non-virtuous actions such as killing, stealing or lying and subtle moral faults are thoughts to commit such actions that arise from imprints in the mind. Because conditions conducive to moral discipline are so rare it is difficult for ordinary beings to abandon even one gross moral fault such as killing let alone all ten non-virtuous actions. Needless to say, there are very few beings who can also cleanse their minds of all the imprints of non-virtue. From this we can see that the practice of moral discipline is vast and complete purity is extremely rare. Therefore we should rejoice in the purity of the second-ground Bodhisattva for whom even the slightest trace of moral degeneration is anathema.

THE DIVISIONS OF THE PERFECTION OF MORAL DISCIPLINE

[II.9] If there is observation of the three –

What is abandoned, by whom and with respect to whom –

That moral discipline is explained as a mundane perfection.

That which is empty of attachment to the three is supramundane.

The perfection of moral discipline has two divisions – the mundane perfection of moral discipline and the supramundane perfection of moral discipline. A perfection of moral discipline in one who conceives the three spheres – what is abandoned, by whom and with respect to whom – to be inherently existent is a mundane perfection of moral discipline. A perfection of moral discipline maintained by a direct realization of the lack of inherent existence of the three spheres is a supramundane perfection of moral discipline. The mundane perfection of moral discipline is practised only by ordinary Bodhisattvas and the supramundane perfection only by Mahayana Superiors. Here, ‘that which is empty of attachment’ refers to the moral discipline practised by Mahayana Superiors who have abandoned all intellectually-formed delusions.

CONCLUSION BY WAY OF EXPRESSING THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

[II.10] This Stainless, free from stains, arises from the moon, the Conquerors’ Son,

Who although not of samsara is the glory of samsara;

And just like the light of the autumn moon,

It relieves the mental torment of living beings.

Just as moonlight arises from the moon, so the second ground arises from the second-ground Bodhisattva who is radiant with the light of stainless moral discipline. Although he is no longer of samsara, out of great compassion he continues to take rebirth in the abodes of samsara, where he is the source of all happiness and good fortune. Just as the autumn moon free from obstruction by clouds soothes the torment of heat, so the second ground free from all stains relieves living beings of the mental torment caused by faulty moral discipline.

This concludes the commentary to the second ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Vasubandhu

Luminous

THE THIRD GROUND, LUMINOUS

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the third ground

2 Explanation of the third ground

Introduction to the third ground has three parts:

1 How the third ground is attained

2 Definition of the third ground

3 Divisions of the third ground

HOW THE THIRD GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the second ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to middling-big innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the second ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned middling-big innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the third ground.

DEFINITION OF THE THIRD GROUND

The definition of the third ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned middling-big innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of patience from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE THIRD GROUND

The third ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the third ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the third ground and the exalted awareness of the third ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the third ground, the uninterrupted path of the third ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the third ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the third ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to small-big innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

EXPLANATION OF THE THIRD GROUND

The third ground will now be explained under the following four headings:

1 The etymology of the ground, the basis of characteristics

2 The good qualities that characterize this ground

3 The characteristics of the first three perfections

4 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

THE ETYMOLOGY OF THE GROUND, THE BASIS OF CHARACTERISTICS

[III.1] Because there arises the light of the fire

That consumes all the fuel of objects of knowledge, this third ground is Luminous.

At this time there arises for the Sugatas’ Son

A copper-like appearance similar to the sun.

The Bodhisattva on the third ground attains a powerful wisdom that is like a fire whose light eradicates all elaborations of dualistic appearance during meditative equipoise, and when he rises from meditation he experiences a coppery glow pervading the whole environment, rather like the appearance of the sky just before sunrise. For this reason the third ground is called ‘Luminous’.

THE GOOD QUALITIES THAT CHARACTERIZE THIS GROUND

This section has four parts:

1 The surpassing patience on this ground

2 The way to rely on other patience

3 The divisions of the perfection of patience

4 The other pure qualities that arise on this ground

THE SURPASSING PATIENCE ON THIS GROUND

[III.2] Even if someone inappropriately angered

Were to cut flesh and bone from his body

Piece by piece for a long time,

He would generate a superior patience towards the mutilator.

[III.3] Furthermore, for the Bodhisattva who has seen selflessness,

What is cut, by whom, at what time and in what manner –

All these phenomena are seen to be like reflections,

Therefore he is patient.

To become angry with someone we have to think, ‘He harmed me or my friends in the past’, ‘He is harming us now’, ‘He will harm us in the future’, and so on but since none of these applies to Bodhisattvas who are endowed with great compassion and who never even wish harm towards anyone, Bodhisattvas are inappropriate objects of anger. Even so, if someone out of confusion were to generate anger towards a third-ground Bodhisattva and then, to inflict great pain on him, were slowly to cut flesh and bone from his body in very small pieces, the Bodhisattva would think only of the great suffering his torturer will experience as a result of his action, and out of great compassion generate a superior patience towards him.

Furthermore, because this Bodhisattva has a non-conceptual realization of selflessness he or she sees the three spheres – what is cut, by whom and at what time and in what manner – to be completely lacking in inherent existence, just like reflections. Through the force of this realization and his great compassion, his mind is not in the least disturbed by the mutilation of his body and he is able to be supremely patient.

These verses describe the surpassing practice of the perfection of patience attained by the Bodhisattva on the third ground. The definition of perfection of patience is a virtuous determination to forbear harm, suffering or profound Dharma that is maintained by bodhichitta. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of patience and the transcendent perfection of patience.

Question If Bodhisattvas on the first two grounds were to have their bodies mutilated they too would patiently forbear the mutilation, and their minds would remain undisturbed, so why is this given as a quality of the third-ground Bodhisattva?

Answer The principal reason why ordinary beings cannot bear to have their body cut is their self-cherishing. Bodhisattvas on the first two grounds have completely overcome self-cherishing and so they could remain patient without pain if their bodies were cut. However, they still have imprints of self-cherishing. When a Bodhisattva reaches the third ground he has abandoned both self-cherishing and its imprints and so he is said to possess a surpassing practice of the perfection of patience that is not possessed by Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds.

THE WAY TO RELY ON OTHER PATIENCE

Since patience is an important practice for everyone, not just for Bodhisattvas, Chandrakirti now explains how beings other than Bodhisattvas should avoid anger and practise patience. This explanation is given in two parts:

1 The unsuitability of getting angry

2 The suitability of relying on patience

THE UNSUITABILITY OF GETTING ANGRY

This section has four parts:

1 Anger is unsuitable because it is unnecessary and very faulty

2 Not wishing future suffering and retaliating harmfully are contradictory

3 Anger is unsuitable because it destroys virtues previously accumulated over a long time

4 Stopping anger having contemplated the many faults of impatience

ANGER IS UNSUITABLE BECAUSE IT IS UNNECESSARY AND VERY FAULTY

[III.4] If someone harms us and we become angry,

Does our anger undo what was done?

Thus getting angry is certainly senseless here

And contradictory with the world beyond.

If someone harms us and we become angry, our anger cannot undo the harm that was done. Although it may seem that anger is justified and that it yields some satisfaction, if we check closely we will see that there is never any point in getting angry. For example, suppose a man called George who has been separated from his family for a long time is travelling home for a family reunion. On the way he encounters an unruly person who says something to upset him and, instead of practising patience and continuing on his way, he answers back and provokes further insult.
