In such a situation they could easily come to blows and George could well spend his holiday in hospital or even jail rather than with his family. George’s retaliation and anger would have served only to bring unhappiness both to himself and to his family. Anger never brings redress but only adds to our present troubles, and because it causes suffering in future lives it is also contradictory with our wish for future happiness.

NOT WISHING FUTURE SUFFERING AND RETALIATING HARMFULLY ARE CONTRADICTORY

[III.5] How can one who wants to assert that he is eradicating

The effects of non-virtuous actions committed in the past

Sow the seeds of future suffering

Through anger and harm towards others?

When we are harmed by others we naturally assume that they are the cause of our suffering, but in reality all the harm we experience is the result of non-virtuous actions we have committed in the past. If we want to eradicate such harmful effects we must learn to accept them patiently as the fruits of our own actions. Each time we do so we purify the non-virtue that led to that experience and ensure that it will not affect us again. Patiently accepting harm with a positive mind gradually purifies non-virtue and sows the seeds of future happiness, but retaliating to those who harm us only sows seeds of future suffering. Therefore wishing for happiness in the future and retaliating with anger are contradictory. Seeing this, we should try to prevent anger and always practise patience.

ANGER IS UNSUITABLE BECAUSE IT DESTROYS VIRTUES PREVIOUSLY ACCUMULATED OVER A LONG TIME

[III.6] Through getting angry with Conquerors’ Sons

Virtues accumulated from giving and moral discipline

Over a hundred aeons are destroyed in an instant,

Therefore there is no evil greater than anger.

Through getting angry with Bodhisattvas for just an instant we can destroy virtues arising from actions such as giving and moral discipline that we have accumulated over a hundred aeons. Moreover, such anger will retard our spiritual practice by making it harder for us to attain realizations, and it will condemn us to lower rebirth in the future. Therefore there is no evil greater than anger. Since we do not know who is a Bodhisattva and who is not, we should always take great care to avoid anger.

In Manjushri Sport Sutra Buddha says:

Anger destroys virtues accumulated over a hundred aeons.

and in Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life Shantideva says:

All the virtuous deeds and merit,

Such as giving and making offerings,

That we have accumulated over thousands of aeons

Can be destroyed by just one moment of anger.

Anger either weakens or destroys the potentiality of our virtuous actions to produce beneficial results in the future. For example, the virtuous action of observing pure moral discipline has the potentiality to cause rebirth as a human, but this potentiality may be weakened or destroyed by subsequent anger. The specific effect will depend on the object and the intensity of the anger. Generally, the effects are far worse if the anger is directed at someone who has higher realizations than oneself. Anger directed at Buddhas and Bodhisattvas is the worst of all. Similarly, the effects of strong anger are far worse than the effects of slight anger. For example, if we generate intense anger towards a Bodhisattva or other highly-realized being, the potentiality to produce a human rebirth will be destroyed. Just as a tree whose roots are cut can never produce fruit, so a virtuous action whose roots are severed by anger can never produce a result. However, if we generate only slight anger towards a higher being and immediately generate regret the adverse effects will be considerably less. If our anger is not so intense and is directed at someone with the same realizations as us it will not destroy the potentiality but it will weaken it and postpone the ripening of its effect. If that anger is not purified we will take rebirth in a lower realm and the fruits of observing moral discipline will not ripen until subsequent lives. If we generate only slight anger towards someone who has lower realizations than us the potentiality will be only slightly weakened. For example, we might take a human rebirth in our next life but experience difficulties in gaining spiritual realizations during that life. However, if we repeatedly generate strong anger towards someone with lower realizations without feeling regret this will destroy the potentiality.

STOPPING ANGER HAVING CONTEMPLATED THE MANY FAULTS OF IMPATIENCE

[III.7abc] Impatience creates unattractive forms, leads to the unholy,

Robs us of our discrimination that knows right from wrong

And soon throws us into lower realms.

Generally, patience is the cause of beautiful forms and anger the cause of unattractive forms. Whenever we get angry our physical appearance transforms and our face becomes ugly and frowning. We develop an intimidating presence that causes others to avoid us as much as possible. We also sow the seeds to be reborn in an ugly form in the future. Moreover, anger leads us to unholy states by destroying our reputation and diminishing our special qualities. If those who are looked on as holy beings repeatedly get angry they soon cease to command the respect of others and eventually come to be regarded as ordinary beings. In future lives too they will become unholy beings.

Anger destroys all our positive minds. For example, it robs us of our ability to discriminate right from wrong. Most of us have the wisdom to know that killing is wrong, but under the influence of anger we can lose this wisdom and take another’s life. All the sufferings that ensue from such actions are the results of anger. Similarly all conflicts in this world from domestic quarrels to world wars arise from anger. Whenever we act out of anger we accumulate negative karma that causes us to take lower rebirth. The sufferings that result from anger in this life are mild compared with the agonies of the lower realms, where the duration of misery is inconceivably long.

By reflecting on these faults we will come to see that anger is wholly destructive and functions only to cause harm to both ourself and others. We should become convinced of this and make a firm decision always to prevent anger.

THE SUITABILITY OF RELYING ON PATIENCE

This has two parts:

1 Contemplating the many benefits of patience

2 In summary, an exhortation to rely on patience

CONTEMPLATING THE MANY BENEFITS OF PATIENCE

[III.7d] Patience produces qualities opposite to what has been explained.

[III.8] From patience come beauty, closeness to holy beings,

Skill in knowing the suitable and unsuitable,

And after this, birth as a human or god,

And the eradication of negativity.

By practising patience we develop qualities that are opposite to the faults of anger. Patience beautifies the body and leads to a handsome and healthy rebirth, it earns us the respect and affection of others and we become close to holy beings and eventually become holy ourself. Our realizations such as skill in knowing what is suitable and unsuitable naturally increase and our non-virtuous actions are gradually purified and eventually eradicated altogether. In the future we will take rebirth as humans or gods. In Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life Shantideva says:

There is no evil greater than anger,

And no virtue greater than patience.

Therefore, I should strive in various ways

To become familiar with the practice of patience.

In Condensed Exposition of the Stages of the Path Je Tsongkhapa says:

Patience is the supreme ornament of the powerful,

The best fortitude against the pain of delusion,

The garuda, enemy of the serpent of hatred

And armour against the weapons of harsh words.

Knowing this, become acquainted in various ways

With the supreme armour of patience.

I who am a Yogi practised in this way;

You who seek liberation, please do the same.

Due to imprints from our past lives we may have a tendency to become angry in certain situations. To counteract this we need to think about the faults of anger repeatedly and keep them in mind all the time. We should regard anger as a poison that has no function other than to harm us. When we feel ourself becoming irritated and on the point of becoming angry we should immediately remember the faults of anger and prevent it from developing. If we always practise in this way our tendency to become angry will gradually diminish and eventually disappear altogether. Then we will have become a person who never gets angry!

Dharma practitioners may sometimes find anger arising in their minds, but they remember the faults of anger straightaway and try to prevent it from developing further. This is very good because they immediately forget their anger and do not bear a lasting grudge. If we do not check anger as soon as it arises, it quickly takes hold of our mind and turns into a lingering resentment. If possible, we should prevent anger from arising at all, but if it does arise in our mind we must immediately take steps to remove it and prevent it from becoming resentment.

IN SUMMARY, AN EXHORTATION TO RELY ON PATIENCE

[III.9] Knowing the faults of anger and the good qualities of patience

In ordinary beings and Conquerors’ Sons,

We should quickly abandon impatience

And always rely on patience praised by Superior beings.

In summary, having contemplated the faults of anger in ordinary beings and the good qualities of patience in Bodhisattvas, we should quickly abandon anger and always rely on the practice of patience that is praised by Superior beings.

THE DIVISIONS OF THE PERFECTION OF PATIENCE

[III.10] Although dedicated to the enlightenment of complete Buddhahood,

If there is observation of the three it is mundane.

Buddha taught that if there is no observation

That is a supramundane perfection.

The perfection of patience has two divisions – the mundane perfection of patience and the supramundane perfection of patience. A perfection of patience in one who conceives the three spheres – oneself, the practice of patience and the object of patience – to be inherently existent is a mundane perfection, even though it is dedicated to the enlightenment of complete Buddhahood. On the other hand, a perfection of patience maintained by a direct realization of the lack of inherent existence of the three spheres is a supramundane perfection.

THE OTHER PURE QUALITIES THAT ARISE ON THIS GROUND

[III.11] The Conquerors’ Son on this ground

Has the mental stabilizations and clairvoyances.

Attachment and hatred are completely extinguished

And he is always able to overcome the desirous attachment of worldly beings.

The third-ground Bodhisattva has many other pure qualities besides patience. He or she attains extraordinary concentration and so has special realizations of the four absorptions of the form realm, the four absorptions of the formless realm, the four immeasurables and the five clairvoyances.

The absorptions of the form and formless realms are often called ‘mundane paths’ because they can lead to rebirth as a form or formless realm god. All samsaric beings live in one of the three realms – the desire realm, the form realm or the formless realm. The desire realm is the grossest of the three realms and has ten levels – the hell realm, the hungry ghost realm, the animal realm, the human realm and the six realms of desire realm gods – Land of the Four Great Kings, Land of the Thirty-three Heavens, Land Without Combat, Joyful Land, Land of Enjoying Emanations and Land of Controlling Emanations. The desire realm is so called because the beings who inhabit it are afflicted with gross desirous attachment.

Compared with the desire realm, the form and formless realms are very pure and peaceful. The form realm has four levels – the first form realm, the second form realm, the third form realm and the fourth form realm. Within these, the first form realm has three levels – Brahma Class, Attending Brahma and Great Brahma. The principal being of the first form realm is the god Brahma. He resides in the Great Brahma level and reigns over the two realms beneath him. The second form realm has three levels – Little Light, Immeasurable Light and Clear Light. These are named after the amount of light that the gods radiate. The third form realm has three levels – Little Virtue, Immeasurable Virtue and Extensive Virtue. These are named after the degree of bliss experienced by the gods who inhabit them. The fourth form realm has eight levels – Cloudless, Born from Merit, Great Result, Not Great, Without Pain, Excellent Appearance, Great Seeing and None Higher. The first three are places of rebirth of ordinary beings and the last five are places of rebirth of Hinayana Superiors. Cloudless is so called because the gods who inhabit it are free from the clouds of the grosser level of bliss experienced by the gods of the third form realm, Born from Merit is so called because rebirth here is the result of great merit and Great Result is so called because it is the highest state ordinary beings can attain by depending on form realm absorptions. The long-life gods mentioned in the Lamrim teachings on the eight unfree states live on this level. The remaining five levels are known as the ‘five Pure Lands’. When Hinayana Foe Destroyers die they often choose to be born in one of these Lands where they can remain at peace for as long as they wish. These Pure Lands are beyond samsara, but they are not Buddha Lands. The form realm is so called because the gods who inhabit it have subtle form aggregates.

The formless realm has four levels – infinite space, infinite consciousness, nothingness and peak of samsara. The last of these is the highest state within samsara. The formless realm is so called because the gods who inhabit it lack the aggregate of form. The various levels of the form and formless realms are differentiated by the level of concentration of the beings who inhabit them.

The gods who live in the form and formless realms have no gross delusions such as anger, jealousy or attachment to external objects. They do not depend on external conditions such as food and clothing, although form realm gods do abide in beautiful celestial mansions that appear spontaneously when they are born. Since they are not born from a womb they do not experience the sufferings of birth and since they do not have gross bodies they do not experience the sufferings of sickness, ageing and death experienced by beings in the desire realm. Many non-Buddhists regard rebirth as a form or formless realm god as a state of liberation. In reality, however, these gods are still trapped in the prison of samsara and when the karma for them to enjoy that rebirth is exhausted they die and fall back to the lower realms.

Bodhisattvas understand that there is no lasting benefit in being reborn in the form and formless realms. However, they still strive to attain the form and formless realm absorptions. These are powerful, blissful minds that are always conjoined with mental suppleness. Meditation on emptiness with a form or formless realm absorption is much more powerful than it is with a desire realm mind because these minds readily mix with emptiness making it much easier to overcome dualistic appearance. When used in this way, these absorptions are not mundane paths that lead to rebirth as a samsaric god but supramundane paths that lead to liberation and enlightenment.

The four absorptions of the form realm are known as the first mental stabilization, the second mental stabilization, the third mental stabilization and the fourth mental stabilization, and the four absorptions of the formless realm are known as the absorption of infinite space, the absorption of infinite consciousness, the absorption of nothingness and the absorption of peak of samsara. These absorptions are attained by abandoning progressively more and more subtle levels of delusion.

The desire realm, the four form realms and the four formless realms each have nine levels of delusion, making eighty-one levels of delusion in all. The nine levels of delusion of the desire realm are big-big, middling-big, small-big, big-middling, middling-middling, small-middling, big-small, middling-small and small-small. The nine levels of delusion of each of the four form realms and four formless realms are named in a similar way. To attain the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization we have to abandon the nine levels of delusion of the desire realm, to attain the actual absorption of the second mental stabilization we have to abandon the nine levels of delusion of the first form realm and so on. It should be noted however that by training in mundane paths we can abandon only manifest delusions, that is we can temporarily prevent the delusions from becoming manifest, but we cannot eradicate them altogether by destroying their seeds. To do this we must train in supramundane paths.

To attain the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization of the form realm we first need to train in the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization. When we attain tranquil abiding we attain the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization of a beginner, which is a form realm mind that has not yet attained superior seeing. Then, with the determination to abandon the delusions of the desire realm, we need to train in the absorption of close preparation that overcomes delusions. This has six stages, which are known as the ‘six attentions’. They are:

(1) Attention cognizing specific characteristics

(2) Attention of belief

(3) Attention of complete isolation

(4) Attention of gathering joy

(5) Attention of analysis

(6) Attention of the conclusion of training

The first of these is a special type of wisdom. After attaining tranquil abiding, a Yogi or Yogini who wishes to attain the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization engages in analytical meditation on the faults of the desire realm and the advantages of the form realm. This is the main cause of attaining superior seeing. Although at this stage the Yogi possesses tranquil abiding he cannot maintain it while he is doing this analysis. Previously he accomplished tranquil abiding by fixing his mind on a stationary object. Now he has to train in the nine mental abidings, overcoming the five obstacles by applying the eight opponents, while his mind is engaged in analysis.

First he or she brings to mind the object, the faults of the desire realm and the advantages of the form realm. This is the first mental abiding. Then he trains principally in improving his mindfulness until he reaches the point where he never forgets the object throughout the entire session, irrespective of whether he is engaged in placement meditation or analytical meditation. This is the fourth mental abiding. Then he must strive to eliminate the faults of subtle mental sinking and subtle mental excitement. The latter are particularly difficult to overcome because the activity of analyzing can easily disturb the stability of concentration. Eventually, however, the Yogi reaches the point where he can maintain effortless, spontaneous concentration while analyzing the faults of the desire realm and the advantages of the form realm. This is the ninth mental abiding.

Through continuing to alternate between analytical meditation and placement meditation, eventually he attains a special mental and physical suppleness induced by analysis. Previously, the stability of his placement meditation slightly hindered his analytical meditation and the movement of his analytical meditation disturbed the stability of his placement meditation. Now he is able both to analyze the object without disturbing the stability of his concentration and concentrate on the object without impeding his analysis. When he attains this special suppleness induced by analysis he attains superior seeing, and his attention cognizing specific characteristics transforms into the attention of belief.

The attention of belief is so called because as a result of the previous analysis it strongly believes the desire realm to be faulty and the form realm to be peaceful. The attention of belief is by nature superior seeing. When the attention of belief becomes powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-big desire realm delusions it transforms into the attention of complete isolation, which is so called because it completely isolates the mind from the grossest level of manifest desire realm delusions. This attention is also the nature of superior seeing. There are six stages to this attention:

(1) Attention of complete isolation that is the direct antidote to big-big desire realm delusions

(2) Attention of complete isolation that is completely released from big-big desire realm delusions

(3) Attention of complete isolation that is the direct antidote to middling-big desire realm delusions

(4) Attention of complete isolation that is completely released from middling-big desire realm delusions

(5) Attention of complete isolation that is the direct antidote to small-big desire realm delusions

(6) Attention of complete isolation that is completely released from small-big desire realm delusions

The first, third and fifth are uninterrupted paths; and the second, fourth and sixth are released paths. The Yogi attains the first two in the same session and then alternates between the practices of subsequent attainment and meditative equipoise until his meditation is powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the middling-big desire realm delusions. With this he attains the third attention of complete isolation and so on.

Having attained release from the three levels of big desire realm delusion, the Yogi now strives to abandon the three levels of middling desire realm delusion. When his meditation is powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-middling desire realm delusions, his attention of complete isolation transforms into the attention of gathering joy. This has six stages, similar to the six stages of the attention of complete isolation, which abandon the three levels of middling desire realm delusion.

When the Yogi attains release from the small-middling desire realm delusions he feels as if he has abandoned all delusions. Objects that used to provoke anger, jealousy or attachment no longer stimulate any delusions and he feels as if he could not generate delusions even if he tried. However, when he returns to his meditation and closely examines his mind he realizes that he still has subtle levels of desire realm delusion within his continuum. He then determines to abandon these. This process of analysis and determination, which is done with the wisdom of superior seeing and the concentration of tranquil abiding, is the attention of analysis.

When this attention becomes powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-small desire realm delusions it transforms into the attention of the conclusion of training. This has five stages, which correspond to the first five stages of the attentions of complete isolation and gathering joy. The first, third and fifth stages are uninterrupted paths that are the direct antidotes to big-small, middling-small and small-small desire realm delusions respectively. The second and fourth stages are released paths that have abandoned big-small and middling-small desire realm delusions respectively. The released path that has abandoned small-small desire realm delusions is the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization.

The stages of accomplishing the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization are similar to the stages of the five supramundane paths. The initial attainment of the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization of a beginner is like a mundane path of accumulation. It is not an actual path of accumulation but it performs a similar function. The attention cognizing specific characteristics is like a mundane path of preparation and the attention of belief is like a mundane path of seeing. Just as on the actual path of seeing the wisdom realizing emptiness is not yet powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to innate delusions so on the mundane path of seeing the superior seeing observing the faults of the desire realm and the advantages of the form realm is not yet powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-big delusions of the desire realm. When the attention of belief transforms into the attention of complete isolation this is like entering the mundane path of meditation. On the actual path of meditation the innate delusions are abandoned level by level by the wisdom realizing selflessness and on the mundane path of meditation the manifest delusions of the desire realm are abandoned in a similar way by the last four attentions. When the small-small desire realm delusions have been abandoned the Yogi attains the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization, which is like a mundane path of No More Learning.

The actual absorption of the first mental stabilization is a far purer, more peaceful and more stable mind than the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization. Unless he or she goes on to develop higher absorptions or is motivated by renunciation or bodhichitta a Yogi who has attained the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization will definitely be reborn in the first form realm in his or her next life. This is because he no longer has the cause to be reborn in the desire realm but has not yet created the cause to be reborn in the second form realm or higher. Since he has no manifest desire realm delusions he cannot generate dependent-related craving and grasping for the desire realm. Instead he develops a subtle type of attachment for the first form realm, which functions as the dependent-related links of craving and grasping. These serve to ripen the potentialities that cause rebirth in the first form realm.

To attain the actual absorption of the second mental stabilization of the form realm, the Yogi meditates on the absorption of close preparation of the second mental stabilization. He meditates on the grossness of the first form realm compared with the peacefulness of the second form realm and generates a determination to abandon the nine levels of delusion of the first form realm by applying the six attentions. These attentions are similar to those of the first mental stabilization except that at this level they function to abandon the delusions of the first form realm instead of the delusions of the desire realm. When the attention of the conclusion of training of the second mental stabilization has abandoned the small-small delusions of the first form realm the Yogi attains the actual absorption of the second mental stabilization. The way to attain the actual absorptions of the third and fourth mental stabilizations of the form realm can be understood from this explanation.

The formless realm is higher than the form realm from the point of view of peacefulness, purity and absence of distracting thoughts. Both ordinary beings and Hinayana Superiors can take rebirth there but Bodhisattvas do not. Formless realm beings lack physical bodies and do not have sense powers so they have no opportunity to listen to Dharma teachings or to communicate with others. Since the only reason Bodhisattvas take rebirth in the abodes of samsara is to benefit living beings, there is no reason for them to take rebirth in a realm where they cannot communicate with its inhabitants. However, Bodhisattvas strive to accomplish the formless realm absorptions because they are extremely subtle and powerful states of mind that allow them to attain deep absorption on emptiness free from gross conceptual distraction.

As mentioned before, there are four actual absorptions of the formless realm:

(1) The absorption of infinite space

(2) The absorption of infinite consciousness

(3) The absorption of nothingness

(4) The absorption of peak of samsara

The way to attain these four absorptions is similar to the way to attain the four absorptions of the form realm. Thus, to attain the actual absorption of infinite space the Yogi must abandon the nine levels of delusion of the fourth form realm by training in the absorption of close preparation of infinite space. Seeing that many problems arise from attachment to forms the Yogi develops a determination to attain a state of formlessness. With this motivation he meditates on unproduced space, the mere absence of form, until he attains tranquil abiding on this object. This is the absorption of close preparation of infinite space of a beginner. Then, with tranquil abiding, he analyzes the faults of form and the good qualities of formlessness. This is the attention cognizing specific characteristics. When he develops the bliss of suppleness arisen from this analysis he attains the attention of belief and when this is able to function as the direct antidote to big-big delusions of the fourth form realm he attains the attention of complete isolation. As with the attention of complete isolation of the form realms, this attention also has six stages – the three uninterrupted paths that are the direct antidotes to the three levels of big delusion of the fourth form realm and the three released paths that have abandoned these delusions. When the attention of complete isolation becomes powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-middling delusions of the fourth form realm it transforms into the attention of gathering joy. After completing this attention the Yogi then analyzes his mind with the attention of analysis and realizes that small delusions of the fourth form realm still remain in his mental continuum. To abandon these he continues to meditate on the union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing observing the vacuity of infinite space until his meditation becomes powerful enough to function as the direct antidote to the big-small delusions of the fourth form realm. At this point he attains the attention of the conclusion of training. Again, this has five stages – three uninterrupted paths and two released paths. The released path that has abandoned small-small delusions of the fourth form realm is the actual absorption of infinite space.

To attain the actual absorption of infinite consciousness the Yogi contemplates the relative grossness of infinite space and subtlety of infinite consciousness. Then concentrating on the infinity of consciousness he completes the stages of the absorption of close preparation of infinite consciousness, which are similar to those already explained except that at this level they function to abandon the nine levels of delusion of the first formless realm. To attain the actual absorption of nothingness the Yogi considers the appearance of consciousness to be gross and meditates on nothingness. Progressing through the same stages as before he gradually abandons the nine levels of delusion of the second formless realm and attains the actual absorption of nothingness. To attain the actual absorption of peak of samsara the Yogi considers the discrimination of nothingness to be a gross discrimination, and he develops a wish to abandon all gross discriminations and remain only in a state of subtle consciousness. Then by concentrating on the cessation of gross discrimination he gradually abandons the nine levels of delusion of the third formless realm and attains the actual absorption of peak of samsara.

Peak of samsara also has nine levels of delusion, from big-big to small-small. It is possible to abandon the first eight levels by following only mundane paths and many non-Buddhist meditators have done so. However, to abandon the small-small delusions of peak of samsara and thereby attain liberation it is necessary to meditate on supramundane paths, or paths that are conjoined with a direct realization of emptiness. These paths are found only within the Buddhist system.

A Yogi who has attained the mundane path of the absorption of peak of samsara in a human body can progress further by generating renunciation and entering the path to liberation, but a person who has taken rebirth in the realm of peak of samsara has no such opportunity. All he can do is abide in a state of subtle consciousness with no mental activity until his karma for remaining in that state is exhausted. Then, with his stock of merit depleted, he dies and falls back to lower realms. The mundane path of peak of samsara only temporarily abandons the eighty levels of delusion. Because the seeds of these delusions remain, the delusions themselves eventually manifest again.

In summary, the eight absorptions of close preparation and the eight actual absorptions of the form and formless realms can be either mundane or supramundane paths. Any absorption that is not motivated by renunciation or bodhichitta is a mundane path and a cause of rebirth in samsara. Many non-Buddhists understand the faults of the desire realm and the good qualities of the upper realms but they do not understand pervasive suffering and so they cannot develop renunciation for all three realms of samsara. Some regard the form realm absorptions as the ultimate attainment while others see them as a step on the way to the higher absorptions of the formless realm, which they consider to be real liberation. From a Buddhist point of view, however, rebirth as a god of the form or formless realm is not a step on the way to liberation but an obstacle to attaining liberation. Generally, form and formless realm gods cannot develop renunciation or bodhichitta nor identify the object of negation of emptiness. For this reason, those who seek liberation or enlightenment pray not to be reborn in these realms.

Although Bodhisattvas have no wish to take rebirth in the upper realms they do nevertheless strive to attain the form and formless realm absorptions. From the great stage of the path of accumulation onwards Bodhisattvas meditate on emptiness with actual form or formless realm absorptions but because of the strength of their bodhichitta motivation these absorptions do not cause rebirth in the upper realms. For Bodhisattvas, the form and formless realm absorptions are causes of enlightenment and are therefore supramundane paths. The definitions of the absorptions of the form and formless realms are given below in the section on the emptiness of definitions (see here).

Besides special realizations of the form and formless realm absorptions, the Bodhisattva on the third ground also has special realizations of the four immeasurables and the five clairvoyances. The four immeasurables are immeasurable love, immeasurable compassion, immeasurable joy and immeasurable equanimity. Immeasurable love is a mind attained in dependence on a concentration that wishes immeasurable living beings to experience happiness. Within the three kinds of love – affectionate love, cherishing love and wishing love – immeasurable love is necessarily wishing love. Immeasurable compassion is a mind attained in dependence on a concentration that wishes immeasurable living beings to be free from suffering. Immeasurable joy is a mind attained in dependence on a concentration that wishes immeasurable living beings never to be separated from happiness. Immeasurable equanimity is a mind attained in dependence on a concentration that wishes immeasurable living beings to be free from attachment and hatred.

Each of the four immeasurables is generated in dependence on four causes – the seed, the observed object, the dominant condition and the immediate condition. The seed of a particular mind is the potentiality for that mind. Every living being has the seeds of the four immeasurables in their mental continuum, which are the main causes of the four immeasurables. When, for example, the seed of immeasurable love within our continuum meets with the other three causes immeasurable love is generated. The observed object of immeasurable love is immeasurable living beings who are seen to be without real happiness. The observed object of immeasurable compassion is immeasurable living beings who are seen to be experiencing suffering. The observed object of immeasurable joy is immeasurable living beings who are seen to be experiencing only limited happiness. The observed object of immeasurable equanimity is immeasurable living beings who are seen to be experiencing unending problems and suffering as a result of their attachment and hatred. The dominant condition of each of the four immeasurables is the Spiritual Guide who teaches us how to generate that mind. These special minds never arise naturally but have to be cultivated by following the instructions of a qualified Spiritual Guide. The immediate condition of each of the four immeasurables is the mind that directly induces it.

Each of the four immeasurables has a threefold division. For example, immeasurable love is divided into immeasurable love observing mere living beings, immeasurable love observing phenomena and immeasurable love observing the unobservable. These can be understood from the explanation of the three types of compassion given above. The definitions of the four immeasurables are given below, in the section on the emptiness of definitions (see here).

The definition of clairvoyance is a mind that directly apprehends its object through the power of an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. There are five clairvoyances – the clairvoyance of miracle powers, the clairvoyance of divine ear, the clairvoyance of knowing others’ minds, the clairvoyance of knowing previous lives and the clairvoyance of divine eye. These are of great help to Bodhisattvas in their work to benefit all living beings. In Lamp for the Path to Enlightenment Atisha says:

Just as a bird without wings cannot fly, so those who lack clairvoyance cannot benefit living beings.

The definition of clairvoyance of miracle powers is a clairvoyance that can produce magical transformations in dependence on an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. Examples are concentrations that can transform one object into many or many into one, make small objects large or large objects small, or enable one to walk on air or through the earth. Because in these impure times beings have little merit and little wisdom, Bodhisattvas no longer make public displays of their miracle powers in case they prove counter-productive, but in the past they used such powers to inspire faith in others.

The definition of clairvoyance of divine ear is a clairvoyance that directly hears gross and subtle sounds in dependence on an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. Examples are mental direct perceivers that directly hear distant sounds and subtle inner sounds that are beyond the range of ordinary hearing. Bodhisattvas use this clairvoyance to know the speech of others so that they can give appropriate advice.

The definition of clairvoyance of knowing others’ minds is a clairvoyance that directly knows the minds of others in dependence on an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. An example is a mental direct perceiver that directly perceives another’s thoughts or feelings. Bodhisattvas use this clairvoyance to help them give appropriate teachings.

The definition of clairvoyance of knowing previous lives is a clairvoyance that directly knows one’s own and others’ previous lives and abodes in dependence on an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. An example is Atisha’s clairvoyance knowing the previous lives of himself, Dromtonpa and his other Tibetan disciples. On the basis of this knowledge he gave special teachings that became known as the Kadam Dharma of the Father and the Kadam Dharma of the Sons. Bodhisattvas use this clairvoyance to increase the range of experience from which they can draw when they teach or meditate.

The definition of clairvoyance of divine eye is a clairvoyance that directly sees distant forms and subtle forms in dependence on an actual form realm absorption that is its uncommon dominant condition. Examples are mental direct perceivers that directly see gross and subtle forms that are beyond the range of ordinary vision. Bodhisattvas use this clairvoyance to locate beings who need help.

Question Since Bodhisattvas on the first two grounds also have all these realizations why are they given as qualities of the third-ground Bodhisattva?

Answer Because the third-ground Bodhisattva has attained an outstanding training in higher concentration, his or her mental stabilizations, absorptions and so forth are much more powerful than those of Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds. Through the force of this concentration he is able to eradicate attachment, hatred, confusion and all the other delusions that arise from middling-big innate true-grasping. He also has great skill in overcoming the desirous attachment and other delusions of worldly beings because he has the confidence and power to guide them into correct paths.

THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE FIRST THREE PERFECTIONS

[III.12] These three Dharmas, giving and so forth,

Are especially praised by the Sugatas for lay people.

They are known as the ‘collection of merit’,

The cause of a Buddha’s Body that is the nature of form.

Although the first three perfections are practised by both lay and ordained Bodhisattvas, Buddha praised them as being especially suited to the lifestyle of lay Bodhisattvas. The perfections of effort, mental stabilization and wisdom, on the other hand, were praised as being more suited to the lifestyle of ordained Bodhisattvas.

The first three perfections are also known as the ‘collection of merit’ because they are the main causes of the Form Body of a Buddha. The perfections of mental stabilization and wisdom are known as the ‘collection of wisdom’ because they are the main causes of the Truth Body of a Buddha. The fourth perfection, the perfection of effort, is equally a cause of both bodies. Thus all six perfections are included within the two collections. When ten perfections are enumerated, the last four are included within the sixth, the perfection of wisdom, and thus within the collection of wisdom.

CONCLUSION BY WAY OF EXPRESSING THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

[III.13] This Luminous, abiding in the sun, the Conquerors’ Son,

First completely removes the darkness within himself

And then strongly wishes to eliminate the darkness of living beings.

Being very sharp on this ground, he never gets angry.

Just as sunlight completely dispels darkness, so the third ground first completely removes the darkness of confusion within the continuum of the Bodhisattva and then seeks to eliminate the darkness of all living beings by striving to attain the perfect enlightenment of Buddhahood. Because the Bodhisattva’s wisdom is very sharp and as clear as the sun it is impossible for him to lose his patience with faulty beings and so he never gets angry.

This concludes the commentary to the third ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Manjushri

Radiant

THE FOURTH GROUND, RADIANT

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the fourth ground

2 Explanation of the fourth ground

Introduction to the fourth ground has three parts:

1 How the fourth ground is attained

2 Definition of the fourth ground

3 Divisions of the fourth ground

HOW THE FOURTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the third ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to small-big innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the third ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned small-big innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the fourth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE FOURTH GROUND

The definition of the fourth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned small-big innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of effort from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE FOURTH GROUND

The fourth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the fourth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the fourth ground and the exalted awareness of the fourth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the fourth ground, the uninterrupted path of the fourth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the fourth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the fourth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to big-middling innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

EXPLANATION OF THE FOURTH GROUND

The fourth ground will now be explained under the following three headings:

1 The surpassing effort on this ground

2 The etymology of this ground

3 The characteristics of abandonment

THE SURPASSING EFFORT ON THIS GROUND

[IV.1] All good qualities follow from effort,

The cause of the two collections of merit and wisdom.

The ground on which effort blazes

Is the fourth, Radiant.

The definition of effort is a virtuous mind that delights in virtue. Thus, in Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life Shantideva says:

Effort is a mind that delights in virtue.

Effort is not simply exertion because it is necessarily a virtuous mind and not all exertion is virtuous. An energetic preoccupation with mundane activities, for example, blocks the mind from engaging in virtue and so is a form of laziness. According to Dharma, a mind that is not happy to engage in virtuous actions is laziness. Laziness closes the door to spiritual attainments.

For those who practise effort no goal is unattainable. If we have effort we will happily engage in practices such as giving, moral discipline and patience. We will strive enthusiastically to attain spiritual realizations and eventually we will attain the causal and resultant grounds. Listening to teachings, understanding their meaning and gaining experience of them in meditation all depend on effort. Similarly, all the attainments of the grounds and paths, including the final attainment of Buddhahood depend on effort. Therefore, it is said that all good qualities follow from effort. Moreover, effort is the cause of the two collections of merit and wisdom, which themselves are the principal causes of the two bodies of a Buddha.

The Bodhisattva on the third ground attained a meditative concentration that surpassed that of the first two grounds. Now as a result of that concentration the Bodhisattva on the fourth ground attains a special mental suppleness that is not attained by Bodhisattvas on the three preceding grounds. Through the force of this suppleness he eliminates all traces of laziness from his mind and so his practice of the perfection of effort becomes surpassing.

The definition of perfection of effort is any effort maintained by bodhichitta. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of effort and the transcendent perfection of effort.

THE ETYMOLOGY OF THIS GROUND

[IV.2abc] There, for the Sugatas’ Son,

There arises an appearance superior to the copper light,

Which is produced from superior meditation on the realizations conducive to complete enlightenment;

On the fourth ground the Bodhisattva attains a meditation on the thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment that is superior to that attained by Bodhisattvas on the three preceding grounds. This causes the fire of his wisdom to blaze more strongly and as a result he experiences a radiant appearance that is even more powerful than the coppery glow experienced on the third ground.

Generally, Hearers, Solitary Realizers and Mahayanists all practise the thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment but they practise them at different levels and accomplish different results. Those practised by Hearers lead to a small enlightenment, those practised by Solitary Realizers lead to a middling enlightenment and those practised by Mahayanists lead to a great enlightenment. Usually, the term ‘enlightenment’ refers to great enlightenment.

The thirty-seven realizations are included in seven groups:

(1) Four close placements of mindfulness

(2) Four correct abandoners

(3) Four legs of miracle powers

(4) Five powers

(5) Five forces

(6) Seven branches of enlightenment

(7) Eight branches of superior paths

The definitions of the thirty-seven realizations are given below in the section on the emptiness of definitions (see here). What follows is a brief explanation of how Bodhisattvas train in these practices.

A close placement of mindfulness is a path of concentration that depends on mindfulness and wisdom. There are four types – close placement of mindfulness of body, close placement of mindfulness of feelings, close placement of mindfulness of mind and close placement of mindfulness of phenomena. The first observes the common and uncommon aspects of the body such as its impermanence and emptiness, the second observes the common and uncommon aspects of pleasant, unpleasant and neutral feelings, the third observes the common and uncommon aspects of primary minds and all mental factors other than feelings, and the fourth observes the common and uncommon aspects of phenomena other than body, feelings and mind. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the small stage of the path of accumulation.

A correct abandoner is a special type of effort that delights in abandoning objects of abandonment by means of opponents. There are four types – correct abandoners that abandon non-virtues already generated, correct abandoners that do not generate non-virtues not yet generated, correct abandoners that increase virtues already generated and correct abandoners that generate virtues not yet generated. The last two are called ‘abandoners’ because to practise any virtue we need to abandon its opposite. Within the four opponent powers the first correct abandoner is the power of regret, the second is the power of promise and the third and fourth are included within the power of reliance and the power of the opponent force. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the middling stage of the path of accumulation.

A leg of miracle powers is a path of concentration possessing the eight opponents to the five obstacles that principally functions as a cause of miracle powers. They are called ‘legs’ because they are causes of miracle powers and because they enable the practitioner to travel to places and accomplish deeds beyond the reach and imagination of ordinary beings. There are four types of leg of miracle powers – those developed through aspiration, effort, mind and analysis. The first type exists in those who already have strong concentration and wisdom. Simply by focusing on the observed object of a particular type of miracle power and developing the aspiration to display that power they can induce the concentration that is the miracle leg. The second type is induced through the force of effort, the third through the force of imprints from previous lives and the fourth through the force of analytical meditation on instructions given by others. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the great stage of the path of accumulation.

There are many types of miracle power such as the ability to manifest one body as many or many bodies as one, the ability to fly, and the ability to manifest cities and islands, but it is very difficult for ordinary beings to recognize such emanations. Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are able to produce countless emanations for the sake of living beings. They can manifest inanimate objects such as houses, food, cities and even entire worlds as well as animate objects such as animals or even Spiritual Teachers but unless we have purified our mind we cannot recognize these as emanations.

All the while we believe things exist from their own side, independent of the mind, we will find it difficult to understand how, for example, Milarepa could transform himself into a flower. To understand these things we must first realize that all phenomena are like dreams and do not exist in the least from their own side. If we understand that the world and everything in it arise from mind we will not find it difficult to understand how Yogis and Yoginis who have brought their minds under control can manifest whatever they wish through the power of their concentration.

The five powers are more accurately known as the ‘five powers of the path’. In this context, a power is a path held by the wisdom of superior seeing observing emptiness that is an uncommon cause of superior paths. There are five types – the powers of faith, effort, mindfulness, concentration and wisdom. The power of faith observes great enlightenment and wishes to attain it, the power of effort strives to engage in all the vast and profound paths of the Mahayana, the power of mindfulness observes and retains extensive Mahayana teachings, and the powers of concentration and wisdom observe profound emptiness. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the first two stages of the path of preparation – heat and peak.

The five forces, or more accurately the ‘five forces of the path’, are paths that have conquered their opposing faults. There are five types – the forces of faith, effort, mindfulness, concentration and wisdom. We can understand these by applying them to a particular practice. For example, if we accomplish the five forces of the path with respect to meditation on emptiness, the force of faith is a faith that has conquered non-faith in emptiness, the force of effort is an effort that has conquered the three types of laziness that make us dislike meditating on emptiness, the force of mindfulness is a mindfulness that has conquered forgetfulness of emptiness, the force of concentration is a concentration that has conquered the five obstacles to perfect concentration on emptiness and the force of wisdom is a wisdom that has destroyed all misunderstandings of the meaning of emptiness. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the second two stages of the path of preparation – patience and supreme Dharma.

A branch of enlightenment is a superior path that causes the attainment of enlightenment. There are seven types – the branches of enlightenment of correct mindfulness, correct wisdom, correct effort, correct joy, correct suppleness, correct concentration and correct equanimity.

In Ornament for Mahayana Sutras Maitreya describes the seven branches of enlightenment metaphorically as the seven treasures of a chakravatin king. In previous ages there were kings who ruled over the entire world and brought peace, harmony and prosperity to everyone. Most chakravatin kings were emanations of high Bodhisattvas who deliberately took rebirth in that position to benefit living beings. Chakravatin kings no longer exist in this world because the beings alive now do not have sufficient merit to be ruled by one, but they still exist in other worlds. When a chakravatin king ascends to the throne, seven treasures spontaneously appear through the power of his merit – a precious wheel, a precious elephant, a precious horse, a precious jewel, a precious queen, a precious minister and a precious general or precious householder. These are described in detail in the book Great Treasury of Merit. The branch of enlightenment of correct mindfulness is like a precious wheel because it enables the Bodhisattva to control all his or her delusions. The branch of enlightenment of correct wisdom is like a precious elephant because it enables him to ride to war against his delusions. The branch of enlightenment of correct effort is like a precious horse because it enables him to advance to the stage of Buddhahood very swiftly. The branch of enlightenment of correct joy is like a precious jewel because it always fills his or her mind with happiness. The branch of enlightenment of correct suppleness is like a precious queen because it removes all mental and physical discomfort and bestows great bliss. The branch of enlightenment of correct concentration is like a precious minister because it fulfils all the Bodhisattva’s wishes. The branch of enlightenment of correct equanimity is like a precious householder because it helps the Bodhisattva to abandon objects of abandonment and practise objects of attainment. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the path of seeing.

A branch of superior paths is a superior path that causes the attainment of higher superior paths. There are eight types – the branches of superior paths of correct view, correct conception, correct speech, correct ends of actions, correct livelihood, correct effort, correct mindfulness and correct concentration. The branch of superior paths of correct view is a superior path that analyzes during the meditation break the emptiness seen during meditative equipoise. The branch of superior paths of correct conception is a superior path that is a motivation wishing to reveal to others the emptiness seen during meditative equipoise. The branch of superior paths of correct speech is a superior path that is the mental intention to maintain pure moral discipline of speech. The branch of superior paths of correct ends of actions is a superior path that is the mental intention to maintain pure moral discipline of body. The branch of superior paths of correct livelihood is a superior path that is the mental intention to maintain pure moral discipline of body and speech together. The branch of superior paths of correct effort is a superior path that strives to abandon unfavourable conditions and advance to higher levels. The branch of superior paths of correct mindfulness is a superior path that never forgets the meaning of the two truths. The branch of superior paths of correct concentration is a superior path that focuses on the meaning of the two truths single-pointedly. The Bodhisattva trains in these practices principally on the path of meditation.

Both the seven branches of enlightenment and the eight branches of superior paths exist on the path of seeing and on the path of meditation but the former are taught principally as good qualities of a Bodhisattva on the path of seeing and the latter as good qualities of a Bodhisattva on the path of meditation. The main purpose of teaching the seven branches of enlightenment is to show that realizations that have abandoned obstructions and attained a deep knowledge of emptiness exist from the path of seeing onwards and the main purpose of teaching the eight branches of superior paths is to show that Bodhisattvas need continually to improve their realizations until they become Buddhas. It is a special quality of Bodhisattvas that no matter how exalted their realizations are they never become complacent.

The main path by which we pass from the stage of a sentient being to the stage of a Buddha is the path of meditation. If we are going to make a long journey we might first take a taxi to the station and then make most of the journey by train. Although taking the taxi was an essential part of the journey if someone asked us how we travelled we would say simply that we had come by train. In the analogy, the path of seeing is like taking the taxi and the path of meditation like taking the train. Although the attainment of the path of seeing marks the beginning of superior paths its duration is very short. As soon as our wisdom becomes powerful enough to abandon big-big innate delusions it transforms into the path of meditation. It is on the path of meditation that most of the work of eradicating delusions and their imprints and completing the training in the ten perfections is accomplished.

THE CHARACTERISTICS OF ABANDONMENT

[IV.2d] And what is related to the view of self is completely eradicated.

The Bodhisattva on the fourth ground has abandoned the small-big, innate view of the transitory collection. Related to this subtle view of the self are a gross self-grasping of persons that apprehends the self to be self-supporting and substantially existent as well as certain conceptions of true existence with respect to the aggregates, sources and elements. These are completely eradicated on the fourth ground.

This concludes the commentary to the fourth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Difficult to Overcome

THE FIFTH GROUND, DIFFICULT TO OVERCOME

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the fifth ground

2 Explanation of the fifth ground

Introduction to the fifth ground has three parts:

1 How the fifth ground is attained

2 Definition of the fifth ground

3 Divisions of the fifth ground

HOW THE FIFTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the fourth ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to big-middling innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the fourth ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned big-middling innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the fifth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE FIFTH GROUND

The definition of the fifth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned big-middling innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of mental stabilization from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE FIFTH GROUND

The fifth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the fifth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the fifth ground and the exalted awareness of the fifth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the fifth ground, the uninterrupted path of the fifth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the fifth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the fifth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to middling-middling innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

EXPLANATION OF THE FIFTH GROUND

The fifth ground will now be explained under the following two headings:

1 The etymology of the fifth ground

2 The surpassing mental stabilization and skill in the truths

THE ETYMOLOGY OF THE FIFTH GROUND

[V.1ab] This great being on the ground Difficult to Overcome

Cannot be defeated even by all the maras.

The Bodhisattva on the fifth ground cannot be overcome even by all the Devaputra maras throughout the universe, therefore this ground is called ‘Difficult to Overcome’. A mara, or demon, is anything that obstructs the attainment of liberation or enlightenment. There are four types – the mara of the delusions, the mara of the aggregates, the mara of the Lord of Death and the Devaputra maras. Of these, only the last are actual living beings.

Our deluded minds such as attachment, anger and confusion are maras because they function only to obstruct our attainment of liberation. Without abandoning the delusions there is no way to attain liberation.

The mara of the aggregates is our appropriated, contaminated aggregates. Generally, an aggregate is an assembly of parts produced by causes and conditions. Aggregate, product and functioning thing are synonyms. A contaminated aggregate is an aggregate that is produced from contaminated causes – delusions and actions motivated by delusions – and that functions to stimulate further delusions. All the places, bodies, minds and enjoyments of samsaric beings are contaminated aggregates. Contaminated aggregates and true sufferings are synonymous. There are two types of contaminated aggregate – internal contaminated aggregates and external contaminated aggregates. The former are contaminated aggregates that are a basis for imputing a person, and the latter are contaminated aggregates that are not a basis for imputing a person. Internal contaminated aggregates and appropriated aggregates are synonyms. Our present five aggregates of form, feeling, discrimination, compositional factors and consciousness are appropriated aggregates.

All our miseries come from these appropriated, contaminated aggregates. Without them there would be no basis for suffering. Each time we take rebirth in samsara we appropriate contaminated aggregates. Having done so, without any choice we have to die, pass through the intermediate state, take another rebirth and so on. This endless cycle of misery, which is known as ‘samsara’, is nothing other than the appropriated, contaminated aggregates. Since we cannot attain liberation without abandoning these contaminated aggregates they are called ‘maras’. However, not all aggregates that are a basis for imputing a person are contaminated aggregates. A Buddha’s aggregates, for example, arise from the collections of merit and wisdom, not from karma and delusion. Only internal contaminated aggregates are maras.

As for the third type of mara, the Lord of Death, or Yama, is not an actual living being but simply uncontrolled death. It is called a ‘lord’ because right now it has complete dominion over our lives. Je Tsongkhapa said there are two main obstacles to the attainment of liberation – death and ignorance. If we lose money, possessions, or friends we may suffer a temporary setback but our spiritual practice will not end. However if we lose our precious human life we lose our opportunity to practise Dharma and thereby our opportunity to attain liberation. For this reason uncontrolled death is called a ‘mara’.

The fourth type of mara, Devaputra, is wrathful Ishvara, a worldly deity inhabiting Land of Controlling Emanations, which is the highest level of the desire realm. He and his manifestations try to prevent Dharma practitioners from attaining liberation from samsara by disturbing their mental peace. If a Dharma practitioner suddenly loses interest in his or her practice, or if someone keeping pure moral discipline develops strong attachment for another person and breaks his or her vows, or when someone who previously had much faith begins to doubt and develop wrong views, these are often the work of Devaputra maras. When Buddha was about to attain enlightenment he was attacked by a hundred thousand million maras, all of whom were manifestations of Devaputra. They tried to disrupt his concentration in many ways such as attacking him with weapons and manifesting alluring women to distract him but because his concentration on love was so powerful they were utterly unable to disturb him.

THE SURPASSING MENTAL STABILIZATION AND SKILL IN THE TRUTHS

[V.1cd] His mental stabilization is surpassing and he also attains great skill in realizing

The subtle nature of the truths of a good mind.

Because the Bodhisattva on the fifth ground has abandoned all conditions discordant with perfect concentration such as gross and subtle distraction his or her practice of the perfection of mental stabilization is surpassing. The definition of perfection of mental stabilization is any concentration maintained by bodhichitta. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of mental stabilization and the transcendent perfection of mental stabilization.

The Bodhisattva on the fifth ground also attains great skill in realizing the gross and subtle nature of the four noble truths. Chandrakirti calls these ‘truths of a good mind’ because they are truths for Superior beings, or noble ones. The four noble truths are – true sufferings, true origins, true cessations and true paths.

The definition of true suffering is a contaminated aggregate that is principally caused by deluded action. They are called ‘true sufferings’ because Superior beings, who see things as they really are, directly see them to have the nature of suffering. There are four types of true suffering – contaminated bodies, contaminated minds, contaminated environments and contaminated enjoyments. The first two are internal true sufferings because they are in the continuum of a person and the second two are external true sufferings because they are not in the continuum of a person.

The definition of true origin is a delusion or action that is the main cause of true sufferings. They are called ‘true origins’ because they are the real source of all suffering and fear. There are two types of true origin – delusion true origins and action true origins. Delusion true origins are the first, eighth and ninth of the twelve dependent-related links, and action true origins are the second and tenth dependent-related links.

The definition of true cessation is the ultimate nature of a mind that has abandoned any obstruction through the force of true paths. True cessations are like the effects of true paths, but they are not actual effects because they are permanent. There are two types of true cessation – Hinayana true cessations and Mahayana true cessations. There are two types of Hinayana true cessation – Hinayana true cessations of intellectually-formed delusions and Hinayana true cessations of innate delusions. There are three types of Mahayana true cessation – Mahayana true cessations of intellectually-formed delusions, Mahayana true cessations of innate delusions and Mahayana true cessations of obstructions to omniscience.

The definition of true path is a Superior being’s realization held by the wisdom directly realizing emptiness. There are two types of true path – Hinayana true paths and Mahayana true paths. Each of these has three types – the path of seeing, the path of meditation and the Path of No More Learning. The ultimate true path is the Mahayana Path of No More Learning, which is actual Buddhahood.

Buddha also taught sixteen aspects of the four noble truths. His purpose was twofold – to explain clearly the existence of liberation and how to attain it, and to eliminate sixteen misconceptions that are the main obstacles to liberation. Each of the four truths has four aspects.

The four aspects of true sufferings are – impermanence, suffering, emptiness and selflessness. By contemplating the first aspect we overcome our attachment to samsaric places, bodies and enjoyments, and by contemplating the second we realize that because the very nature of samsaric objects is suffering they are all objects to be abandoned. By contemplating the third we realize gross selflessness, and by contemplating the fourth we realize subtle selflessness. In Commentary to Valid Cognition Dharmakirti says:

Seeing selflessness liberates us from samsara. All the other aspects are taught for the sake of this.

This means that Buddha taught the first three aspects of true sufferings as a foundation for meditating on and realizing the fourth aspect. It is the realization of subtle selflessness that liberates us from samsara.

The four aspects of true origins are – cause, origin, strong production and condition. By contemplating the first we gain a deep conviction that all suffering has a cause, and by contemplating the second we realize that delusions and deluded actions are the origin of all suffering. By contemplating the third we realize that true origins are capable of producing strong suffering such as the suffering of the hells, and by contemplating the fourth we realize that it is true origins that create the conditions for all adversity such as sickness, poverty, famine and war. Contemplating these four aspects strengthens our determination to abandon true origins.

The four aspects of true cessations are – cessation, peace, supreme attainment and definite abandonment. By contemplating the first we realize that liberation is a true cessation of all true origins and therefore of all true sufferings, and by contemplating the second we realize that liberation is real peace because it is the abandonment of all delusions. By contemplating the third we realize that liberation is a supreme attainment because it is completely non-deceptive, and by contemplating the fourth we realize that it is a definite abandonment because it is an irreversible release from samsaric faults. Contemplating these four aspects encourages us to strive to attain true cessations.

The four aspects of true paths are – path, antidote, accomplishment and definite abandoner. The principal true path is the wisdom directly realizing emptiness. By contemplating the first aspect we realize that this wisdom is a path because it leads us to the destination of liberation, and by contemplating the second we realize that it is the antidote because it directly eliminates delusions. By contemplating the third we realize that it is an accomplishment because it leads to perfect attainments, and by contemplating the fourth we realize that it is a definite abandoner because it is the principal method for abandoning all suffering and all faults. Contemplating these four aspects encourages us to meditate on true paths.

The sixteen misconceptions eliminated by contemplating the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths are:

(1) Contaminated aggregates are permanent

(2) Contaminated aggregates are the nature of happiness

(3) Contaminated aggregates are pure

(4) Contaminated aggregates are truly existent

(5) Suffering has no cause but arises naturally

(6) Suffering arises only because of external circumstances

(7) All suffering is caused by an external Deity

(8) Suffering is permanent

(9) Liberation does not exist

(10) Form or formless realm rebirths are actual liberation

(11) Certain temporary cessations of delusions and suffering are supreme liberation

(12) Liberation is not irreversible but can degenerate

(13) There is no path to liberation

(14) The wisdom directly realizing selflessness is not the path to liberation

(15) Worldly paths such as mundane concentrations or practices of physical asceticism are paths to liberation

(16) There is no spiritual path that can eradicate suffering completely

The first four are misconceptions with respect to true sufferings, the next four are misconceptions with respect to true origins, the next four are misconceptions with respect to true cessations and the last four are misconceptions with respect to true paths. All these misconceptions can be overcome by meditating sincerely on the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths. For example, the first three can be overcome by meditating on impermanence and suffering, the fourth by meditating on emptiness and selflessness, the next four by meditating on the four aspects of true origins and so on.

The root text says that the Bodhisattva on the fifth ground has great skill in realizing the ‘subtle nature’ of the four truths. According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school there are two types of four noble truths – gross four noble truths and subtle four noble truths. This is because there are two types of self-grasping of persons – gross self-grasping of persons (grasping at a self-supporting, substantially existent person) and subtle self-grasping of persons (grasping at an inherently existent person). The difference between these two types of self-grasping is explained in the ninth chapter of the book Meaningful to Behold.

Because there are two types of self-grasping there are two types of delusion that arise from them – gross delusions and subtle delusions – and because there are two types of delusion there are two types of karma created through the force of these delusions. Therefore there are two types of true origin – gross true origins and subtle true origins. Delusion and karma that arise in dependence on grasping at a self-supporting, substantially existent person are gross true origins and their results are gross true sufferings. Delusion and karma that arise in dependence on grasping at an inherently existent person are subtle true origins and their results are subtle true sufferings. A path that directly realizes the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person is a gross true path and the cessation that is an abandonment of the conception of a self-supporting, substantially existent person is a gross true cessation. A path that directly realizes the lack of an inherently existent person is a subtle true path and the cessation that is an abandonment of the conception of an inherently existent person is a subtle true cessation.

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person is a gross selflessness and comparatively easy to realize. Even ordinary beings can attain a direct realization of this selflessness, but no matter how long we meditate on it we will not be able to abandon actual self-grasping. The best we will achieve will be a temporary abandonment of gross self-grasping and the delusions that depend on it. Therefore, the wisdom directly realizing the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person is not an actual true path and the cessation to which it leads is not an actual true cessation. However, the conception of a self-supporting, substantially existent person is a delusion true origin and the sufferings to which it gives rise are true sufferings.

To know the presentations of the gross and subtle four noble truths is to know the complete path to liberation. Therefore Dharmakirti says that if we want to attain liberation all we need is a Teacher who is skilled in the four noble truths.

Question Sometimes Buddha says there are four truths and at other times he says there are two truths. How are the four truths related to the two truths?

Answer The two truths are ultimate truth and conventional truths. All emptinesses are ultimate truths and all phenomena other than emptiness are conventional truths. All objects of knowledge are included within these two truths. We may wonder, therefore, why Buddha also taught the four truths. His purpose was to show what is to be abandoned and what is to be practised by those seeking liberation. Thus, true sufferings and true origins are to be abandoned and true cessations and true paths are to be practised. The four noble truths, however, are not separate from the two truths but are included within them. True sufferings, true origins and true paths are conventional truths, and true cessations are ultimate truths. This is clearly established in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and in Nagarjuna’s Sixty Verses of Reasoning.

It is very important to understand how true cessations are ultimate truths, or emptinesses. The reason is as follows. Because our mind is presently covered by obstructions the emptiness of our mind is also covered by obstructions. When through meditation on true paths our mind is freed from any obstruction, simultaneously the emptiness of our mind is also freed from that obstruction. A freedom of the emptiness of the mind from any obstruction through meditation on true paths is a true cessation. Because such cessations are not different from the emptiness of the mind true cessations are emptinesses and therefore ultimate truths.

True paths and true cessations are Dharma Jewels. Right now it is not easy for us to attain realizations of actual true paths and true cessations, but if we practise sincerely and continuously, eventually these realizations will come.
