If we have even the slightest experience of Dharma we should regard it as the seedling from which these realizations will eventually grow and nourish it accordingly. Our present experiences of Dharma, therefore, are precious and should not be disregarded or neglected. If we care for a young seedling in the appropriate way it will eventually grow into a large tree and bear fruit. In the same way, if we carefully nourish our present experiences of Dharma they will eventually grow into realizations of true paths and true cessations and bear the fruit of liberation. We should never forget that we already have the seeds of actual Dharma Jewels within us.

The attainments of actual true paths and actual true cessations come from an understanding of the emptiness, or the lack of inherent existence, revealed by the Madhyamika-Prasangika school. This is the main subject of the present work and it will now be explained extensively in the following chapters.

This concludes the commentary to the fifth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Nagarjuna

Approaching

THE SIXTH GROUND, APPROACHING

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the sixth ground

2 Explanation of the sixth ground

INTRODUCTION TO THE SIXTH GROUND

As mentioned before, Guide to the Middle Way is principally a commentary to the presentation of emptiness given by Nagarjuna in Fundamental Wisdom. Chandrakirti sets this commentary in the context of his explanation of the sixth ground because it is on this ground that the practice of the perfection of wisdom becomes surpassing.

Since Chandrakirti’s main purpose is to establish the supremacy of the Madhyamika-Prasangika view he presents the commentary as a series of debates between the Madhyamika-Prasangikas and proponents of other tenets, both Buddhist and non-Buddhist. It is important to study these debates in detail and not to pass over them superficially or to dismiss them as having no practical application. Penetrating the meaning established by these debates is an indispensable method for developing wisdom realizing emptiness. If we spend a long time on each debate, thinking about its significance and its application with strong concentration we will gradually clear away the wrong views that obstruct the path to inner peace and develop a lucid wisdom cognizing the ultimate nature of reality. It is especially important to dwell at length on the interchange between the Chittamatrins and the Madhyamika-Prasangikas and to try to understand how these two apparently opposing views can be united. Many great Yogis, including Je Tsongkhapa, Gyalwa Ensapa and Khedrub Sangye Yeshe, have praised as pre-eminent the union of these two views.

Although the debates appear to be disputes between formal schools of thought we should understand that they are presented in this way only to help us to clarify our thoughts. The various participants often perform the function of anticipating doubts or misunderstandings that may arise in our own minds. If we contemplate deeply the replies given by the Madhyamika-Prasangikas we will gradually dispel such doubts and misunderstandings. As Chandrakirti himself says, these debates are not presented merely for the sake of argument or to discredit others; their purpose is only to reveal emptiness to help us attain liberation from samsara.

The sixth ground will now be introduced under the following three headings:

1 How the sixth ground is attained

2 Definition of the sixth ground

3 Divisions of the sixth ground

HOW THE SIXTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the fifth ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to middling-middling innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the fifth ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned middling-middling innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the sixth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE SIXTH GROUND

The definition of the sixth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned middling-middling innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of wisdom from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE SIXTH GROUND

The sixth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the sixth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the sixth ground and the exalted awareness of the sixth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the sixth ground, the uninterrupted path of the sixth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the sixth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the sixth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to small-middling innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

EXPLANATION OF THE SIXTH GROUND

The sixth ground will now be explained extensively under the following four headings:

1 The etymology of this ground and the surpassing perfection of wisdom

2 A praise of the perfection of wisdom

3 An explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising

4 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

THE ETYMOLOGY OF THIS GROUND AND THE SURPASSING PERFECTION OF WISDOM

[VI.1] Abiding in a mind of meditative equipoise on Approaching

He approaches the state of complete Buddhahood.

He sees the thatness of dependent arising

And through abiding in wisdom attains cessation.

Through the force of the powerful concentration attained on the fifth ground the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground is always happy to meditate on emptiness and his or her mind abides in a very special meditative equipoise. Through the great skill in the four truths he attained on the fifth ground he attains a surpassing practice of the perfection of wisdom. He can now see profound emptiness extremely clearly. With this special concentration and wisdom he quickly approaches the state of complete Buddhahood. For this reason the sixth ground is called ‘Approaching’. In the scriptures emptiness is often called ‘thatness’ because it is the ultimate nature of phenomena.

Because the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground possesses a special wisdom he attains an extraordinary absorption of cessation. The definition of absorption of cessation is an uncontaminated wisdom focused single-pointedly on emptiness in dependence on the actual absorption of peak of samsara. Some Hinayana Superiors attain an uncontaminated mind focused single-pointedly on emptiness before completing all eight actual absorptions but that is not an absorption of cessation.

It is important to distinguish the absorption of cessation from the concentration of perfect liberation of cessation and the absorption without discrimination. All three are similar in that they are concentrations attained through stopping gross feelings and gross discriminations, but they are quite different from the point of view of their bases. The absorption of cessation can be attained only by Superior beings, the concentration of perfect liberation of cessation can be attained by ordinary beings who have entered the path to liberation and the absorption without discrimination can be attained by anyone who has accomplished the actual absorption of the fourth mental stabilization of the form realm, even if they have not entered the path to liberation. Bodhisattvas on the great stage of the path of accumulation have attained all the form and formless realm absorptions and also the concentration of perfect liberation of cessation but they have not attained the absorption of cessation. Because both the concentration of perfect liberation of cessation and the absorption of cessation are motivated by renunciation or bodhichitta they are causes of liberation or enlightenment. The absorption without discrimination, however, is motivated by ignorance and is a cause of samsaric rebirth.

The absorption without discrimination is a concentration of the fourth form realm that observes nothingness and that is attained by stopping gross feelings and gross discriminations. As mentioned before, there are eight levels of the fourth form realm, three inhabited by ordinary beings and five by Hinayana Superiors. In the highest of the three levels of ordinary beings, Great Result, there is a land called ‘Land Without Discrimination’. The gods who inhabit this land are called ‘long-life gods’. In their entire life they have only two gross minds – one at the very beginning and one just before they die. For the rest of the time they are absorbed in nothingness with no mental activity whatsoever. They remain in this state for many aeons – for as long as their karma for this rebirth is not exhausted – but when they emerge from it the moment before they die they feel as if they had entered the absorption only a moment before. The lower Buddhist Vaibhashika school believe that between birth and death these gods have no mind. According to the higher schools, however, this is impossible. What happens is that their gross minds cease by dissolving into their subtle mind. The main cause of rebirth as a long-life god is the absorption without discrimination.

Sometimes to pacify a disturbed mind it may be beneficial to practise a facsimile of absorption without discrimination by letting our mind go blank without any manifest thoughts or feelings. This is the meditation taught by the Chinese monk Hashang. As we will see later, he wrongly claimed that this was the meditation on emptiness taught by Buddha. Since it is very relaxing to disengage the mind in this way many people are fooled into believing that this meditation is a path to liberation, but in reality it is a cause of rebirth in samsara. If we practise the absorption without discrimination on the basis of the actual absorption of the fourth mental stabilization of the form realm it leads to rebirth as a long-life god, and if we practise it with a desire realm mind it leads to rebirth as a spirit.

Although the absorption of cessation is also a concentration attained through the cessation of gross feelings and gross discriminations its actual object is ultimate truth, emptiness. Here, ‘cessation’ refers to a cessation of dualistic appearance and ‘absorption’ to a state in which, through the force of concentration, all the elements in the body are perfectly balanced, comfortable and healthy.

To enter the absorption of cessation the Yogi or Yogini must prevent gross minds by withdrawing gross feelings and gross discriminations. For a Superior being with a desire realm body, this means preventing the five sense consciousnesses and the gross mental consciousness. For a form realm being, it means preventing the eye consciousness, ear consciousness, body consciousness and gross mental consciousness. Because form realm beings have bodies made of light and do not eat food, they have no need of a tongue sense power or a nose sense power. For formless realm beings to enter the absorption of cessation they need to prevent only the gross mental consciousness.

Initially, the absorption of cessation can be entered only from the actual absorption of peak of samsara but with training Superior Bodhisattvas develop the ability to enter it instantaneously from any level of mind. To train in this absorption in one session they begin by meditating on the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization of the form realm, then enter the absorption of cessation, then the actual absorption of the second mental stabilization, then the absorption of cessation and so on up to the actual absorption of peak of samsara. From there they enter the absorption of cessation once again and emerge with a desire realm mind. Thus, from the subtlest level of mind, the absorption of cessation, they immediately manifest the grossest level, the mind of the desire realm. This indicates that they have very powerful concentration. With the desire realm mind they relax for a while and then they begin the sequence over again, moving between the eight actual absorptions and the absorption of cessation and finally relaxing again with the desire realm mind. For the Superior Bodhisattva engaged in this training the eight actual absorptions and the absorption of cessation are all wisdoms of meditative equipoise mixed non-dualistically with emptiness. Buddha called this training the ‘concentration of a lion circling’. It is one of the principal practices of a Superior Bodhisattva. Through this practice, he or she completes the training in meditative stabilization and eventually attains the ability of a Buddha to engage in meditative equipoise on emptiness and the activities of subsequent attainment simultaneously. Only Buddhas can remain single-pointedly absorbed in emptiness while giving teachings and guiding living beings along the spiritual path.

Question Bodhisattvas on the first five grounds also attain the absorption of cessation, so why is it given as a good quality of the sixth ground?

Answer The reason is that the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground attains an extraordinary absorption of cessation as a result of completing the three trainings in higher wisdom – great skill in knowledge of the four noble truths, great skill in knowledge of the serial and reverse orders of the twelve dependent-related links and great skill in knowledge of emptiness. Thus it is said that the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground attains a surpassing practice of the perfection of wisdom.

The definition of perfection of wisdom is a wisdom maintained by bodhichitta that realizes the ultimate nature of phenomena. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of wisdom and the transcendent perfection of wisdom.

A PRAISE OF THE PERFECTION OF WISDOM

[VI.2] Just as one person with sight can easily lead

A whole group of blind people to where they want to go,

Similarly, here, wisdom takes those qualities that lack sight

And goes to the state of a Conqueror.

Chandrakirti praises the perfection of wisdom by showing how it leads all the other perfections to the resultant grounds of Buddhahood. Just as one person with sight can easily lead an entire group of blind people to where they want to go, so the perfection of wisdom takes all the other perfections such as giving that lack the view of emptiness to the final destination of Buddhahood.

Because our mind is covered by the two obstructions, which prevent us from attaining enlightenment, we are like a blind person. The perfection of wisdom is like a guide. It alone has the power to lead us to the city of enlightenment by removing the two obstructions. Even if we accomplish all the other perfections, such as giving, moral discipline and patience we will never attain enlightenment without the perfection of wisdom.

In The Three Principal Aspects of the Path Je Tsongkhapa says:

But, even though you may be acquainted with renunciation and bodhichitta,

If you do not possess the wisdom realizing the way things really are,

You will not be able to cut the root of samsara,

Therefore strive in the means for realizing dependent relationship.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE PROFOUND THATNESS OF DEPENDENT ARISING

This section explains in great detail the emptiness realized by the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground. It is presented in five parts:

1 A promise to explain the profound meaning

2 Recognizing a suitable recipient for an explanation of the profound meaning

3 How good qualities arise when it is explained to such a person

4 Exhorting those who are suitable recipients to listen

5 The actual explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising

A PROMISE TO EXPLAIN THE PROFOUND MEANING

[VI.3] I will explain the very profound Dharma

According to the works of Superior Nagarjuna

Where it is presented through scripture and reasoning

Just as he realizes it.

The preceding chapters of the Guide present the stages of the vast path principally according to Nagarjuna’s Precious Garland. Now the sixth chapter presents the stages of the profound path according to Nagarjuna’s Fundamental Wisdom. Thus the sixth chapter is the main body of the Guide and the other chapters are the limbs that support it.

It is customary for an author to compose a promise to explain in which he indicates what the subject matter of the book will be and what his reasons are for composing it. This promise is usually placed at the beginning of the book, but in this case Chandrakirti includes it at the beginning of the sixth chapter. He does so to indicate that his principal intention in composing the Guide is to reveal the profound meaning of emptiness. He says that he will explain the very profound Dharma of emptiness according to the works of Superior Nagarjuna, where it is presented in dependence on numerous scriptural citations and extensive logical reasoning in just the same way as it is realized by the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground.

Since the Guide explains Buddha’s final view of emptiness in accordance with the works of Nagarjuna it is important to develop faith in Nagarjuna and be convinced of the authenticity of his works. All the great Masters of the Madhyamika-Prasangika and Madhyamika-Svatantrika schools revere Nagarjuna as a valid author and meditation Master.

Nagarjuna’s life and works were prophesied several times by Buddha. In a well-known passage in Gone to Lanka Sutra Buddha is asked who will uphold the doctrine after he has passed away. Buddha replies:

In the Southern region, in the Land of the Palms,

The monk Shriman of great renown,

Known by the name, ‘Naga’,

Will refute the extremes of existence and non-existence.

Having proclaimed to the world my teachings,

The unsurpassed Great Vehicle,

He will accomplish the ground Very Joyful,

And depart to the Land of Bliss.

As predicted, four hundred years after Buddha passed away, a son was born to a prosperous Brahmin family living in an area of Southern India known as Bedarwa, or the ‘Land of the Palms’. An oracle predicted that the child would live for only seven days, but that his lifespan could be extended by a further seven days if gifts were bestowed on a hundred ordinary people, by a further seven months if offerings were made to a hundred brahmins, or by a further seven years if offerings were made to a hundred monks. However, the oracle knew of no method to extend his life beyond that. Accordingly, his parents made offerings to a hundred monks, and as a result were able to live happily with their son for seven years.

As the child’s seventh birthday drew near, however, they sent him on a pilgrimage with several of their servants, for they could not bear to witness his death. Guided by a manifestation of Avalokiteshvara, the party made its way to Nalanda Monastery where they met the great Teacher Saraha. They explained the boy’s plight to Saraha and he told them that the child could avert an untimely death by staying at Nalanda and taking ordination as a monk. He gave the child an empowerment into the long-life practice of Buddha Amitayus and encouraged him to practise that yoga extensively.

On the eve of his seventh birthday the child recited the mantra of Amitayus without interruption and as a result averted an untimely death. The following day he ordained as a monk and was given the name ‘Shrimanta’. He remained at Nalanda where under the protection of Manjushri he was able to study all the Sutras and Tantras. He soon became a fully-accomplished scholar and Teacher and his reputation spread widely. Eventually he was appointed Abbot of Nalanda.

Nagarjuna’s life comprised three great periods of auspicious deeds that correspond to Buddha’s three turnings of the Wheel of Dharma, which is why he is often referred to as ‘the Second Buddha’. The first period was during his tenure as Abbot of Nalanda. Unfortunately, the moral discipline of the monks had degenerated since the time Buddha first gave the vows and Nagarjuna was very active in restoring the purity of the discipline. He clarified many points of moral discipline in extensive teachings and composed a number of works on pure conduct. These writings, known as the Collection of Advice, include such works as Precious Garland, Friendly Letter, Tree of Wisdom, A Hundred Wisdoms and Drops for Healing Beings. These activities are likened to Buddha’s first turning of the Wheel of Dharma.

Nagarjuna is best remembered, however, for the works of the second period. Not long after Buddha passed away, the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras, the principal Mahayana teachings, disappeared from this world. It is said that this is because some nagas who had received this teaching from Buddha had taken the Perfection of Wisdom scriptures to their own world for safekeeping. There remained only a few practitioners who could understand these teachings and most of them kept their practice secret. The only teachings of Buddha to remain widespread were the Hinayana teachings and as a result many people assumed that these were the only teachings Buddha had given. Some time later the nagas invited Nagarjuna to visit them, and returned the Perfection of Wisdom scriptures to him. Nagarjuna brought the scriptures to the human world and propagated them widely. Because of his special relationship with the nagas and because he cured many nagas of sickness by means of special ritual prayers, Nagarjuna was given the name ‘Protector of the nagas’. ‘Arjuna’ was added to his name because he spread the Mahayana teachings with great speed and accuracy just as the legendary archer Arjuna had delivered arrows from his bow. Hence he finally became known as ‘Protector Nagarjuna’.

Because he had a very lucid mind and great wisdom, Nagarjuna was able perfectly to understand the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and explain them to others. He spread these teachings widely, thus instigating a great revival of the Mahayana doctrine in this world. He presented a system of reasoning which, because it steers a flawless course between the two extremes of existence and non-existence, became known as the ‘Philosophy of the Middle Way’, or ‘Madhyamaka’. Nagarjuna composed many commentaries to the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras that elucidate the Madhyamaka view. These treatises, known as the Collection of Reasonings, include the famous Fundamental Wisdom of the Middle Way and its four limbs – Sixty Reasonings, Seventy Emptinesses, Finely Woven and Refutation of Objections. He also wrote Compendium of Sutras, Five Stages of the Completion Stage of Guhyasamaja and many other commentaries to the Sutras and Tantras. These activities are likened to Buddha’s second turning of the Wheel of Dharma.

Nagarjuna’s third period of auspicious deeds took place towards the end of his life. Acting on advice from Tara, he returned to Southern India and dwelt at a place called Mount Splendour where he gave further extensive teachings on both the Sutras and Tantras and composed many more texts. These writings, known as the Collection of Praises, include such works as Praise of the Dharmadhatu, Praise of the Supramundane, Praise of the Inconceivable and Praise of the Ultimate. These activities are likened to Buddha’s third turning of the Wheel of Dharma.

It is not possible in such a brief account even to begin to do justice to Nagarjuna’s life and works. Throughout his life he devoted himself entirely to reviving the Mahayana Dharma and to sustaining the Mahayana Sangha. To this end he gave prolific teachings, composed many books and performed countless other excellent deeds. As mentioned in Gone to Lanka Sutra, Nagarjuna had accomplished the realization of the Bodhisattva’s first ground, called ‘Very Joyful’. He then advanced further and finally reached the land of the supreme bliss of enlightenment.

RECOGNIZING A SUITABLE RECIPIENT FOR AN EXPLANATION OF THE PROFOUND MEANING

[VI.4] Even while an ordinary being, if on hearing of emptiness

Great joy arises within again and again,

The eyes moisten with tears of great joy

And the hairs of the body stand on end,

[VI.5abc] Such a person has the seed of the mind of a complete Buddha.

He is a vessel for teachings on thatness

And ultimate truth should be taught to him.

If those who are unsuitable recipients listen to teachings on emptiness there is a danger they might misunderstand and fall into the extreme of non-existence. Indeed, Nagarjuna himself says that if emptiness is taught to those with little wisdom and they find fault with the teaching they will experience suffering as a result. The following story illustrates the dangers of teaching emptiness to those who are not ready. In ancient times there was a great meditator called Elephant Skin, who was so called because he used to meditate in a tent made from the skin of a dead elephant. Through the force of his renunciation he meditated continuously on emptiness until he completely eradicated all his delusions and became a Foe Destroyer. His fame quickly spread and finally reached the king of that region. The king visited the Yogi and requested teachings so that he too might acquire such fame. Elephant Skin explained to the king how all phenomena are empty of true existence. The king, however, did not have the wisdom to understand this teaching and took Elephant Skin to be saying that phenomena do not exist at all. Outraged that such perverse views were being spread in his kingdom, the king ordered Elephant Skin to be put to death. Some years later the king met another Teacher who carefully explained to him all the stages of the path, from the preciousness of our human life through to the faults of samsara. He then gradually introduced the king to the subtle view that all phenomena lack true existence. This time the king understood and was struck with great remorse when he realized that his first Teacher had in fact given him authentic teachings.

Chandrakirti describes the kind of person who is best suited to receive an explanation of emptiness. He says that even though the person may be a beginner, if on hearing teachings on emptiness they repeatedly develop a feeling of great joy, their eyes moisten with tears of great joy and the hairs of their body stand on end, these are internal and external signs that for that person the potentiality to realize emptiness is about to ripen. Such a person is an ideal vessel to receive teachings on profound thatness. In general, all living beings have the potential to realize emptiness because they all have the seed of Buddhahood but it is only when this seed becomes active and powerful that they become ideal recipients for teachings on emptiness.

Je Tsongkhapa says that even though we might not yet be the ideal recipient that Chandrakirti describes here, if we nevertheless have a good motivation and great faith it is beneficial for us to listen to teachings on emptiness and it is appropriate for Teachers to give instructions. Listening to such teachings creates a great stock of merit and sows the seed for us to understand emptiness in the future. However, the Teacher must be very skilful in the way he or she explains emptiness.

In Compendium of Sutras Nagarjuna says that if we have a pleasing mind towards profound Dharma we will collect a great store of merit, gradually acquire all the mundane and supramundane qualities and eventually attain enlightenment. In Sutra Given by the Infant Rahadatta Buddha says that if those who listen to the profound Dharma of emptiness with doubts receive a great amount of merit, what need is there to mention those who listen without doubts? Buddha also makes a similar point in Vajra Cutting Sutra.

HOW GOOD QUALITIES ARISE WHEN IT IS EXPLAINED TO SUCH A PERSON

[VI.5d] After that, good qualities will grow in him.

[VI.6] He will take up and always maintain pure moral discipline,

Practise giving, rely on compassion,

Become acquainted with patience,

Fully dedicate all his virtues to enlightenment to liberate living beings

[VI.7a] And have respect for perfect Bodhisattvas.

When a suitable recipient receives teachings on emptiness he or she will develop an unmistaken view of emptiness and as a result develop many special qualities. He will treasure the view of emptiness as his most precious possession and will see that if he takes rebirth in the lower realms in his next life he will lose this precious view. To prevent this happening he will take vows and always maintain pure moral discipline. Seeing that even if he takes a human rebirth in his next life he will not be able to continue his practice if he is hindered by poverty or lack of basic resources, he will practise giving extensively. Seeing that his practice of emptiness will be a cause of Buddhahood only if it is conjoined with great compassion, he will always rely on meditation on compassion and bodhichitta. Seeing that anger destroys virtues and leads to rebirth in the lower realms and separation from holy beings, he will always practise patience. Seeing that to complete the path to Buddhahood he must train in all the perfections, he will also practise effort and concentration. Moreover, he will fully dedicate all his virtues to the attainment of full enlightenment so that he can liberate all living beings from samsara. Having found the correct view of emptiness he will always maintain great respect for the Teachers from whom he received these precious teachings as well as for all other objects of refuge.

EXHORTING THOSE WHO ARE SUITABLE RECIPIENTS TO LISTEN

[VI.7bcd] Since beings who are skilled in the ways of the profound and the vast

Gradually attain the ground Very Joyful

Those who seek that should listen to this path.

If we become skilled in the stages of the profound path of emptiness and combine them with the stages of the vast path of the Mahayana we will gradually attain the first ground, Very Joyful, and then all the other grounds until we eventually attain full enlightenment. Therefore, we should study carefully the following instructions on profound emptiness.

Identifying the Object of Negation

THE ACTUAL EXPLANATION OF THE PROFOUND THATNESS OF DEPENDENT ARISING

This section has four parts:

1 How the correct meaning is revealed in the scriptures

2 Identifying the object of negation

3 Establishing the meaning of the scriptures by reasoning

4 An explanation of the divisions of emptiness

HOW THE CORRECT MEANING IS REVEALED IN THE SCRIPTURES

The principal scriptures that reveal Buddha’s ultimate view, the correct meaning of emptiness, are the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. These include the Perfection of Wisdom in a Hundred Thousand Lines, the Perfection of Wisdom in Twenty-five Thousand Lines, the Perfection of Wisdom in Eight Thousand Lines, the Condensed Perfection of Wisdom Sutra and the Essence of Wisdom Sutra, more commonly known as the Heart Sutra.

When Chandrakirti introduces the sixth chapter in his Autocommentary, to show how the correct meaning of emptiness is revealed in the scriptures he quotes from Sutra on the Ten Grounds where Buddha explains how a Bodhisattva advances from the fifth to the sixth ground by realizing the ten equalities of phenomena:

(1) The equality of all conventional phenomena in lacking signs

(2) The equality of all phenomena in lacking characteristics

(3) The equality of all future things in lacking production

(4) The equality of all phenomena in non-production

(5) The equality of all phenomena in separation

(6) The equality of all phenomena in complete purity from the beginning

(7) The equality of all phenomena in lacking elaboration

(8) The equality of all phenomena in lacking acceptance and rejection

(9) The equality of all phenomena in resembling illusions, dreams, shadows, echoes, the moon in water, reflections and emanations

(10) The equality of all phenomena in lacking being thing and non-thing

Each of these ten equalities is mere emptiness, lack of inherent existence. If we understand these we understand the meaning that is the object of meditation of the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground. Their principal meaning can be understood as follows. Buddha’s ultimate view, the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena, is very subtle and profound, and among Buddha’s countless followers only the Madhyamika-Prasangikas understand it correctly. Proponents of other Buddhist tenets such as the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas and the Chittamatrins assert that all phenomena are inherently existent. Why do they assert this? They argue that we know that phenomena have distinct signs such as colour, shape and function, and distinct characteristics such as good, bad and neutral qualities. Moreover, we can know past, present and future things, we can know that some things are already produced whereas others are yet to be produced and we can know that some phenomena are things and others are non-things. How could all these different signs and characteristics exist if phenomena were not inherently existent, if they did not exist from their own side?

The Madhyamika-Prasangikas reply that even though conventionally phenomena have their own uncommon signs by which they are identified, these signs and the phenomena that possess them are all equally empty of inherent existence because none of these conventional phenomena exists with respect to the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. All that appears to the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being is ultimate truth, emptiness. Thus, in Heart Sutra Buddha says:

Therefore, Shariputra, in emptiness there is no form, no feeling, no discrimination, no compositional factors, no consciousness. There is no eye, no ear, no nose, no tongue, no body, no mentality; no form, no sound, no smell, no taste, no tactile object, no phenomenon. There is no eye element and so forth up to no mentality element and also up to no element of mental consciousness. There is no ignorance and no exhaustion of ignorance and so forth up to no ageing and death and no exhaustion of ageing and death. Likewise there is no suffering, origin, cessation or path; no exalted awareness, no attainment, and also no non-attainment.

From this we can understand the meaning of the first equality, the equality of all conventional phenomena in lacking signs. In just the same way even though all phenomena have their own characteristics, even though some are not yet produced and some are already produced, even though some are to be accepted and others are to be rejected and even though some are things and some are non-things, all these phenomena are equally empty of inherent existence. They are mere elaborations – imputations of conceptual thought that do not appear to the wisdom of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. They have been separate from inherent existence from the very beginning and even though they can appear clearly to the mind they completely lack true existence like illusions, dreams, shadows, echoes, the moon in water, reflections and emanations. We should try to understand the ten equalities in this way.

IDENTIFYING THE OBJECT OF NEGATION

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, emptiness is lack of inherent existence, and therefore to realize emptiness we must negate inherent existence. Inherent existence is the object of negation and its non-existence is emptiness. In the sixth chapter of the Guide Chandrakirti presents many reasons proving the non-existence of inherently existent phenomena, but trying to apply this reasoning without first identifying the object of negation would be like firing a gun without knowing the target. The full impact of meditation on emptiness is achieved only when we clearly identify how inherently existent phenomena appear to our minds and then realize that there are no inherently existent phenomena. Thus, in Guide to the Bodhisattva’s Way of Life Shantideva says:

Without first correctly identifying the object to be negated, true existence,

You cannot apprehend its negation, or non-existence, emptiness.

His meaning is that without first identifying the object to be negated – inherently existent phenomena that are projected by the mind – we will not be able to apprehend their non-existence, emptiness.

To identify the object of negation of emptiness is to attain a clear mental image of inherently existent phenomena. We may think that it is impossible to have a mental image of a non-existent but if we close our eyes and picture a rabbit with a horn on its head we will see that it is perfectly possible. Indeed, it is only when we have a clear mental image of a horned rabbit that we can be certain such creatures do not exist. It is the same with realizing emptiness. We can know with certainty the non-existence of inherently existent phenomena only when we have a clear mental image of how inherently existent phenomena would be if they did exist.

The object of negation explained by the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, inherent existence, is very subtle and difficult to identify, and the emptiness that is its non-existence is very subtle and difficult to realize. Therefore, as a first step, Buddha taught the less subtle view of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school. The object of negation taught by this school is easier to identify and the emptiness that is its non-existence is easier to realize. Contemplating the view of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school helps us to understand the more subtle view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school.

In describing the object of negation and emptiness both schools use similar terminology. For example, they both refer to the object of negation as ‘true existence’, and to emptiness as ‘lack of true existence’, but they each mean something different by these terms. For the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas something would be truly existent if it existed wholly independent of conceptual thought, whereas for the Madhyamika-Prasangikas something would be truly existent if it existed in any way independent of conceptual thought. Because they give different explanations of true existence, the object of negation, they also give different explanations of emptiness, the non-existence of the object of negation. The difference between these two explanations will now be explained under the following two headings:

1 Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school

2 Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school

IDENTIFYING THE OBJECT OF NEGATION ACCORDING TO THE MADHYAMIKA-SVATANTRIKA SCHOOL

This section has three parts:

1 Identifying true existence and true-grasping

2 Explaining true and false with reference to worldly people by means of an analogy

3 Applying this analogy to the meaning

IDENTIFYING TRUE EXISTENCE AND TRUE-GRASPING

Many of the great masters of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school composed commentaries to Nagarjuna’s Fundamental Wisdom interpreting it from the point of view of Madhyamika-Svatantrika tenets. The most well-known of these commentaries are Lamp for Wisdom by Bhavaviveka, Discrimination of the Two Truths by Gyanagarbha, Ornament for the Middle Way by Shantirakshita, and Illumination of the Middle Way by Kamalashila. The following presentation of the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school is derived from the last of these.

According to the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas, existing in dependence on appearing to mind, existing nominally, and existing conventionally are synonyms. All phenomena exist in dependence on appearing to mind, all phenomena exist nominally and all phenomena exist conventionally. Being conceived by mind and being imputed by mind are also synonyms. All phenomena are conceived by mind and all phenomena are imputed by mind. Moreover, all phenomena exist in dependence on being conceived by mind, and all phenomena exist in dependence on being imputed by mind.

If something existed without being conceived by mind it would be truly existent. No phenomenon is truly existent. True existence is the object of negation of emptiness and lack of true existence is emptiness. Any mind that apprehends true existence is a true-grasping mind. This is the criterion of true existence and true-grasping according to the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school.

The Madhyamika-Svatantrikas do not assert that phenomena are merely imputed by mind. They say that even though phenomena exist in dependence on being imputed by mind they also exist from their own side and therefore are inherently existent. If phenomena did not exist from their own side at all, if they were mere imputations of mind, they would not exist. Therefore, phenomena do not exist entirely from their own side, but they also do not exist entirely from the side of the mind.

In so far as the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert that phenomena do not exist entirely from their own side their view is much more subtle than the views of the lower schools, but in so far as they assert that phenomena exist from their own side their view is not as subtle as the view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school. According to the Madhyamika-Prasangikas, phenomena are merely imputed by conceptual thought and do not exist from their own side in the least. Compared with this view, the view of the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school is gross.

EXPLAINING TRUE AND FALSE WITH REFERENCE TO WORLDLY PEOPLE BY MEANS OF AN ANALOGY

The Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert that emptiness is ultimate truth and that all other phenomena are conventional truths. This means that emptiness alone is a true object and all other phenomena are false objects. Thus they would say that this book, which is a conventional truth, is a false object whereas its emptiness, which is an ultimate truth, is a true object. In saying that the book is a false object they do not mean that it is not a book or that it does not exist. They explain what they mean by true and false by referring to the way these terms are used by ordinary people, and to help us understand this they use the analogy of a magician’s horse.

In ancient times magicians could conjure up appearances such as animals or people by blowing mantras on a substance and then applying that substance to an object such as a stone or a tree. We can imagine a situation in which one such magician has conjured up the appearance of a horse. In the case of an ordinary member of the audience who is taken in by the spell the horse appears to be real and he conceives it to be a real horse. In the case of the magician himself a horse also appears to his mind but he is not taken in by the spell and so he does not conceive it to be a real horse. In the case of a member of the audience with great wisdom whose mind is not affected by the spell there is no appearance of a horse to his mind and he does not conceive there to be a real horse.

These three people – the ordinary member of the audience, the magician and the wise member of the audience whose mind is not affected by the spell – are analogous to living beings who have not realized emptiness, living beings who have realized emptiness and Buddhas respectively. In the case of a living being who has not realized emptiness this book, for example, will appear as truly existent and he or she will assent to that appearance by conceiving it to be truly existent. In the case of a living being who has realized emptiness, because he has not yet abandoned obstructions to omniscience this book will still appear to his mind as truly existent, but because he has realized emptiness he will not believe that appearance and he will not conceive the book to be truly existent. This is rather like someone watching a film about mountains who, although there appears to be a mountain in the room, does not think that there actually is a mountain in the room. In the case of a Buddha, who has attained a direct realization of lack of true existence and abandoned obstructions to omniscience there is no appearance of a truly existent book, and he or she does not conceive there to be a truly existent book.

When an ordinary being looks at a book, both the book and a truly existent book appear to his or her mind. In reality there is no truly existent book so the way the book appears does not correspond to the way it exists. This lack of correspondence between the way it appears and the way it exists indicates that the book is a deceptive object, a false object. It is perfectly normal to say that something is false if it appears in one way and exists in another; indeed this is precisely the criterion of falsity used by ordinary people. For example, ordinary people would accept that a reflection of a face is deceptive, or false, because there appears to be a face where no face exists. Similarly, they would say that a theory is false if it does not correspond to the facts. By using this criterion of falsity we can see how all phenomena other than emptiness are false objects because they all appear to be truly existent when they are not.

Emptiness, on the other hand, is a true object because the way it appears corresponds to the way it exists. When emptiness appears directly to the mind only lack of true existence is perceived. Whereas a book, for example, appears to a non-conceptual direct perceiver mixed with the appearance of a truly existent book, emptiness appears to a non-conceptual direct perceiver without the appearance of true existence. What appears is only emptiness, or lack of true existence, and what exists is only emptiness, or lack of true existence. Since the way it appears to a non-conceptual direct perceiver corresponds to the way it exists, emptiness is a true object.

Again, it is perfectly normal to say that something is true if the way it appears corresponds to the way it exists, and this is precisely the criterion of truth used by ordinary people. For example, ordinary people say that a person is being true if he presents himself as he is. However, it is important to realize that such a person is true only with respect to the minds of worldly people who have not realized emptiness. In reality, that person is not true because he appears to be truly existent when he is not. Worldly people do not realize that the appearance of a truly existent person is a mistaken appearance, which is why they say that the person appears the way he is. However, Superior beings who have a direct realization of emptiness realize that the appearance of a truly existent person is a mistaken appearance because it does not correspond to the way he exists.

Thus, what is true for worldly beings is false for Superior beings. Who is correct, worldly beings or Superior beings? Superior beings are correct because they possess uncontaminated minds. Only the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of Superior beings directly realizing emptiness is an uncontaminated mind free from pollution by true-grasping and its imprints. The direct perceivers of ordinary beings, on the other hand, are contaminated minds polluted by true-grasping and its imprints.

Another reason why conventional phenomena are false objects is that they appear to be different natures from their parts when in reality they are not. All phenomena have parts because whatever is a phenomenon is either a thing or a non-thing and all things have parts and all non-things have parts. Whatever is a thing is either a form or a formless thing and all forms have parts and all formless things have parts. All forms have parts because they are composed of particles. Some Vaibhashika and Sautrantika schools assert that the tiniest particles do not have parts because they are physically indivisible, but according to the Madhyamika school they have directional parts and so are mentally divisible. If even the smallest forms have parts it follows that all gross forms that are composed of them also have parts.

Similarly, all formless things have parts. For example, mind is a thing because it is an impermanent phenomenon produced from causes and conditions, and it is formless because it always lacks form. All minds have temporal parts because they have former and later moments. They also have parts from the point of view of how they apprehend their objects. An eye consciousness apprehending the colours of a mosaic, for example, has many parts because it has one part apprehending blue, one part apprehending green and so on.

Non-things are permanent phenomena that are uncaused such as unproduced space and emptiness. Unproduced space has parts because there is the space inside a house, the space outside a house and so on. Emptiness has parts because there is the emptiness of a book, the emptiness of a chair and so on. By extension we can understand how all other non-things have parts.

All phenomena are the same nature as their parts. For example, a car has many parts but it is not a different nature from those parts. If it were, it would be possible to destroy all the parts of the car without destroying the car, but this is not possible. However, when we think of a car we perceive a vividly appearing car that is a different nature from its parts. Since the way the car appears does not correspond to the way it exists the car is a false object. In this way we can understand how all conventional phenomena are false objects.

APPLYING THIS ANALOGY TO THE MEANING

In the analogy given above, the eye consciousness of the ordinary member of the audience is contaminated by the magician’s spell. As a result, he sees a horse that appears to be real and, assenting to that appearance, conceives it to be a real horse. This is analogous to ordinary living beings who have not realized emptiness. All their minds are contaminated by the ignorance of true-grasping and as a result phenomena appear to their minds to be truly existent and they conceive them to be truly existent. Just as the ordinary member of the magician’s audience believes what he sees to be true, so living beings who have not realized emptiness grasp at the truly existent phenomena that appear to their minds as true. Even after living beings have realized emptiness they still have obstructions to omniscience, which cause phenomena to appear to be truly existent. However, through the force of their realization of emptiness they do not assent to this appearance and so do not conceive phenomena to be truly existent. They become like the magician to whom a horse appears as if it were a real horse but who, because he is not taken in by the spell, does not assent to that appearance and does not conceive it to be a real horse.

When living beings realize emptiness directly and their minds mix with emptiness in meditative equipoise, all dualistic appearance subsides into emptiness and only emptiness appears to their mind. While they are in meditative equipoise they become like the wise member of the audience to whom no horse appears and who does not conceive there to be a real horse. However, for as long as they remain living beings they have not abandoned obstructions to omniscience and so when they rise from meditative equipoise phenomena again appear to them as truly existent. In other words, when they rise from meditation they become like the magician again. When they finally abandon obstructions to omniscience and attain Buddhahood, both the appearance of true existence and the conception of true existence cease completely and they remain for all time like the wise member of the audience.

The analogy of the magician’s spell was introduced by the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas because such magicians were commonplace in India at the time. However this is not the only analogy we can use. There are many other analogies that illustrate how phenomena appear to be truly existent when they are not such as mistaking a pleasant encounter in a dream for a real encounter, mistaking a monster in a film for a real monster, mistaking a pile of stones in the distance for a person, or mistaking a mark on the wall for a spider. The scriptures also use analogies such as mirages, emanations, echoes and reflections.

IDENTIFYING THE OBJECT OF NEGATION ACCORDING TO THE MADHYAMIKA-PRASANGIKA SCHOOL

As we have seen, the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas say that all phenomena lack true existence because they do not exist entirely from their own side, but they do not lack inherent existence because they do exist from their own side to some extent. The Madhyamika-Prasangikas disagree. They say that all phenomena without exception are merely imputed by thought and do not exist from their own side in the least. They say that if there were any sense in which phenomena existed from their own side they would be truly existent. In other words, if something were inherently existent it would be truly existent. No phenomenon is inherently existent. The object of negation of emptiness, therefore, is inherent existence, or existence from its own side. Any mind that apprehends inherently existent phenomena is a true-grasping mind and a wrong awareness.

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangikas, therefore, to realize emptiness we must realize the non-existence of inherent existence, and to do this we must know what inherently existent phenomena would be like if they did exist. To identify this subtle object of negation, inherent existence, we first need to understand how all phenomena are merely imputed by conceptual thought. There are three ways in which we can understand this, which will now be explained under the following three headings:

1 Understanding mere imputation by means of scriptures

2 Understanding mere imputation by means of analogies

3 Understanding mere imputation by means of reasoning

UNDERSTANDING MERE IMPUTATION BY MEANS OF SCRIPTURES

There are many scriptures that explain how all phenomena are merely imputed by thought. For example, in Sutra Requested by Upali Buddha says:

There is nothing that is the creator

Of the various attractive flowers that bloom,

Or the beautiful, glistening, supreme golden houses;

For they are all established by the power of conception;

All worlds are imputed by conception.

There is an infinite number of worlds and some, like the worlds of the gods, are very beautiful. In these worlds the houses are made of gold and glistening jewels and they stand in beautiful gardens of exquisite flowers. Other worlds, including parts of the human and animal worlds, are unattractive. Inhabiting all these different worlds is a great variety of living beings. All these worlds and all their inhabitants are merely imputed by thought. They have no creator other than conceptual mind.

Some people believe that this world was created by Brahma, a worldly god inhabiting the first form realm. Brahma’s world evolved before the human world evolved and when the inhabitants of his world saw the human world evolving out of empty space beneath theirs they naturally assumed it was the work of Brahma. Some were subsequently reborn as humans and, because they still had the imprint of this belief, again developed the view that this world was created by Brahma. Some have composed books setting out this belief.

If we examine carefully, however, we will see that there is no creator of the world other than mind. The subtle conventional nature of the world is its being mere imputation by conceptual thought. No matter how much we search, we will never find a world that is independent of conceptual imputation. Therefore the world depends entirely on mind for its existence.

As with all other things, this world came into being in dependence on causes. Had there been no causes there would be no world. The main cause of this world was the collective karma of the beings who inhabit it. Since karma originates in the mind it follows that this world was produced principally by mind. The creation of the world also required secondary, or co-operative, causes, such as the amassing of atomic particles. At one time this universe was just empty space, then one atom appeared and gradually particles amassed to form the universe as we know it. Where did the first atom come from? It can only have been produced by the collective karma of the beings inhabiting this world. There is no valid reason for saying that it was created by Brahma or by any other god. The entire world arose due to karma and karma arises from mind; therefore the actual creator of this world is mind.

UNDERSTANDING MERE IMPUTATION BY MEANS OF ANALOGIES

Chandrakirti, in his commentary to Aryadeva’s Four Hundred and Je Tsongkhapa in Clear Illumination of the Intention use the analogy of an imagined snake to show how all phenomena are merely imputed by thought. A man walking through a field at dusk comes across a coil of speckled rope in the grass and, mistaking it for a snake, develops fear. Even though a snake appears vividly to his mind that snake does not exist from its own side. It is merely a projection of his mind, imputed by conceptual thought in dependence on the rope. Other than this, no snake can be found because neither the coil of rope as a whole nor any part of it is a snake.

In just the same way, all phenomena are merely imputed by conceptual thought. For example, the I does not exist from its own side; it is merely a projection of the mind imputed by conceptual thought in dependence on the aggregates. If we try to find an I other than the mere conceptual imputation ‘I’ we will not succeed because neither the collection of the aggregates nor any individual aggregate is the I. Existing phenomena such as the I differ from the imagined snake in that they are valid imputations, but there is no difference from the point of view of their being merely imputed by conceptual thought.

In the analogy, because the man sees the rope in the twilight he mistakenly apprehends a snake and develops fear. To remove this fear he must remove the mind apprehending a snake by realizing that there is no snake. Even then, if the rope is left in the same place there is a danger that he will make the same mistake in the future. The only way to remove this danger is to remove the rope. Similarly, living beings observing their aggregates in the darkness of their ignorance mistakenly apprehend an inherently existent I. This mind grasping at an inherently existent I is the root of samsara and the source of all fear. To remove the fears of samsara we must remove this mind by realizing that there is no inherently existent I. Even then, there will be a danger of the mind grasping at an inherently existent I recurring if we continue to grasp at inherently existent aggregates. Therefore, the only way to remove the fears of samsara entirely is first to realize the lack of inherent existence of the I and then to realize the lack of inherent existence of the aggregates.

Again, we can use other analogies such as seeing a spider on a wall where there is only a mark, seeing a person in the distance where there is only a pile of stones or generating fear during a movie. By contemplating these analogies we can understand how all phenomena are merely imputed by thought.

UNDERSTANDING MERE IMPUTATION BY MEANS OF REASONING

To begin with, we should try to understand how our own I is merely imputed by conceptual thought. We can do this by relying on the following reasoning. If the I were not merely imputed by conceptual thought it would exist from its own side, and if it existed from its own side it would be found on investigation. However, if we are not satisfied with the mere conceptual imputation ‘I’ and search for an I we will not find one either within the aggregates or separate from the aggregates. Therefore the I does not exist from its own side but is merely imputed by conceptual thought. Once we understand how our own I is merely imputed, we can extend our investigation to other living beings and then to all other phenomena. In this way we will gradually come to see how all phenomena are merely imputed by conceptual thought.

By relying on scriptures, analogies and reasoning we will realize that all phenomena are merely imputed by conceptual thought. In this context the word ‘merely’ excludes any mode of existence other than being imputed by conceptual thought. Phenomena do not exist from their own side in any sense whatsoever. If a phenomenon were not merely imputed by conceptual thought but existed from its own side in any way it would be inherently existent. No phenomenon is inherently existent. Inherent existence is the subtle object of negation of emptiness and its non-existence is emptiness, ultimate truth.

‘Inherent existence’, ‘true existence’ and ‘natural existence’ all mean the same and all are objects of negation. Once we have a clear generic image of the object of negation we should strive to realize its non-existence, emptiness. The method for realizing lack of inherent existence is the reasoning presented in the sixth chapter of the Guide such as the reasoning of vajra fragments and the sevenfold reasoning. When through relying on this reasoning we realize that there are no inherently existent phenomena at all we will have realized emptiness.

Whereas inherent existence, or true existence, is the object of negation, grasping at inherent existence, or true-grasping, is the principal object to be abandoned. This mind is the source of all suffering and the root of samsara. It is important to be clear about what the object to be abandoned is because there are many misunderstandings concerning this. One such misunderstanding that was promoted in Tibet by the Chinese monk Hashang is still current today and is a great obstacle to spiritual development. Hashang was a follower of Buddha but he completely misunderstood Buddha’s teachings on emptiness and spread a dangerous heresy among the Tibetan people. According to Hashang, since truly existent phenomena appear to all conceptual minds, all conceptual minds are objects to be abandoned. He said that just as all dogs hurt when they bite, regardless of whether they are white dogs or black dogs, so all conceptual minds harm us regardless of whether they are virtuous minds or non-virtuous minds. Similarly, just as both white and black clouds obscure the sun, so both virtuous and non-virtuous conceptual minds obscure our mind. The ultimate view of emptiness is attained by preventing all conceptual minds and allowing the mind to go blank. This, Hashang claimed, was the actual meaning of Buddha’s teachings on emptiness.

Before Hashang came to Tibet a very pure Buddhadharma flourished there. Many people correctly identified the middle way and as a result gained profound realizations. However, Hashang’s view quickly spread and as a result many Tibetans found themselves without the means to practise either the profound path or the vast path. By meditating on nothingness instead of emptiness they had forsaken the profound path, and by abandoning all conceptual minds including love, compassion and bodhichitta, they had forsaken the vast path. The path to enlightenment was blocked for them. Even the practice of observing the laws of karma was lost.

Seeing this, King Trisong Detsen, the thirty-seventh king of Tibet, invited Kamalashila from India to debate with Hashang. Kamalashila conclusively defeated Hashang and Hashang was banished from Tibet. King Trisong Detsen then issued a proclamation declaring that from then on all Tibetans were to follow the teachings of Nagarjuna. However, Hashang’s heresy was not completely expunged and even today there are many who advocate this view.

Hashang’s wrong views arose from an inability to identify both the object of negation of emptiness and the principal object to be abandoned. If we also fail to identify these clearly there is a danger of these wrong views persisting and blocking the spiritual development of this and future generations. Therefore we should be very clear about what is the object to be negated and what is the object to be abandoned. The object of negation is true existence, which is existence in any way independent of conceptual imputation, and the object to be abandoned is true-grasping, which is a conceptual mind that apprehends, or conceives, true existence.

Although true existence appears to all conceptual minds, not all conceptual minds apprehend, or conceive, true existence. Only conceptual minds that conceive true existence are true-grasping minds. Virtuous minds such as love, compassion and bodhichitta are conceptual minds but they are not true-grasping minds and so they are not objects to be abandoned. Only by understanding such distinctions can we practise both the profound path, which is the cause of the Truth Body of a Buddha, and the vast path, which is the cause of the Form Body of a Buddha, and thereby attain full enlightenment.

Another area of misunderstanding is the type of negation that is realized. Some say that when we realize emptiness we realize an affirming negative but this is incorrect. Emptiness is not an affirming negative but a non-affirming negative.

There are two types of phenomenon – affirmative phenomena and negative phenomena. Affirmative phenomena are objects such as people, chairs, tables and so forth that are realized without the mind explicitly eliminating an object of negation. A negative phenomenon is a phenomenon that is realized through the explicit elimination of the phenomenon’s object of negation by the mind that apprehends that phenomenon. There are two types of negative phenomenon – affirming negatives and non-affirming negatives. An affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that eliminates its object of negation while realizing another phenomenon. An example is a well-fed man’s not eating during the day. A mind that realizes this explicitly eliminates the object of negation, his eating during the day, while implicitly realizing another phenomenon – that he must eat during the night! Another example is the opposite of non-pot because the mind that realizes this explicitly eliminates the object of negation, non-pot, while implicitly realizing pot.

A non-affirming negative is a negative phenomenon realized by a mind that merely eliminates its object of negation without realizing another phenomenon. The absence of a horn on a rabbit’s head is an example of a non-affirming negative because the mind that realizes this merely eliminates the object of negation, a horn on a rabbit’s head, without realizing another phenomenon. All emptinesses are non-affirming negatives. For example, selflessness of persons is a non-affirming negative because the mind that realizes it merely eliminates the object of negation, an inherently existent person, without realizing another phenomenon. Similarly, selflessness of phenomena is a non-affirming negative because the mind that realizes it merely eliminates the object of negation, inherently existent phenomena, without realizing another phenomenon.

Generally, non-affirming negatives are quite difficult to understand, and there are many who mistakenly think that there is no object to be realized in a mere negation. If we want to realize emptiness, however, we must strive to understand the real nature of non-affirming negatives. Previously in Tibet many Teachers failed to distinguish between a non-affirming negative and non-existence and as a result they strayed from Nagarjuna’s view. This may still be the case today. To avoid making such mistakes we need to study clear and practical instructions on how to identify the object of negation, such as those found in the books Joyful Path of Good Fortune, Meaningful to Behold, The New Meditation Handbook, The New Heart of Wisdom and The Oral Instructions of Mahamudra.

Chandrakirti

Refuting Production from Self

ESTABLISHING THE MEANING OF THE SCRIPTURES BY REASONING

This section has two parts:

1 Establishing selflessness of phenomena by reasoning

2 Establishing selflessness of persons by reasoning

ESTABLISHING SELFLESSNESS OF PHENOMENA BY REASONING

As we will see later, Buddha explained many divisions of emptiness, or selflessness, but the principal division is a twofold division into selflessness of persons and selflessness of phenomena. Selflessness of persons is the lack of inherent existence of persons, and selflessness of phenomena is the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena other than persons. These two selflessnesses are distinguished only from the point of view of their bases, not from the point of view of their nature. All selflessnesses are the same nature, mere absence of inherent existence.

In Condensed Perfection of Wisdom Sutra Buddha says that we should know all other living beings as we know our self and we should know all other phenomena as we know living beings. This means that we should first realize the emptiness of our self, then the emptiness of other persons and then the emptiness of phenomena other than persons. In other words, we should first realize selflessness of persons and then selflessness of phenomena. Chandrakirti, however, presents selflessness of phenomena first. His purpose is to dislodge the strong adherence to inherent existence in the minds of those who propound tenets lower than the Madhyamika-Prasangikas. Proponents of lower tenets hold tightly to the view of inherent existence mainly because they cannot understand how it is possible for things to be produced from causes if neither cause nor effect exists from its own side. For them, the very fact that causes produce effects proves that causes and effects exist from their own side and therefore that they are inherently existent. To remove this wrong conception Chandrakirti begins with a refutation of inherently existent production.

Establishing selflessness of phenomena by reasoning has four parts:

1 Refuting the four extremes of production within both truths

2 Rejecting arguments against this refutation

3 How dependently-arising production eliminates wrong conceptions that grasp at extremes

4 Identifying the result of logical analysis

REFUTING THE FOUR EXTREMES OF PRODUCTION WITHIN BOTH TRUTHS

There are many ways to refute inherently existent production but the most powerful method is the refutation of the four extremes of production. This refutation is known as ‘vajra fragments’ because just as a vajra is so powerful that even one fragment can shatter a mountain, so this reasoning is extremely powerful in destroying the conception of inherently existent production. The reasoning is presented in three parts:

1 There is no inherently existent production

2 Proving this by reasoning

3 The meaning established by the refutation of the four extremes of production

THERE IS NO INHERENTLY EXISTENT PRODUCTION

[VI.8ab] It does not arise from itself; how can it come from other?

Also it is not from both; how can it be without a cause?

The reasoning of vajra fragments is as follows. Things are not inherently produced because they are not produced from self, from other, from both self and other or without a cause. Production from self, from other, from both self and other and without a cause are called ‘extremes’ because to assert any of these positions is to fall into the extreme of existence. These four extremes exhaust all possibilities of inherently existent production and since none of them exists there is no inherently existent production.

Production from self is asserted by the Samkhya school, the oldest of the Brahmaic schools, production from other is asserted by some non-Buddhist schools and by all Buddhist schools below the Madhyamika-Prasangikas, production from both self and other is asserted by some sections of the Samkhya school and by the Jains, and production without a cause is asserted by the Charavaka school, a nihilist school.

PROVING THIS BY REASONING

This section has four parts:

1 Refuting production from self

2 Refuting production from other

3 Refuting production from both

4 Refuting production without a cause

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM SELF

In Fundamental Wisdom Nagarjuna refutes production from self with powerful logical reasoning. Later, as a commentary to this, Chandrakirti provided additional reasoning to refute production from self. These two sets of reasoning will now be presented under the following two headings:

1 Refuting production from self with the reasoning from Chandrakirti’s commentary

2 Refuting production from self with the reasoning from Fundamental Wisdom

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM SELF WITH THE REASONING FROM CHANDRAKIRTI’S COMMENTARY

This section has three parts:

1 Refuting the system of the Samkhya school

2 Even worldly people whose minds are not affected by tenets do not assert production from self

3 Conclusion from these refutations

REFUTING THE SYSTEM OF THE SAMKHYA SCHOOL

Samkhyas We assert production from self because effects are produced from causes that are the same entity as themselves. For example, when a barley seed meets with appropriate conditions such as moisture and warmth a barley sprout is produced. Although the seed is the cause and the sprout is its effect they are both the same entity, or nature. Since a sprout is produced from a seed that is the same entity as itself there is production from self.

The refutation of this position is in two parts:

1 Refuting production from a cause that is the same entity

2 Refuting that cause and effect are the same entity

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM A CAUSE THAT IS THE SAME ENTITY

This refutation is in three parts:

1 It follows that production from a cause that is the same entity is pointless

2 That things are produced from the same nature is contrary to reasoning

3 Refuting a denial of these faults

IT FOLLOWS THAT PRODUCTION FROM A CAUSE THAT IS THE SAME ENTITY IS POINTLESS

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.8c] There is no point in it arising from itself.

There is no point in a barley sprout arising from a seed that is the same entity as itself because the sprout already exists at the time of the seed and so has no need of production.

THAT THINGS ARE PRODUCED FROM THE SAME NATURE IS CONTRARY TO REASONING

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.8d] Moreover, it is not reasonable that what has been produced is produced again.

[VI.9abc] If you assert that what is already produced is produced again

Then the production of sprouts and so forth is not found here

And seeds will continue to be produced until the end of time.

If a sprout is the same entity as its seed it follows that it has already been produced at the time of the seed, and it is not reasonable to assert that what has already been produced is produced again. If you assert that what is already produced is produced again then two consequences follow. First, sprouts and so forth will never be produced because the production of a sprout follows the cessation of its seed and seeds that are forever being produced never cease. Second, once a seed is produced it is produced again, and having been produced again it must be produced yet again and so on. Therefore it follows that the production of seeds is endless and so seeds will continue to be produced until the end of time.

REFUTING A DENIAL OF THESE FAULTS

Samkhyas We do not have to accept either of the foregoing consequences because we can see clearly that sprouts are produced and that seeds cease. A sprout is produced when its cause, the seed, meets with conditions such as moisture and warmth and in being produced it causes the seed to disintegrate.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.9d] How can it destroy that?

If the seed and the sprout are the same entity, how can the sprout destroy the seed? Can a sprout destroy itself?

REFUTING THAT CAUSE AND EFFECT ARE THE SAME ENTITY

This refutation is presented in three parts:

1 It follows that the shape and so forth of the sprout are not different from those of the seed

2 Refuting a denial of this fault

3 It follows that both the seed and the sprout are similar in being either apprehendable or unapprehendable at any one time

IT FOLLOWS THAT THE SHAPE AND SO FORTH OF THE SPROUT ARE NOT DIFFERENT FROM THOSE OF THE SEED

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.10ab] For you, the shape, colour, taste, potentiality and ripening of a sprout

Are not different from those of its cause, the seed.

If a cause such as a seed and its effect, the sprout, are the same entity it follows that the shape, colour, taste, potentiality and ripening of a sprout are not different from those of its seed. However, even worldly people can see that they are different; therefore a cause and its effect are not the same entity.

REFUTING A DENIAL OF THIS FAULT

Samkhyas We do not incur this fault because when a seed produces a sprout its previous nature is destroyed and it becomes a different entity.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.10cd] If its previous nature is destroyed and it becomes an entity other than that,

At that time how is it the nature of that?

If in producing the sprout the seed’s previous nature is destroyed and it becomes a different entity, how can the seed be the same nature as the sprout at that time? Surely it is contradictory to say that a seed and its sprout are the same nature and yet the seed must change its nature to transform into the sprout.

IT FOLLOWS THAT BOTH THE SEED AND THE SPROUT ARE SIMILAR IN BEING EITHER APPREHENDABLE OR UNAPPREHENDABLE AT ANY ONE TIME

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.11] If, for you, the seed and the sprout are not different here

Then either the sprout is unapprehendable just like the seed

Or, since they are the same, that is also apprehendable just like the sprout.

Therefore you should not assert this.

If two visual objects are the same nature they must be produced simultaneously and disintegrate simultaneously. When one appears to sense awareness the other also appears, and if one does not appear to sense awareness the other also does not appear. You Samkhyas assert that a seed is the same nature as its sprout. If that is so then at the time of the sprout either the sprout does not appear to sense awareness just like the seed or the seed appears to sense awareness just like the sprout. Since neither is the case you should not assert that a seed and its sprout are the same nature.

EVEN WORLDLY PEOPLE WHOSE MINDS ARE NOT AFFECTED BY TENETS DO NOT ASSERT PRODUCTION FROM SELF

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.12ab] Because though a cause has disintegrated its effect is still seen,

Even the worldly do not assert that they are the same.

Even people who do not propound tenets know that although a cause such as a seed has disintegrated, its effect, the sprout, can still be seen. Therefore, they do not assert that a seed and its sprout are the same nature and so they do not assert production from self. The idea of production from self never arises naturally but is a mental fabrication that comes from adhering to mistaken tenets. A mind that holds production from self, therefore, is an intellectually-formed delusion not an innate delusion.

CONCLUSION FROM THESE REFUTATIONS

[VI.12cd] Therefore this fabrication that things arise from self

Is unacceptable in thatness and in the world.

This fabrication of the Samkhyas that things arise from self is unacceptable both ultimately and conventionally.

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM SELF WITH THE REASONING FROM FUNDAMENTAL WISDOM

[VI.13] If production from self is asserted,

Then product and producer, object and agent, are one.

Since they are not one, production from self should not be asserted

Because of the consequences extensively explained.

If production from self is asserted, it follows that a cause and its effect are inherently the same nature and so are identical in all respects. Thus a product, such as a sprout and its producer, the seed, are inherently one. As Nagarjuna says in Fundamental Wisdom:
