The oneness of cause and effect

Is not acceptable at any time.

If cause and effect are one,

Then product and producer are one.

Furthermore it follows that an object and its agent are also inherently one. Again, Nagarjuna says in Fundamental Wisdom:

If wood and fire are one,

Object and agent are one.

Since a product and its producer are not one and an object and its agent are not one, production from self should not be asserted. Those who assert production from self incur all the consequences extensively explained in Fundamental Wisdom and Guide to the Middle Way.

At this point it is customary to study a detailed debate that arises out of differing interpretations of Nagarjuna’s refutation of production from self. The debate is long and complex and there is not the space here to consider it at length, but it might be helpful briefly to outline the main points.

The participants are three of Nagarjuna’s disciples – Buddhapalita, Bhavaviveka and Chandrakirti. In his commentary to Fundamental Wisdom Buddhapalita refutes the Samkhyas’ assertion of production from self by means of two consequences. His actual words are:

There is no production of things from self because their production would be pointless and because extreme consequences would follow. A thing that exists in its own entity has no need of production. If, even though it exists, it is produced, it will never not be produced.

Buddhapalita’s first consequence is: it follows that if things already exist in the entity of their own cause their production again is pointless. The second consequence is: it follows that if a thing already exists and yet must be produced again it is never not being produced and so its production is endless.

Bhavaviveka analyzes this reasoning in Lamp for Wisdom and finds three faults. His first criticism is that Buddhapalita fails to provide a reason and an example that are capable of refuting the Samkhyas’ position. He does not find Buddhapalita’s consequences adequate and seeks to reconstruct them in the form of autonomous syllogisms, that is syllogisms in which the three modes – the property of the subject, the forward pervasion and the reverse pervasion – inherently exist in the reason and in which the three terms – the subject, the predicate, and the reason – inherently exist and appear commonly to both parties in the debate. Bhavaviveka finds the autonomous syllogisms reconstructed from Buddhapalita’s reasoning unsuitable and proposes an alternative syllogism for refuting production from self:

The subjects, the inner sources such as an eye sense power, are not ultimately produced from self because of existing – like, for example, existent consciousness.

Bhavaviveka’s second criticism is that Buddhapalita’s consequences do not counter the mistaken reasoning of the Samkhyas because they fail to prove to a Samkhya that there is no production from self. His third criticism is that the probanda of the syllogisms reconstructed from Buddhapalita’s consequences affirm production from other and so contradicts the Madhyamika tenet that the negation of the four extremes of production is a non-affirming negative.

In his commentary to Fundamental Wisdom called Clear Words, Chandrakirti rejects all three of Bhavaviveka’s criticisms. To the first point Chandrakirti replies that Buddhapalita’s consequences are perfectly capable of causing a Samkhya to abandon the view of production from self because they clearly reveal contradictions within the Samkhyas’ position. If after contemplating these contradictions a Samkhya were to continue to hold to the view of production from self there would be no point in stating reasons and examples to convince him because he would already have shown himself to be unreasonable. Moreover, even if reasons were used they could not be stated in the form of autonomous syllogisms because inherently existent reasons possessing the three modes do not exist and it is quite wrong for a Madhyamika to assert them.

By analyzing Buddhapalita’s own explanation of his consequences, Chandrakirti shows that Bhavaviveka’s second criticism is also invalid because both consequences are addressed to the fallacies in the Samkhyas’ reasoning. Chandrakirti turns the criticism around and shows how it is Bhavaviveka’s syllogism that is inadequate in this respect.

As far as Bhavaviveka’s third criticism is concerned, Chandrakirti points out that it is based on the misunderstanding that Buddhapalita is obliged to accept the opposite of his consequences. Chandrakirti shows that not all consequences imply their opposite. Buddhapalita merely refutes production from self and does not affirm production from other.

Having defended Buddhapalita, Chandrakirti goes on to attack Bhavaviveka’s general position, thereby throwing into relief the essential differences between the Madhyamika-Prasangika and Madhyamika-Svatantrika schools. Chandrakirti first points out that there is no justification for Bhavaviveka’s inclusion of the term ‘ultimately’ in his proposed syllogism because this is the occasion for refuting production from self and production from self does not exist either conventionally or ultimately. He then refutes the basic assumption underlying Bhavaviveka’s use of autonomous syllogisms, that the subject of a syllogism appears commonly to both parties in a debate. Chandrakirti shows that the subject of a syllogism cannot appear to a non-Madhyamika-Prasangika in the same way that it appears to a Madhyamika-Prasangika because for a non-Madhyamika-Prasangika it will appear to be certified as inherently existent by a valid cognizer whereas for a Madhyamika-Prasangika it will not.

Vajradhara

Refuting Production from Other

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

This section has two parts:

1 A description of the position asserting production from other

2 Refuting this system

A DESCRIPTION OF THE POSITION ASSERTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

The Vaibhashika, Sautrantika and Chittamatra schools are known as ‘proponents of things’ because they assert that things are truly existent. Whereas all Buddhist schools refute production from self, production from both self and other and production without a cause, the proponents of things do not refute production from other. In this context, ‘production from other’ means not simply production from other causes but production from inherently existent other causes. Conventionally all things are produced from causes that are other than themselves, but nothing is produced from inherently existent other causes.

The proponents of things believe that if causes were not inherently existent they would not be able to produce their effects. Therefore they assert that things are produced from inherently existent other causes. They support their belief with a quotation from Sutra where Buddha says:

The causes of things are the four conditions that exist by way of their own characteristics.

Thus they believe that causes and effects are inherently existent and inherently other. This assertion of production from other is now extensively refuted by the Madhyamika-Prasangikas.

REFUTING THIS SYSTEM

The refutation of production from other is presented in two parts:

1 A general refutation of production from other

2 A refutation of the Chittamatra system in particular

A GENERAL REFUTATION OF PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

This section has five parts:

1 The actual refutation of production from other

2 Denying that worldly people can damage this refutation

3 The good qualities of this refutation

4 There is no inherently existent production at any time

5 The good qualities of refuting inherently existent production within both truths

THE ACTUAL REFUTATION OF PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

This refutation has three parts:

1 Refuting production from other in general

2 Refuting particular production from other

3 Refuting production from other having analyzed effects by way of four alternatives

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER IN GENERAL

This has two parts:

1 Refuting by means of the consequence of excess

2 Refuting a denial of this fault

REFUTING BY MEANS OF THE CONSEQUENCE OF EXCESS

[VI.14] If other arises in dependence on other

Then thick darkness arises even from flames.

Indeed everything arises from everything

Because all non-producers are similar in also being other.

If an inherently existent other effect arises in dependence on an inherently existent other cause, then because cause and effect are inherently existent other they do not depend on each other but are completely unrelated. If effects arise from independent and unrelated causes then thick darkness arises even from the flames that dispel it, rice sprouts arise from barley seeds and medicinal plants arise from poisonous seeds. Indeed everything whether effect or not arises from everything whether cause or not because a non-cause is similar to a cause in that both are inherently existent other than and completely unrelated to the effect. The assertion of production from other, therefore, grants too much as a consequence.

REFUTING A DENIAL OF THIS FAULT

This section has two parts:

1 The denial of the fault

2 Refuting this denial

THE DENIAL OF THE FAULT

Proponents of things

[VI.15] ‘Something that can be produced is definitely called an ‘‘effect’’,

And that which has the ability to produce it, though other, is a cause.

Thus, because it is produced from a producer of the same continuum

A rice sprout is not from barley or any other as they are.’

Although causes and their effects are inherently existent other, everything does not arise from everything because we can see clearly that particular causes produce particular effects and particular effects arise from particular causes. Something that has the ability to produce another thing is correctly called the cause of that thing even though it is inherently existent other than it, but things that do not have the ability to produce it are not its causes, though they too are inherently existent other. Likewise something that can be produced from another thing is correctly called the effect of that thing, but things that cannot be produced from it are not its effects, though they too are inherently existent other. For example a rice seed can produce a rice sprout that is inherently existent other, but a barley seed cannot produce a rice sprout even though it too is inherently existent other. Similarly, a rice sprout can be produced by a rice seed that is inherently existent other, but a rice sprout cannot be produced by a barley seed even though it too is inherently existent other. Moreover, a rice sprout is produced from a rice seed that is its own previous continuum and not from a barley seed or any other seed as barley sprouts and so forth are. Therefore even though a cause and its effect are inherently existent other it does not follow that everything arises from everything and we do not incur the consequence of excess.

REFUTING THIS DENIAL

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.16] If you say this, then just as barley, corollas, kengshuka and so forth

Are not called producers of a rice sprout, do not possess the ability,

Are not of the same continuum and are not similar,

So too the rice seed is not any of these because it is other.

Phenomena that are not related to a rice sprout such as barley, the corollas of lotuses and kengshuka flowers are not called producers of a rice sprout, do not possess the ability to produce one, are not of the same continuum as a rice sprout and are not of a similar type to a rice sprout. In just the same way, the rice seed too is not the producer of the rice sprout, lacks the ability to produce the rice sprout, is not of the same continuum as the rice sprout and is not of a similar type to the rice sprout. Why? Because the rice seed too is inherently existent other than and therefore completely unrelated to the rice sprout.

REFUTING PARTICULAR PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

This section has two parts:

1 Refuting production from other where a cause precedes its effect

2 Refuting production from other where a cause is simultaneous with its effect

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER WHERE A CAUSE PRECEDES ITS EFFECT

This refutation has two parts:

1 The actual refutation

2 Rejecting arguments against this refutation

THE ACTUAL REFUTATION

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.17] A sprout does not exist at the time of its seed,

So without otherness how can the seed be other?

Therefore, since production of a sprout from a seed is not established,

Give up this position of so-called ‘production from other’.

If something is inherently existent it must always have been inherently existent. It could not have been non-existent one moment and existent the next. Therefore, if a sprout is inherently existent it must always have been inherently existent and so it must have existed at the time of its seed. However, even you proponents of things can see that a sprout does not exist at the time of its seed. Therefore it follows that a sprout is not inherently existent.

If a sprout is not inherently existent it cannot be inherently other than its seed, and without an inherently existent other sprout with respect to what can the seed be inherently other? Therefore, there is no production of a sprout from an inherently existent other seed. You proponents of things should give up this position of so-called ‘production from other’.

REJECTING ARGUMENTS AGAINST THIS REFUTATION

Objection

[VI.18abc] ‘Just as the highness and lowness of the two arms of a balance

Are seen to be simultaneous,

So too are the producing of what is to be produced and the ceasing of the producer.’

You say that a sprout is not inherently existent because it is not simultaneous with its seed but this is not strictly true. Consider, for example, the following analogy. When a balance is tipped one arm moves up while the other moves down. Because the actions of ascending and descending occur simultaneously, the highness and lowness of the two arms of a balance are also simultaneous. In just the same way, because the actions of the producing of what is to be produced – the sprout – and the ceasing of the producer –the seed – occur simultaneously, the two agents – the seed and the sprout – must also be simultaneous. Therefore, a seed and its sprout are inherently other and the fault you have stated does not apply.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.18d] If you say this, even though they are simultaneous, there is no simultaneity here; it does not exist.

[VI.19abc] Since that being produced is approaching production, it does not exist,

And that ceasing, though existent, is said to be approaching cessation;

So how are they similar to a balance?

Even though the highness and lowness of the two arms of a balance are simultaneous, a seed and its sprout are not. At the time of the seed the sprout is being produced, but since it is still approaching production the entity of the sprout has not yet arisen and so it does not exist. At that time the seed is ceasing and although it is still existent it is said to be approaching cessation. Thus, while the seed exists the sprout does not and when the sprout exists the seed has ceased, so how are a seed and a sprout similar to the two arms of a balance?

Objection Even though the seed and the sprout do not exist simultaneously, the action of the sprout’s production and the action of the seed’s cessation do.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.19d] This production [of the sprout] without an agent [the sprout itself] is also an unacceptable entity.

Although at the time of the seed the action of the seed’s cessation exists, the action of the sprout’s production does not because the sprout does not exist. It is unacceptable to say that the action of the sprout’s production exists when the agent of that action, the sprout itself, does not.

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER WHERE A CAUSE IS SIMULTANEOUS WITH ITS EFFECT

Objection

[VI.20ab] ‘An eye consciousness is other than its simultaneous producers,

The eyes and so forth and the discrimination and so forth that arise with it.’

Even though there is no production from inherently existent other where a cause precedes its effect, there is production from inherently existent other where a cause is simultaneous with its effect. An example of simultaneous cause and effect is an eye consciousness and the eye sense power that is its dominant condition together with the specific mental factors such as the discrimination and so forth in its retinue. The eye sense power and the mental factors arise simultaneously with the eye consciousness but they are inherently other than the eye consciousness and are its causes.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.20cd] If this is so, what need is there for an existent to arise?

If you say it does not exist, the faults in that have already been explained.

Since the eye consciousness already exists at the time of its causes, the eye sense power and so forth, what need is there for it to arise again? If you said that the eye consciousness does not exist at the time of its causes this would be correct, but then you would be saying that the eye consciousness is produced from inherently existent other causes that precede it and the faults in that have already been explained.

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM OTHER HAVING ANALYZED EFFECTS BY WAY OF FOUR ALTERNATIVES

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.21] If a producer producing a product that is other is a cause

Then what is produced, an existent, a non-existent, both, or neither?

If it is an existent, what need is there for a producer and what need is there if it is a non-existent?

What need is there for both and what need is there for neither?

If, as you proponents of things assert, a producer producing a product that is inherently existent other than it is a cause, then what kind of effect is produced – an inherently existent effect, a non-existent effect, an effect that is both existent and non-existent or an effect that is neither existent nor non-existent? If the effect is inherently existent it exists from its own side and has no need of a producer. If the effect is a non-existent what need is there of a producer? A horn on a rabbit’s head does not require a producer! Furthermore, effects that are both existent and non-existent and effects that are neither existent nor non-existent are impossible, so what need have they for producers? Since these four alternatives exhaust all possibilities of production from inherently existent other, production from other is completely refuted.

Tilopa

The Two Truths

DENYING THAT WORLDLY PEOPLE CAN DAMAGE THIS REFUTATION

This section has two parts:

1 Denying damage by worldly people’s belief in production from other

2 Denying damage by worldly people because there is no production from other for the worldly, even nominally

DENYING DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE’S BELIEF IN PRODUCTION FROM OTHER

This section has two parts:

1 The argument that there is damage by worldly people

2 Showing that there is no damage by worldly people

THE ARGUMENT THAT THERE IS DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE

Objection

[VI.22] ‘Since they rely on their own views and assert the worldly to be valid

What is the point of stating reasons here?

Worldly people also realize that other arises from other

So production from other exists; what need for reasons here?’

Since worldly people rely only on their own common sense views and believe what they see to be valid, what is the point in stating reasons here to prove production from other? Worldly people realize through their own valid cognizers that inherently existent other effects arise from inherently existent other causes. Since they already know that production from other exists, what need is there to state reasons to prove something that is manifest? If you deny production from other your position will be damaged by the common sense perceptions of ordinary people.

SHOWING THAT THERE IS NO DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE

Reply This objection reveals a lack of understanding of the two truths. To answer it fully we must first explain the two truths, and then we can show what can and cannot be damaged by worldly people. These points will now be presented under the following five headings:

1 A general presentation of the two truths

2 Applying this to the present subject

3 An explanation of the respective natures of the two truths

4 How the charge of damage by worldly people is itself damaged

5 How there can be damage by worldly people

A GENERAL PRESENTATION OF THE TWO TRUTHS

Although there are infinite objects of knowledge, they are all included in two truths – ultimate truths and conventional truths. All emptinesses are ultimate truths and all phenomena other than emptinesses are conventional truths. The definition of ultimate truth is the principal object of a valid cognizer that apprehends a truth. The Tibetan term for ultimate truth is don dam denpa, in which don means ‘object’, dam means ‘holy’ and denpa means ‘truth’. An ultimate truth is an object because it is the principal object of the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of Superior beings, it is holy because it is the door to liberation and it is a truth because it exists just as it appears to a non-conceptual direct perceiver. Although all ultimate truths are the same nature, they can be divided in various ways according to their different bases. Thus there are sixteen emptinesses, four emptinesses and so forth. These are explained in more detail below.

The definition of conventional truth is the principal object of a valid cognizer that apprehends a false object. The Tibetan term for conventional truth is kun dzob denpa, in which kun means ‘manifold’, dzob means ‘false’ and denpa means ‘truth’. Conventional truths are manifold because, unlike emptinesses which are all the same nature, there are countless different conventional truths each with its own nature. Conventional truths are false objects because they do not exist in the way that they appear, that is they appear to be truly existent when they are not. They are called ‘truths’ because they are true for the true-grasping mind. Thus, conventional truths appear as truly existent and for the true-grasping mind this appearance is true.

The two truths will now be explained extensively under the following three headings:

1 All phenomena have two natures

2 The divisions of conventional truths with respect to the awareness of worldly people

3 Mistaken conceived objects do not exist even nominally

ALL PHENOMENA HAVE TWO NATURES

[VI.23] All things hold two entities –

Those that are found by seeing correctly and by seeing falsely.

It is said that the object of seeing correctly is thatness

And that of seeing falsely a conventional truth.

All phenomena, both permanent objects and impermanent things, have two natures – an ultimate nature and a conventional nature. Their ultimate nature is the main object of a valid cognizer realizing a truth and their conventional nature is the main object of a valid cognizer realizing a false object. Buddha said the main object of a valid cognizer realizing a truth is thatness, or ultimate truth, and the main object of a valid cognizer realizing a false object is a conventional truth.

We can understand that one object has two natures by considering the example of a car. The car itself and its parts are the conventional nature of the car, whereas the lack of inherent existence of the car and its parts is its ultimate nature. The same can be applied to all other objects.

The two truths do not contradict each other but are completely compatible. To understand ultimate truths fully we must understand conventional truths, and to understand conventional truths fully we must understand ultimate truths. Eventually we must understand the union of the two truths, known as the ‘union of appearance and emptiness’. Here, conventional truths are called ‘appearance’ because they are mere appearances to mistaken minds. Without realizing this union it is impossible to attain liberation from samsara. To understand this view perfectly we must rely on texts by valid authors such as Nagarjuna, Chandrakirti and Je Tsongkhapa.

THE DIVISIONS OF CONVENTIONAL TRUTHS WITH RESPECT TO THE AWARENESS OF WORLDLY PEOPLE

As already explained, all conventional truths are false objects because they appear to be truly existent when they are not. However, worldly people who have not realized emptiness do not realize this and so they distinguish between correct conventional truths and incorrect conventional truths. Thus, they would regard a face, for example, as correct or true but a reflection of a face in a mirror as incorrect, or false. In reality, however, this is a specious division because there are no correct conventional truths.

Both conventional truths that are correct with respect to the awareness of worldly people and conventional truths that are incorrect with respect to the awareness of worldly people can be divided into object-possessors and objects. The definition of an object-possessor that is correct with respect to the awareness of worldly people is a mind that is such that a person who has not realized emptiness does not realize that it is a mistaken awareness. An example is a mind apprehending a truly existent form. The definition of an object that is correct with respect to the awareness of worldly people is a phenomenon that is only an object and is such that a person who has not realized emptiness does not realize that it does not exist as it appears. An example is a visual form. The definition of an object-possessor that is incorrect with respect to the awareness of worldly people is a mind that is such that a person who has not realized emptiness realizes that it is a wrong awareness. An example is a mind to which a white snow mountain appears as yellow. The definition of an object that is incorrect with respect to the awareness of worldly people is a phenomenon that is only an object and is such that a person who has not realized emptiness realizes that it does not exist as it appears. An example is a reflection of a face in a mirror. The divisions of conventional truths with respect to the awareness of worldly people will now be explained more fully under the following two headings:

1 An explanation of correct and incorrect object-possessors with respect to the awareness of worldly people

2 An explanation of correct and incorrect objects with respect to the awareness of worldly people

AN EXPLANATION OF CORRECT AND INCORRECT OBJECT-POSSESSORS WITH RESPECT TO THE AWARENESS OF WORLDLY PEOPLE

[VI.24] Furthermore, it is said that seeing falsely is of two types –

With clear powers and with faulty powers.

Awareness with faulty powers is held to be incorrect

When compared with awareness with good powers.

There are two types of mind that see falsely – minds generated in dependence on powers that are not affected by temporary causes of mistaken awareness, such as a sense direct perceiver apprehending form and an innate true-grasping mind apprehending a truly existent form, and minds generated in dependence on powers that are affected by temporary causes of mistaken awareness, such as a mind apprehending a white snow mountain as yellow and an intellectually-formed true-grasping mind. According to worldly people, the second type of mind is incorrect when compared with the first.

In general, there are two causes of mistaken awareness – ultimate causes and temporary causes. The ultimate causes of all mistaken awarenesses are innate true-grasping and its imprints, but worldly people do not recognize these as a source of error. They recognize only temporary, or contributory, causes of mistaken awareness. These are of two types – those that affect the sense powers and those that affect the mental power. Those that affect the sense powers are also of two types – internal causes and external causes. Examples of the first are floaters, jaundice and eating dhatura. Floaters can generate false appearances such as the appearance of hairs floating in front of the eyes, jaundice can cause us to see white objects as yellow and eating dhatura, a powerful medicinal herb, can cause things to appear golden. Examples of external causes of error that affect the sense powers are a face reflected in a mirror, spring sunlight on grey sand, a voice in an empty cave and a magician’s substance together with his spell. The first can generate a mind that sees a reflection of a face as an actual face, the second can generate a mind that sees a mirage as water, the third can generate a mind that hears an echo of a voice as an actual voice and the fourth can generate a mind that sees, for example, an illusory horse as an actual horse.

Examples of temporary causes of mistaken awareness that affect the mental power are adhering to mistaken tenets, relying on incorrect reasons and sleep. Examples of the first are adhering to the belief that Ishvara created the world and adhering to a philosophical view of a truly-existent self. Examples of the second are reasoning that there are no past and future lives because they cannot be seen and reasoning that we will always take a higher rebirth because we are human. Examples of the third are dreaming of an elephant in the room and dreaming of being someone else. There are many other examples of temporary causes of mistaken awareness that affect both the sense powers and the mental power.

AN EXPLANATION OF CORRECT AND INCORRECT OBJECTS WITH RESPECT TO THE AWARENESS OF WORLDLY PEOPLE

[VI.25] Whatever the worldly realize

By apprehending through the six powers without faults

Is true for the worldly.

The remainder are held by the worldly to be incorrect.

If worldly people realize an object with any of the six types of awareness that is not affected by temporary causes of mistaken awareness, they regard that object as true or correct. This is because, not having realized emptiness, they do not realize that these objects do not exist in the way that they appear. Other objects such as reflections, echoes and mirages are held by worldly people to be incorrect. This is because even people who have not realized emptiness realize that such objects do not exist in the way that they appear.

MISTAKEN CONCEIVED OBJECTS DO NOT EXIST EVEN NOMINALLY

[VI.26] A nature as projected by Tirthikas

Completely under the influence of the sleep of unknowing

And what is projected on illusions, mirages and so forth –

These are non-existent even for the worldly.

Mistaken conceived objects such as a fundamental nature that is the source of all that exists, Ishvara the creator of the universe and a permanent self that are asserted by non-Buddhist proponents of tenets, or Tirthikas, who out of ignorance adhere to mistaken beliefs, and also spurious objects such as a real horse projected onto an illusion of a horse, water projected onto a mirage, a face projected onto a reflection and so forth are all mere projections of the mind and do not exist at all, even for worldly people. The valid cognizers of worldly people contradict the existence of phantoms but they do not contradict the refutation of production from other.

APPLYING THIS TO THE PRESENT SUBJECT

[VI.27] Just as what is observed by eyes with floaters

Does not damage awareness without floaters,

So minds lacking stainless wisdom

Do not damage a mind without stains.

Now the charge that the refutation of production from other is damaged by the direct perceivers of worldly people can be answered. To recapitulate, the charge is that since production from other is affirmed by the valid cognizers of worldly people and is so obvious that there is no need to state reasons to prove it, the attempt to refute production from other is futile. This argument rests on the assumption that the valid cognizers of worldly people are completely unmistaken, but this has now been shown to be not the case. In fact, all minds of worldly people including their direct valid cognizers are mistaken. Although only some of their minds are affected by temporary causes of mistaken awareness, all their minds are affected by the ultimate causes of mistaken awareness – the ignorance of true-grasping and its imprints. Whatever appears to the minds of worldly people appears as truly existent. Therefore, worldly people apprehend only false objects; they never apprehend true objects.

By contrast, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of Superior beings is an uncontaminated mind completely free from the stains of true-grasping and its imprints. Such a mind is utterly non-mistaken and whatever appears to it is true. Since the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of Superior beings sees the non-existence of production from other it follows that there is no production from other. That worldly people see things differently is of no consequence. If one person has floaters that causes him to see hairs floating in front of him we would not say that what he sees invalidates the awareness of a person with clear sight who sees no hairs in that place. In the same way the contaminated minds of worldly people distorted by true-grasping and its imprints do not invalidate the uncontaminated mind of meditative equipoise of Superior beings. The charge of damage, therefore, is reversed. Rather than the refutation of production from other being damaged by the perceptions of worldly people, it is the perceptions of worldly people that are damaged by the uncontaminated mind of Superior beings.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE RESPECTIVE NATURES OF THE TWO TRUTHS

This section has two parts:

1 An explanation of conventional truths

2 An explanation of ultimate truth

AN EXPLANATION OF CONVENTIONAL TRUTHS

[VI.28] Because confusion obstructs nature it is conventional.

Whatever is fabricated by it but appears as true

Is said by the Able One to be a conventional truth;

But fabricated things exist only conventionally.

The Sanskrit term for conventional truth is samvrtisatya, in which samvrti means ‘obscurer’ and satya means ‘truth’. A conventional truth, therefore, is a truth for an obscurer. In this context the obscurer is the true-grasping mind. True-grasping is a form of ignorance that superimposes on phenomena a fabrication of true existence thereby obstructing the view of their ultimate nature, or emptiness. In Gone to Lanka Sutra Buddha says:

Conventionally things are produced,

Ultimately they have no nature.

That which is mistaken with respect to this lack of nature

Is said to be conventional with respect to reality.

Everyone correctly believes that things such as cars and houses are produced in dependence on causes and conditions. These products, however, exist only conventionally and not ultimately. If they existed ultimately they would be inherently existent and if they were inherently existent they could not have been produced in dependence on causes. The true-grasping mind, however, is mistaken with respect to this lack of inherent existence. It conceives things as inherently existent and so obscures their ultimate reality. For this reason true-grasping is said to be ‘conventional with respect to reality’, that is, an obscurer of reality.

Buddha said that whatever is distorted by true-grasping in this way but appears as true to living beings is a conventional truth. However, conventional truths are true only for the true-grasping mind. For those who have abandoned true-grasping – Hinayana Foe Destroyers, Bodhisattvas on the eighth ground and above and Buddhas – they are not true objects at all but false objects. This is because these beings who are free from true-grasping directly realize them to be false. Thus, these fabricated things exist only conventionally.

Further explanation of the two truths can be found in the book The New Heart of Wisdom and the ninth chapter of the book Meaningful to Behold. It should be noted, however, that the definitions of conventional truth and ultimate truth mentioned in Meaningful to Behold are not actual definitions but general descriptions that reveal the meaning of the two truths according to Shantideva’s root text.

AN EXPLANATION OF ULTIMATE TRUTH

[VI.29] Whatever wrong entities such as floating hairs

May be projected due to floaters,

That which is the actual entity is seen by clear eyes.

You should understand thatness here in the same way.

Chandrakirti explains the nature of ultimate truths with the help of an analogy. Suppose two people are looking at the space in front of them. One has floaters due to tiredness or some other cause and sees floating hairs but the other has perfectly clear sight and sees no floating hairs. What is actually there, an absence of floating hairs, is seen by the person with clear eyes because his eye sense power is free from temporary causes of mistaken awareness. In a similar way, when an ordinary being and a Buddha look at an object such as a visual form the ordinary being, whose mind is polluted by true-grasping sees a truly existent form, whereas the Buddha sees a lack of truly existent form. Again, what is actually there is seen by the Buddha because his or her mind is completely free from all causes of mistaken awareness. Thus, ultimate truth, or lack of true existence, is seen directly only by unmistaken awareness.

This analogy does not directly reveal the nature of ultimate truths but shows how they are seen by a mind free from distortion. Because ultimate truth is not like a physical object whose nature can be displayed for examination, it is helpful to try to understand it through analogies such as this. Indeed, it is said that those who teach ultimate truth, emptiness, should use appropriate analogies wherever possible.

Chandrakirti advises us that we should understand ultimate truth in the way that Buddhas see forms. When a form appears to us, if at the same time we see the lack of true existence of that form we have understood ultimate truth and the union of appearance and emptiness because at that time the appearance of form helps us to understand the lack of true existence of form. When this happens our understanding of emptiness is complete.

HOW THE CHARGE OF DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE IS ITSELF DAMAGED

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.30] If the worldly are valid, then since the worldly see thatness

What need is there for other Superiors,

And what need is there for superior paths?

That the confused are valid cannot also be correct.

[VI.31ab] In all cases the worldly are not valid;

Therefore, on the occasion of thatness, there is no damage by the worldly.

According to you proponents of things, our refutation of production from other is contradicted by the fact that worldly people see production from other. You say that worldly people see an inherently existent sprout produced by an inherently existent seed that is other than it. If the seed and the sprout are inherently existent they must exist in the way they appear and so they must be true. Since truth, ultimate nature, thatness and emptiness are synonyms, it follows that worldly people see thatness, or emptiness, directly with their valid cognizers. If worldly people see emptiness directly, it follows that from the beginning they are Superior beings and that they are naturally released from samsara. Therefore, what need is there for other Superior beings and what need is there to train in superior paths to attain liberation?

In reality, worldly people do not realize emptiness at all because they are confused with respect to ultimate truth. Although worldly people have valid cognizers they do not have valid cognizers of emptiness. Therefore, on the occasion of our explaining thatness there is no damage by the worldly and so the refutation of production from other is not damaged by worldly people.

HOW THERE CAN BE DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE

[VI.31cd] If objects of the worldly are denied

There is damage from the worldly by worldly renown.

It should not be thought that worldly people are entirely confused, that they realize nothing and therefore can invalidate nothing. The conventional existence of objects such as people, cars and houses is established by the valid cognizers of worldly people. If someone were to deny the existence of such objects, their claim would be damaged by the perceptions of worldly people because such objects are established by worldly renown. However, worldly people cannot damage the refutation of production from other because production from other is not established by worldly renown.

DENYING DAMAGE BY WORLDLY PEOPLE BECAUSE THERE IS NO PRODUCTION FROM OTHER FOR THE WORLDLY, EVEN NOMINALLY

[VI.32] From having only sown the seeds

The worldly claim, ‘I produced this child’

Or think, ‘I planted this tree’,

Therefore, there is no production from other even for the worldly.

The way worldly people speak about cause and effect shows that they have no innate idea of production from other. For example, when his wife gives birth the husband thinks that he fathered the child, and when a tree grows the gardener who originally planted the seedling thinks, ‘I planted this tree.’ Both these examples show that there is no production from other for worldly people. In the first case, for example, if the father thought that the cause, his seed, were inherently other than the effect, the child, he would not claim to have produced the child. It is the same with the gardener and his tree. Therefore, the assertion that effects arise from causes that are inherently existent other entities is damaged by the beliefs of worldly people.

The belief held by some non-Buddhists that the self is a separate entity from the aggregates is also invalidated in a similar way. If, for example, worldly people hurt their hand they say, ‘I have hurt myself’ and if their bodies are sick they say, ‘I am sick’, thus revealing that they do not think of themselves as being separate entities from their aggregates. In Essence of Good Explanation Je Tsongkhapa says:

The mind that apprehends the self and the aggregates as different,

And the mind that apprehends them as the same,

Are both only intellectually-formed minds.

In the same way, the mind that apprehends production from other is only an intellectually-formed mind. It never arises in worldly people who do not propound tenets. There is no production from other for worldly people. Therefore it is quite wrong for those who hold this mistaken view to call on the perceptions of worldly people to support their belief.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THIS REFUTATION

[VI.33] Because a sprout is not other than its seed

The seed is not destroyed at the time of the sprout,

And because they are not one

We do not say that the seed exists at the time of the sprout.

Having shown that the refutation of production from other is entirely free from fault, Chandrakirti now shows how it has the good qualities of avoiding the two extremes and leading to a realization of emptiness. For those who assert production from other it is impossible to avoid falling into the two extremes of non-existence and existence. For example, if a seed and its sprout are inherently existent other they are completely unrelated and so the sprout is not a continuation of the seed, and so at the time of the sprout there is nothing that is the continuation of the seed. Alternatively, since the seed is inherently existent it remains as a seed forever and so the seed exists at the time of the sprout.

The refutation of production from other avoids both these extremes. Because a sprout is not inherently other than its seed, the continuum of the seed is not destroyed at the time of the sprout, and because the seed and the sprout are not inherently one, it is not necessary to say that the seed still exists at the time of the sprout. If you contemplate for a long time how a seed and its sprout are neither inherently different nor inherently the same you will come to understand how they lack inherent existence, and if you apply the same reasoning to all other objects you will eventually realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena. Therefore the refutation of production from other has the good qualities of avoiding the two extremes and leading us to a realization of emptiness.

THERE IS NO INHERENTLY EXISTENT PRODUCTION AT ANY TIME

This section has two parts:

1 Refuting the assertion of inherent existence

2 Rejecting an argument against this refutation

REFUTING THE ASSERTION OF INHERENT EXISTENCE

Madhyamika-Svatantrikas Even though ultimately things lack true existence, conventionally they are inherently existent. If they were not inherently existent they would not exist at all. Thus, although production from inherently existent other does not exist ultimately, it does exist conventionally, or nominally.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas If you say this then three consequences follow:

1 It follows that a Superior being’s meditative equipoise causes the destruction of things

2 It follows that nominal truths can withstand analysis

3 It follows that ultimate production is irrefutable

IT FOLLOWS THAT A SUPERIOR BEING’S MEDITATIVE EQUIPOISE CAUSES THE DESTRUCTION OF THINGS

[VI.34] If the dependent exist by way of their own characteristics

Then things are destroyed by being negated,

Therefore emptiness causes the destruction of things.

Since this is not reasonable, things do not exist.

You Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert that things such as forms and feelings that are dependent on causes and conditions exist by way of their own characteristics and so are inherently existent. However, a Superior being’s exalted awareness of meditative equipoise directly sees the lack of inherently existent things.

Since according to you inherently existent things are the same as existent things, it follows that in negating inherently existent things a Superior being’s exalted awareness also negates existent things. Therefore, according to you the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise directly realizing emptiness destroys things! Since this is not reasonable it follows that things do not exist inherently.

IT FOLLOWS THAT NOMINAL TRUTHS CAN WITHSTAND ANALYSIS

[VI.35] Since, if these things are analyzed,

No object is found on this side of things

Away from the nature of thatness,

Worldly nominal truths should not be analyzed.

If things such as forms are inherently existent it follows that they will be found when analyzed. However, these things are merely imputed by mind. If we are satisfied with them as mere names they exist and function, but if we search for them through analysis no object is found other than the nature of thatness, or emptiness. Therefore we should be satisfied with worldly nominal truths, that is existent things, as mere names and not analyze them further. In Essence of Good Explanation Je Tsongkhapa explains four ways to analyze things. These are explained below in the section on selflessness of persons.

IT FOLLOWS THAT ULTIMATE PRODUCTION IS IRREFUTABLE

[VI.36] By the reasoning on the occasion of thatness

Production from self and other is inadmissible.

Since by that reasoning it is also inadmissible nominally,

By what is production established for you?

When, with perfect reasoning, we established ultimate truth, we proved that there is no production from self and no production from other. This reasoning also proves that inherently existent production does not exist even conventionally; so by what valid cognizer is inherently existent production established for you Madhyamika-Svatantrikas?

According to you, although there is no truly existent, or ultimate, production of things nevertheless conventionally things are produced inherently. However, you cannot hold this position because it is an inner contradiction. If things are inherently produced even conventionally they must be produced without depending on anything and if they are produced without depending on anything they are produced ultimately. Therefore, if you assert that things are inherently produced, even nominally, you cannot refute ultimate, or truly existent, production.

REJECTING AN ARGUMENT AGAINST THIS REFUTATION

Proponents of things If things such as forms are not inherently produced either ultimately or conventionally, they do not exist at all and so they do not produce effects. For example, if a visual form does not exist from its own side it cannot generate an eye consciousness apprehending it.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.37] Empty things such as reflections that depend on collections

Are also not unknown.

Just as, there, awareness of their aspects is generated

From empty reflections and so forth,

[VI.38ab] So, although all things are empty,

They nevertheless generate from that emptiness.

Again you reveal a failure to understand the two truths. If you understood the union of the two truths you would know that conventional truths such as cause and effect exist only because they lack inherent existence. For example, everyone will agree that a reflection of a face in a mirror is false because it does not exist as it appears. Even so, it is a functioning thing that arises in dependence on a collection of causes and conditions such as a face, a mirror and light. Moreover, a reflection generates a consciousness perceiving its aspect. Thus, reflections and so forth, which are empty of inherent existence, produce effects such as eye consciousnesses, which are also empty of inherent existence. In just the same way, although all things are empty of inherent existence nevertheless from these empty causes empty effects are generated.

If things were inherently existent they would never produce effects because they would never change. Similarly, they would not be produced because they would not depend on anything else. Therefore those who deny lack of inherent existence cannot establish cause and effect. As Nagarjuna says in Fundamental Wisdom:

For whom emptiness is impossible

For them everything is impossible.

Indeed everything, including samsara, nirvana and the four noble truths, would be impossible. Again Nagarjuna says:

It follows that even the four noble truths

Are non-existent for him.

The four noble truths exist just because they lack inherent existence. Thus there is the dependent relationship of karma and delusion producing suffering, the dependent relationship of wisdom leading to liberation and so forth. If things were inherently existent, such dependent relationships would be impossible because inherently existent things do not depend on anything else. Cause and effect is a gross dependent relationship. Subtle dependent relationship is the dependence of all phenomena on imputation by conceptual thought. Both gross and subtle dependent relationships exist only because phenomena lack inherent existence.

Naropa

The Good Qualities of this Refutation

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF REFUTING INHERENTLY EXISTENT PRODUCTION WITHIN BOTH TRUTHS

This section has two parts:

1 The good quality of easily avoiding extreme views

2 The good quality of great consistency with cause and effect

THE GOOD QUALITY OF EASILY AVOIDING EXTREME VIEWS

[VI.38cd] And since they lack inherent existence in both truths

They are neither permanent nor annihilated.

Whereas those who assert inherently existent production fall into the two extremes of existence and non-existence, those who refute inherently existent production both ultimately and nominally are led to the view of the middle way that avoids both extremes. Since all things lack inherent existence they are free from the extreme of existence and since they are nominally existent they are free from the extreme of non-existence. By meditating on this we will eventually realize the union of the two truths and be led from samsara to a state of enlightenment. These are the special qualities of refuting inherently existent production, and especially production from other.

THE GOOD QUALITY OF GREAT CONSISTENCY WITH CAUSE AND EFFECT

This section has three parts:

1 Not asserting inherent existence does not entail acceptance of a consciousness-basis-of-all and so forth

2 Showing by analogy how an effect arises after an action has ceased

3 Rejecting arguments against this

NOT ASSERTING INHERENT EXISTENCE DOES NOT ENTAIL ACCEPTANCE OF A CONSCIOUSNESS-BASIS-OF-ALL AND SO FORTH

[VI.39] Since it does not inherently cease

It has ability even though there is no basis-of-all.

Thus you should know that an appropriate effect will arise

Even though, in some cases, a long time elapses after an action has ceased.

For those who assert inherent existence there is the problem of how a karmic effect can arise from an action that ceased a long time ago, in some cases many aeons ago. The solution proposed by the Chittamatrins and by some Madhyamika-Svatantrikas is as follows. When an action ceases an imprint is stored at a deep level of consciousness where it remains as a potential until conditions for it to ripen are encountered. This deep level of consciousness, which is known as the ‘consciousness-basis-of-all’, has three principal characteristics – (1) it is a stable mind that passes from one life to another bearing the entire store of karmic imprints accumulated during previous lives and so is the basis for the continuity of actions and their effects, (2) it is the basis for storing potentials from which various minds and their appearances arise and (3) it is the self, or person.

Those who assert a consciousness-basis-of-all say that if such a consciousness did not exist there would be no basis for preserving karmic imprints from one life to another and so there would be the fault of actions being exhausted without their effects having been experienced. They also assert a deluded mentality that is related to the consciousness-basis-of-all. This is a self-grasping mind that takes the consciousness-basis-of-all as its observed object and conceives a self-supporting, substantially existent self. Therefore according to these schools there are eight different types of consciousness – the six consciousnesses asserted by the other Buddhist schools, the consciousness-basis-of-all and the deluded mentality.

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school, however, it is both unnecessary and erroneous to posit a consciousness-basis-of-all. It is not the case that without a consciousness-basis-of-all actions are exhausted without their effects having been experienced. When an action ceases it does not inherently cease. Therefore the cessation of an action can produce an effect even though there is no consciousness-basis-of-all. From every action that is performed an appropriate effect will eventually arise even though in some cases a long time elapses between the original action and the maturation of its effect.

How is it that the cessation of an action produces an effect? The cessation of an action occurs in dependence on causes. If there were nothing to cause the cessation of actions, actions would never cease and so absurdly they would be permanent. However, since actions do cease, the cessation of an action has a cause. Since whatever has a cause is a functioning thing, and whatever is a functioning thing produces its own effect, it follows that the cessation of an action is a functioning thing that produces an effect.

The cessation of all things occurs in dependence on causes. For example, in Dependent Relationship Sutra Buddha says:

Because of birth there is ageing and death.

This shows that death has a cause and therefore must produce an effect. Because cessation occurs in dependence on causes it is not inherently existent. If cessation were inherently existent it would never occur. If there were no cessation there would be no past, present or future. Thus in a world of inherent existence there would be no time. However, because cessation is not inherently existent but is a functioning thing it follows that past, present and future are also functioning things.

This presentation of the three times is unique to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school and is not easily understood by the lower schools. The Vaibhashikas, for example, believe that the three times are particular instances of one substance. They say that the substance of the sprout existing at the time of the seed is the future of the seed, the substance of the seed existing at the time of the sprout is the past of the sprout and the substance of the sprout existing at the time of the sprout is the present of the sprout. Since past, present and future are substances they are functioning things and impermanent.

The Vaibhashikas assert that when a seed transforms into a sprout the aspect of the seed changes but its essential substance remains the same. Similarly, if a gold coin is melted down and made into an ornament the aspect of the gold changes but its substance remains the same. All the higher Buddhist schools find fault with this assertion. They say that it is impossible for the substance of a sprout to exist separately from the sprout. Therefore, to say that the substance of the sprout exists at the time of the seed is tantamount to saying that the sprout exists at the time of the seed.

The Sautrantikas and Madhyamika-Svatantrikas say that past and future are non-affirming negatives and permanent phenomena and that present is a functioning thing and impermanent. According to the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas, the definition of past is that part of a thing that has been produced and already ceased. An example is a seed at the time of its sprout. They say that this is a non-affirming negative because all that is realized by the mind apprehending it is the non-existence of a seed that formerly existed. There are three types of past – pasts of forms, consciousnesses and non-associated compositional factors. The definition of future is that part of a thing that is to be produced but not yet produced. An example is a sprout at the time of its seed. There are three types of future – futures of forms, consciousnesses and non-associated compositional factors. All futures are also non-affirming negatives and permanent. The definition of present is that part of a thing that is produced and not yet ceased. Examples are the seed itself, or the sprout itself. There are three types of present – forms, consciousnesses and non-associated compositional factors.

The definitions and divisions of the three times given by the Madhyamika-Prasangikas are the same as those given by the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas but the Madhyamika-Prasangikas explain them in quite a different way. They do not accept that past and future are non-affirming negatives but assert all three times to be functioning things. To understand this we need to contemplate carefully the following reasoning.

If someone were to ask, for example, ‘Is the Emanation Body of Buddha Shakyamuni past, present, or future?’ most of us would reply that it is past. We would say this because it is past with respect to us, but why should we regard our position in time as more valid than anyone else’s? For example, from the point of view of those alive at the time of Buddha Shakyamuni his Emanation Body is a present and from the point of view of those alive at the time of Buddha Kashyapa it is a future. Thus, if we judge time from the point of view of the observer we have to say that Buddha’s Emanation Body is a past, a present and a future! This problem arises only because we judge time from the point of view of ourself rather than from the point of view of the object.

According to the Madhyamika-Prasangikas there are no past things and no future things; all functioning things are necessarily present. However, there are pasts of things and futures of things, and these are functioning things because they are produced from causes and produce effects. A seed, for example, is a present but it has a past and a future. The past of the seed is the cessation of the seed. Even though this cessation is a past at the time of the seed it is a future and when the seed is destroyed it is a present. Thus, the past of a seed is a functioning thing that exists after that seed has ceased. Similarly, the future of a seed is a functioning thing that exists before that seed exists. Before the seed exists the future of the seed is a present but at the time of the seed it is a past.

Altogether there are eight profound points unique to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school that are not easily understood by the lower schools. They are:

(1) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence there is no consciousness-basis-of-all

(2) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence there are no self-cognizers

(3) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence there are no inherently existent conclusive reasons that possess the three modes

(4) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence there are external objects

(5) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence Hearers and Solitary Realizers realize the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena

(6) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence self-grasping of phenomena is a delusion

(7) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence cessation is a functioning thing

(8) Since all phenomena lack inherent existence the three times are functioning things

All eight points are explained in this book. The third, fifth sixth, seventh and eighth have already been explained. The first has been touched on and will be explained in greater detail below, along with the second and fourth.

SHOWING BY ANALOGY HOW AN EFFECT ARISES AFTER AN ACTION HAS CEASED

[VI.40] Having seen the observed object of a dream

A fool will generate attachment even when awake.

Likewise, there is still an effect from an action

Even though it lacks inherent existence and has ceased.

We can understand how an action that has ceased produces an effect by considering the following analogy. Suppose a foolish man with strong attachment sees a beautiful woman in his dreams and when he awakes continues to generate attachment for her. Even though the dream woman lacked inherent existence and even though she has ceased by the time he awakes, nevertheless she still produces an effect by generating attachment in his mind. Likewise, even though an action lacks inherent existence and even though there is no consciousness-basis-of-all the action still produces an effect after it has ceased.

REJECTING ARGUMENTS AGAINST THIS

This section has two parts:

1 Rejecting the argument that the ripening of the effect would be endless

2 Rejecting the argument of contradiction with the scriptures that reveal a consciousness-basis-of-all

REJECTING THE ARGUMENT THAT THE RIPENING OF THE EFFECT WOULD BE ENDLESS

Objection You say that when an action ceases it does not inherently cease, but if actions did not inherently cease the process of an action producing an effect would never stop and so the ripening of effects would be endless.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.41] Although the objects are similar in not existing,

Nevertheless one with floaters sees the appearance of floating hairs

But not the appearance of other things.

In the same way, you should understand that ripened actions cannot ripen again.

[VI.42] Thus it is seen that non-virtuous ripening is from non-virtuous actions

And virtuous ripening is from virtuous actions.

Those who realize that virtue and non-virtue do not exist will be liberated.

However, analyzing actions and their effects is discouraged.

What you say does not follow because actions produce definite effects. For example there are many causes of mistaken awareness. Some, such as floaters, cause the appearance of floating hairs, whereas others, such as pressure on the eyeball, cause the appearance of two moons, etc. However, even though these spurious objects are all similar in not existing, a person with floaters sees the appearance of floating hairs but not the appearance of other things such as two moons. This helps us to understand how an action that has already ripened cannot ripen again. Thus, even though both virtuous and non-virtuous actions are similar in not inherently ceasing, nevertheless unpleasant effects arise from non-virtuous actions and pleasant effects arise from virtuous actions. Since the effects of actions are definite, the process of their effects ripening cannot be endless. Those who realize that virtuous and non-virtuous actions do not exist inherently will quickly eradicate self-grasping and thereby attain liberation from samsara.

The subtle relationships between particular actions and their effects are very difficult to realize. In the Sutras, Buddha says:

The fully-ripened effects of actions are inconceivable.

If ordinary beings try to understand the subtle relationships of actions and their effects through detailed analysis there is a great danger of their developing wrong views and rejecting karma entirely. Therefore Buddha advised us against over-analysis of actions and their effects, encouraging us instead to rely on the scriptures for our understanding of such points.

REJECTING THE ARGUMENT OF CONTRADICTION WITH THE SCRIPTURES THAT REVEAL A CONSCIOUSNESS-BASIS-OF-ALL

This section has two parts:

1 The actual rejection of the argument of contradiction with the scriptures

2 An analogy of speech through the power of intention

THE ACTUAL REJECTION OF THE ARGUMENT OF CONTRADICTION WITH THE SCRIPTURES

Chittamatrins In saying that actions and their effects can be established without a consciousness-basis-of-all you contradict Interpreting the Intention Sutra in which it says that the consciousness-basis-of-all is the basis of actions and their effects.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.43] ‘Basis-of-all exists’, ‘Person exists’,

‘These aggregates alone exist’ –

These teachings are for those

Who cannot understand this very profound meaning.

It is true that Buddha taught that consciousness-basis-of-all exists. He also taught that a substantially existent person exists and that the aggregates alone truly exist. However, all these teachings require interpretation because they were given not according to Buddha’s final intention but according to the capacities and inclinations of disciples who do not understand the very profound meaning of emptiness just explained.

AN ANALOGY OF SPEECH THROUGH THE POWER OF INTENTION

[VI.44] Even though he is free from the view of the transitory collection

Buddha reveals ‘I’ and ‘mine’.

In the same way, even though things lack inherent existence

‘Existence’ is revealed as an interpretative meaning.

Buddha’s purpose in teaching consciousness-basis-of-all and inherently existent phenomena such as inherently existent other-powered phenomena even though they do not exist was gradually to guide his disciples who are inclined to believe in these things to a correct realization of lack of inherent existence. Since Buddha often taught according to the inclinations of his disciples, not all his words have a definitive meaning. For example, even though he is free from the view of the transitory collection and its imprints and has abandoned all conceptions grasping at I and mine, nevertheless Buddha reveals these through his use of expressions like ‘I’ and ‘mine’. In the same way, even though things are not inherently existent Buddha reveals inherent existence as a teaching of interpretative meaning. Therefore the refutation of consciousness-basis-of-all and the refutation of inherent existence do not contradict these scriptures.

Atisha

Refuting the Chittamatra System

A REFUTATION OF THE CHITTAMATRA SYSTEM IN PARTICULAR

As mentioned before, all the Buddhist schools below the Madhyamika-Prasangikas assert production from other, and their assertions are generally refuted by the refutation presented above. However Chandrakirti uses the occasion of the refutation of production from other to provide an extensive refutation of the Chittamatra system in particular. This refutation, which takes the form of a debate between the Chittamatrins and the Madhyamika-Prasangikas, is presented in three parts:

1 Refuting an inherently existent consciousness without externals

2 Refuting the validity of the reason establishing other-powered phenomena as inherently existent

3 The word ‘only’ in ‘mind only’ does not exclude external objects

REFUTING AN INHERENTLY EXISTENT CONSCIOUSNESS WITHOUT EXTERNALS

This section has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

STATING THE OTHER SYSTEM

The following verses summarize the main points of the Chittamatra position:

Chittamatrins

[VI.45] ‘An apprehender is not seen without an apprehended.

By realizing the three realms as mere consciousness

The Bodhisattva abiding in wisdom

Realizes thatness in mere consciousness.

[VI.46] Just as waves arise from a great ocean

When it is stirred by the wind,

Likewise, because of its potentials a mere consciousness arises

From the seed of all, which is called ‘basis-of-all’.

[VI.47] Therefore whatever is an other-powered entity

Is the cause of imputedly existent things.

It arises without external objects, exists,

And has the nature of not being an object of any elaboration.’

No object exists without being apprehended by a subjective mind, and a subjective mind cannot exist without an apprehended object. Objects are empty of being separate entities from their minds and minds are empty of being separate entities from their objects. This emptiness, which is called the ‘non-duality of apprehended and apprehender’, is the profound emptiness that is the door to liberation. A more subtle emptiness does not exist. A Bodhisattva on the sixth ground realizes that all phenomena of the three realms are merely the nature of consciousness and in this way realizes the thatness of non-duality and experiences all the good qualities of the surpassing perfection of wisdom.

All things such as forms and the minds that apprehend them arise from the ripening of their potentials on the consciousness-basis-of-all. Therefore forms do not exist externally to the mind. For example, when we see a blue object a potential for a mind to which blue appears is placed on the consciousness-basis-of-all. When this potential subsequently ripens a mere consciousness to which blue appears arises. Both the mind and its aspect, blue, are generated simultaneously from the same potential. Since blue arises entirely from a potential on the consciousness-basis-of-all it is not an external object but is the same nature as the mind that apprehends it. Just as waves that arise from a great ocean when it is stirred by the wind are not a separate substance from the ocean, so forms that arise from potentials on the consciousness-basis-of-all are not a separate substance from the mind. Everything is the nature of mind; nothing exists externally to the mind.

Even though there are no external objects all other-powered phenomena are truly existent entities. An other-powered phenomenon is anything that is generated from causes and conditions. Other-powered phenomenon and functioning thing are synonyms. An eye consciousness apprehending blue is an example of a truly existent other-powered phenomenon. It is an other-powered phenomenon because it arises in dependence on causes and conditions that are other than it. It is truly existent for three reasons:

(1) It arises from its own cause, a potential on the consciousness-basis-of-all, without there being any external objects.

(2) In dependence on this eye consciousness, a conceptual mind is generated that conceives the eye consciousness and its object, blue, to be different entities. This is a self-grasping mind and a wrong awareness. Its conceived object – subject and object being different entities – is a fictitious entity merely imputed by the mind.

(3) It is not the direct object of speech or conception and therefore has the nature of not being the object of any elaboration.

All things such as visual forms, sounds, smells, tastes and tactile objects arise from potentials on the consciousness-basis-of-all and so they are all the same nature as the mind that apprehends them and they are all truly existent.

REFUTING THIS SYSTEM

This section has two parts:

1 An extensive presentation of the refutation

2 The conclusion from this refutation

AN EXTENSIVE PRESENTATION OF THE REFUTATION

This section has three parts:

1 Refuting examples of a truly existent consciousness without external objects

2 Refuting a consciousness generated from its potential

3 This refutation and meditation on unattractiveness are not contradictory

REFUTING EXAMPLES OF A TRULY EXISTENT CONSCIOUSNESS WITHOUT EXTERNAL OBJECTS

This section has two parts:

1 Refuting the example of a dream

2 Refuting the example of seeing floating hairs

REFUTING THE EXAMPLE OF A DREAM

This section has three parts:

1 The example of a dream does not prove that consciousness is truly existent

2 The example of a dream does not prove that there are no external objects when awake

3 The example of a dream proves that all things are false

THE EXAMPLE OF A DREAM DOES NOT PROVE THAT CONSCIOUSNESS IS TRULY EXISTENT

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.48] Where is there an example of a mind without an external object?

If you say it is like a dream then let us consider that.

For us, mind does not exist even when dreaming;

Therefore you do not have an example.

[VI.49] If mind exists because we remember the dream when awake,

Then it is the same with external objects.

Just as according to you we remember, thinking, ‘I saw’,

So, like that, external objects also exist.

Do you Chittamatrins have an example of a truly existent mind without external objects?

Chittamatrins Yes, we have a perfect example. Suppose you fall asleep in a small room and dream of an elephant. Clearly the object of the dream, an elephant in the room, does not exist and yet there is a truly existent mind to which it appears. In a similar way, even though external objects do not exist there are truly existent minds to which they appear.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas Let us consider this example. You say that the object of the dream does not exist and yet the dream mind truly exists. According to our system however neither the elephant nor the mind truly exists at any time, either when dreaming or when awake. Therefore you do not have a correct example.

Chittamatrins The dream mind must truly exist because we can remember the experience of the dream when awake.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas Then it is just the same with external objects. For example, according to you the dream mind truly exists because we remember it by thinking, ‘I saw an elephant.’ In that case the object of the dream, the elephant, also truly exists because we remember that as well. Thus if a mind truly exists its object also truly exists. Since according to you the mind to which external objects appear truly exists, it follows that the external objects that appear to that mind also truly exist. On the other hand, if you want to say that external objects do not truly exist you will also have to say that mind does not truly exist either. Therefore you are wrong to assert that there is a truly existent mind without external objects.

THE EXAMPLE OF A DREAM DOES NOT PROVE THAT THERE ARE NO EXTERNAL OBJECTS WHEN AWAKE

Chittamatrins

[VI.50] ‘Because eye awareness is impossible in sleep, it does not exist,

Only mental awareness exists;

Yet its aspect is conceived as external.

As it is in dreams, so it is here.’

When we are asleep the sense awarenesses do not function; only the mental awareness functions. Therefore an object of eye awareness does not exist at that time; all dream appearances are mere appearances to the mental awareness. For example, dream blue is a mere aspect that appears directly to the mental awareness. Dreamers, however, conceive that blue to be an external object. Even though dreamers conceive there to be external objects, in reality there are no external objects in a dream. It is exactly the same when we are awake. Even though ordinary beings conceive there to be external objects, in reality there are no external objects.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.51] If you say this, then just as for you external objects are not produced in dreams,

So mind too is not produced.

The eyes, the visual object and the mind they generate –

All three are also false.

[VI.52a] And those three of the remainder, ears and so forth, are also not produced.

You say that external objects are not inherently produced in dreams. Well, the same is true of the mental awareness – it too is not inherently produced in dreams. The eye sense power of the dream, the visual object of the dream and the dream mind that they generate are all false objects because they do not appear in the way that they exist. It is the same with the other dream sense powers, dream sense objects and dream sense awarenesses. For example, dream ears, dream sounds and the dream mind that they generate are also not inherently produced. Thus, the example of the dream does not prove that there are no external objects when awake – it proves that there is no inherently existent mind when asleep.

THE EXAMPLE OF A DREAM PROVES THAT ALL THINGS ARE FALSE

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.52bcd] Just as when dreaming, so here when awake, things are false.

That mind does not exist, objects of enjoyment do not exist

And the sense powers do not exist.

[VI.53] Here, as when awake,

So when not awake these three exist;

And on waking all three no longer exist.

It is just the same when waking from the sleep of confusion.

Just as minds, objects and sense powers are false when dreaming, so too they are false when awake because even during the waking state these things do not appear as they exist. Thus, whether awake or asleep minds do not inherently exist, objects enjoyed by the senses do not inherently exist, and the sense powers do not inherently exist.

Dream minds, objects and sense powers exist with respect to the dreaming mind during sleep in much the same way as waking minds, objects and sense powers exist with respect to the waking mind when awake. When we wake from sleep the minds, objects and sense powers of the dream cease to exist with respect to the waking mind. In the same way, when we wake from the sleep of confusion the minds, objects and sense powers of the waking state cease to exist with respect to the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. This shows that all things that exist, both when dreaming and when awake, are false. Therefore you should not say that consciousness is truly existent but external objects are not.

As mentioned before, when a Superior being is in meditative equipoise all dualistic appearance subsides into emptiness. With respect to that wisdom conventional phenomena such as minds, sense objects and sense powers do not exist. If they were truly existent they would definitely appear to that mind because whatever is true must appear to an exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. Therefore, minds, sense objects and sense powers are all false objects because they do not appear to the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. In fact all the conventional phenomena of the base, the path and the result are false objects. As Venerable Milarepa says:

From the point of view of ultimate truth,

Even Buddhas do not exist.

Meditators, objects of meditation,

Grounds and paths also do not exist.

The resultant body and wisdom do not exist.

Therefore beyond sorrow does not exist.

All these are merely imputed words and names.

All environments and their beings of the three worlds

Have not existed from the beginning and are not produced.

There is no foundation and no simultaneous production.

There are no actions and no ripening of actions.

Therefore there is not even the name ‘samsara’.
