I have perceived that all this is the ultimate meaning.

REFUTING THE EXAMPLE OF SEEING FLOATING HAIRS

Chittamatrins There is another example of a truly existent consciousness without external objects. When a person with floaters develops an eye consciousness seeing hairs floating in front of his eyes, a truly existent mind is generated within his continuum, but its object, floating hairs, does not exist at all.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.54] A mind of sense powers affected by floaters

And the hairs seen due to those floaters

Are both true with respect to that mind,

But both are false with respect to one who sees objects clearly.

[VI.55] If mind exists without an object of knowledge

Then when his eyes focus on the place of those hairs

Even one without floaters will generate a mind of floating hairs.

Since this is not the case, it does not exist.

For a person whose eye sense power is affected by floaters, both the mind seeing floating hairs in the space in front and the floating hairs themselves are truly existent with respect to that mind, but they are both false with respect to the mind of a person who sees objects clearly. When a person with clear sight looks at that place neither floating hairs nor a mind to which floating hairs appears arises for him. Therefore, the mind with floaters and the floating hairs that appear to it are either both truly existent or both false. It is not appropriate to say that one is truly existent while the other is false.

You Chittamatrins say that although there is no object of knowledge, floating hairs, nevertheless the mind to which they appear truly exists. If this is the case then if a person with clear sight looks at the place where the hairs are seen, he too will generate a mind seeing floating hairs. This is because a mind seeing floating hairs is inherently produced and does not depend on anything else to generate it. After all, the floating hairs are equally non-existent for both the mind with floaters and the mind with clear sight. However, a person with clear sight does not generate a mind seeing floating hairs; therefore a truly existent mind without externals does not exist.

REFUTING A CONSCIOUSNESS GENERATED FROM ITS POTENTIAL

This section has three parts:

1 Refuting that a consciousness to which an external object appears is generated or not generated from the ripening or non-ripening of imprints

2 Again refuting that consciousness exists without external objects

3 The refutation of the Chittamatra system is not damaged by the scriptures

REFUTING THAT A CONSCIOUSNESS TO WHICH AN EXTERNAL OBJECT APPEARS IS GENERATED OR NOT GENERATED FROM THE RIPENING OR NON-RIPENING OF IMPRINTS

This section has two parts:

1 Stating the other position

2 Refuting this position

STATING THE OTHER POSITION

Chittamatrins

[VI.56abc] ‘The observer does not have that mind

Because he does not have a ripened potential for it,

Not because of the absence of a thing existing as an object of knowledge.’

An observer with clear sight does not generate a mind seeing floating hairs because he does not have a ripened potential for that mind, not because there are no floating hairs. Just as we would not say that a mind seeing floating hairs is generated because floating hairs exist, so we do not say that a mind seeing floating hairs is not generated because floating hairs do not exist. If a potential for a mind seeing floating hairs ripens, that mind is generated; if it does not ripen, that mind is not generated. So even though mind is truly existent there is a difference between someone who has a ripened potential to see floating hairs and someone who does not. Therefore it does not follow that a person with clear sight will generate a mind seeing floating hairs.

REFUTING THIS POSITION

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.56d] If you say this, it cannot be proven because that potential does not exist.

You say that there is a difference between a mind seeing floating hairs being generated because the potential for it has ripened and a mind seeing floating hairs not being generated because a potential for it has not ripened. However this cannot be proven because a potential producing an inherently existent mind does not exist. An inherently existent mind does not depend on anything, even a potential, for its production so there can be no potential for an inherently existent mind. Furthermore, there is no inherently existent potential with respect to a present mind, no inherently existent potential for a future mind and no inherently existent potential with respect to the past.

This will now be explained extensively under the following three headings:

1 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the present

2 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the future

3 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the past

REFUTING AN INHERENTLY EXISTENT POTENTIAL WITH RESPECT TO THE PRESENT

[VI.57a] A potential for the produced is impossible.

If there is a potential with respect to a present mind it is either a different entity from that mind or the same entity as that mind. If the mind and its potential are different entities then since, according to you, they are inherently existent they are inherently different and therefore completely unrelated and it is not possible for a potential to be a cause of something to which it is not related. If the mind and its potential are the same entity, then there are the faults of simultaneous cause and effect and production from self. Therefore a potential for a mind that is already produced is impossible.

REFUTING AN INHERENTLY EXISTENT POTENTIAL WITH RESPECT TO THE FUTURE

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.57bcd] And there is also no potential for an unproduced entity.

Without characteristics there is no possessor of characteristics,

Otherwise it would exist for a child of a childless woman.

There is also no potential for an inherently existent mind that is not yet produced. If a future mind exists at the same time as its potential then there are the faults of simultaneous cause and effect and production from self. If it does not exist at the same time as its potential it follows that there is a time when the mind does not exist, in which case it will never exist. If an inherently existent mind does not exist at one time it will never exist. If first a thing does not exist and then it comes into existence, this is a perfect indication that it lacks inherent existence. However, since according to you a future mind is inherently existent it follows that it does not exist at all, and if the mind does not exist, its potential also does not exist. If the characteristics, in this case a future mind, do not exist, the possessor of characteristics, a potential for that mind, also does not exist; otherwise a potential for a child of a childless woman would exist.

Chittamatrins A future mind does not exist at the same time as its potential because a future mind is yet to come. It is precisely because the mind will come in the future that we say a potential for it exists in the present. Therefore we do not incur this fault.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.58ab] If you want to state it in terms of what is to come,

Then without a potential it will never arise.

An inherently existent mind cannot depend on anything. Being inherently existent and depending on a potential are contradictory. Therefore, if a future mind is inherently existent it has no potential for its production, and without such a potential that mind will never arise. Thus you do incur the fault mentioned above.

Chittamatrins Even though a future mind and its potential do not exist simultaneously, nevertheless they exist by way of mutual dependence because one is the cause and the other is its effect.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.58cd] The holy ones have said

That whatever exists in mutual dependence does not exist.

If a future mind and its potential are mutually dependent they are not inherently existent. The holy ones such as Buddha Shakyamuni and Protector Nagarjuna have said that whatever exists in mutual dependence does not inherently exist.

REFUTING AN INHERENTLY EXISTENT POTENTIAL WITH RESPECT TO THE PAST

Chittamatrins A future mind arises from a ripened potential on the consciousness-basis-of-all. That potential remains from a previous mind of a similar type that has now ceased.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.59] If it comes from the ripened potential of what has ceased,

Then other arises from the potential of other.

For you, possessors of continuums exist in mutual difference;

Therefore everything arises from everything.

Because, according to your system, the possessor of the continuum of an earlier mind is inherently different from that of a later mind, it follows that the future mind arises from the potential of an inherently existent other mind. If earlier and later minds are inherently existent other, they are completely unrelated. If an effect arises from a cause that is completely unrelated to it, then thick darkness arises from flames and everything arises from everything. The consequence of excess applies because you are asserting production from inherently existent other.

Chittamatrins Even though the possessor of the earlier continuum is inherently different from that of the later continuum, this does not mean that they have different continuums. Both have the same continuum and so they are not unrelated. Therefore we do not incur the fault that everything arises from everything.

This is the Chittamatrins’ principal defence against the charge that the consequence of excess applies to their presentation of production from other.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.60] If you say that there, different possessors of continuums

Do not have different continuums and so there is no fault,

This cannot be proven,

For there is no possibility of a non-different continuum.

[VI.61] Phenomena dependent on Maitreya and Upayagupta

Are not included in the same continuum because they are other.

Thus it is not reasonable that whatever are different by way of their own characteristics

Are included within the same continuum.

You cannot prove your assertion because there is no possibility of two inherently existent other phenomena having the same continuum. If, as you say, the earlier and later minds are inherently existent then they are completely unrelated and there is no sense in which they can be said to have the same continuum. For example, because two people called Maitreya and Upayagupta are unrelated they are not the same continuum. Therefore, it is not reasonable to assert that earlier and later things that are inherently different are included in the same continuum.

AGAIN REFUTING THAT CONSCIOUSNESS EXISTS WITHOUT EXTERNAL OBJECTS

This section has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

STATING THE OTHER SYSTEM

Chittamatrins

[VI.62] ‘The production of an eye consciousness

Arises entirely from its immediate potential.

A potential that is the basis for its consciousness

Is called the ‘‘eye’’, a sense power possessing form.

[VI.63] Here, when consciousness arises from a sense power,

Appearances such as blue arise from their seeds

Without there being external objects.

Not realizing this, beings think they are external objects.

[VI.64] Just as when dreaming, without there being another form,

A mind with an aspect of that arises from the ripening of its potential,

Likewise, here, when awake,

Mind exists without there being external objects.’

Even though there are no external objects, nevertheless the five sense consciousnesses, the five sense powers and the five objects of the senses exist. For example, an eye consciousness apprehending blue is produced entirely from its potential, an imprint of a previous eye consciousness apprehending blue. That imprint was placed on the consciousness-basis-of-all immediately the previous eye consciousness apprehending blue ceased. A potential that acts as the basis for an eye consciousness apprehending blue is an eye sense power possessing form and is the dominant condition of that eye consciousness. The remaining four sense powers can be understood in the same way.

Just as sense powers exist without there being any external objects, so do sense objects such as colours, sounds and smells. For example, when an eye consciousness apprehending blue arises from its sense power, a potential on the consciousness-basis-of-all, its object, the appearance of blue, also arises from that same potential. Thus, what we call colours, sounds, smells and so forth are only appearances to the mind that arise from imprints on the consciousness-basis-of-all; they do not exist outside the mind. Not realizing this, ordinary beings think that they are external objects.

To understand how forms such as blue exist we should consider what happens when we dream, say, of an elephant. The elephant in our dream is not outside the mind because there is no elephant in the room, it is not the mind itself because it is not an awareness and it is not separate from the mind because if the mind apprehending the elephant ceases the elephant disappears. The elephant is just an appearance to mind that is otherwise indescribable. In the same way, forms such as blue are not outside the mind, are not the mind itself and are not separate from the mind, they are mere appearances to mind that are otherwise indescribable.

It is essential to realize that all forms are merely the nature of mind. When we see a car, for example, we should realize that it is merely an appearance to the consciousness-basis-of-all – it does not exist outside the mind. External objects are the subtle object of negation of emptiness and the mind that conceives them is self-grasping of phenomena and the source of all delusions. An object’s lack of being a separate entity from the mind is ultimate emptiness, the subtle selflessness of phenomena, and the mind that directly realizes this is the wisdom that destroys all delusions and leads to liberation.

Even though external objects do not exist, nevertheless we generate inherently existent minds to which they appear. For example, if we dream of blue, even though there is no blue outside the mind we generate an inherently existent mind with an aspect of blue merely from the ripening of its potential on the consciousness-basis-of-all. In the same way, when we are awake we generate inherently existent minds to which external objects appear, even though there are no external objects.

REFUTING THIS SYSTEM

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.65] If, as you say, mental consciousness with appearances such as blue

Arises in dreams where there are no eyes,

Why is it not also generated from the ripening of potentials

In blind people here, where there is no eye sense power?

If a mental consciousness with a clear appearance of blue arises merely from the ripening of its potential in dreams where there is no eye sense power, presumably such a mind also arises even for blind people during their dreams. If so, why do blind people not generate such a mind from ripening potentials when they are awake? After all, for a blind person both the dream state and the waking state are the same in that there is no eye sense power during either.

Chittamatrins It is true that blind people lack eye sense powers, and it is true that they possess potentials both when dreaming and when awake; however, a potential for a sixth consciousness, a mental consciousness to which forms appear clearly, will ripen for them only in dreams. This is because for blind people the conditions for such a potential to ripen exist during dreams, but not when awake. Therefore it does not follow that blind people can generate such minds when awake.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.66] If you say a potential for the sixth

Ripens in dreams but not when awake,

Then just as there is no ripening of a potential for the sixth here,

Why not say there is none during dreams?

You would be more consistent if you said that just as there are no conditions for the ripening of a potential for a sixth mental consciousness to which forms appear clearly in blind people when they are awake, so there are no conditions for such a mind to ripen during dreams because you have no valid reason establishing the existence of these conditions during dreams.

Chittamatrins Of course we have a valid reason. Blind people generate a mental consciousness to which forms appear clearly during their dreams because sleep, which is the condition for its potential to ripen, exists at that time.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.67] Just as lack of eyes is not the cause of this,

So too in dreams sleep is not the cause.

Therefore you should say that in dreams too

Things and eyes are the causes of false subjective realizers.

Just as lack of eyes is not the cause of the ripening of a potential for this mind in a blind person who is awake, so too sleep is not the cause of that potential ripening in dreams because, according to you, a dream mind is inherently existent and does not depend on causes.

In reality of course dream minds are not inherently existent but are generated in dependence on causes and conditions, just like waking minds. In the waking state, things such as forms meet with sense powers such as eyes and generate minds such as an eye consciousness. Therefore, if you want to be precise you should say that in dreams too false things such as dream forms meet with false sense powers such as dream eyes, and are the causes of false subjective realizers such as a dream eye consciousness.

Although there is no eye sense power and therefore no eye consciousness or object of eye consciousness during dreams there can be a mental consciousness to which forms appear clearly. This is called a ‘dream eye consciousness’. Its dominant condition, or sense power, is called a ‘dream eye’ and the object that appears to it is called a ‘dream form’. A dream eye is not a real eye and a dream eye consciousness is not a real eye consciousness, but a dream form is a real form because it is a form that is a phenomena source. Forms that do not appear to the eye consciousness of ordinary beings but which appear clearly to their mental consciousness are phenomena sources.

There are twelve sources, which include all objects of knowledge. Within these, there are six object sources – form source, sound source, smell source, taste source, tactile object source and phenomena source – and six power sources – eye source, ear source, nose source, tongue source, body source and mentality source. They are called ‘sources’ because they are the sources of consciousness.

The definition of form source is an object experienced by eye consciousness. An example is the blue of the sky. The definition of sound source is an object experienced by ear consciousness. An example is the sound of a musical instrument. The definition of smell source is an object experienced by nose consciousness. An example is the fragrance of a rose. The definition of taste source is an object experienced by tongue consciousness. An example is the taste of honey. The definition of tactile object source is an object experienced by body consciousness. An example is the smoothness of skin. The definition of phenomena source is an object of mental consciousness that is other than the first five sources. An example is mind. Thus, not all forms are form sources. For example, an elephant in a dream does not appear to an ordinary eye consciousness and so it is not a form source, but it does appear clearly to the mental consciousness and so it is a phenomena source.

The definition of eye source is a sense power possessing form that principally and directly generates its own effect, an eye consciousness. It is the inner energy power in the very centre of the eye organ that functions directly to generate eye awareness. The definition of ear source is a sense power possessing form that principally and directly generates its own effect, an ear consciousness. It is the inner energy power in the very centre of the ear organ that functions directly to generate ear awareness. The definition of nose source is a sense power possessing form that principally and directly generates its own effect, a nose consciousness. It is the inner energy power in the very centre of the nose organ that functions directly to generate nose awareness. The definition of tongue source is a sense power possessing form that principally and directly generates its own effect, a tongue consciousness. It is the inner energy power in the very centre of the tongue organ that functions directly to generate tongue awareness. The definition of body source is a sense power possessing form that principally and directly generates its own effect, a body consciousness. It is the inner energy power pervading the entire body that functions directly to generate body awareness, which also pervades the entire body. The definition of mentality source is a power that lacks form and that principally and directly generates its own effect, a mental consciousness. An example is any consciousness that principally and directly generates a mental consciousness. Eye source and eye sense power are synonymous, ear source and ear sense power are synonymous and so on.

There are six consciousnesses that are generated in dependence on these six object sources and six power sources. They are the eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness and mental consciousness. As explained previously, the Chittamatrins assert eight consciousnesses because they say there are three types of mental consciousness – the sixth mental consciousness, the consciousness-basis-of-all and the deluded mentality. They have three reasons for asserting a consciousness-basis-of-all:

(1) it is the basis for conveying karmic potentialities from one life to another

(2) since there are no external objects it is the basis for storing potentials from which the various minds and their appearances arise

(3) it is the very continuity of a person from one life to another and so it is the self.

These reasons are refuted by the Madhyamika-Prasangikas as follows:

(1) The Chittamatrins have invented a consciousness-basis-of-all that is a repository of karmic potentials awaiting the conditions to ripen because they do not understand how an action that has ceased produces an effect. In reality karmic potentials are borne from one life to another by the mere I and there is no need to posit a consciousness-basis-of-all to explain this.

(2) Since external objects exist, a consciousness such as an eye consciousness is generated by an object meeting a sense power, and not from potentials stored on the consciousness-basis-of-all. There is no need to posit a consciousness-basis-of-all to explain how consciousness arises. Buddha sometimes spoke of a ‘basis-of-all’, but only when he was referring to emptiness. It was never his final intention to assert a consciousness-basis-of-all. Since there is no consciousness-basis-of-all there is no deluded mentality observing it and so the number of consciousnesses is definitely six.

(3) The self is merely imputed on the aggregates and cannot be found within them. A self that is a consciousness is a non-existent, like a child of a childless woman.

The definition of eye consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, an eye sense power. An example is a primary mind that sees the colour blue. The definition of ear consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, an ear sense power. An example is a primary mind that hears the sound of music. The definition of nose consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, a nose sense power. An example is a primary mind that smells the fragrance of a rose. The definition of tongue consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, a tongue sense power. An example is a primary mind that experiences the taste of honey. The definition of body consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, a body sense power. An example is a primary mind that experiences roughness or smoothness. The definition of mental consciousness is a consciousness that is principally generated from its own dominant condition, a mental power. An example is a primary mind remembering a previously known object.

Primary mind, consciousness and mentality are synonyms. Each consciousness is accompanied by a number of distinct mental factors such as feeling, discrimination and intention. The feeling that accompanies an eye consciousness, for example, is not an eye consciousness but it is an eye awareness. More information on primary minds and mental factors can be found in the book How to Understand the Mind.

[VI.68abc] Since any answer you may give

Is seen to be like an assertion,

You should abandon these arguments.

Since any answer you Chittamatrins may give to the Madhyamika-Prasangikas will be a mere assertion that cannot prove anything, you should abandon these arguments. The Madhyamika-Prasangikas can refute with perfect reasoning your assertion of inherently existent other-powered phenomena, and you have no valid arguments with which to respond.

THE REFUTATION OF THE CHITTAMATRA SYSTEM IS NOT DAMAGED BY THE SCRIPTURES

[VI.68d] Nowhere have Buddhas taught that things exist.

The Madhyamika-Prasangika refutation of the Chittamatra system is unassailable because besides being able to withstand logical scrutiny it is free from contradiction by the scriptures. Nowhere in the scriptures of definitive meaning have Buddhas taught that things exist inherently. Some scriptures such as Interpreting the Intention Sutra say that other-powered phenomena are inherently existent but these are intermediate teachings given to those who cannot understand the subtle emptiness of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school. Because such scriptures do not reveal Buddha’s final intention, their meaning requires interpretation.

THIS REFUTATION AND MEDITATION ON UNATTRACTIVENESS ARE NOT CONTRADICTORY

Chittamatrins In the Sutras it explains how Yogis meditate on unattractiveness to overcome attachment to such things as places and bodies. In one such meditation they generate a concentration to which there appears clearly the ground covered with skeletons. This mind is inherently existent but its object is not. When you say there are no inherently existent minds but there are external objects you contradict the experience of these Yogis.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.69] Yogis following the instructions of their Spiritual Guide

Who see the ground covered with skeletons

Also see all three to be lacking production

Because it is taught to be a false attention.

[VI.70] If, as you say, as it is with objects of sense consciousness

So it is with the objects of the mind of unattractiveness,

Then if someone else directs their mind to that place

They will also see; thus it is not false.

[VI.71ab] As it is with a sense power affected by floaters and the like,

So it is with a hungry ghost’s mind seeing a flowing river as pus.

On the contrary, it is you who have contradictions in your position for your view contradicts both scripture and reason. It is true that some Yogis by relying on the instructions of their Spiritual Guide develop a concentration whereby they see clearly the ground covered with skeletons, but they also see that the mind, the object and the sense power are not inherently produced because in the Sutras Buddha explains that, being a conventional truth, this mind is false. According to you, however, it is a true mind and if the mind is true its object must also be true. So clearly you are in contradiction with the Sutras.

Your position also contradicts reason because according to you the objects of the mind of unattractiveness are just like the objects of sense consciousness. Take for example a situation where a number of people are watching a display of dancing. One person looking in the direction of the display sees the dancers with his eye consciousness and others who look in the same direction see them too. In the same way, when a Yogi in meditation sees the ground covered with skeletons, if someone else who is not familiar with this meditation directs their mind to the same place they will also see the ground covered with skeletons. This is because according to you the mind that sees the ground covered with skeletons is inherently existent and does not depend on meditation for its production. If it can be produced for a Yogi without depending on meditation, it can also be produced for the non-meditator in the same way. In reality, of course, this is not the case. The concentration to which there appears the ground covered with skeletons is not inherently existent nor is it a wrong awareness.

Furthermore, you cannot say that a mind generated from a sense power affected by floaters, a mind seeing an illusion, a mind seeing a reflection or a hungry ghost’s mind seeing a river as pus and blood are examples of inherently existent minds without external objects. We have already explained the faults in the first and these faults also apply to all these other examples.

When a hungry ghost looks at flowing water he sees only pus and blood. At that time pus and blood newly arise in that place as the environmental effect of the hungry ghost’s karma. Pus and blood appear to the hungry ghost and pus and blood actually exist. Since the mind of a hungry ghost that sees pus and blood is not deceptive it is a valid cognizer. If a god, a human and a hungry ghost were to look at a glass containing a moist, liquid substance the god would see nectar, the human water and the hungry ghost pus and blood. For the god, nectar newly arises as the environmental effect of his karma and he sees the nectar directly with a valid cognizer. Similarly, for the human, water newly arises as the environmental effect of his karma and he sees the water directly with a valid cognizer, and for the hungry ghost pus and blood newly arise as the environmental effect of his karma and he sees the pus and blood directly with a valid cognizer. There are not, however, three different liquids on the same base. For example, if three people – one a friend, one an enemy and one a complete stranger – look at a person called Peter, the first will see an attractive person, the second an unattractive person and the third a person who is neither attractive nor unattractive, but there are not three different Peters.

THE CONCLUSION FROM THIS REFUTATION

[VI.71cd] In short, the meaning you should understand is this –

Just as objects of mind do not exist, mind also does not exist.

In short, the meaning of the extensive refutation presented above is this – just as external objects do not inherently exist, so the minds to which they appear also do not inherently exist. Minds and their objects are mutually dependent and both lack inherent existence.

REFUTING THE VALIDITY OF THE REASON ESTABLISHING OTHER-POWERED PHENOMENA AS INHERENTLY EXISTENT

This section has four parts:

1 Refuting self-cognizers as a proof of other-powered phenomena

2 The Chittamatra system is deficient in both truths

3 Therefore it is advisable to follow only the system of Nagarjuna

4 Refuting other-powered phenomena is not the same as refuting worldly nominalities

REFUTING SELF-COGNIZERS AS A PROOF OF OTHER-POWERED PHENOMENA

This section has four parts:

1 On investigation self-cognizers are unacceptable as a proof of other-powered phenomena

2 Refuting the other’s reply that they are acceptable

3 Self-cognizers are unacceptable by other reasoning too

4 An inherently existent other-powered phenomenon is similar to a child of a childless woman

ON INVESTIGATION SELF-COGNIZERS ARE UNACCEPTABLE AS A PROOF OF OTHER-POWERED PHENOMENA

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.72] If with no apprehended object and no apprehender

An other-powered thing exists empty of both,

By what is its existence known?

It is unsuitable to say that it exists without being apprehended.

You Chittamatrins say that there is no apprehended object separate from the mind apprehending it and no apprehender separate from its apprehended object. Thus you assert that an other-powered thing such as a consciousness inherently exists empty of both the object being a separate entity from its subject and the subject being a separate entity from its object. If this is so, since it is unsuitable to say that an object of knowledge exists without being apprehended by a valid cognizer, by what valid cognizer is the existence of this inherently existent consciousness known?

Chittamatrins An inherently existent consciousness is known by a valid self-cognizer, which is that aspect of the consciousness that knows itself.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.73a] That it is experienced by itself is not proven.

A consciousness that is experienced by itself is not proven. It is no more possible for a consciousness to experience itself than it is for an eye to see itself, a knife to cut itself or sugar to sweeten itself. Therefore self-cognizers do not exist.

REFUTING THE OTHER’S REPLY THAT THEY ARE ACCEPTABLE

This section has two parts:

1 The actual refutation of the other system

2 How, according to our system, memory develops even though self-cognizers do not exist

THE ACTUAL REFUTATION OF THE OTHER SYSTEM

Chittamatrins The existence of memory proves the existence of self-cognizers. For example, if we see a blue object we can subsequently remember not only the blue but also our having seen blue. In other words, we remember both the object and the mind that cognized the object. Since we cannot remember something we have not previously experienced we must have experienced the mind seeing blue when it arose. If the eye consciousness seeing blue was experienced there are only two possibilities – either it was experienced by another consciousness or it was experienced by itself. If it were experienced by another consciousness that consciousness in turn would have to have been experienced by another consciousness and so on ad infinitum. Since this is clearly absurd the eye consciousness cannot have been experienced by another consciousness. Therefore it must have been experienced by itself. A mind that knows itself without depending on an object is a self-cognizer. Therefore the existence of memory proves the existence of self-cognizers.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.73bcd] If you say it is proven by memory at a later time

The unproven that you assert as a proof

Does not prove anything.

[VI.74] Even if self-cognizers are admitted,

It is impossible for memory to remember

Because, being other, it would be as if generated in an unknowing continuum.

Such distinctions are also destroyed by this reasoning.

When you say that the existence of self-cognizers is proven by memory generated later, are you referring to inherently existent memory or mere memory? If you are saying that inherently existent memory proves the existence of self-cognizers you are asserting an unproven entity, inherently existent memory, as a proof and something that is unproven does not prove anything. If you are saying that mere memory proves the existence of self-cognizers, this is also unsuitable because whereas mere memory exists, self-cognizers do not.

Even if self-cognizers are admitted, as they are in your system, it is impossible for memory to remember anything because, according to you, the mind that originally experiences the object and the mind that subsequently remembers it are inherently existent other and thus completely unrelated. It is not possible for a mind to remember the experiences of another completely unrelated mind. It would be as if the memory were generated in a completely different continuum. For example, if Peter experiences the taste of an apple, Paul cannot subsequently remember that experience because Paul’s mind is different from and completely unrelated to Peter’s mind. You cannot say that two completely unrelated minds are in the same continuum, nor can you say that an experiencing consciousness, although inherently existent other, is nevertheless the cause of a subsequent remembering consciousness, because if the two minds are inherently existent other they must be unrelated and so cannot be cause and effect. All distinctions such as unrelated minds being in the same continuum and inherently existent cause and effect are destroyed by this reasoning.

HOW, ACCORDING TO OUR SYSTEM, MEMORY DEVELOPS EVEN THOUGH SELF-COGNIZERS DO NOT EXIST

Chittamatrins If there are no self-cognizers, how do you explain the development of memory?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.75] Because for us this memory is not other than

That by which the object was experienced,

Memory thinks, ‘I saw’.

This is also the way of worldly convention.

Because for us memory is not inherently existent other than the consciousness that originally experienced the object, we can say that both the original mind and the remembering mind are in the same continuum and that both minds have the same object. Therefore, even though there are no self-cognizers a memory that thinks, ‘I saw blue’ can develop. When we remember blue, for example, we remember both, ‘I saw blue’ and ‘I saw blue.’ In other words we remember both the object, the blue itself, and the subject, the eye consciousness. Even though the eye consciousness is not the I it is perfectly natural to remember it by thinking, ‘I saw blue.’ For example, even though I am not my hand if my hand is in pain it is perfectly natural for me to say, ‘I am in pain.’ The remembering consciousness remembers the previous subject through the force of remembering the object not because the previous subject was experienced by a self-cognizer. This is also the way it is understood by worldly people. Because you assert self-cognizers you cannot establish the existence of memory whereas we can give a perfectly adequate account of memory without the need to posit self-cognizers.

SELF-COGNIZERS ARE UNACCEPTABLE BY OTHER REASONING TOO

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.76] Therefore, if there are no self-cognizers,

By what is your other-powered phenomenon apprehended?

Since agent, object and action are not identical,

It cannot apprehend itself.

If an eye consciousness seeing blue experienced itself then the agent (the experiencer), the object (what is experienced) and the action (the actual experiencing) would be identical and thus indistinguishable. Since this is absurd, it follows that an eye consciousness cannot apprehend itself. So how are we to understand your assertion of an inherently existent consciousness that is an other-powered phenomenon? If such a consciousness exists it must be apprehended either by a valid cognizer that is other than itself or by a valid cognizer that is identical with itself. You have already dismissed the first possibility and we have disproved the second by showing that there are no self-cognizers. Therefore, by what valid cognizer is your other-powered phenomenon apprehended? Clearly there is none and since whatever is not apprehended by a valid cognizer is non-existent it follows that an inherently existent consciousness does not exist.

AN INHERENTLY EXISTENT OTHER-POWERED PHENOMENON IS SIMILAR TO A CHILD OF A CHILDLESS WOMAN

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.77] If there exists a thing that is an other-powered entity

Without production and with a nature not known,

By what would its existence be impossible?

Can a child of a childless woman harm others?

Previously we established that an other-powered phenomenon such as consciousness is not produced from self or other and now we have established that there are no self-cognizers to certify its existence. If an other-powered phenomenon can exist inherently without production and without being known by a valid cognizer, we can only wonder by what reason you would consider its existence to be impossible. You should take care not to be harmed by a child of a childless woman because the fact that there is no proof of its existence and no valid cognizer that apprehends it does not seem to preclude the possibility that it exists!

THE CHITTAMATRA SYSTEM IS DEFICIENT IN BOTH TRUTHS

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.78] Since not even the slightest other-powered phenomenon exists,

What is the cause of conventionalities?

Out of attachment to a substance in the other’s view

Even all the objects known to the world are forsaken.

According to you, other-powered phenomena are inherently existent, but if something is inherently existent it cannot depend on anything else. Therefore there are no other-powered phenomena, and if there are no other-powered phenomena what is the cause of a conventional mind such as a mind of self-grasping? If it is generated without a cause it follows that it can be generated even in the continuum of a Buddha!

Out of attachment to the substance of mind alone you disallow external objects and thereby forsake all the objects known to the world, such as eating, sleeping and walking. If these conventional phenomena do not exist then ultimate truths also do not exist because ultimate truths depend on conventional truths as their bases. The Chittamatra system, therefore, is deficient in its presentation of both conventional and ultimate truths.

THEREFORE IT IS ADVISABLE TO FOLLOW ONLY THE SYSTEM OF NAGARJUNA

[VI.79] Those who are outside the path of Master Nagarjuna

Have no means of peace.

They depart from the truths of convention and thatness

And, because they depart from them, cannot attain liberation.

[VI.80] Nominal truths are the method,

And ultimate truth arises from the method.

Those who do not know how these two are distinguished

Will enter mistaken paths due to wrong conceptions.

If we have a sincere desire to attain liberation from suffering we should follow only the system of Nagarjuna. If we do not we will have no means of attaining the permanent peace of liberation. Why is this? To attain liberation we must realize the two truths – conventional truth and ultimate truth – and these are established only in Nagarjuna’s system. Those who follow systems other than Nagarjuna’s cannot establish the two truths and so they cannot attain liberation.

To realize ultimate truth we must first realize nominal truths. Thus it is said that nominal truths are the method and ultimate truth arises from the method. Those who do not know how to distinguish nominal truths from ultimate truth will develop wrong conceptions that will lead them into mistaken paths.

Nominal truths are the objects we know simply by using their names without the need for analysis such as our self, our body and other things that we use in our everyday life. For example, we can readily understand a man reading a book. We do not need to engage in analysis to understand a man, a book or the act of reading – the terms themselves are sufficient. Nominal truths are the bases for understanding ultimate truth. If nominal truths were non-existent or inherently existent, there would be no basis for ultimate truth. Since we cannot realize ultimate truth without correctly realizing nominal truths Buddha explained that nominal truths are the method for realizing ultimate truth.

Saying that nominal truths are the method for realizing ultimate truth is not the same as saying that conventional truths are the method for realizing ultimate truth. We can fully realize conventional truths only after we have realized ultimate truth; therefore conventional truths cannot be the method for realizing ultimate truth. In Song of the Practice of the View of Emptiness Changkya Rolpai Dorje says:

In the lap of the mother

I found the father.

In this context ‘mother’ means ultimate truth, emptiness, and ‘father’ means conventional truth. Changkya Rolpai Dorje is saying that he realized conventional truth from his understanding of ultimate truth.

REFUTING OTHER-POWERED PHENOMENA IS NOT THE SAME AS REFUTING WORLDLY NOMINALITIES

Chittamatrins By denying inherently existent other-powered phenomena you are denying all worldly nominalities, including this debate.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.81] We do not assert any conventionalities

The way you assert other-powered things.

However, even though they do not exist, for the sake of the result

We say to the worldly that they do.

On the contrary, it is you who are asserting non-existents such as other-powered things that exist by way of their own entities. We do not assert any conventional phenomena in this way and so in refuting inherently existent other-powered phenomena we are not denying worldly nominalities. It is true that Buddha sometimes said that other-powered phenomena such as the aggregates are inherently existent, but these teachings were given according to the capacities of disciples and do not reveal his final intention. His purpose was to help certain disciples abandon mistaken tenets and enter into correct paths. Thus even though conventional phenomena such as the aggregates do not exist inherently, sometimes for the same reason we also say that they do exist in this way.

Chittamatrins If conventionalities are not inherently existent, how do they exist?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.82] But if they did not exist as worldly

In the way that they are non-existent for Foe Destroyers

Who have abandoned their aggregates and entered peace,

Then we would not say that they exist even nominally.

Conventionalities exist because they are worldly nominalities, not because they are inherently existent. If phenomena such as forms did not exist as worldly nominalities we would not say that they existed at all, even nominally. For example, in the case of Foe Destroyers who have abandoned contaminated aggregates and entered the peace of nirvana, their contaminated aggregates do not exist as worldly nominalities and so do not exist at all. Conventionalities, however, do exist as worldly nominalities and for this reason we say they exist. Existing as a mere name, existing conventionally and existing merely through conceptual imputation all mean the same. All phenomena including emptiness exist in these three ways. If something does not exist in these three ways it does not exist at all. These three modes of existence, however, are subtle conventionalities and can be fully realized only after we have realized emptiness.

Chittamatrins Just as you reject our assertion of inherently existent other-powered phenomena, so we reject your assertion of conventionalities.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.83] If you are not harmed by the worldly,

Then refute them in front of the worldly.

Thus you and the worldly should debate on this,

And afterwards we will rely on the stronger.

If you reject conventionalities you reject worldly nominalities. If you can do so without being harmed by the worldly then you should indeed refute them in front of the worldly. You and the worldly should debate on this and afterwards we will rely on the stronger. However, we have no doubt who will win. You deny the existence of external objects that worldly people can see clearly with their valid cognizers so we are certain they would defeat you in debate.

THE WORD ‘ONLY’ IN ‘MIND ONLY’ DOES NOT EXCLUDE EXTERNAL OBJECTS

This section has three parts:

1 Explaining the intention of the statement in Sutra on the Ten Grounds that says that there is only mind

2 External objects and internal mind are the same in either being existent or being non-existent

3 Explaining the intention of the statement in Gone to Lanka Sutra that says that there is only mind

EXPLAINING THE INTENTION OF THE STATEMENT IN SUTRA ON THE TEN GROUNDS THAT SAYS THAT THERE IS ONLY MIND

This section has three parts:

1 The Sutra on the Ten Grounds proves that the word ‘only’ does not exclude external objects

2 This meaning is also established in other Sutras

3 The word ‘only’ establishes that mind is principal

THE SUTRA ON THE TEN GROUNDS PROVES THAT THE WORD ‘ONLY’ DOES NOT EXCLUDE EXTERNAL OBJECTS

Chittamatrins You assert external objects only because you fear harm from worldly people if you were to reject them. You would do better, however, to refute external objects out of fear of contradicting Buddha’s scriptures because in Sutra on the Ten Grounds Buddha says:

These three realms are only mind.

What clearer proof could there be of the non-existence of external objects?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.84] It says that a Bodhisattva on Approaching

Realizes the three realms to be only consciousness

To realize the refutation of a permanent self as creator.

In fact, he realizes that only mind is creator.

It is true that this Sutra says that a Bodhisattva on the sixth ground, Approaching, realizes the three realms to be only consciousness, but this does not prove that there are no external objects. In this context the word ‘only’ excludes not external objects but a permanent self, the general principle, Ishvara and so forth that are asserted by various non-Buddhists to be the creator of the world. In fact, this Bodhisattva realizes that only mind is the creator of the three realms.

THIS MEANING IS ALSO ESTABLISHED IN OTHER SUTRAS

[VI.85] Therefore, to increase the wisdom of the intelligent,

In Gone to Lanka Sutra the All-Knowing One uttered

This vajra in the nature of speech that destroys the high mountains of the Tirthikas

To clarify the meaning.

[VI.86] In their own treatises

Tirthikas speak of person and so forth,

But seeing that these are not the creator

The Conqueror said that only mind is the creator of the world.

To overcome wrong views and to increase the wisdom of the intelligent who are able to understand profound emptiness Buddha says in Gone to Lanka Sutra:

Person, continuum, aggregates,

Conditions, atoms, the general principle,

And Ishvara are all said to be creators;

But I say only mind is the creator.

This statement is like a vajra in the nature of speech because just as one vajra can shatter a whole range of mountains, so this statement destroys the wrong views that are like high mountains in the minds of the non-Buddhist Tirthikas. Buddha shows clearly that none of the phenomena from the person through to Ishvara is the creator of the world but that the world is created by mind alone. His purpose in uttering these words was to clarify the meaning of other Sutras such as Sutra on the Ten Grounds where he speaks of only mind.

In their own treatises, different Tirthikas assert one or other of these things, from the person through to Ishvara, to be the creator of the world. Buddha, however, understands that none of these things is the creator – only mind is the creator of the world. This is the meaning of the statement in Sutra on the Ten Grounds that ‘These three realms are only mind.’

THE WORD ‘ONLY’ ESTABLISHES THAT MIND IS PRINCIPAL

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.87] Just as ‘increase of thatness’ is said for ‘Buddha’,

So too, in Sutra, ‘only mind’ is said for

‘Only mind is principal in the world.’

The meaning of the Sutra here is not to deny forms.

[VI.88] If the Great One knew that these are only mind

And if he denied forms there,

Why did he say again there

That mind arises from ignorance and karma?

When the compassionate, skilful Buddha said that the three realms are only mind, his intention was to show that mind has primacy over forms. For example, Buddha sometimes used the term ‘increase of thatness’ to mean ‘Buddha’. The Tibetan word for Buddha is sang gyay. According to one etymology, sang means ‘awakened from the sleep of delusion’, and gyay means ‘increase of the wisdom of thatness, or emptiness’. Thus a Buddha is someone who has awakened from the sleep of delusion and perfectly increased the wisdom of emptiness. Even though Sutra says only ‘increase of thatness’ and does not mention ‘awakened from the sleep of delusion’, nevertheless the latter is understood and the phrase is taken to mean ‘Buddha’. Similarly, in Sutra on the Ten Grounds the phrase ‘only mind’ is used for ‘only mind is principal.’ Although ‘is principal’ is not mentioned it is understood and the phrase should be taken to mean ‘only mind is principal in the world.’ In other words, the meaning is that within the three realms mind and not form is the principal agent. This Sutra does not deny external forms.

If, as you believe, Buddha knew that these three realms are only the nature of inherently existent mind and if he denied external forms in Sutra on the Ten Grounds, why did he say again in the same Sutra when he was explaining the twelve dependent-related links that dependent-related consciousness arises from dependent-related ignorance and dependent-related compositional actions? If mind is inherently existent it cannot arise in dependence on anything.

Other schools How can you prove that the world is created principally by mind?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.89] All the various worldly environments

And the living beings, the inhabitants, are created by mind.

It is said that all living beings are born from karma,

And if there is no mind there is no karma.

[VI.90] Even though forms exist

They have no creator like mind.

Therefore a creator other than mind is rejected.

Forms, however, are not denied.

All the various worldly environments arose from the collective karma or actions of the living beings who inhabit them, and all the living beings, the inhabitants, arose from their own individual karma. Since all actions are accumulated by mind it follows that all worlds and their inhabitants are created by mind. Even bodily and verbal actions originate in the mind. If there is no mind there are no actions. Thus a person can accumulate actions but a picture of a person cannot. Although we often say, ‘I created this’, or, ‘He created that’, the real creator is our mind. Since the mental predominates over the physical some texts say that the mind is like a master and the body like its slave.

You may say that the world developed from the amassing of many atomic particles. This is true, but what caused these particles to assemble? Only the karma of living beings inhabiting this world. According to the scriptures this world originally arose from the water element, which arose from the wind element, which in turn arose from empty space. The amassing of atomic particles was only the secondary cause of this world, the main cause was the collective karma of the living beings who inhabit it. Otherwise, why should this world have arisen out of empty space?

All phenomena without exception are created by mind because all phenomena are imputed by conceptual mind. No phenomenon exists from its own side. As already quoted, in Sutra Requested by Upali Buddha says:

There is nothing that is the creator

Of the various, attractive flowers that bloom

Or the beautiful, glistening, supreme, golden houses;

For they are all established by the power of conception.

All worlds are imputed by conception.

Also, in Ornament for Clear Realization Venerable Maitreya says:

Impure worlds develop because living beings are impure. This proves that we can accomplish a pure world, or Pure Land of Buddha, by becoming a pure being ourself.

Since living beings’ minds are impure the world they inhabit is impure, but when their minds become pure their world becomes pure. This shows that the world depends on mind. Purity and impurity, beauty and ugliness, good and bad all depend on mind. For this reason mind is more important than external things. So that we may understand this, Sutra on the Ten Grounds rejects a creator other than mind. However, it does not deny the existence of external forms. Therefore we do not need to fear contradiction with the scriptures when we assert the existence of external objects.

EXTERNAL OBJECTS AND INTERNAL MIND ARE THE SAME IN EITHER BEING EXISTENT OR BEING NON-EXISTENT

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.91] For one who remains with the worldly,

All five aggregates exist as they are known by the worldly.

If a Yogi wishes to manifest the exalted awareness of thatness

Those five will not arise for him.

[VI.92] If forms do not exist, do not hold to the existence of mind;

And if mind exists, do not hold to the non-existence of forms.

Buddha rejects them all equally in the Wisdom Sutras,

But they are taught in the Abhidharmas.

[VI.93] You have destroyed these stages of the two truths.

However your substance does not exist because it has been refuted.

Therefore you should know that by these stages from the beginning

Things are not produced in thatness, but are produced for the worldly.

It is inconsistent of you Chittamatrins to assert internal mind while denying external forms because either both exist or both do not exist. Both exist nominally from the point of view of worldly renown, but neither exists ultimately from the point of view of thatness, or emptiness. Thus, all five aggregates, that is all internal minds and all external forms, exist because they are known by worldly renown. However, when a Superior being experiences the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise realizing thatness, none of these five arise for him or her. This is because once his mind has absorbed in single-pointed concentration on thatness all dualistic appearance subsides into emptiness and conventional phenomena such as the mind and external forms cease to appear to him. This shows that both internal mind and external forms lack inherent existence and do not exist ultimately. Therefore, if you want to assert that external objects do not exist do not hold to the existence of mind, and if you want to assert that mind exists do not hold to the non-existence of external objects.

This is also established by scripture as well as by reasoning. For example, Buddha rejects the inherent existence of all five aggregates in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras, but other scriptures such as the Abhidharmas say that all five aggregates are inherently existent. The Perfection of Wisdom Sutras are for disciples who have the wisdom to realize profound thatness and the Abhidharmas are given as intermediate teachings to disciples who are not yet able to understand profound thatness.

To summarize, both internal minds and external objects exist from the point of view of conventional truth but not from the point of view of ultimate truth. You Chittamatrins have destroyed these stages of the two truths in asserting that internal mind inherently exists whereas external forms do not exist at all. However this inherently existent mind that you assert to be a substantially existent other-powered phenomenon does not exist because it has been conclusively refuted. Therefore, if you want to understand the two truths correctly you should know that by these stages from the beginning neither internal mind nor external forms are produced ultimately, but both are produced nominally.

EXPLAINING THE INTENTION OF THE STATEMENT IN GONE TO LANKA SUTRA THAT SAYS THAT THERE IS ONLY MIND

This section has two parts:

1 The statement that there are no external objects but only mind is of interpretative meaning

2 A method for recognizing Sutras of interpretative and definitive meaning

THE STATEMENT THAT THERE ARE NO EXTERNAL OBJECTS BUT ONLY MIND IS OF INTERPRETATIVE MEANING

This section has two parts:

1 Showing by means of the scriptures that it is of interpretative meaning

2 Showing by means of reasoning that it is of interpretative meaning

SHOWING BY MEANS OF THE SCRIPTURES THAT IT IS OF INTERPRETATIVE MEANING

This section has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Other Sutras like this are also of interpretative meaning

THE ACTUAL MEANING

Chittamatrins It is not only Sutra on the Ten Grounds that teaches that there are no external objects. For example, in Gone to Lanka Sutra Buddha says:

External objects do not exist.

Mind appears as various things

Such as bodies, enjoyments and places;

I explain these as only mind.

When you assert external objects you contradict this Sutra and others like it.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.94] In the Sutra that says

‘External objects do not exist, mind appears as various things’,

Forms are denied for those with strong attachment to forms;

But that is also of interpretative meaning.

[VI.95ab] The Blessed One says that it is of interpretative meaning;

And it is also established by reasoning to be of interpretative meaning.

It is true that Gone to Lanka Sutra says that external forms do not exist and that mind appears as various things, but this is a Sutra of interpretative meaning. This Sutra denies external forms to help those with strong attachment to forms such as bodies, enjoyments and places. By meditating on the lack of external objects such people can temporarily reduce their attachment. However, we should not understand this Sutra to mean that external objects do not exist. For example, Buddha also taught those with strong attachment to meditate on the ground covered with skeletons but we would not infer from this that the ground actually is covered with skeletons!

We can be certain that Gone to Lanka Sutra is of interpretative meaning because the Blessed One says so in the same Sutra. Furthermore, as we will see below, it is also established by reasoning to be of interpretative meaning.

OTHER SUTRAS LIKE THIS ARE ALSO OF INTERPRETATIVE MEANING

[VI.95cd] This scripture makes it clear that other Sutras of this kind

Are also of interpretative meaning.

In Gone to Lanka Sutra Buddha says:

Just as a doctor administers medicine

Patient by patient,

So Buddha expounds ‘only mind’

To living beings.

This scripture makes it clear that Gone to Lanka Sutra and other Sutras of this kind such as Interpreting the Intention Sutra are of interpretative meaning. For example, when a doctor administers medicine he treats each patient differently according to their needs; he does not give them all the same medicine. If a patient is in great pain the doctor will first administer a pain killer to reduce the pain and then he will begin to treat the disease that is causing it. In the same way, when Buddha teaches Dharma he administers Dharma medicine for the mind according to the needs of individual disciples; he does not give everyone the same instructions. If a disciple is suffering greatly from the pain of attachment to forms Buddha first administers the Chittamatrin view that there are no external forms. This has the effect of temporarily reducing his or her problem of attachment, but to remove its root, self-grasping, the disciple must apply another remedy – the Madhyamika-Prasangika view. This shows clearly that teachings on ‘only mind’ are of interpretative, not definitive, meaning.

In his Autocommentary to the Guide, Chandrakirti mentions four Sutras that are of interpretative meaning – the Sutra revealing the non-existence of external objects, the Sutra revealing consciousness-basis-of-all, the Sutra differentiating the three natures as truly existent or not truly existent and the Sutra revealing three final vehicles. Although the Chittamatrins believe that these are all Sutras of definitive meaning, Chandrakirti proves with the aid of Gone to Lanka Sutra and with powerful reasoning that they are all of interpretative meaning. An extensive account of this is given by Je Tsongkhapa in Essence of Good Explanation Revealing Interpretative and Definitive Meaning.

SHOWING BY MEANS OF REASONING THAT IT IS OF INTERPRETATIVE MEANING

[VI.96] The Buddhas have said that if objects of mind do not exist,

The absence of mind is easily realized.

Since if objects of mind do not exist the refutation of mind is established,

Objects of mind are refuted first.

The Buddhas have said that once we have realized that external forms do not exist inherently we will easily realize that internal mind also does not exist inherently. Therefore, Buddha first refutes inherently existent external objects of mind and then refutes inherently existent mind. Thus Buddha’s statement that there are no external objects must be interpreted to mean that there are no inherently existent external objects. Since Buddha’s words in this case do not explicitly reveal his actual intention but require interpretation we say that this Sutra is of interpretative meaning.

A METHOD FOR RECOGNIZING SUTRAS OF INTERPRETATIVE AND DEFINITIVE MEANING

[VI.97] Thus, having understood this explanation of the scriptures,

You should realize that any Sutra whose meaning does not explain thatness

Is taught as interpretative, and you should interpret it.

You should know that those whose meaning is emptiness are of definitive meaning.

Having understood this explanation of interpretative and definitive meaning in the scriptures you should know how to distinguish the two types of Sutra. The definition of Sutra of interpretative meaning is a Sutra whose main meaning is not emptiness and that principally and explicitly teaches conventional truths. Examples are Interpreting the Intention Sutra and the four Sutras mentioned above. The definition of Sutra of definitive meaning is a Sutra that principally and explicitly reveals emptiness. Examples are the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. This method for recognizing the two types of Sutra is based on King of Concentration Sutra where it says:

As the Sugatas taught emptiness,

Know these Sutras to be of definitive meaning.

Where sentient beings, persons and beings are taught,

Know these Dharmas to be all of interpretative meaning.

This verse teaches that Sutras that principally and explicitly reveal the lack of inherent existence of persons and phenomena are of definitive meaning, and Sutras that principally and explicitly reveal conventional phenomena such as sentient beings and so forth are of interpretative meaning. This way of distinguishing the two types of Sutra accords with the tenets of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school. The assertions of the lower schools are different. The Vaibhashikas do not even believe in the existence of Sutras of interpretative meaning.

Dromtonpa

The Meaning of this Refutation

Having refuted production from self and production from other, Chandrakirti now briefly refutes the two remaining positions – production from both self and other and production without a cause.

REFUTING PRODUCTION FROM BOTH

Production from both self and other is asserted by the non- Buddhist Jains. It will be helpful to begin by considering their argument.

Jains All external and internal things are produced from both self and other. For example, because a clay pot is the same nature as the clay from which it is made it is produced from self, but because it is a different nature from the potter who made it, it is also produced from other. The same is true of all other external things. Similarly, internal things such as people are also produced from both self and other. A woman, for example, is produced from the self of her last life and in that respect she is produced from self, but she is also produced in dependence on her parents of this life who are other than herself, and in this respect she is produced from other.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.98] Production from both is also not a suitable entity.

Why? Because all the faults already explained apply.

It does not exist for the worldly nor is it asserted in thatness

Because production from either is not established.

Since neither production from self nor production from other is possible, it is also not suitable to assert production from both self and other. Why? Because all the faults of production from self and production from other that have already been explained apply to production from both. Furthermore, production from both self and other does not exist either nominally or ultimately because production from either self or other is not established in the two truths. Therefore production from both should not be asserted at all.

REFUTING PRODUCTION WITHOUT A CAUSE

Production without a cause is asserted by the non-Buddhist Charavakas.

Charavakas We do not assert either production from self or production from other; rather we believe that all things are produced entirely without causes. If you look at external things such as flowers you will see that they have various shapes, colours, scents and so forth, but no one made these, they simply developed naturally. Thorns, for example, are sharp and peas are round but no one made them like this; it is simply the nature of a thorn to be sharp and of a pea to be round. It is the same with internal things such as the eye of a peacock’s feather or the colours of a butterfly’s wing – all these things simply arise naturally without causes.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.99] If there is production entirely without causes

Then everything is produced from everything all the time,

And so to obtain fruit the people of this world

Do not have to gather seeds and so forth in a hundred ways.

[VI.100] If living beings are empty of causes, they are unapprehendable

Like the fragrance and colour of an upala flower in the sky,

But a very colourful world is apprehended.

Therefore you should know that, like your mind, the world comes from causes.

If, as you say, things are produced entirely without causes then everything is produced from everything. Butter is produced from water, oil from sand, water from fire and children from men because none of these things requires its own cause to be produced. Furthermore, because things do not require causes, everything is produced all the time. The beautiful flowers that grow on the mountains in the summer also grow there in the winter because they do not have to await their causes to be produced. It also follows that to obtain fruit and reap harvests the people of this world do not have to work hard in a hundred different ways such as gathering seeds and cultivating crops because fruit and other produce arise naturally without causes.

We cannot apprehend the fragrance and colour of an upala flower that grows in the sky because there is nothing to be known. In the same way, if living beings are empty of causes they are unapprehendable because there is nothing to be known. Living beings change continually because they are produced afresh in each moment. However, according to you there is no production because there are no causes, and since it is not possible for living beings to exist without being produced it follows that living beings do not exist at all. Clearly this is not the case because a very colourful world inhabited by living beings is apprehended. Therefore, living beings are produced from causes. When you see blue, for example, your mind apprehending blue is produced in dependence on the colour blue that is its cause. In the same way, you should understand that the world and its inhabitants are produced only in dependence on causes.

Charavakas We can say that the world and its inhabitants arise from the maturation of the four basic elements – earth, wind, fire and water. Even mind arises from these elements. For example, just as a state of inebriation arises from a potential within alcohol so a state of consciousness arises from a potential within the elements. The consciousness of a new-born child arises from the elements of the mother’s ovum and the father’s sperm, therefore there is no need to posit a previous mental continuum. Whatever is produced exists only within this present life; there is no evidence for the existence of future lives. There are three reasons why future lives do not exist – (1) we cannot see future lives (2) the mind of this life is produced only from the elements of this life and not from a previous mental continuum and (3) since mind and body are the same substance the mind dies when the body dies. Therefore there are no past or future lives. This is clearly explained in the works of our founder.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.101] The nature of those elements that are the objects of your mind

Is not the nature of this.

How could one who has such thick mental darkness here

Correctly realize the world beyond?

[VI.102] You should realize that when you deny the world beyond

You are conceptualizing the nature of objects of knowledge with a wrong view

Because you have a body that is a basis for developing such a view.

It is the same when you assert the nature of the elements to be existent.

[VI.103] How these elements do not exist has already been explained.

How? Because production from self, other, both and no cause

Have already been refuted in general above.

Therefore, these unmentioned elements also do not exist.

Your first reason is not valid because it does not follow that something does not exist just because you are unable to see it. You have thick mental darkness even with respect to the gross objects of this life so how could you be expected to realize correctly the subtle phenomena of past and future lives? Your confusion about the manifest objects of this life is illustrated by your second reason. The nature of those gross elements such as the body that are the objects of your knowledge is not the same nature as the mind. If mind can develop merely from physical elements without a previous mental continuum then soil, wind, fire and water can generate new consciousness and become living beings. Since this is clearly impossible, your second reason is also invalid.

As for your third reason, mind and body are not the same substance because they are different in aspect, function and entity. In aspect, mind is empty of form, invisible and completely lacking in physical properties, whereas body is form, visible, and possesses many physical properties. Mind functions to cognize, discriminate and experience objects but body cannot perform any of these functions. Mind is like a guest and the body is like its guest house; thus they are completely different entities. Even in this life the mind can be made to leave the body and return to it, or even to enter another body, so how can mind and body be the same substance?

It is all very well for you to refer to your founder’s book but if we examine how it came about we will see that it is not a valid scripture. Your founder engaged in many inappropriate actions and composed a long book of a hundred thousand verses only to protect his reputation and justify his lifestyle. In this book he denies the existence of past and future lives, the faults of negative actions, the benefits of virtuous actions, the laws of karma, hidden phenomena and valid cognizers other than direct perceivers. This book may be popular with you Charavakas but no intelligent person would refer to it.

You should realize that when you deny past and future lives you are conceptualizing the nature of objects of knowledge wrongly because you have taken rebirth as a Charavaka and so have become a basis for holding such a wrong view. It is the same when you assert the nature of the four elements to be truly existent. How these elements do not truly exist has already been explained above. We have already given a general refutation of production from self, other, both and no cause and although the four elements were not specifically mentioned they were included in the refutation. Therefore these elements also do not truly exist.

THE MEANING ESTABLISHED BY THE REFUTATION OF THE FOUR EXTREMES OF PRODUCTION

[VI.104ab] Since production from self, other, both, or without depending on a cause do not exist

Things are free from inherent existence.

If things were inherently existent they would have to be produced from self, from other, from both self and other or without depending on a cause. These four extremes exhaust all possibilities. Since it has been conclusively established that production from self, other, both or without depending on a cause do not exist, we can know with certainty that things are free from inherent existence.

The refutation of the four extremes of production enables us to accomplish three great results:

(1) Through contemplating that things are not produced from self, other, both, or without a cause we realize that things lack inherent existence.

(2) Through meditating on the lack of inherent existence of things we gain a deep experience of emptiness.

(3) Through this experience eventually we attain liberation, the permanent cessation of all suffering.

These attainments are possible because of the extensive explanation of the refutation of the four extremes of production given above. Therefore studying this subject has great meaning.

REJECTING ARGUMENTS AGAINST THIS REFUTATION

This section has two parts:

1 The actual rejection of arguments

2 A summary

THE ACTUAL REJECTION OF ARGUMENTS

Proponents of things If things are not inherently produced they are not produced at all, so how do you explain the fact that worldly people clearly see things such as colours?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.104cd] Because worldly beings have thick confusion like a mass of cloud

Objects appear incorrectly to them.

[VI.105] Just as some, due to visual impairments, wrongly apprehend floating hairs,

Two moons, peacocks’ feathers, flies and so forth,

So too the unwise through the faults of confusion

See various produced phenomena with their minds.

[VI.106] ‘Since actions arise in dependence on confusion, without confusion they will not arise.’

Certainly only the unwise conceptualize this.

The wise, who have completely eliminated thick darkness with the sun of their excellent minds,

Understand emptiness and are liberated.

Just as when it rains a mass of dark cloud obscures the sky, so worldly beings have thick confusion that obscures the nature of things. Objects appear incorrectly to them and they apprehend things as inherently existent. Some people, due to visual impairments such as floaters, see floating hairs, two moons, auras of light resembling peacocks’ feathers and flies where there are none. Even though none of these things exists they are wrongly apprehended as existent because the sense powers are impaired. Similarly, even though there are no inherently existent things worldly beings apprehend things to be inherently existent due to the confusion in their minds.

In Dependent Relationship Sutra Buddha says that dependent-related compositional actions arise in dependence on dependent-related ignorance and that without dependent-related ignorance there can be no dependent-related compositional actions. Certainly only the unwise conceptualize this to mean that inherently existent actions arise from inherently existent ignorance. The wise, through correctly realizing dependent relationship with the sun of their excellent minds, understand the lack of inherent existence of compositional actions and thereby eliminate the thick darkness of ignorance. As a result they are liberated from samsara. Worldly beings, on the other hand, cling to things as inherently existent and so continue to experience relentless suffering. From this we can see that if we want freedom from the sufferings of samsara we should give up worldly views and follow the view of the wise Madhyamikas.

Proponents of things

[VI.107] ‘If things did not exist in thatness

They would not exist even nominally,

Like a child of a childless woman;

Therefore, they must be inherently existent.’

If, as you say, things did not exist inherently, they would not exist at all, even nominally and so everything would be non-existent. For example, because a child of a childless woman does not exist ultimately it does not exist even nominally and so is completely non-existent.
