Without a part-possessor there are no parts and if there are no parts there is no collection of parts. Therefore, it is impossible for the mere collection of its parts to be the cart.

The last line of this verse in the root text reads ‘Therefore, it is impossible for the mere shape to be the cart.’ Some texts say that it should be changed to read, ‘Therefore it is impossible for the mere collection to be the cart’ since this is the occasion of refuting the collection of the parts to be a cart. However it is possible to interpret the existing words without contradiction and there is no need to change them.

REFUTING THE ASSERTION THAT A CART IS THE MERE SHAPE OF ITS PARTS

This section has two parts:

1 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the shape of its individual parts

2 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the shape of the collection of its parts

REFUTING THE ASSERTION THAT A CART IS THE SHAPE OF ITS INDIVIDUAL PARTS

Objection A cart is the shape of its individual parts.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.153] According to you, the shape of each part is the same

When assembled into a cart as it was before.

Just as with those that were separate,

So too there is no cart even now.

[VI.154] If the wheels and so forth have different shapes

Now at the time of the cart, they must be visible,

But they are not.

Therefore, the mere shape is not the cart.

When you say that the shape of the individual parts is the cart, is the shape of each part the same after the cart has been assembled as it was before, or is it different? If you say that the shape of each part is the same after it is assembled, then just as there was no cart when the individual parts were separate so there is no cart when the parts are assembled. If the shapes of the individual parts are not the cart before it is assembled, how can they be the cart when they are assembled if they do not change in the process? If you say that at the time of the cart the wheels, axle and so forth have different shapes from those they had before they were assembled we should be able to see these different shapes, but we cannot. Therefore a cart is not the mere shape of its individual parts.

REFUTING THE ASSERTION THAT A CART IS THE SHAPE OF THE COLLECTION OF ITS PARTS

Objection A cart is the shape of the collection of its parts.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.155] Since for you there is not the slightest collection

That shape is not of the collection of parts,

And since it does not depend on anything

How, in this case, can it be the shape?

If the cart is the shape of the collection of its parts, that shape must be imputed on the collection and the collection must be the basis for imputing that shape. According to your system, a basis of imputation must be substantially existent. On the other hand, you say that there is no such thing as a substantially existent collection because a collection is necessarily imputedly existent. Therefore it follows that the collection of the parts of the cart cannot be a basis for imputing the shape of the cart. If the shape is not imputed on the collection of parts it has no basis of imputation on which to depend, so how can the cart be the shape of the collection of its parts? Moreover, the shape of the cart is not the cart because the cart is the possessor and the shape is the possession. Possessor and possession cannot be one.

TRANSFERRING THIS REASON TO OTHERS

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.156] You should know that all things are produced

Just as you have asserted here,

With aspects of effects having untrue natures

Arising in dependence on untrue causes.

[VI.157] Because of this, it is also unsuitable to say that a mind of a pot

Observes the forms and so forth that exist like that.

Since there is no production, forms and so forth do not exist.

Therefore, it is also unsuitable that their shape does.

In effect, what you have just said is that a shape that is not substantially existent is imputed in dependence on a collection of parts that is also not substantially existent. You should know that all things are produced just like this, with imputedly existent effects that lack true existence arising in dependence on imputedly existent causes that also lack true existence.

The reasoning refuting the assertion that a cart is the collection of its parts also applies to all other things such as pots, houses, cars and clothes. A pot, for example, is composed of eight atomic substances: the four elements – earth element, wind element, fire element and water element – and the four substances arising from the elements – form, smell, taste and tactile objects. Because a pot consists of these eight atomic substances, these substances are parts of the pot, but they are not the pot. Therefore it is unsuitable to say that a mind observing a pot observes the eight atomic substances, forms and so forth, that are the collection of its parts. Furthermore, since there is no inherently existent production the eight atomic substances, form and so forth, that are the basis of imputation do not exist substantially. Therefore it is also unsuitable to assert that the shape that is imputed on them is substantially existent.

REJECTING AN ARGUMENT AGAINST THIS EXPLANATION

Lower schools According to you, if we search for a cart in these seven ways we will never find it but this is tantamount to saying that the cart does not exist at all.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.158] Indeed it is not established by the seven ways

Either in thatness or for the worldly,

But from the point of view of the worldly without analysis

It is imputed here in dependence on its parts.

Indeed a cart is not established by the seven ways either ultimately or nominally, but from the point of view of worldly designation it exists without analysis merely imputed in dependence on its parts. Thus a cart exists simply by worldly designation. There is no cart other than the mere name ‘cart’ that is imputed by worldly people. We are satisfied with the mere name ‘cart’ and do not feel the need to investigate further. In this respect we are just like normal people, for they too are satisfied with the mere name ‘cart’ and without further investigation use carts to carry things.

SHOWING THAT THE NOMINAL MEANING OF OTHER NAMES IS ALSO ESTABLISHED

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.159] It is a part-possessor and a component-possessor.

For living beings a cart is called an ‘agent’

And for beings it exists as a taker.

Do not destroy conventionalities known to the world.

According to our system it is perfectly possible to designate other names to a cart. For example, with respect to its parts a cart is a part-possessor, with respect to its components it is a component-possessor and because it takes its parts it can be called an ‘agent’ or a ‘taker’. Such names are established by worldly convention. Therefore, we can give a faultless presentation of objects such as carts entirely according to worldly conventions. You, however, defy worldly conventions and thereby fail to account for anything. In fact the fault that you attribute to us, that we deny the existence of everything, actually applies to you. Take a cart for example. It has been proven that a cart does not exist within its individual parts or within the collection of its parts, and yet you deny the existence of a cart merely imputed in dependence on its parts. Therefore, according to you there is no cart and by the same token there is no pot, no car, no house and so on. We would like to ask you not to destroy these conventionalities that are well known to the world!

THIS PRESENTATION HAS THE GOOD QUALITY OF ALLOWING US EASILY TO ABANDON CONCEPTIONS GRASPING AT EXTREMES

This section has five parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Rejecting an argument against this

3 Applying the analogy of the cart to the meaning of the nominal self

4 Showing other good qualities of asserting a self that is dependently imputed

5 Recognizing the self that is the basis both of the bondage of delusion and of liberation

THE ACTUAL MEANING

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.160] How can it be said that that which is non-existent in the seven ways exists

When its existence is not found by Yogis?

Since they realize thatness easily,

Its existence should be asserted in the same way here.

How can it be said that a cart that is non-existent in the seven ways exists inherently when its inherent existence is not found even by Yogis? When Yogis analyze a cart, for example, in the seven ways, and fail to find a cart they easily realize the lack of inherent existence of the cart. Through realizing the emptiness of the cart they then realize its subtle conventional nature, that it is mere name. In the Madhyamika-Prasangika system we assert the existence of things such as carts in just the same way as they are realized by these Yogis.

If you proponents of lower tenets want to be free from faults and gain a perfect understanding of the two truths you should abandon your mistaken views and take up the system of the Madhyamika-Prasangikas. In this system we assert that all things such as carts are mere name and we do not search further. In this way we can give a flawless presentation of the two truths and avoid falling into the extremes of existence and non-existence.

REJECTING AN ARGUMENT AGAINST THIS

Objection How can you say that the parts of a cart do not exist inherently when everyone can clearly see the wheels and so forth?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.161] If a cart does not exist then in that case,

Since there is no part-possessor, its parts also do not exist.

For example, if a cart is burned its parts no longer exist.

Likewise, when the part-possessor is consumed by the fire of wisdom, so too are the parts.

As already explained, a cart is not inherently existent because it cannot be found by the sevenfold analysis. If a cart does not inherently exist there is no inherently existent part-possessor, and so the parts also do not inherently exist. For example, if the part-possessor, the cart, is burned by fire its parts are also burned and no longer exist. Likewise, when the fuel of the self-grasping mind apprehending an inherently existent part-possessor is consumed by the fire of wisdom realizing emptiness, so too is the self-grasping mind apprehending inherently existent parts. Thus neither the cart nor its parts are inherently existent.

APPLYING THE ANALOGY OF THE CART TO THE MEANING OF THE NOMINAL SELF

[VI.162] In the same way, the self is held by worldly renown

To be an appropriator in dependence on the aggregates,

The elements and likewise the six sources.

The appropriated are the object and it is the agent.

The analogy of a cart is given to help us understand how the self is not inherently existent but is merely imputed in dependence on its parts. Of course any other object could have been taken as an analogy but it is useful when examining an internal object such as the self to take an external object such as a cart as an analogy. Just as a cart cannot be found when analyzed in the seven ways neither can the self, and just as a cart exists as mere imputation so too does the self. In just the same way, the self is established by worldly renown as an appropriator merely imputed in dependence on its parts – the five aggregates, the six elements and the six sources. All these are the appropriated, the object of the action, and the self is the appropriator, the agent of the action.

SHOWING OTHER GOOD QUALITIES OF ASSERTING A SELF THAT IS DEPENDENTLY IMPUTED

[VI.163] Because the thing does not exist it is not stable and not unstable,

It is not born and does not perish.

It also has no permanence and so forth

And it is without oneness or otherness.

Once we have realized that the self is not inherently existent but merely imputed on the aggregates, we will then realize that it is not inherently stable and not inherently unstable, it is not inherently born and does not inherently perish, it has no inherently existent permanence or impermanence and it is without inherently existent oneness or otherness. We will realize all this simply from realizing that the self is empty of inherent existence. Why is this? It is because once we have realized the emptiness of a characterized phenomenon we automatically realize the emptiness of all its characteristics.

From this we can understand that the realization that the self is not inherently existent but dependently imputed enables us to overcome not only the view of the transitory collection but also all other deluded views. The deluded views referred to here, the view that the self is inherently stable and so forth, are all included in extreme view within the five types of deluded view.

RECOGNIZING THE SELF THAT IS THE BASIS BOTH OF THE BONDAGE OF DELUSION AND OF LIBERATION

Question If the self does not exist inherently but is merely imputed, what is it that is presently trapped within samsara and that will eventually attain liberation?

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.164] The self with respect to whom a mind grasping at I

Always arises strongly in living beings,

And with respect to whose possessions a mind grasping at mine arises,

That self exists uninvestigated and well-known to confusion.

It is true that the self that is the basis of both samsara and liberation cannot be found if we search for it, but this does not mean that it does not exist at all because if we do not search for it it exists by way of worldly renown. This means that it exists by way of being apprehended by the valid cognizers of worldly beings. Because the valid cognizers of worldly people apprehend the I, the I exists. Thus the I is a mere apprehension of the valid minds of worldly people – it is mere imputation, mere name. If we are satisfied with this mere apprehension, this mere name, ‘I’, it exists and functions, but if we are not satisfied and search for it we will not find it.

Since beginningless time, living beings trapped in samsara have habitually generated a strong view of the transitory collection grasping at I and mine. The self that is the observed object of the view of the transitory collection grasping at I and with respect to whose possessions a mind grasping at mine arises is the self that is the basis of samsara and liberation. It exists uninvestigated and well-known to the valid minds of worldly people.

In the root text the valid minds of worldly people are called ‘confusion’. This refers to the valid minds of those who have not yet realized emptiness. It does not mean actual confusion because confusion is a wrong awareness and not a valid mind.

It is important to stress again the need to put great effort into distinguishing the existent self that is the observed object of the view of the transitory collection from the non-existent self that is its conceived object. To do this we must first realize the lack of inherent existence of the self by analyzing it in seven ways like a cart. Only then will we be able to realize that the self exists as mere conceptual imputation.

NEGATING INHERENTLY EXISTENT MINE

[VI.165] Since without an agent there is no [object of the] action,

Without a self there is no mine.

Therefore Yogis who see that self and mine are empty

Will attain liberation.

Just as it is unsuitable to assert inherently existent self, so it is unsuitable to assert inherently existent mine. Without an agent there is no object of the action. For example, without a potter there is no pot. Therefore, without an inherently existent self there is no inherently existent mine. Since the view of the transitory collection grasping at I and mine is the root of samsara, those who realize that self and mine lack inherent existence will attain liberation from samsara.

THE ANALYSIS OF THE SELF AND THE CART ALSO APPLIES TO OTHER THINGS

This section has three parts:

1 Applying it to things such as pots and woollen cloth

2 Applying it to cause and effect

3 Rejecting an argument against this

APPLYING IT TO THINGS SUCH AS POTS AND WOOLLEN CLOTH

[VI.166] Such things as pots, woollen cloth, canvas, armies, forests, rosaries, trees,

Houses, hand carts, guest houses and so forth

Should be realized in just the same way as they are spoken of,

Because the Able One would never argue with the worldly.

[VI.167] Parts and part-possessors, qualities and quality-possessors, attachment and the attached,

Characteristics and bases of characteristics, firewood and fire and so forth –

Objects such as these do not exist in seven ways when analyzed like a cart,

But otherwise do exist by way of worldly renown.

The reasoning that establishes that the self and the cart do not exist in seven ways but are merely imputed by conception also applies to other things. Thus things such as pots, woollen cloth, canvas, armies, forests, rosaries, trees, houses, hand carts, guest houses and so forth – in fact anything imputed by worldly people in dependence on a valid name – should be realized without investigation to be existent in just the same way as they are spoken of by worldly people. Buddha accepted all these things just as worldly people impute them. He would never argue with worldly people about what they realize with their valid cognizers.

Furthermore, objects such as parts and part-possessors, qualities and quality-possessors, attachment and people with attachment, characteristics and bases of characteristics and firewood and fire are also not inherently existent because they do not exist in seven ways when analyzed like a cart, but they do exist by way of worldly renown because they are all imputed in dependence on valid names by worldly people. Thus we should be satisfied with all these things as mere names just as they are imputed by worldly people; then we will have no difficulty in establishing the two truths of phenomena such as pots and woollen cloth. For example, the lack of inherent existence of a pot is an ultimate truth and the pot existing as mere imputation by conception is a conventional truth. If we are not satisfied with the mere names of things and search further we will find it impossible to establish either of the two truths, and like the proponents of things fall into the two extremes.

APPLYING IT TO CAUSE AND EFFECT

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.168] If a cause produces a product it is a cause

And if no effect is produced then, lacking that, it is not a cause,

But if an effect has a cause it is produced.

Therefore, tell us what arises from what and what precedes what?

[VI.169] If you say that a cause produces an effect through meeting

Then if they are the same potential, producer and effect are not different,

And if they are different, there is no distinction between cause and non-cause.

Having rejected these two, there is no other possibility.

[VI.170ab] If you say that causes do not produce effects then so-called effects do not exist

And without an effect there is no reason for a cause, and they do not exist.

Cause and effect are also not inherently existent. For example, if a cause such as a seed produces a product such as a sprout it is a cause, but if no effect is produced by that seed it is not a cause. Therefore causes depend on their effects. Since we can see clearly that all effects such as sprouts are produced by their causes effects also depend on their causes. Since cause and effect are mutually dependent they lack inherent existence and, like a cart, cannot be found on investigation.

If you assert that cause and effect are inherently existent, then what arises from what and what precedes what? Do effects arise from causes or do causes arise from effects? Do causes precede effects or do effects precede causes? If you say that effects arise from causes, you contradict your assertion that effects are inherently existent because something that is inherently existent does not depend on causes. If you say that causes arise from effects you will only lay yourselves open to ridicule. If you say that causes precede effects then since causes are inherently existent they never cease and if causes never cease effects are never produced because effects arise only on the cessation of their causes. If you say that effects precede causes, again you will simply lay yourselves open to ridicule.

Furthermore, if you say that cause and effect are inherently existent do causes meet their effects or not? If you say that a cause produces an effect through meeting do the cause and effect meet like one person meeting another or do they meet like water flowing into water? If you say it is like one person meeting another cause and effect are simultaneous, but this is impossible. If you say that a cause meets its effect like water flowing into water it follows that cause and effect mingle and become one potential, like a river flowing into a lake. Since they are the same potential they are identical and so cause and effect are not different, which is absurd. If you assert that a cause produces an effect without meeting it then since, according to you cause and effect are inherently different they are completely unrelated. If effects can arise from causes with which they are completely unrelated there is no distinction between cause and non-cause, which is absurd. When a cause produces an effect it must do so either by meeting or by not meeting; there is no third possibility. Since for you neither of these can be established this is a clear indication that you have no correct reasons for saying that cause and effect are inherently existent. If you say that inherently existent causes do not produce effects there are no inherently existent effects, and since without its producing an effect there is no reason for calling it a cause you should also say that causes do not exist inherently.

Proponents of things But these faults also apply to you because cause and effect must either meet or not meet, there is no third possibility.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.170cd] Since both of these are just like illusions, we are not at fault

And worldly people’s things exist.

Since for us both causes and effects lack inherent existence and therefore are just like illusions or reflections we do not incur the fault of falling into the extreme of existence, and since, according to our system, all things imputed by worldly people in dependence on valid names do exist we do not incur the fault of falling into the extreme of non-existence.

REJECTING AN ARGUMENT AGAINST THIS

This section has two parts:

1 The argument that the refutation of inherently existent cause and effect has similar faults

2 Replying that it does not have similar faults

THE ARGUMENT THAT THE REFUTATION OF INHERENTLY EXISTENT CAUSE AND EFFECT HAS SIMILAR FAULTS

Proponents of things

[VI.171] ‘Do these faults not apply to you as well,

For your refutation would refute what is to be refuted either by meeting it or by not meeting it?

When you say this you destroy only your own position.

Thus you are not able to refute what you seek to refute.

[VI.172] And because without any reason you cast aspersions on everything

With false consequences that even in your own words turn back on yourselves,

You will not be accepted by the Holy Ones,

For, because you have no position of your own, you can only dispute by refuting.’

When we said that cause and effect are inherently existent you criticized us by stating the consequence that a cause must produce its effect either by meeting or by not meeting and since neither of these is the case and there is no third possibility our position must be invalid. Well, do these faults not apply to you as well? Your so-called refutation would refute our position either by meeting it or by not meeting it. If the first were the case, your reasons and our reasons would merge and become indistinguishable. If the second were the case, we would be unable to distinguish a refutation from a non-refutation. Since there is no third possibility your position is invalid. Thus, when you say this you destroy only your own position and you are not able to refute our position, which is what you seek to do.

Because without any reason you cast aspersions on everything with false consequences that fail to refute our position but which even in your own words turn back on yourselves, you will not be accepted by the Holy Ones. Because you have no position of your own, you have nothing constructive to say but can only dispute with others by refuting.

REPLYING THAT IT DOES NOT HAVE SIMILAR FAULTS

This section has four parts:

1 How refutation and proof are accepted within our position

2 An explanation clarifying the reason why the others’ consequence is not similar

3 Lack of inherent existence can be established but others cannot establish its opposite in the same way

4 How to understand the remaining refutations not explained here

HOW REFUTATION AND PROOF ARE ACCEPTED WITHIN OUR POSITION

This section has two parts:

1 How refutation of others’ positions is accepted nominally

2 How proofs within our own position are accepted

HOW REFUTATION OF OTHERS’ POSITIONS IS ACCEPTED NOMINALLY

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.173] The fault that you have stated here, that a refutation refutes what is to be refuted

Either by meeting or by not meeting,

Definitely applies to those who hold the position,

But since we do not hold that position the consequence does not follow.

The fault that you have stated here, that our refutation should refute your position either by meeting or by not meeting, definitely applies to those who hold the position that things are inherently existent, but since we do not hold this position the consequence of meeting or not meeting does not follow. However our refutation of your system does exist nominally, undamaged by your criticism.

HOW PROOFS WITHIN OUR OWN POSITION ARE ACCEPTED

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.174] Just as for you at the time of an eclipse and so forth

The characteristics of the orb of the sun are seen even in a reflection,

And although the meeting or non-meeting of the sun and the reflection are certainly inappropriate,

Nevertheless it arises dependently and merely nominally.

[VI.175] And although it is untrue, it is used to beautify the face.

Just as that exists, so too in the same way here,

Our reasons are seen to be effective in cleaning the wisdom face,

For although they are not suited, you should know that with them you can realize the object to be established.

Just as our refutations of others’ positions exist nominally, so too do proofs within our own tradition. Even though nothing exists inherently, nevertheless causes produce effects, and correct reasons prove the objects to be established. For example, if we want to look at the sun at the time of an eclipse both the orb of the sun and its characteristics can be seen by looking at its reflection in water. The reflection of the sun is not inherently existent and if we search for it by investigating whether it meets with the sun or not we will not find it. Nevertheless, it arises in dependence on the sun and exists merely nominally. What is more, it is a reliable sign indicating the characteristics of the sun in the sky. Similarly, a reflection of a face in a mirror is not truly existent because if we investigate to see whether it meets the actual face or not we will not find it. Nevertheless, it exists nominally and we can use it to clean or beautify our face. Just as a reflection of a face lacks inherent existence but is effective in helping to clean the face, so within the Madhyamika position our reasons are effective in cleaning the stains of ignorance from the wisdom face of our opponents such as you proponents of things. Although our reasons such as the reasoning of dependent relationship and the sevenfold reasoning are not inherently existent, you should know that with them you can realize the object to be established, lack of inherent existence.

AN EXPLANATION CLARIFYING THE REASON WHY THE OTHERS’ CONSEQUENCE IS NOT SIMILAR

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.176] If the reasons that cause the objects they establish to be understood existed as things

And if the object established, that which is actually understood, were an existent entity,

You could apply the reasoning of meeting and so forth,

But since they do not exist, you can only despair.

If the reasons such as the reasoning of dependent relationship and the sevenfold reasoning were inherently existent and if the object they establish, the lack of inherent existence of things, were also inherently existent you could apply the consequence of meeting and so forth and your criticisms would be valid, but since they are not you can only despair.

LACK OF INHERENT EXISTENCE CAN BE ESTABLISHED BUT OTHERS CANNOT ESTABLISH ITS OPPOSITE IN THE SAME WAY

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.177] We can very easily induce the realization

That all things lack things,

But you cannot easily make others understand inherent existence in the same way.

So why confound the world with a net of bad views?

With our valid reasons and analogies we can very easily lead others to realize that all things lack inherent existence, but because you have no valid reasons or analogies you cannot make others accept inherent existence in the same way. So why do you confound worldly beings with a net of bad views? Worldly beings are already bound to samsara by the innate view of the transitory collection and as a result experience relentless suffering. Why do you entrap them further with your net of intellectually-formed views grasping at an inherently existent self? Our task is to help living beings escape from their suffering by abandoning self-grasping, not to lead them to even more suffering by increasing their self-grasping!

HOW TO UNDERSTAND THE REMAINING REFUTATIONS NOT EXPLAINED HERE

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[VI.178] Having understood the last refutation just taught,

You should use it here to answer the position of meeting and so forth.

We are not like disputants who only refute.

Any remainder from what has been explained should be understood by this position.

To summarize, in the foregoing reasoning we have extensively explained selflessness of phenomena and selflessness of persons, and on both occasions we refuted others’ systems and established our own. Again the proponents of things sought to discredit us by returning our consequence of meeting and so forth, and again we refuted their system and established our own. Having understood this last refutation you should use it here to answer the position of meeting and so forth. Since we have used valid reasons and analogies and since we have not only refuted others’ positions but also established our own, we are not like disputants who only refute. Once you have understood our reasoning you can use it to refute any assertions of the proponents of things that have not been explained above.

The Madhyamika scholars’ principal intention in refuting others’ positions and establishing their own is to free living beings from wrong views and to lead them to the correct view of profound emptiness. In this way they hope to free all living beings from the sufferings of samsara and lead them to the happiness of liberation. Since they are motivated only by the wish to benefit living beings it is advisable to follow them.

Je Tsongkhapa

The Divisions of Emptiness

AN EXPLANATION OF THE DIVISIONS OF EMPTINESS

This section has two parts:

1 The divisions of emptiness in brief

2 An extensive explanation of the meaning of each division

THE DIVISIONS OF EMPTINESS IN BRIEF

[VI.179] To liberate living beings, the Blessed One said

That this selflessness has two types when divided by way of persons and phenomena;

And then again, according to disciples,

He explained many divisions of these.

[VI.180] Having extensively explained

Sixteen emptinesses

He again explained four in brief,

And these are regarded as the Mahayana.

There are countless objects of knowledge and they are all empty of inherent existence. Because the emptiness of all phenomena is the same nature, it is not possible to distinguish different types of emptiness from the point of view of their nature. For example, in a row of houses each house is clearly distinguishable because it has a different nature from the others, but the space inside the houses is all the same nature. If the houses were demolished there would be no basis for distinguishing the space of one house from the space of another. The only way to distinguish the space of one house from that of another is with reference to the particular house that encloses it. Similarly, the only way to distinguish different types of emptiness is with reference to the particular bases of emptiness.

To liberate living beings from the two obstructions and lead them to enlightenment, Buddha explained two types of emptiness, or selflessness – selflessness of persons and selflessness of phenomena. In this context, ‘phenomena’ means all phenomena other than persons. All emptinesses are included in these two selflessnesses. Although persons and phenomena other than persons are different natures, the selflessness of persons and the selflessness of phenomena are not. They are both simply lack of inherent existence. Thus the division into two selflessnesses is made from the point of view of the bases of emptiness – persons and phenomena other than persons – not from the point of view of the emptiness itself.

Buddha also taught other divisions of emptiness according to the needs of disciples. For example, he gave an extensive explanation of sixteen emptinesses and a condensed explanation of four emptinesses. The sixteen emptinesses are:

(1) The emptiness of the inner

(2) The emptiness of the outer

(3) The emptiness of the inner and outer

(4) The emptiness of emptiness

(5) The emptiness of the great

(6) The emptiness of the ultimate

(7) The emptiness of the produced

(8) The emptiness of the unproduced

(9) The emptiness of beyond extremes

(10) The emptiness of the beginningless and endless

(11) The emptiness of the not rejected

(12) The emptiness of nature

(13) The emptiness of all phenomena

(14) The emptiness of definitions

(15) The emptiness of the unobservable

(16) The emptiness of no thing

The four emptinesses are:

(1) The emptiness of things

(2) The emptiness of non-things

(3) The emptiness of nature

(4) The emptiness of other entities

Buddha gave an extensive explanation of emptiness in the Mahayana Sutras but only a brief explanation in the Hinayana Sutras. Thus, any Sutra that explains these twenty emptinesses is a Mahayana Sutra.

AN EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE MEANING OF EACH DIVISION

This section has two parts:

1 An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into sixteen

2 An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into four

AN EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE DIVISION OF EMPTINESS INTO SIXTEEN

This section has four parts:

1 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the inner and so forth

2 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the great and so forth

3 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of beyond extremes and so forth

4 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of all phenomena and so forth

AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR EMPTINESSES, THE EMPTINESS OF THE INNER AND SO FORTH

This section has four parts:

1 The emptiness of the inner

2 The emptiness of the outer

3 The emptiness of the inner and outer

4 The emptiness of emptiness

THE EMPTINESS OF THE INNER

[VI.181] Eyes are empty of eyes

Because that is their nature.

Ears, nose, tongue, body and mind

Should be understood in the same way.

[VI.182] Because they do not remain constant

And do not disintegrate,

The lack of inherent existence

Of the six, eyes and so forth,

Is said to be the emptiness of the inner.

Eyes are empty of inherently existent eyes because the lack of inherently existent eyes is their ultimate nature. Here, ‘eyes’ refers to the eye sense power. The remaining five powers – ear sense power, nose sense power, tongue sense power, body sense power and mental power – should be understood in the same way. The six powers are not permanent and they do not inherently disintegrate, therefore they are completely empty of inherent existence.

In general there are two types of phenomenon – inner and outer. Inner phenomena are those that are conjoined with a continuum of consciousness and outer phenomena are those that are not. Within inner phenomena the six powers – the eye sense power and so forth – are known as the ‘six inner sources’ and their lack of inherent existence is called the ‘emptiness of the inner’. This was taught by Buddha as a method for abandoning self-grasping of inner phenomena.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE OUTER

[VI.183] Forms are empty of forms

Because that is their nature.

Sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects and phenomena

Are just the same.

[VI.184ab] The lack of inherent existence of forms and so forth

Is said to be the emptiness of the outer.

Forms that are not conjoined with a continuum of consciousness are empty of inherently existent forms because the lack of inherently existent forms is their ultimate nature. The remaining five outer sources – sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects and phenomena – should be understood in the same way. None of these phenomena is inherently permanent and they do not inherently disintegrate, therefore they are completely empty of inherent existence. Because in this case the bases of emptiness are outer phenomena, the lack of inherent existence of forms and so forth is called the ‘emptiness of the outer’. By meditating on this emptiness we overcome self-grasping of outer phenomena.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE INNER AND OUTER

[VI.184cd] The lack of inherent existence of both

Is the emptiness of the inner and outer.

[VI.185ab] The lack of inherent existence of phenomena

Is explained as emptiness by the wise.

The physical bases of the eyes and the other sense powers – the eye organ, ear organ and so on – are both inner and outer phenomena. They are inner because they are conjoined with a continuum of consciousness and because they are the basis of mind, and they are outer because they can be seen by eye consciousness. The lack of inherent existence of that which is both inner and outer is called the ‘emptiness of the inner and outer’. Because lack of inherent existence is the ultimate nature of these phenomena it is explained as emptiness by the wise. By meditating on this emptiness we overcome self-grasping of phenomena that are both inner and outer.

THE EMPTINESS OF EMPTINESS

[VI.185cd] And that emptiness too is said to be

Empty of the entity of emptiness.

[VI.186] The emptiness of what is called ‘emptiness’

Is said to be the emptiness of emptiness.

It was taught to overcome the mind

That apprehends emptiness as a thing.

Emptiness itself is empty of inherently existent emptiness. The emptiness of emptiness was taught by Buddha to overcome the mind that apprehends emptiness as inherently existent.

When we first realize selflessness of persons and selflessness of phenomena we still have dualistic appearance during meditative equipoise on emptiness and so emptiness appears to our mind mixed with the appearance of true existence. To overcome this we must meditate on the emptiness of emptiness. Eventually through this meditation all dualistic appearance subsides into emptiness and only emptiness appears to our mind. At that point our mind mixes with emptiness like water mixing with water. Only with this meditation can we eliminate the two obstructions and attain enlightenment.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR EMPTINESSES, THE EMPTINESS OF THE GREAT AND SO FORTH

This section has four parts:

1 The emptiness of the great

2 The emptiness of the ultimate

3 The emptiness of the produced

4 The emptiness of the unproduced

THE EMPTINESS OF THE GREAT

[VI.187] Because they pervade all environments

And their beings,

And because they are without end like the immeasurables,

The directions are great.

[VI.188] That which is the emptiness

Of all these ten directions

Is the emptiness of the great.

It was taught to overcome grasping at the great.

The ten directions are called ‘great’ because they pervade all environments and their beings. When we meditate on the four immeasurables we cannot find an end to living beings or their various worlds pervading space. In the same way, when we contemplate the ten directions we cannot find an end to them. Therefore they are called ‘great’ and the lack of inherent existence of the ten directions is called the ‘emptiness of the great’. It was taught by Buddha to overcome the mind that apprehends the ten directions as inherently existent.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE ULTIMATE

[VI.189] Because it is the supreme purpose,

The ultimate is nirvana.

That which is its emptiness

Is the emptiness of the ultimate.

[VI.190] The Knower of the ultimate

Taught the emptiness of the ultimate

To overcome the mind

That apprehends nirvana as a thing.

Here, ‘ultimate’ refers to ultimate nirvana. When the mind is finally freed from the two obstructions the emptiness of the mind is also freed from them. The emptiness of a mind freed from the two obstructions is a Truth Body and a nirvana. Because this nirvana is the ultimate goal, the supreme purpose of every living being, it is called the ‘ultimate’. The lack of inherent existence of ultimate nirvana is called the ‘emptiness of the ultimate’. Buddha taught this emptiness to overcome the mind that apprehends nirvana as inherently existent.

In general, there are two types of nirvana – a nirvana that is an abandonment merely of the delusion-obstructions, which is a Hinayana nirvana, and a nirvana that is an abandonment of both the delusion-obstructions and the obstructions to omniscience, which is a Mahayana nirvana. Both are necessarily emptiness, ultimate truth. In the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras Buddha calls emptiness itself ‘natural nirvana’ but it is not an actual nirvana. An actual nirvana is necessarily a true cessation and a liberation.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE PRODUCED

[VI.191] Because they arise from conditions,

The three realms are definitely explained as produced.

That which is their emptiness

Is said to be the emptiness of the produced.

In the Sutras the three realms – the desire realm, the form realm and the formless realm – are called ‘produced’ to show that they arise from their own causes and conditions and are not created by gods such as Ishvara. The lack of inherent existence of the three realms is called the ‘emptiness of the produced’.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE UNPRODUCED

[VI.192] Whatever lacks production, abiding and impermanence

Is unproduced.

That which is its emptiness

Is the emptiness of the unproduced.

Production, abiding and disintegration are characteristics of impermanent, produced phenomena. Any phenomenon that lacks these characteristics is permanent and unproduced. Thus, for example, space, generic images and the subtle conventional natures of all phenomena lack production, abiding and disintegration and so are unproduced phenomena. The lack of inherent existence of unproduced phenomena is called the ‘emptiness of the unproduced’.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR EMPTINESSES, THE EMPTINESS OF BEYOND EXTREMES AND SO FORTH

This section has four parts:

1 The emptiness of beyond extremes

2 The emptiness of the beginningless and endless

3 The emptiness of the not rejected

4 The emptiness of nature

THE EMPTINESS OF BEYOND EXTREMES

[VI.193] Whatever is without extremes

Is described as beyond extremes.

The mere emptiness of that

Is explained as the emptiness of beyond extremes.

Whatever is free from the two extremes of existence and non-existence is called ‘beyond extremes’ and its lack of inherent existence is called the ‘emptiness of beyond extremes’. As explained before, the extreme of existence is phenomena being inherently existent and the extreme of non-existence is phenomena being non-existent. Since neither of these exists, all phenomena are beyond extremes. A mind holding phenomena to be inherently existent is called a ‘view of existence’ and a mind holding phenomena to be non-existent is called a ‘view of non-existence’.

The middle way that is free from the two extremes is profound emptiness. If it is a middle way it is necessarily a mere absence of inherent existence. Sometimes texts such as Fundamental Wisdom and Guide to the Middle Way are called the ‘middle way’ but this is because they reveal the middle way not because they are the actual middle way. Wisdom realizing emptiness is known as the ‘view of the middle way’ because its main object is the middle way, emptiness.

Some texts explain that since all phenomena are free from extremes they are all the middle way. However, it does not seem suitable to say that ordinary objects such as chairs and tables are the middle way and it is certainly not suitable to refer to wrong paths, delusions and wrong views as the middle way.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE BEGINNINGLESS AND ENDLESS

[VI.194] Because samsara lacks both

A first beginning and a final end

It is described as beginningless and endless.

Because it is free from coming and going, it is like a dream.

[VI.195] In the scriptures it clearly says that

That which is the isolation of this samsara

Is called the ‘emptiness

Of the beginningless and endless’.

Samsara lacks a first beginning and, if we do not apply the antidotes, it will have no final end. Therefore it is called ‘beginningless and endless’. Furthermore, because there is no inherently existent coming from former lives or going to future lives in samsara, samsara is empty of inherent existence like a dream. In the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras the lack of inherent existence of samsara is called the ‘emptiness of the beginningless and endless’.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE NOT REJECTED

[VI.196] Rejected is clearly explained as

Cast aside or forsaken.

Not rejected, or not given up,

Is that which should not be rejected at any time.

[VI.197] That which is the emptiness

Of the not rejected

Is therefore called

The ‘emptiness of the not rejected’.

In this context, Mahayana paths are called ‘not rejected’ because they should not be rejected at any time. The lack of inherent existence of Mahayana paths is called the ‘emptiness of the not rejected’.

If we reject Mahayana paths we will have no chance to attain full enlightenment. To indicate that it is a great mistake to abandon Mahayana paths, in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras Buddha calls them the ‘not rejected’ and because Mahayana paths are empty of inherent existence Buddha explained the emptiness of the not rejected. Therefore, we should understand that while it is a great mistake to give up the practice of Mahayana Dharma and Mahayana paths we should not grasp at them as being inherently existent.

THE EMPTINESS OF NATURE

[VI.198] Because the very entity

Of the produced and so forth

Was not made by Hearers, Solitary Realizers,

Conquerors’ Sons, or Tathagatas,

[VI.199] So the very entity of the produced and so forth

Is explained as their very nature.

That which is the emptiness of that

Is the emptiness of nature.

The ultimate truth of all phenomena such as produced phenomena is their very nature. It was not made by Hearers, Solitary Realizers, Bodhisattvas, Buddhas or any other being. The lack of inherent existence of this ultimate nature is called the ‘emptiness of nature’.

The ultimate nature of any phenomenon is its lack of inherent existence. Because they do not realize the ultimate nature of phenomena, living beings grasp at phenomena as being inherently existent. This gives rise to delusions such as attachment and hatred and these in turn give rise to contaminated actions that cause rebirth in samsara. Thus, all the misery in this world arises from not knowing the ultimate nature of phenomena. In Condensed Perfection of Wisdom Sutra Buddha says:

With wisdom we can fully understand the nature of phenomena

And then we will be free from every suffering in the three realms.

Therefore, if we want to be free from the sufferings of samsara we must put effort into realizing the ultimate nature of phenomena, lack of inherent existence.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE FOUR EMPTINESSES, THE EMPTINESS OF ALL PHENOMENA AND SO FORTH

This section has four parts:

1 The emptiness of all phenomena

2 The emptiness of definitions

3 The emptiness of the unobservable

4 The emptiness of no thing

THE EMPTINESS OF ALL PHENOMENA

[VI.200] The eighteen elements, the six contacts,

The six feelings that arise from them,

Likewise, those possessing form and those not possessing form

And produced and unproduced phenomena –

[VI.201ab] That which is the isolation of all of these

Is the emptiness of all phenomena.

There are many different phenomena. There are eighteen elements, which consist of six objects – forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects and phenomena; six powers – eye sense power, ear sense power, nose sense power, tongue sense power, body sense power and mental power; and six consciousnesses – eye consciousness, ear consciousness, nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, body consciousness and mental consciousness. There are six contacts, which are the mental factor contact associated with each of the six consciousnesses, and six feelings, which are the feelings that arise from each of the six contacts. There are phenomena possessing form and phenomena not possessing form, as well as produced phenomena and unproduced phenomena. The lack of inherent existence of all of these phenomena is called the ‘emptiness of all phenomena’.

THE EMPTINESS OF DEFINITIONS

When Buddha taught the fourteenth division of emptiness in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras he gave an extensive explanation of the definitions of phenomena, from forms through to the knower of all aspects. These are now presented under the following three headings:

1 A brief explanation

2 An extensive explanation

3 A summary

A BRIEF EXPLANATION

[VI.201cd] That which is the non-thing of suitable to be form and so forth

Is the emptiness of definitions.

The definition of form is suitable to be form. The lack of inherent existence of this and of all other definitions is called the ‘emptiness of definitions’.

AN EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION

This section has three parts:

1 The definitions of the phenomena of the base

2 The definitions of the phenomena of the path

3 The definitions of the phenomena of the result

THE DEFINITIONS OF THE PHENOMENA OF THE BASE

[VI.202] Form has the definition, suitable to be form,

Feeling has the nature of experience,

Discrimination is apprehending signs,

And compositional factors are produced phenomena.

[VI.203] The definition of consciousness

Is cognizing aspects of individual objects.

The definition of aggregate is suffering.

The nature of the elements is said to be a poisonous snake.

[VI.204] The sources are said by Buddha

To be the doors for generation.

Within dependent relationship, that which arises

Is defined as coming together.

The definition of aggregate of form is suitable to be form. This means that anything that is suitable to appear to any of the five sense consciousnesses – visual forms, sounds, smells, tastes and tactile objects – is form. The definition of aggregate of feeling is a mental factor that functions to experience pleasant, unpleasant or neutral objects. The definition of aggregate of discrimination is a mental factor that functions to apprehend the uncommon sign of an object. The definition of aggregate of compositional factors is any product that is not one of the other four aggregates. This includes all mental factors apart from feeling and discrimination as well as persons, potentialities, karmic imprints and so forth. The definition of aggregate of consciousness is a primary mind that cognizes the general aspect of an object. These are the definitions of the five aggregates in general. Within these, there are two types – contaminated aggregates and uncontaminated aggregates. The definition of contaminated aggregate is an aggregate with the nature of suffering that arises from delusions that are its causes. An example is any of the five contaminated aggregates of an ordinary being. The definition of uncontaminated aggregate is an aggregate that arises in dependence on an uncontaminated wisdom. An example is any of the five aggregates of a Buddha.

The definition of element is that which holds its own nature. An example is any phenomenon because all phenomena hold their own natures. There are two types – contaminated element and uncontaminated element. The definition of contaminated element is an element that holds any part of the environment, beings or enjoyments of samsara. In the scriptures, contaminated elements are likened to a poisonous snake because living beings are held within samsara and subjected to suffering in much the same way as a victim is held and tormented by a poisonous snake. There are eighteen contaminated elements. Whatever is a contaminated element is necessarily a product. The contaminated element of phenomena consists of all contaminated mental factors, seeds of delusions, imprints of delusions and so forth.

The definition of source is a door for generating consciousness. An example is any phenomenon because all phenomena are doors for generating consciousness of themselves. If there is no object, a consciousness cannot be generated; therefore phenomena are sources of consciousness. There are twelve sources, which can be either contaminated or uncontaminated. The definition of contaminated source is a source that is a door for generating suffering. An example is any of the five contaminated aggregates. The definition of uncontaminated source is a source that is a door for generating an uncontaminated mind. An example is emptiness.

The definition of dependent-related phenomenon is that which depends on its parts. There are two types – produced dependent-related phenomena and unproduced dependent-related phenomena. The definition of produced dependent-related phenomenon is a dependent-related phenomenon that arises from causes and conditions. The root text says ‘coming together’, which means the assembling of causes and conditions. There are two types of produced dependent-related phenomena – contaminated produced dependent-related phenomena and uncontaminated produced dependent-related phenomena. Examples of the first are the twelve dependent-related links, dependent-related ignorance and so forth. An example of the second is the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of a Superior being. The definition of unproduced dependent-related phenomenon is a dependent-related phenomenon that does not depend on causes and conditions. Examples are any permanent phenomenon such as unproduced space, emptiness or any non-affirming negative.

THE DEFINITIONS OF THE PHENOMENA OF THE PATH

[VI.205] The perfection of giving is giving away.

Moral discipline is defined as without torment.

Patience is defined as without anger.

Effort is defined as without non-virtue.

[VI.206] Mental stabilization is defined as gathering.

Wisdom is defined as without attachment.

These are given as the definitions

Of the six perfections.

[VI.207] The mental stabilizations, the immeasurables,

And likewise others that are formless

Are said by the Perfect Knower

To have the definition unperturbed.

[VI.208] The thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment

Are defined as causing definite emergence.

The definition of emptiness

Is complete isolation through not observing.

[VI.209] Signlessness is pacification.

The definition of the third is the absence of suffering and confusion.

The [concentrations of] perfect liberation

Are defined as perfectly liberating.

The definition of Mahayana path is a path conjoined with spontaneous bodhichitta. There are six types of Mahayana path – the perfection of giving, the perfection of moral discipline, the perfection of patience, the perfection of effort, the perfection of mental stabilization and the perfection of wisdom. The definition of giving is a virtuous determination to give. The definition of moral discipline is a virtuous determination to abandon non-virtuous actions and faults. The definition of patience is a virtuous determination to forbear harm, suffering or profound Dharma. The definition of effort is a virtuous mind that delights in virtue. The definition of mental stabilization is a virtuous mind that remains single-pointedly on a virtuous object. The definition of wisdom is a virtuous, intelligent mind that functions to dispel doubt by realizing its object thoroughly. If the practice of giving is conjoined with spontaneous bodhichitta it is a perfection of giving. The remaining five perfections can be understood in the same way.

The root text says that moral discipline is ‘without torment’. This means that a mind controlled by pure moral discipline is free from the pain of the delusions. Patience is said to be ‘without anger’ because a mind controlled by patience is completely free from anger. Effort is said to be ‘without non-virtue’ because a mind controlled by effort engages only in virtue. Mental stabilization is called ‘gathering’ because developing pure concentration is the basis for gathering all good qualities. Wisdom is said to be ‘without attachment’ because the wisdom realizing emptiness does not grasp at inherent existence.

The definition of perfection of giving for a Bodhisattva with sharp faculties is a virtuous determination to give that possesses the three attributes of motivation, helper and function. The motivation for practising the perfection of giving must be to lead all living beings to the bliss of Buddhahood. The ‘helper’ of the perfection of giving is the wisdom realizing emptiness. For a Bodhisattva with sharp faculties the perfection of giving is necessarily held by this wisdom. A Bodhisattva who has not yet realized emptiness has the practice of the perfection of giving, but not an actual realization of the perfection of giving. The function of the perfection of giving is to eliminate conditions discordant with giving such as miserliness, attachment and self-cherishing, and to ripen living beings. When Bodhisattvas give things to others their main motivation is to establish a good relationship with the recipient so that they can guide them along the spiritual path. For this reason Bodhisattvas sometimes strive to acquire wealth and possessions even though they have no desire for these things from their own side. The remaining five perfections can be understood in the same way. These definitions of the six perfections are given in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras.

The definition of absorption is a single-pointed virtuous mind of either the form or the formless realm. There are two types of absorption – absorptions of close preparation and actual absorptions. The definition of absorption of close preparation is a single-pointed virtuous mind of the upper realms that is the main cause of any of the eight actual absorptions. There are eight absorptions of close preparation – the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization, the absorption of close preparation of the second mental stabilization, the absorption of close preparation of the third mental stabilization and the absorption of close preparation of the fourth mental stabilization, which are all absorptions of close preparation of the form realm; and the absorption of close preparation of infinite space, the absorption of close preparation of infinite consciousness, the absorption of close preparation of nothingness and the absorption of close preparation of peak of samsara, which are all absorptions of close preparation of the formless realm.

The definition of absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization is the absorption of close preparation that is the main cause of attaining the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization. The definitions of the remaining seven absorptions of close preparation can be understood from this.

The definition of actual absorption is a released path of absorption that is attained by means of any of the eight absorptions of close preparation. There are eight actual absorptions – the actual absorption of the first mental stabilization, the actual absorption of the second mental stabilization, the actual absorption of the third mental stabilization and the actual absorption of the fourth mental stabilization, which are all actual absorptions of the form realm; and the actual absorption of infinite space, the actual absorption of infinite consciousness, the actual absorption of nothingness and the actual absorption of peak of samsara, which are all actual absorptions of the formless realm.

The definition of actual absorption of the first mental stabilization is a released path of absorption that is released from the nine levels of delusion of the desire realm and that is attained by means of meditation on the absorption of close preparation of the first mental stabilization. The definition of actual absorption of the second mental stabilization is a released path of absorption that is released from the nine levels of delusion of the first form realm and that is attained by means of meditation on the absorption of close preparation of the second mental stabilization. The definitions of the remaining six actual absorptions can be understood from these. The actual absorption of the third mental stabilization is released from the nine levels of delusion of the second form realm, the actual absorption of the fourth mental stabilization is released from the nine levels of delusion of the third form realm, the actual absorption of infinite space is released from the nine levels of delusion of the fourth form realm, the actual absorption of infinite consciousness is released from the nine levels of delusion of the first formless realm, the actual absorption of nothingness is released from the nine levels of delusion of the second formless realm and the actual absorption of peak of samsara, which is the eighth actual absorption, is released from the nine levels of delusion of the third formless realm. The ninth level of delusion of the fourth formless realm, peak of samsara, cannot be abandoned by mundane paths. To abandon this we need to enter supramundane paths.

The definition of immeasurable compassion is a compassion observing immeasurable living beings that is attained in dependence on any of the four actual absorptions of the form realm or the four actual absorptions of the formless realm. The definition of immeasurable love is a love observing immeasurable living beings that is attained in dependence on the four actual absorptions of the form realm and the four actual absorptions of the formless realm. The definition of immeasurable equanimity is an equanimity observing immeasurable living beings that is attained in dependence on the four actual absorptions of the form realm and the four actual absorptions of the formless realm. The definition of immeasurable joy is a joy observing immeasurable living beings that is attained in dependence on the four actual absorptions of the form realm and the four actual absorptions of the formless realm.

Buddha said that the four mental stabilizations of the form realm, the four immeasurables and the four formless realm absorptions are all by nature unperturbed because to attain any of them we must first overcome anger.

The definition of realization conducive to enlightenment is a path that causes definite emergence from samsara or solitary peace. There are thirty-seven realizations – four close placements of mindfulness, four correct abandoners, four legs of miracle powers, five powers, five forces, seven branches of enlightenment and eight branches of superior paths.

The definition of close placement of mindfulness is a path of concentration on any of the common or uncommon aspects of body, feelings, mind or phenomena that depends on mindfulness and wisdom. There are four types – close placement of mindfulness of body, close placement of mindfulness of feelings, close placement of mindfulness of mind and close placement of mindfulness of phenomena. The definition of close placement of mindfulness of body is a path of concentration on any of the common or uncommon aspects of the body that depends on mindfulness and wisdom. The definition of close placement of mindfulness of feelings is a path of concentration on any of the common or uncommon aspects of feelings that depends on mindfulness and wisdom. The definition of close placement of mindfulness of mind is a path of concentration on any of the common or uncommon aspects of mind that depends on mindfulness and wisdom. The definition of close placement of mindfulness of phenomena is a path of concentration on any of the common or uncommon aspects of phenomena other than body, feelings and mind that depends on mindfulness and wisdom.

The definition of correct abandoner is a path of effort that strives to abandon what is to be abandoned and practise what is to be practised. There are four types – correct abandoners that abandon non-virtues already generated, correct abandoners that do not generate non-virtues not yet generated, correct abandoners that increase virtues already generated and correct abandoners that generate virtues not yet generated. The definition of the first is a path of effort that strives to abandon non-virtues already generated, the definition of the second is a path of effort that strives to abstain from non-virtue, the definition of the third is a path of effort that strives to increase virtues already generated and the definition of the fourth is a path of effort that strives to generate virtues not yet generated.

The definition of leg of miracle powers is a path of concentration observing emanated objects and activities. There are four types – the legs of miracle powers of aspiration, effort, mind and analysis. The definition of leg of miracle powers of aspiration is a leg of miracle powers induced by a strong wish to display miracle powers. The definition of leg of miracle powers of effort is a leg of miracle powers induced by constant and forceful effort. The definition of leg of miracle powers of mind is a leg of miracle powers induced principally through the ripening of potentials within the mind. The definition of leg of miracle powers of analysis is a leg of miracle powers induced principally through analytical meditation on instructions given by others.

The definition of a power that is a realization conducive to enlightenment is a path that has acquired great power to produce its effect, superior paths. There are five types – the powers of faith, effort, mindfulness, concentration and wisdom.

The definition of a force that is a realization conducive to enlightenment is a path of patience or above on the path of preparation that cannot be affected by adverse conditions. There are five types – the forces of faith, effort, mindfulness, concentration and wisdom.

The definition of branch of enlightenment is a superior path that directly realizes emptiness. There are seven types – the branches of enlightenment of correct mindfulness, correct wisdom, correct effort, correct joy, correct suppleness, correct concentration and correct equanimity.

The definition of branch of superior paths is a path that generates its effect, higher superior paths. There are eight types – the branches of superior paths of correct view, correct conception, correct speech, correct ends of actions, correct livelihood, correct effort, correct mindfulness and correct concentration.

There are three doors of perfect liberation – the door of perfect liberation of emptiness, the door of perfect liberation of signlessness and the door of perfect liberation of wishlessness. The definition of the first is the emptiness that is the lack of inherent existence of the entity of any phenomenon. An example is the lack of inherent existence of the entity of a sprout. The definition of the second is the emptiness that is the lack of inherent existence of the cause of any phenomenon. An example is the lack of inherent existence of the cause of a sprout. The definition of the third is the emptiness that is the lack of inherent existence of the effect of any phenomenon. An example is the lack of inherent existence of the effect of a sprout.

Meditation on the first door of perfect liberation leads to a realization that the entities of phenomena lack true existence, and this realization leads to the pacification of the true-grasping that conceives the entities of phenomena to be truly existent. In the root text, ‘not observing’ refers to lack of inherent existence and ‘isolation’ means liberation. Meditation on the second door of perfect liberation leads to a realization that causes do not truly exist and this realization leads to the pacification of the true-grasping that conceives the causes of things to be truly existent. Here ‘sign’ means cause and so ‘signlessness’ means the lack of true existence of causes. Meditation on the third door of perfect liberation leads to a realization that effects do not truly exist and this realization leads us to liberation from the effect of samsara, suffering and its cause, confusion. Here, ‘wish’ means the objects that are wished for, both those on the side of samsara and those on the side of liberation. ‘Wishlessness’ is the lack of inherent existence of all these objects.

All three doors of perfect liberation are the same in that they are mere lack of inherent existence. Therefore, strictly speaking there is only one door of perfect liberation – emptiness. In other texts it says there is only one door of liberation and that besides emptiness a second door cannot be found. Thus, the three doors of perfect liberation are distinguished not from the point of view of emptiness but from the point of view of their bases.

The definition of concentration of perfect liberation is a single-pointed virtuous mind of the upper realms that is liberated from obstructions to absorption. There are eight types – the concentration of perfect liberation that observes various emanated forms both large and small while inwardly retaining the discrimination of a form-possessor, the concentration of perfect liberation that observes various emanated forms both large and small while inwardly having abandoned the discrimination of a form-possessor, the concentration of perfect liberation that observes various beautiful emanated forms, the concentration of perfect liberation of the absorption of infinite space, the concentration of perfect liberation of the absorption of infinite consciousness, the concentration of perfect liberation of the absorption of nothingness, the concentration of perfect liberation of the absorption of peak of samsara and the concentration of perfect liberation of the absorption of the cessation of feelings and discriminations.

THE DEFINITIONS OF THE PHENOMENA OF THE RESULT

[VI.210] The forces are said to be the nature of

Utterly perfect decisiveness.

The fearlessnesses of the Protector

Are the nature of utter firmness.

[VI.211] The correct, specific cognizers

Have the definition inexhaustible confidence and so on.

Accomplishing the benefit of living beings

Is called ‘great love’.

[VI.212] Completely protecting those who suffer

Is great compassion.

Joy is defined as supreme joy,

And equanimity should be known by the definition unmixed.

[VI.213] Whatever are asserted to be

The eighteen unshared qualities of a Buddha

Are defined as unsurpassed

Because the Blessed One is never surpassed by them.

[VI.214] The exalted awareness knowing all aspects

Is said to have the definition direct perceiver.

Others, being limited,

Are not called ‘direct perceivers’.

The definition of a force of a Buddha is an ultimate realization that is utterly victorious over all adverse conditions such as the two obstructions. There are ten forces of a Buddha, which are explained in detail in the chapter Resultant Grounds.

The definition of a quality of fearlessness of a Buddha is an utterly firm, ultimate realization that is entirely free from fear in expounding Dharma. There are four types – fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of definite emergence, fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of overcoming obstructions, fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of excellent abandonments and fearlessness in revealing the Dharma of excellent realizations. When Buddhas give Dharma teachings they have supreme confidence and are completely free from nervousness or hesitation, even if they have to address a vast audience of highly realized beings. With utter confidence they can admit to being fully enlightened and to possessing all the excellent qualities of a Buddha’s body, speech and mind, knowing that there is no one who can refute it. Similarly, they can declare that they have overcome all delusions and their imprints and are completely without faults. Because Buddhas have abandoned all objects to be abandoned, from gross moral faults such as killing to the most subtle obstructions to omniscience, they can confidently teach others how to do the same. Similarly, they can reveal from their own experience how to accomplish everything that is to be realized. Buddhas understand all these things in general and they also understand how they apply to each individual disciple. Therefore, they always give advice that is perfectly suited to the listener.

The definition of correct, specific cognizer is an ultimate realization that knows the entities, divisions and so forth of all phenomena without error. There are four types – correct cognizers of specific phenomena, correct cognizers of specific meanings, correct cognizers of specific, definite words and correct cognizers of specific confidence. An example of the first is a wisdom of a Buddha that realizes the specific, uncommon signs of all phenomena, an example of the second is a wisdom of a Buddha that realizes the specific divisions of all phenomena, an example of the third is a wisdom of a Buddha that realizes the specific etymological explanations of all phenomena and an example of the fourth is a wisdom of a Buddha that experiences inexhaustible confidence in revealing Dharma.

The definition of the great love that is a quality of a Buddha is an ultimate love that bestows benefit and happiness on all living beings. The definition of the great compassion that is a quality of a Buddha is an ultimate compassion completely protecting suffering beings. The definition of the great joy that is a quality of a Buddha is an ultimate joy that is supremely joyful in leading all living beings to a state of happiness. The definition of the great equanimity that is a quality of a Buddha is an ultimate realization unmixed with attachment or hatred.

The definition of an unshared quality of a Buddha is an uncommon quality of the body, speech or mind of a Buddha that is not possessed by other Superior beings. There are eighteen unshared qualities – six unshared activities, six unshared realizations, three unshared deeds and three unshared exalted awarenesses. They are called ‘unsurpassed’ because these qualities in Buddha Shakyamuni are never surpassed by others.

The six unshared activities are – not possessing mistaken activities of body, not possessing mistaken activities of speech, not possessing mistaken activities of mind, not possessing a mind not in meditative equipoise, not possessing conceptuality and not possessing neutrality. All Buddha’s bodily, verbal and mental actions are completely pure and unmistaken because they arise from the all-knowing exalted wisdom. Sometimes Hinayana Foe Destroyers and even Bodhisattvas on the three pure grounds may act mistakenly due to the imprints of delusions, but Buddhas never make mistakes. Even when they are engaged in activities of subsequent attainment such as giving teachings to others their mind remains in meditative equipoise. Only Buddhas can manifest unmistaken minds during subsequent attainment. Moreover, because their minds are completely free from conceptuality they do not need conceptual motivation to act. All their actions arise spontaneously through the force of their unobstructed great compassion. All Buddha’s actions are virtuous. Buddhas do not engage even in neutral actions, let alone in negative ones.

The six unshared realizations are – not possessing degeneration of aspiration, not possessing degeneration of effort, not possessing degeneration of mindfulness, not possessing degeneration of concentration, not possessing degeneration of wisdom and not possessing degeneration of perfect liberation. Buddhas have already accomplished their own purpose so their only aspiration is to accomplish the purpose of others. They have completed the perfection of effort and so all their actions arise naturally and spontaneously. Because their mind is a subtle mind of clear light realizing conventional truths and ultimate truth directly and simultaneously their mindfulness, concentration and wisdom never degenerate, and because they have attained true cessations of the two obstructions their experience of liberation is supreme and indestructible.

The three unshared deeds are – deeds of body preceded by and followed by exalted awareness, deeds of speech preceded by and followed by exalted awareness and deeds of mind preceded by and followed by exalted awareness. Because Buddha’s body, speech and mind are the nature of omniscient wisdom all his deeds of body, speech and mind are completely pure, unobstructed and all-pervasive. For example, Buddha’s body is not obstructed by physical forms. Wherever Buddha’s mind is his or her body is there too. Since his mind pervades all objects of knowledge so does his body. Therefore if we make prayers to Buddha we can be confident that he is immediately present. Buddha’s speech is completely free from faults such as being too loud, too soft, unclear, or unpleasant to listen to. No matter how far away the listener is, Buddha’s speech is always perfectly audible and intelligible. Just as thunder spontaneously manifests from the sky when the necessary atmospheric conditions occur, so Buddhas spontaneously give perfect teachings whenever their unobstructed wisdom and compassion meet with receptive disciples. Because Buddha’s mind is perfectly pure and unobstructed his environment and enjoyments are also pure. Thus, for example, if we offer a bowl of water to Buddha, he experiences only uncontaminated nectar.

The three unshared exalted awarenesses are – unobstructed exalted awareness that knows all the past without obstruction, unobstructed exalted awareness that knows all the future without obstruction and unobstructed exalted awareness that knows all the present without obstruction. To understand how Buddhas can know all three times directly and simultaneously we need to contemplate deeply the explanation of the three times given previously.

The definition of knower of all aspects is an exalted awareness that is completely free from obstructions to omniscience and knows all aspects of all objects of knowledge directly and simultaneously. It is synonymous with omniscient mind and Wisdom Truth Body and is possessed only by Buddhas. Ordinary beings do not know all aspects of even one object, let alone all objects.
