In Ornament for Clear Realization Maitreya gives three reasons why Buddha’s mind knows all phenomena directly and simultaneously – (1) Buddhas directly realize the two truths of all phenomena because they have completed meditation on the two truths being one entity (2) Buddhas have complete knowledge of all phenomena being of one taste in the state of emptiness and (3) a Buddha’s mind is completely free from the two obstructions.

The knower of all aspects is often called the ‘Mother of Buddhas’ because it fulfils Buddha’s wishes, just as a mother fulfils the wishes of her children. Buddha’s main wish is to lead all beings to the supreme happiness of full enlightenment and he can fulfil this wish only because he possesses the knower of all aspects. Because he has attained omniscient wisdom, Buddha is able perfectly to turn the Wheel of Dharma and lead countless beings along the path to liberation and enlightenment.

The root text calls the knower of all aspects ‘direct perceiver’ because it is the ultimate direct perceiver of all aspects. Others who are not Buddhas do not have this mind.

A SUMMARY

[VI.215] Whether they are definitions of produced phenomena

Or definitions of unproduced phenomena,

Their mere emptiness

Is the emptiness of definitions.

All definitions, from the definition of form up to the definition of the knower of all aspects, are included in two categories – definitions of produced phenomena and definitions of unproduced phenomena. The lack of inherent existence of all these is explained in Sutra as the ‘emptiness of definitions’.

THE EMPTINESS OF THE UNOBSERVABLE

[VI.216] The present does not remain

And past and future do not exist.

Because they are not observed anywhere

They are explained as unobservable.

[VI.217] That which is the very isolation

Of the entities of these unobservables,

Because they neither remain constant nor disintegrate,

Is the emptiness of the unobservable.

A present thing does not remain for a second moment. Moreover, at that time the arising of past things has ceased and the arising of future things does not yet exist. Therefore, the three times do not exist together anywhere. For this reason they are said to be ‘unobservable’. Because they are not inherently constant and because they do not inherently disintegrate the three times are empty of inherent existence. The lack of inherent existence of the three times is called the ‘emptiness of the unobservable’.

THE EMPTINESS OF NO THING

[VI.218] Because they arise from conditions

Things lack the entity of assembling.

The emptiness of assembling

Is the emptiness of no thing.

Things do not exist inherently because they arise from the assembling of their causes and conditions, therefore the assembling of causes and conditions is called ‘no thing’. The emptiness of the assembling of causes and conditions is called ‘the emptiness of no thing’.

The sixteen emptinesses listed above are distinguished not in terms of their entities nor in terms of the reasoning that establishes them but in terms of the functions of the meditative concentrations that observe them. In terms of their entities they are all the same because they are all mere lack of inherent existence. Similarly in terms of the reasoning that establishes them they are not different because once we have realized one emptiness we can realize all the others through the same reasoning. The meditative concentrations that observe these sixteen emptinesses, however, perform different functions. Thus meditation on the emptiness of the inner functions to overcome true-grasping, attachment and other negative conceptions with respect to inner phenomena such as our body and meditation on the emptiness of the outer functions to overcome true-grasping, attachment and other negative conceptions with respect to outer phenomena such as our possessions. The functions of the other meditative concentrations can be understood in the same way.

AN EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE DIVISION OF EMPTINESS INTO FOUR

This has four parts:

1 The emptiness of things

2 The emptiness of non-things

3 The emptiness of nature

4 The emptiness of other entities

THE EMPTINESS OF THINGS

[VI.219] The term ‘thing’

Indicates the five aggregates when condensed.

That which is their emptiness

Is explained as the emptiness of things.

In the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras Buddha uses the term ‘thing’ to indicate the five aggregates. This is because when all things are condensed they are included within the five aggregates. Thus all the objects of the five senses – forms, sounds, smells, tastes and tactile objects – are the aggregate of form; all feelings are the aggregate of feeling; all discriminations are the aggregate of discrimination; all mental factors other than feeling and discrimination such as aspiration, concentration and wisdom, as well as all persons, potentials, karmic imprints and imprints of delusions are the aggregate of compositional factors; and all primary minds are the aggregate of consciousness. Things are called ‘aggregates’ because each thing is an aggregation of parts dependent on causes and conditions. Since there is not a single thing that is not included within the aggregates, the lack of inherent existence of the five aggregates is called the ‘emptiness of things’. Buddha explained this emptiness to overcome the mind that grasps at produced phenomena as inherently existent.

THE EMPTINESS OF NON-THINGS

[VI.220] ‘Non-thing’

Indicates unproduced phenomena when condensed.

That which is the emptiness of non-things

Is the emptiness of non-things.

The term ‘non-thing’ indicates all unproduced phenomena such as unproduced space, nirvana, and emptiness. These phenomena are unproduced because they do not depend on the assembling of causes and conditions. Since whatever is produced in dependence on causes and conditions is called a ‘thing’, phenomena that are not produced are called ‘non-things’ and the lack of inherent existence of non-things is called the ‘emptiness of non-things’. Buddha explained this emptiness to overcome the mind that grasps at unproduced phenomena as inherently existent.

THE EMPTINESS OF NATURE

[VI.221] Nature’s lack of entityness

Is called the ‘emptiness of nature’.

Thus, it is explained that because nature is not created

It is called ‘nature’.

The ultimate nature of a phenomenon is its lack of existing from its own side. Because this nature is not created anew by anyone, but has existed since beginningless time it is called ‘ultimate nature’. A pot for example does not exist from its own side and its lack of existing from its own side has existed since beginningless time. Moreover the ultimate nature of phenomena is itself empty of inherent existence. Ultimate nature’s lack of inherent existence is called the ‘emptiness of nature’. Buddha explained this emptiness to overcome the mind that grasps at the ultimate nature of phenomena as inherently existent.

THE EMPTINESS OF OTHER ENTITIES

[VI.222] Whether Buddhas actually appear

Or do not appear

The emptiness of all things

Is explained as the other entity.

[VI.223] The perfect end and thatness

Are the emptiness of other entities.

These explanations have been given

According to Perfection of Wisdom.

‘Other entity’ here means a superior phenomenon such as emptiness. Although things are created in dependence on causes and conditions their lack of inherent existence is not created by anyone. It was not created by Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, gods or any other being. Thus whether Buddhas actually appear in this world or not the lack of inherent existence of all things exists from beginningless time without being created by anyone. For this reason lack of inherent existence is thoroughly non-deceptive and superior to conventional phenomena. This is why it is called the ‘other entity’.

In the Sutras, Buddha describes three phenomena as ‘other’ – emptiness, or thatness, because it is superior to conventional phenomena; the wisdom directly realizing emptiness because it is superior to worldly beings’ minds; and nirvana, or the perfect end, because it is superior to samsara. Since all three lack inherent existence their emptiness is called the ‘emptiness of other entities’. Buddha explained this emptiness to overcome the mind that grasps at superior phenomena as inherently existent.

All these explanations, of the two selflessnesses, the sixteen emptinesses and the four emptinesses, have been given exactly according to Buddha’s Perfection of Wisdom Sutras. They have not been fabricated by Chandrakirti.

CONCLUSION BY WAY OF EXPRESSING THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

[VI.224] Thus, with the rays of his wisdom he attains a clear appearance

Just like an olive resting in the palm of his hand

And realizing that from the beginning all these three worlds have been without production

He enters into cessation through the power of nominal truth.

[VI.225] Even though his thought is constantly directed towards cessation,

He still generates compassion for protectorless living beings.

After this, through his wisdom he will also defeat

All those born from the Sugata’s speech and all Middling Buddhas.

[VI.226] This king of the geese, spreading his broad, white wings of convention and thatness,

Comes to the fore of the geese of living beings

And then, through the force of his powerful winds of virtue,

Goes to the supreme – the ocean of the Conquerors’ qualities.

In summary, the Bodhisattva on the sixth ground possesses the special qualities of a surpassing perfection of wisdom. With the light rays of his wisdom he dispels all darkness obscuring emptiness and attains a clear appearance such that emptiness appears as clearly to his mind as an olive resting in the palm of his hand would appear to his eye consciousness. Realizing that the environments and the inhabitants of all three worlds – the naga world beneath, the human world above and the god world on high – have been without inherently existent production from the beginning, his mind and emptiness mix indistinguishably as one taste and he enters into the absorption of cessation. He attains this cessation through the power of nominal truth, not through the power of true existence.

In addition to these special good qualities of wisdom, the sixth-ground Bodhisattva also possesses special good qualities of method. Even though his mind is completely pacified and constantly and single-pointedly directed towards emptiness, he nevertheless continues to increase his compassion for living beings and always strives to work for their benefit.

The Bodhisattva will now advance to the seventh ground, Gone Afar, whereon his or her wisdom will surpass that of all Hearers and Solitary Realizers. In the root text it says ‘defeat’, but the meaning is ‘outshine’. Generally, Hinayana Foe Destroyers have excellent qualities of wisdom because they have realized emptiness directly and so have completely abandoned self-grasping, but their wisdom compares with that of a seventh-ground Bodhisattva as the light of a firefly compares with that of the sun. The sun has no wish to outshine fireflies, it just does so naturally. In the same way, seventh-ground Bodhisattvas have no wish to outshine Hinayana Foe Destroyers, they just do so naturally.

In Birth Stories there is a story about one of Buddha Shakyamuni’s previous lives when he was born as a king of geese. During this life he protected countless geese from suffering and led them to the land of happiness. Chandrakirti summarizes the sixth chapter by comparing the sixth-ground Bodhisattva to the king of the geese. His realizations of the stages of the vast and profound paths are his broad white wings of convention and thatness. Spreading these, he comes to the fore of the geese of the countless living beings who are his disciples and expounds the vast and profound Dharma to them. Finally, through the force of his powerful winds of virtue he and all his disciples go to the supreme state of Buddhahood. Implicitly this teaches that if we want to attain Buddhahood we must enter into the Mahayana path and through training on both the vast and profound paths complete the collections of merit and wisdom. Just as a bird cannot fly with only one wing, so we cannot attain Buddhahood by training in only one of these paths.

This concludes the commentary to the sixth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Jampel Gyatso

Gone Afar

THE SEVENTH GROUND, GONE AFAR

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the seventh ground

2 The good qualities of the seventh ground

Introduction to the seventh ground has four parts:

1 How the seventh ground is attained

2 Definition of the seventh ground

3 Divisions of the seventh ground

4 Etymology of the seventh ground

HOW THE SEVENTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the sixth ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to small-middling innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the sixth ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned small-middling innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the seventh ground.

DEFINITION OF THE SEVENTH GROUND

The definition of the seventh ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned small-middling innate true-grasping, its principal object of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of skilful means from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE SEVENTH GROUND

The seventh ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the seventh ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the seventh ground and the exalted awareness of the seventh ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the seventh ground, the uninterrupted path of the seventh ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the seventh ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the seventh ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to the three types of small innate true-grasping, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

ETYMOLOGY OF THE SEVENTH GROUND

In Ornament for Mahayana Sutras it says that as a result of meditating on the paths for a very long time the seventh-ground Bodhisattva has attained the final path possessing true-grasping and gross effort; therefore the seventh ground is called ‘Gone Afar’.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE SEVENTH GROUND

[VII.1] Here, on Gone Afar, he can enter into cessation

Instant by instant,

And he has also attained a surpassing perfection of means.

The Bodhisattva on the seventh ground can enter into and rise from absorption of cessation, or emptiness, instant by instant. Here emptiness is called ‘cessation’ because through fixing the mind on emptiness we eventually attain the cessation of all elaborations of dualistic appearance. As explained before, when ordinary beings meditate on emptiness they do not find it difficult to rise from meditation because their minds do not completely mix with emptiness, but when Superior Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds meditate single-pointedly on emptiness they experience difficulty in rising from meditation because their minds mix with emptiness like water mixing with water. When the Bodhisattva reaches the seventh ground, however, he attains a special power of quick wisdom that enables him to enter into and rise from meditation on emptiness within one instant. Buddhas have completed the power of quick wisdom, which means that they can perform meditative equipoise on emptiness and subsequent attainment simultaneously.

The Bodhisattva on the seventh ground has also attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of skilful means. Generally Bodhisattvas on the first six grounds also have the perfection of skilful means but on the seventh ground this perfection becomes surpassing, which means that it becomes completely pure. Thus the Bodhisattva on the seventh ground has more power to benefit others than Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds. The definition of perfection of skilful means is a mind maintained by bodhichitta that is skilled in the means of accomplishing the two purposes. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of skilful means and the transcendent perfection of skilful means. The two purposes are to attain great enlightenment for oneself and to lead all other living beings to that state.

In The Bodhisattvas’ Grounds Asanga explains that there are two perfections of skilful means – the perfection of skilful means that is skilled in accomplishing all the qualities of a Buddha within oneself and the perfection of skilful means that is skilled in ripening all other living beings. The first has six parts:

(1) Always looking on all living beings with compassion

(2) Always looking at the ultimate nature of all phenomena

(3) Always desiring the exalted awareness of unsurpassed enlightenment

(4) Always looking after living beings and never considering samsara to be the main object of abandonment

(5) Always taking rebirth in the abodes of samsara out of great compassion

(6) Always striving to attain Buddhahood

The second also has six parts:

(1) Causing even the smallest virtuous roots in living beings to ripen into immeasurable fruits

(2) Causing living beings to accomplish great roots of virtue

(3) Eliminating anger in those who dislike Buddha’s doctrine

(4) Encouraging those who are favourably disposed towards the doctrine to enter into it

(5) Ripening the mental continuums of those who have entered into the doctrine

(6) Causing those who are ripened to attain liberation

Thus, altogether there are twelve perfections of skilful means, and they are all surpassing for the Bodhisattva on the seventh ground.

This concludes the commentary to the seventh ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

The Three Pure Grounds

THE EIGHTH GROUND, IMMOVABLE

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the eighth ground

2 The good qualities of the eighth ground

Introduction to the eighth ground has four parts:

1 How the eighth ground is attained

2 Definition of the eighth ground

3 Divisions of the eighth ground

4 Etymology of the eighth ground

HOW THE EIGHTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the seventh ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to the three types of small innate true-grasping. This is the uninterrupted path of the seventh ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned the three types of small innate true-grasping. This is the first moment of the eighth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE EIGHTH GROUND

The definition of the eighth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned the three types of small innate true-grasping, its principal objects of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of prayer from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE EIGHTH GROUND

The eighth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the eighth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the eighth ground and the exalted awareness of the eighth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the eighth ground, the uninterrupted path of the eighth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the eighth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the eighth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to the three types of big obstruction to omniscience, occurs at the very end. Between these two, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

ETYMOLOGY OF THE EIGHTH GROUND

Because this ground is completely free from true-grasping and all other delusions, it cannot be moved by the mind of true-grasping; therefore it is called ‘Immovable’.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE EIGHTH GROUND

This section has three parts:

1 The surpassing prayers on this ground and how he is raised from cessation

2 Showing that he has extinguished all delusions

3 Showing that he has attained the ten powers

THE SURPASSING PRAYERS ON THIS GROUND AND HOW HE IS RAISED FROM CESSATION

[VIII.1] To attain virtues superior to those of before

This great being strives repeatedly for Immovable

On which they never return.

His prayers become extremely pure,

And he is raised from cessation by the Conquerors.

Even though the Bodhisattva on the seventh ground has become a great being, nevertheless he strives repeatedly to attain the eighth ground, Immovable, because he sees that a Bodhisattva on that ground possesses virtuous qualities superior even to those of a seventh-ground Bodhisattva. In particular, he or she sees that on the eighth ground the Bodhisattva completely abandons all delusions and their seeds such that they never return.

The Bodhisattva on the eighth ground attains a surpassing practice of the perfection of prayer. This means that his prayers become extremely pure and he attains a power of prayer not possessed by Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds. Although the perfection of prayer exists even on the first ground it does not become surpassing until the eighth. In Sutra on the Ten Grounds it says that through the power of his prayer a Bodhisattva on the eighth ground can accomplish in one instant a purpose that a first-ground Bodhisattva would take a hundred thousand aeons to accomplish. The definition of perfection of prayer is a mind maintained by the bodhichitta that aspires to accomplish either of the two purposes by means of prayer. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of prayer and the transcendent perfection of prayer.

When the eighth-ground Bodhisattva enters meditative equipoise, he or she attains a special realization similar to the clear light of a Buddha’s Truth Body. At that time, Buddhas appear directly to him and encourage him to rise from cessation and strive to accomplish a Buddha’s Form Body to help living beings. They say to him, ‘O Son of the Lineage, it is very good that you have abandoned all delusions and attained a wisdom similar to the Truth Body, but without abandoning your practice of the Truth Body you must now rise from cessation and strive to complete the collection of merit to attain a Buddha’s Form Body.’ In this way he is raised from cessation by the Conquerors.

SHOWING THAT HE HAS EXTINGUISHED ALL DELUSIONS

[VIII.2] Because his mind of non-attachment does not remain with faults

The eighth-grounder has thoroughly pacified those stains together with their roots,

But although his delusions are extinguished and he is the highest of the three grounds

He cannot yet attain all the qualities of the Buddhas, which are as endless as space.

The previous verse explained how the Bodhisattva on the eighth ground has qualities of realization superior to those of the Bodhisattva on the seventh ground. The present verse now explains how he or she also possesses superior qualities of abandonment. Because his exalted awareness is completely free from the faults of the delusions, the eighth-grounder has thoroughly abandoned all delusions together with their roots. However, even though his delusions are extinguished and he is the highest being in the three realms he cannot yet attain all the qualities of the Buddhas, which are as endless as space. Therefore he strives to advance to higher grounds.

SHOWING THAT HE HAS ATTAINED THE TEN POWERS

[VIII.3] Although samsara has ceased, he attains the ten powers,

And with these causes his nature to be displayed as various beings within samsara.

Since the Bodhisattva on the eighth ground has abandoned all delusions the continuum of samsara has ceased for him and it is not possible for him to take rebirth in samsara without choice. However, to benefit living beings and to complete the remaining paths he or she displays the aspect of various beings within samsara. These forms, which are in essence the nature of his mind, arise purely in dependence on uncontaminated actions. The Bodhisattva is able to display these forms because on the eighth ground he attains the ten powers. These are:

(1) The power of life

(2) The power of mind

(3) The power of resources

(4) The power of actions

(5) The power of birth

(6) The power of prayer

(7) The power of aspiration

(8) The power of manifestation

(9) The power of exalted awareness

(10) The power of Dharma

Buddha explains these in Sutra on the Ten Grounds.

This concludes the commentary to the eighth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

THE NINTH GROUND, GOOD INTELLIGENCE

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the ninth ground

2 The good qualities of the ninth ground

Introduction to the ninth ground has four parts:

1 How the ninth ground is attained

2 Definition of the ninth ground

3 Divisions of the ninth ground

4 Etymology of the ninth ground

HOW THE NINTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the eighth ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to the three types of big obstruction to omniscience. This is the uninterrupted path of the eighth ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned the three types of big obstruction to omniscience. This is the first moment of the ninth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE NINTH GROUND

The definition of the ninth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned the three types of big obstruction to omniscience, its principal objects of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of force from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE NINTH GROUND

The ninth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the ninth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the ninth ground and the exalted awareness of the ninth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the ninth ground, the uninterrupted path of the ninth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the ninth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the ninth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to the three types of middling obstruction to omniscience, occurs at the very end. Between these two the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

ETYMOLOGY OF THE NINTH GROUND

Because the Bodhisattva on the ninth ground attains the good qualities of the four correct, specific cognizers, this ground is called ‘Good Intelligence’.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE NINTH GROUND

[IX.1] On the ninth all his forces become completely pure.

Likewise he also attains the completely pure qualities of the correct cognizers of phenomena.

On the ninth ground the Bodhisattva attains a surpassing perfection of force, which means that all his forces become completely pure. The definition of perfection of force is a realization maintained by bodhichitta that cannot be overcome by opposing forces. Altogether there are thirteen forces:

(1) The force of intention

(2) The force of superior intention

(3) The force of mindfulness

(4) The force of concentration

(5) The force of correct preparation

(6) The force of power

(7) The force of confidence

(8) The force of prayer

(9) The force of perfection

(10) The force of great love

(11) The force of great compassion

(12) The force of the dharmata

(13) The force of the blessings of all the Tathagatas

The perfection of force has two divisions – the transcending perfection of force and the transcendent perfection of force. Besides the perfection of force, the Bodhisattva on the ninth ground also attains the completely pure qualities of the four correct, specific cognizers of phenomena. Strictly speaking these are qualities of a Buddha but a Bodhisattva on the ninth ground possesses a similitude of them.

This concludes the commentary to the ninth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

THE TENTH GROUND, CLOUD OF DHARMA

This has two parts:

1 Introduction to the tenth ground

2 The good qualities of the tenth ground

Introduction to the tenth ground has four parts:

1 How the tenth ground is attained

2 Definition of the tenth ground

3 Divisions of the tenth ground

4 Etymology of the tenth ground

HOW THE TENTH GROUND IS ATTAINED

The Bodhisattva on the ninth ground continues to meditate on emptiness until he or she attains the uninterrupted path that is the direct antidote to the three types of middling obstruction to omniscience. This is the uninterrupted path of the ninth ground. In the next moment he attains the released path that has completely abandoned the three types of middling obstruction to omniscience. This is the first moment of the tenth ground.

DEFINITION OF THE TENTH GROUND

The definition of the tenth ground is a Superior Bodhisattva’s path that has abandoned the three types of middling obstruction to omniscience, its principal objects of abandonment, and that has attained a surpassing practice of the perfection of exalted awareness from within the ten perfections.

DIVISIONS OF THE TENTH GROUND

The tenth ground has three divisions – the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the tenth ground, the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the tenth ground and the exalted awareness of the tenth ground that is neither of the two. The first has three divisions – the released path of the tenth ground, the uninterrupted path of the tenth ground and the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the tenth ground that is neither of the two. The first of these occurs at the very beginning of the tenth ground and the second, which is the direct antidote to the three types of small obstruction to omniscience, occurs at the very end. The uninterrupted path of the tenth ground is called the ‘vajra-like concentration of the path of meditation’ because it mixes with emptiness like water mixing with water and since in the next moment one becomes a Buddha it is never again separated from emptiness. This mind is also called the ‘exalted awareness of the final continuum’ because it is the final moment of the mental continuum of a sentient being. Between the released path of the tenth ground and the uninterrupted path of the tenth ground, the exalted awareness of meditative equipoise that is neither of the two and the exalted awareness of subsequent attainment arise alternately.

ETYMOLOGY OF THE TENTH GROUND

Within the sky-like mind of the tenth-ground Bodhisattva clouds of realizations such as compassion, wisdom and concentration send down a rain of Dharma to ripen the virtuous crops of living beings; therefore this ground is called ‘Cloud of Dharma’.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE TENTH GROUND

[X.1] On the tenth ground, he receives holy empowerments from Buddhas in all directions,

And he also attains a supreme, surpassing exalted awareness.

Just as rain falls from rain clouds, so for the sake of living beings’ virtuous crops

A rain of Dharma spontaneously falls from the Conquerors’ Son.

The Bodhisattva on the tenth ground manifests a million minds of concentration and receives holy empowerments from all the Buddhas in the ten directions. Buddhas from all the Buddha Lands of the ten directions appear before him or her and radiate light from the hair curl at their foreheads. This light enters the Bodhisattva’s body through his crown and he receives all their blessings. This is called the ‘empowerment of great light’. They then proclaim, ‘You are like an actual Buddha’ and honour him or her as a Buddha. In the Sutras it says that a Bodhisattva on the eighth ground is like a prince, a Bodhisattva on the ninth ground like a regent and a Bodhisattva on the tenth ground like an actual king. This indicates that although the tenth-ground Bodhisattva is not yet an actual Buddha he or she possesses qualities similar to those of a Buddha.

The Bodhisattva on the tenth ground also attains a surpassing perfection of exalted awareness because he or she attains a special wisdom that correctly knows the signs of all phenomena. Although Bodhisattvas on the lower grounds also have the perfection of exalted awareness theirs does not possess the power of the tenth-ground Bodhisattva’s. The definition of perfection of exalted awareness is a mind maintained by bodhichitta that knows the conventional nature of all phenomena through its own power. It has two divisions – the transcending perfection of exalted awareness and the transcendent perfection of exalted awareness.

The sixth perfection, the perfection of wisdom, principally realizes the ultimate nature of phenomena, whereas the tenth perfection, the perfection of exalted awareness, principally realizes their conventional nature. Otherwise they are the same because they are both perfections of wisdom. Within the ten perfections the last four are principally induced by wisdom and they are all included within the perfection of wisdom. Thus there is no contradiction in saying that all the trainings of a Bodhisattva are included within six perfections.

The tenth-ground Bodhisattva also engages in the practice of benefiting other living beings by bestowing on them a rain of Dharma. Just as, without conception and without effort, rain falls from rain clouds and sustains crops on the earth, so for the sake of living beings’ virtuous crops, without any conceptual exertion a rain of Dharma spontaneously falls from the clouds of compassion, wisdom and so forth in the sky-like mind of this Conquerors’ Son. In this way, countless living beings will be liberated from the sufferings of samsara.

This concludes the commentary to the tenth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

Khedrubje

The Good Qualities of the Ten Grounds

The good qualities of the ten grounds has three parts:

1 The good qualities of the first ground

2 The good qualities of the second to the seventh grounds

3 The good qualities of the three pure grounds

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE FIRST GROUND

[XI.1] At that time he can see a hundred Buddhas

And realize their blessings.

He remains alive for a hundred aeons

And engages perfectly in the ends of the former and the later.

[XI.2] This Wise One can enter into and rise from the absorptions of a hundred concentrations.

He can cause a hundred worlds to shake and illuminate them.

Likewise, through his magical emanations he can cause a hundred living beings to ripen,

And visit a hundred Pure Lands.

[XI.3] He can completely open the doors of Dharma, and this Son of the Powerful Able One

Can cause bodies to be displayed throughout his body,

Each body being endowed with and beautified by its retinue,

And revealing a hundred Conquerors’ Sons.

When a Bodhisattva attains the first ultimate bodhichitta, Very Joyful, he or she attains twelve special qualities. At that time he can:

(1) See a hundred Buddhas in an instant

(2) Realize their blessings in an instant

(3) Remain alive for a hundred aeons

(4) See the ends of the previous hundred aeons and the next hundred aeons in an instant

(5) Enter into and rise from the absorptions of a hundred concentrations in an instant

(6) Cause a hundred worlds to shake through his magical powers in an instant

(7) Illuminate a hundred worldly realms through his magical powers in an instant

(8) Cause a hundred living beings to ripen through his magical emanations in an instant

(9) Visit a hundred Buddhas’ Pure Lands in an instant

(10) Completely open a hundred doors of Dharma in an instant

(11) Cause a hundred different bodies to be displayed throughout his or her body in an instant

(12) Endow each of these hundred bodies with a retinue of a hundred Conquerors’ Sons

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE SECOND TO THE SEVENTH GROUNDS

[XI.4] These qualities are attained by the Wise One abiding on Very Joyful,

And in just the same way they are perfectly attained in thousands

By the abider on Stainless.

On the next five grounds, the Bodhisattva attains

[XI.5] A hundred thousand of these, a hundred ten million, a thousand ten million,

Then a hundred, thousand ten million

And then ten million a hundred thousand million multiplied by a hundred and further multiplied by a thousand.

Whereas the Bodhisattva abiding on Very Joyful attains these twelve qualities in hundreds, the Bodhisattva abiding on the second ground, Stainless, attains them in thousands. This means that in an instant he or she can see a thousand Buddhas and so forth. On the third ground the Bodhisattva attains a hundred thousand of these twelve qualities, on the fourth ground a billion, on the fifth ground ten billion, on the sixth ground a trillion and on the seventh ground a hundred thousand trillion.

THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE THREE PURE GROUNDS

The first seven grounds are called the ‘seven impure grounds’ because the Bodhisattvas who abide on them have not yet abandoned delusion-obstructions, and the last three grounds are called the ‘three pure grounds’ because the Bodhisattvas who abide on them have abandoned delusion-obstructions. However, Bodhisattvas on the three pure grounds have not yet abandoned obstructions to omniscience. The good qualities attained by the Bodhisattvas on the three pure grounds are explained in the next four verses.

[XI.6] Abiding on the ground, Immovable, free from conceptions,

He attains qualities equal in number

To however many atoms there are

In a hundred thousand of the three thousand worlds.

The Bodhisattva abiding on the eighth ground, Immovable, who is free from conceptions apprehending true existence, attains these twelve qualities equal in number to however many atoms there are in a hundred thousand of the three thousand worlds. For example, in one instant he or she can see as many Buddhas as there are atoms in a hundred thousand of the three thousand worlds. The magnitude of the three thousand worlds is explained as follows. Our world, the Unforgetting World, consists of Mount Meru surrounded by the four continents and their sub-continents. A thousand of these worlds is called the ‘thousand worlds’, a thousand of these is called the ‘two thousand worlds’ and a thousand of these is called the ‘three thousand worlds’. If we multiply these by a hundred thousand and then try to imagine how many atoms these worlds contain – that is the number of Buddhas seen in one instant by the Bodhisattva on the eighth ground. The remaining eleven qualities can be understood in the same way.

[XI.7] The Bodhisattva abiding on the ground Good Intelligence

Attains the previously mentioned qualities

Equal in number to the atoms in a hundred thousand countless

Perfectly increased by ten.

The Bodhisattva abiding on the ninth ground, Good Intelligence, attains these twelve qualities equal in number to the atoms in a million times a countless number of the three thousand worlds.

[XI.8] Briefly, the qualities of the tenth

Have passed beyond what can be expressed in words,

There being as many as there are atoms

In all the inexpressibles.

[XI.9] Moment by moment he can display in his pores

Perfect Buddhas beyond number

Together with Bodhisattvas

And likewise gods, demi-gods and humans.

The tenth ground can be explained only briefly because its qualities have passed beyond what can be expressed in words, there being as many of these twelve qualities as there are atoms in the inexpressible number of Buddha Lands. Moment by moment this Bodhisattva can display in his or her pores the bodies of perfect Buddhas beyond number together with their retinues of countless Bodhisattvas. Likewise, he is able to display in his pores gods, demi-gods, Brahmas, Indras, protectors of the world, humans, Hearers, Solitary Realizers and many other different aspects of living beings, all in an instant. These and all the other good qualities of the tenth-ground Bodhisattva are explained extensively in Sutra on the Ten Grounds.

When we first hear of the special qualities of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas we may find them incredible and we may even doubt that it is possible for anyone to possess such qualities. This is because at present our mind is largely undeveloped. Trying to comprehend the qualities of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas with our present mind is like trying to reflect an image of the whole of space within a small mirror. As our mind develops, however, our mental capacity will expand and we will become more like these high beings. Then we will be able more easily to understand their special qualities.

Je Phabongkhapa

Resultant Grounds

A PRESENTATION OF RESULTANT GROUNDS

This section has five parts:

1 How Buddhahood is first attained

2 A presentation of Buddha’s bodies and good qualities

3 Explaining Emanation Bodies

4 Proving that there is one final vehicle

5 Explaining the duration of enlightenment and remaining

HOW BUDDHAHOOD IS FIRST ATTAINED

This has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Rejecting an argument

THE ACTUAL MEANING

[XI.10] Just as the moon in a stainless sky illuminates clearly,

Previously you strove again for the ground that generates the ten forces.

In Akanishta you accomplished the aim for which you strove –

All those unequalled, ultimate good qualities of the supreme state of pacification.

[XI.11] Just as space has no divisions due to the divisions of vessels,

So thatness has no divisions made by things.

Therefore, perfectly realizing them to be of one taste,

O Good Knower, you realize all objects of knowledge in an instant.

So far, Chandrakirti has explained the natures, divisions, functions and good qualities of the ten causal grounds. He now explains how resultant grounds are attained. Buddha Shakyamuni, for example, first generated bodhichitta and then trained on the Mahayana paths until he reached the ninth ground. Then he strove again for the exalted awareness of the final continuum of the tenth ground. This realization, the vajra-like concentration of the path of meditation, is the direct cause of the ten forces, the unsurpassed qualities of a Buddha. It is like a moon in a clear autumn sky. Just as a moon in a clear sky dispels all darkness and illuminates clearly all forms, in the same way the exalted awareness of the final continuum dispels all darkness of the obstructions to omniscience and causes the body of a Buddha to appear clearly.

Buddha Shakyamuni accomplished the aim for which he strove – all those unequalled, ultimate good qualities of the supreme state of Buddhahood – in the Pure Land of Akanishta. In just the same way, all other beings who have become Buddhas have first generated bodhichitta then trained on the Mahayana paths until they attained the exalted awareness of the final continuum and then attained enlightenment in the Pure Land of Akanishta. This is explained in many Mahayana Sutras. According to the lower schools such as the Vaibhashikas, Buddha Shakyamuni attained enlightenment in Bodh Gaya in India. In reality, however, he attained enlightenment in Akanishta many aeons before he appeared in this world. He merely displayed the manner of attaining enlightenment at Bodh Gaya to show the beings of this world that it is possible to accomplish such great results through practising Dharma.

When Buddha Shakyamuni first attained enlightenment in Akanishta he directly realized all objects of knowledge in an instant. He could do this because previously with the vajra-like concentration of the path of meditation he had abandoned all obstructions to omniscience. Although there are countless conventional phenomena, each with a different entity, all emptinesses are the same entity. For example, even though there are many vessels in this world that enclose space, space itself does not have separate divisions because all space is the same entity – mere lack of obstructive contact. In the same way, even though there are many different objects in this world, emptiness does not have separate divisions because all emptinesses are the same entity – mere lack of inherent existence. Thus, because Buddha Shakyamuni perfectly realizes all phenomena as of one taste in emptiness he directly realizes all phenomena in one instant.

REJECTING AN ARGUMENT

This section has two parts:

1 Stating the other position

2 Refuting this position

STATING THE OTHER POSITION

Objection

[XI.12] ‘If pacification is thatness, wisdom does not engage in it;

And with no mind engaging, certainly an object-possessor of the object of knowledge is not possible.

Without knowing anything, how can it be a knower? That is a contradiction.

If there is no one who knows, how can you teach others, “It is like this”?’

You say emptiness is mere lack of inherent existence. If that is the case wisdom cannot apprehend it because there is no uncommon sign for a knower to discriminate and so there is no object for the mind to apprehend. If the mind does not engage in an object there is no object-possessor of emptiness. It makes no sense to call a mind an object-possessor realizing an object of knowledge if it does not apprehend an object. Furthermore, how can that mind be a knower if it does not know anything? That is a contradiction. If there is no knower realizing emptiness there is no person realizing emptiness, so how can you teach others, ‘Emptiness is like this’ and so on? In short, it is not suitable to assert either a knower realizing emptiness or a person realizing emptiness.

REFUTING THIS POSITION

This section has two parts:

1 Rejecting the argument that a knower of thatness is unacceptable

2 Rejecting the argument that a person knowing thatness is unacceptable

REJECTING THE ARGUMENT THAT A KNOWER OF THATNESS IS UNACCEPTABLE

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[XI.13] Since non-production is thatness and the mind has freedom from production,

By depending on that aspect it realizes thatness.

For example, when a mind possesses any aspect it knows that object thoroughly.

In just the same way, this knows by depending on a nominality.

Lack of inherently existent production is thatness. Since Buddha’s mind apprehends unmistakenly the aspect of the mere absence of inherently existent production, by apprehending that aspect it realizes thatness. Even according to your system, when a mind apprehends any aspect such as blue you say that that mind knows its object thoroughly. In just the same way, in our system because Buddha’s mind apprehends an aspect of thatness it knows thatness by realizing this nominality. Thus we can establish a knower of thatness and we do not incur the first fault, that there is no mind that knows emptiness.

REJECTING THE ARGUMENT THAT A PERSON KNOWING THATNESS IS UNACCEPTABLE

Madhyamika-Prasangikas We are also free from the second fault, that there is no person who knows emptiness, because Buddha knows emptiness directly and teaches it extensively to disciples. In this way he leads many living beings to a state of liberation.

Objection Even if we accept that there is a person who realizes emptiness directly it would still be impossible for him to teach it to others because his mind and emptiness would have mixed as of one taste and he would have no motivation that would cause him to teach.

Madhyamika-Prasangikas

[XI.14] Through the power of his Enjoyment Body maintained by merit

And of its Emanations,

Sounds that reveal the Dharma of thatness arise from space and others.

Due to these, worldly beings can also realize thatness.

[XI.15] Just as here a potter with great strength

Expends much energy for a long time turning the wheel,

And then, while he is not generating effort,

It turns and is seen to be a cause of a pot,

[XI.16] So like that, is he who resides in a body with the nature of Dharma.

Without generating any effort now

He engages in deeds that are completely beyond thought

Due to the special qualities of his prayers and the virtues of beings.

It is true that Buddhas have no conceptual motivation to teach Dharma but this does not mean that they do not teach. Buddha Shakyamuni, for example, attained his Enjoyment Body and its Emanation Bodies principally through his vast collection of merit. Through the power of this merit sounds that reveal the Dharma of thatness arise from his two bodies even though he has no conceptual motivation. These teachings are heard by Hearers, Solitary Realizers, Bodhisattvas and so forth and as a result these beings also realize thatness. There are many examples of teachings arising from objects that lack conceptual motivation. For example, in the story of the Bodhisattva Sadaprarudita told at the end of the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra in Eight Thousand Lines it explains how he heard teachings arising from space. Through the power of Buddha’s blessings many beings have heard teachings on emptiness arising from inanimate objects such as stones and trees. Thus, there is Sutra Arisen from Trees Blown by the Wind, Sutra Arisen from the Crown Protrusion of the Tathagata and so on.

It is one of the extraordinary qualities of Buddha that he can benefit countless living beings while his mind abides immovably as the Truth Body, or Dharmakaya. Even though he lacks the direct generation of a motivation, nevertheless countless beings will receive benefit from his deeds of expounding Dharma. If you wonder how it is possible for Buddha to work for the benefit of others without a conceptual motivation you should consider the following analogy. A potter first expends much energy turning the wheel and then when he stops applying effort the wheel continues to turn,and functions as a cause of a pot. In the same way, through the strength of his practice while training in previous lives on the Mahayana paths, Buddha put great effort into completing the two collections of merit and wisdom and although he no longer expends effort nevertheless he continues to turn the Wheel of Dharma and benefit countless living beings. Thus, Buddha resides in the Truth Body and engages in deeds of teaching Dharma and so forth that are completely beyond thought without generating any effort. He can do this because of the special qualities of his prayers made while training on the paths and the ripening of virtuous seeds of liberation in the minds of living beings.

A PRESENTATION OF BUDDHA’S BODIES AND GOOD QUALITIES

This section has two parts:

1 A presentation of Buddha’s bodies

2 A presentation of the good qualities of the forces

A PRESENTATION OF BUDDHA’S BODIES

This section has three parts:

1 An explanation of the Truth Body

2 An explanation of the Enjoyment Body

3 An explanation of the Body corresponding to its cause

AN EXPLANATION OF THE TRUTH BODY

[XI.17] That pacification that comes from the burning of all the dry tinder of objects of knowledge

Is the Truth Body of the Conquerors.

At that time there is no production and no disintegration.

Since minds have ceased, it is experienced directly by the body.

The definition of Truth Body is the emptiness of the mind or the mind itself completely purified of all obstructions to omniscience. Here, ‘dry tinder of objects of knowledge’ means the obstructions to omniscience and ‘burning’ means abandoning. There are two types of Truth Body – Wisdom Truth Body and Nature Truth Body. The Wisdom Truth Body is the mind of a Buddha mixed inseparably with emptiness. Because a Buddha’s mind is completely mixed with emptiness like water mixed with water, and because his mind never moves from that state, all his minds are the Wisdom Truth Body. When, prior to attaining Buddhahood, we attain a direct realization of emptiness and our mind mixes with emptiness like water mixing with water we attain a similitude of the Wisdom Truth Body. This is only a temporary state, and sooner or later the mind moves and separates from emptiness. A Buddha’s mind, however, never separates from emptiness. Therefore only Buddhas possess the actual Wisdom Truth Body.

The Nature Truth Body is the emptiness of Buddha’s mind that possesses two purities – the purity that is the absence of inherent existence from the very beginning and the purity that is freedom from the two obstructions. We all have two Buddha natures – the naturally abiding Buddha nature and the increasing Buddha nature. The first is the emptiness of our very subtle mind, which will become the Nature Truth Body of a Buddha when we become a Buddha. The second is our very subtle mind itself. Through our increasing the qualities of this mind eventually it will become the Wisdom Truth Body of a Buddha.

How is the Truth Body attained? Through training on the Mahayana paths a Yogi or Yogini eventually attains the exalted awareness of the final continuum, which is the last moment of the path of meditation. This concentration functions as the direct antidote to the three types of small obstruction to omniscience. In the next moment, he or she attains the released path that has completely abandoned all obstructions. This is the first moment of Buddhahood. Simultaneously, his or her mind becomes the Wisdom Truth Body, the emptiness of his or her mind becomes the Nature Truth Body and his or her subtle form body becomes the Enjoyment Body.

His Nature Truth Body, which is his main body, has no production or disintegration. Moreover, at that time all conceptual minds have ceased. Therefore the Nature Truth Body is first directly experienced by the body of non-conceptual wisdom. Some interpret the last line of this verse to mean that because Buddha has no mind, the Truth Body is experienced by his body, but this is not correct. It is absurd to suggest that a Buddha has no mind.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE ENJOYMENT BODY

[XI.18] This pacified body is resplendent like a wish-granting tree

And without conception like a wish-fulfilling jewel.

It will remain always until living beings are liberated for the fortune of the world,

And appear to those who are free from elaboration.

The definition of Enjoyment Body is an ultimate form body that possesses the five certainties. The five certainties are:

(1) Certainty of body. Although the Enjoyment Body is pacified of all conceptual minds, nevertheless for the benefit of living beings it appears like a wish-granting tree, resplendent with the major marks and minor indications.

(2) Certainty of doctrine. Although the Enjoyment Body is without conception, nevertheless it benefits living beings like a wish-fulfilling jewel by teaching only Mahayana Dharma.

(3) Certainty of place. Although it manifests countless Emanation Bodies the Enjoyment Body itself always abides in the Pure Land of Akanishta.

(4) Certainty of time. Although Emanation Bodies display the manner of passing away the Enjoyment Body will remain until all living beings are liberated, for the fortune of worldly beings.

(5) Certainty of retinue. Although the Enjoyment Body has no discrimination, feeling close to some or distant from others, nevertheless it appears only to those who are free from elaboration, that is to Superior Bodhisattvas.

AN EXPLANATION OF THE BODY CORRESPONDING TO ITS CAUSE

This section explains the Emanation Body. Since Emanation Bodies are principally manifested by the Enjoyment Body, they are known as a ‘body corresponding to its cause’. The Emanation Body will now be explained under the following three headings:

1 How he displays all his deeds in one pore of his body

2 How he displays all the deeds of others there

3 An explanation of his completely excellent mastery of his wishes

HOW HE DISPLAYS ALL HIS DEEDS IN ONE PORE OF HIS BODY

[XI.19] The Powerful Able One, at one time, in one Form Body

Corresponding to that cause, clearly and without disorder

Makes a complete and exquisite display

Of everything that happened during his previous lives, now ceased.

[XI.20] What the Buddha Lands and their Powerful Able Ones were like,

What their bodies, deeds and powers were like,

How many assemblies of Hearers there were and what they were like,

What forms the Bodhisattvas took there,

[XI.21] What the Dharma was like and what he was like then,

What deeds were performed from listening to Dharma,

How much giving was practised towards them –

All these he displays in one body.

[XI.22] Likewise what moral discipline, patience, effort, concentration and wisdom

He practised during previous lives

He displays clearly all these deeds without leaving anything out

In just one pore of his body.

The definition of Emanation Body is an ultimate Form Body not possessing the five certainties. Since the Truth Body can be seen only by Buddhas and the Enjoyment Body only by Superior Bodhisattvas, the Enjoyment Body manifests countless Emanation Bodies that can be seen by ordinary beings. For example, the Enjoyment Body Munivairochana manifested a hundred million Emanation Bodies of Buddha Shakyamuni in a hundred million different worlds. Each of these Emanation Bodies has inconceivable powers. Buddha Shakyamuni, the Powerful Able One who appears in a Form Body corresponding to its cause, the Enjoyment Body of Munivairochana, can make a complete and exquisite display of everything that happened during his previous lives in one tiny pore of his body. He can display clearly and in the correct order all his places of rebirth since beginningless time and all his bodies, friends, relatives and enjoyments that have now ceased.

When he was a Bodhisattva training on the paths he made offerings to countless Buddhas in countless Buddha Lands. He can display all these in one pore of his present body. He can display all the characteristics of these Pure Lands and the bodies, deeds and powers of the Buddhas who reside in them. Furthermore he can show how many assemblies of Hearers there were there and what they were like, how many Bodhisattvas there were there and what forms they took, what good qualities they had, what kind of Dharma was expounded to the various assemblies of Hearers and Bodhisattvas, what forms he himself took, sometimes as a Brahmin, sometimes as a monk, sometimes as a lay person and so forth, what deeds the Bodhisattvas performed after listening to Dharma and what kind of giving he practised when making offerings to the Buddhas. All these he displays in just one tiny pore of his body.

Likewise, during his previous lives as a Bodhisattva, Buddha Shakyamuni also practised extensively the remaining five perfections – moral discipline, patience, effort, mental stabilization and wisdom. He displays clearly all these deeds – where he practised in what bodies he practised, the way he practised and so forth without leaving anything out, in just one pore of his body.

HOW HE DISPLAYS ALL THE DEEDS OF OTHERS THERE

[XI.23] Buddhas who have passed away, those who are yet to come

And those of the present dwelling in the world

Revealing Dharma in a loud voice carrying to the ends of space

And bestowing breath on living beings tormented by suffering –

[XI.24] All their deeds from first generating the mind

Through to the essence of enlightenment,

Knowing these things to be the nature of illusions

He displays them all clearly at one time in one pore.

[XI.25] Likewise the deeds of all Superior Bodhisattvas,

Solitary Realizers and Hearers of the three times

And all the activities of the remaining beings –

He displays all of these at one time in one pore.

Besides being able to display his own deeds, Buddha Shakyamuni can also display all the deeds of all other beings. Thus he can display clearly, at one time and in just one pore all Buddhas who have passed away, those who are yet to come and those who are presently dwelling in the world teaching Dharma to relieve the suffering of living beings. He can also display all their deeds from first generating bodhichitta through to attaining the essence of enlightenment. He can do this because he has an ultimate realization of the emptiness of all phenomena and knows all phenomena to be like illusions.

Buddha Shakyamuni can also display at one time and in one pore all the deeds of all Superior Bodhisattvas, Solitary Realizers and Hearers of the three times, as well as all the activities of ordinary Bodhisattvas, Solitary Realizers and Hearers.

AN EXPLANATION OF HIS COMPLETELY EXCELLENT MASTERY OF HIS WISHES

[XI.26] This Pure One, by enacting his wishes,

Displays the worlds throughout space on a single atom

And an atom filling the directions of infinite worlds

Without the atom becoming larger or the worlds becoming smaller.

[XI.27] Not being governed by conceptuality, you will show in each instant

Until the end of samsara

As many countless different deeds

As there are atoms in all the worlds.

Because Buddha Shakyamuni’s mind is completely pure, untainted by any defilement, he has perfect control over his wishes. He can emanate anything simply by enacting his wishes. For example, he can display all the worlds throughout space on a single atom and a single atom pervading all infinite worlds without the atom becoming larger or the worlds becoming smaller. Only a Buddha has such powers. Furthermore, because he is free from conceptuality, Buddha Shakyamuni can show in each instant until the end of samsara countless different emanations, displaying as many emanations as there are atoms in all the worlds.

The good qualities of body, speech and mind of Buddha Shakyamuni, his various emanations and his countless deeds are explained extensively in the Vinaya Sutras, Sutra on the Hundred Actions, Sutra of the Wise and Foolish and Birth Stories. If we know the good qualities of Buddha Shakyamuni we will know the good qualities of all Buddhas and we will understand that when we become enlightened we will have exactly the same qualities. Therefore we should develop strong faith in Buddha, pay respect to him and make offerings; and to benefit all living beings we should strive to become a Buddha ourself.

A PRESENTATION OF THE GOOD QUALITIES OF THE FORCES

This section has four parts:

1 Briefly presenting the ten forces

2 An extensive explanation

3 Why all the qualities cannot be described

4 The benefits of understanding the two good qualities

BRIEFLY PRESENTING THE TEN FORCES

[XI.28] The force knowing source and non-source,

Likewise knowing full ripening of actions,

Understanding the various desires,

And the force knowing the various elements,

[XI.29] Likewise knowing supreme and non-supreme powers,

Going everywhere,

And the force knowing the mental stabilizations,

[Concentrations of] perfect liberation, concentrations, absorptions and so forth,

[XI.30] Knowing recollections of previous places,

Likewise knowing death and birth,

And the force knowing the cessation of contaminations –

These are the ten forces.

The ten forces that are good qualities of a Buddha’s mind are:

(1) The force knowing source and non-source

(2) The force knowing full ripening of actions

(3) The force knowing the various desires

(4) The force knowing the various elements

(5) The force knowing supreme and non-supreme powers

(6) The force knowing all paths going everywhere

(7) The force knowing the mental stabilizations, concentrations of perfect liberation, concentrations, absorptions and so forth

(8) The force knowing recollections of previous lives

(9) The force knowing death and birth

(10) The force knowing the cessation of contaminations

AN EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION

Each of the ten forces will now be explained.

THE FORCE KNOWING SOURCE AND NON-SOURCE

[XI.31] Any cause from which something is definitely produced

Is said by the Omniscient Ones to be the source of that.

The opposite of what is explained is not a source.

The knower of infinite objects of knowledge that has abandoned obstructions is said to be a force.

Buddha said that any cause from which an effect is produced is the source of that effect. For example, a seed from which a sprout is produced is the source of that sprout. Thus all causes are the sources of their effects. For example, virtuous actions are the source of happiness and non-virtuous actions are the source of suffering. On the other hand, wheat seeds, for example, are not the source of rice, non-virtuous actions are not the source of happiness and virtuous actions are not the source of suffering. Because ordinary beings do not know the sources of happiness they engage in actions that increase their suffering instead of increasing their happiness, and because they do not know the sources of suffering they continually create the causes of suffering for themselves even though they have no wish to suffer. Therefore it is essential to know what is a source and what is not a source. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing source and non-source is an exalted awareness that has abandoned all obstructions and that knows directly the infinite objects of knowledge that are source and non-source.

THE FORCE KNOWING FULL RIPENING OF ACTIONS

[XI.32] The desirable, the undesirable, the reverse of these, actions of abandonment

And their full ripening – a great variety –

The powerful, able, unobstructed knower engaging individually

That encompasses objects of knowledge of the three times is said to be a force.

There are countless actions, such as virtuous actions, non-virtuous actions, actions that are a mixture of virtue and non-virtue and uncontaminated actions that have abandoned non-virtue. Similarly, there is a great variety of effects of actions such as fully-ripened effects, environmental effects, effects similar to the cause and bodies of the nature of mind that are effects of uncontaminated actions. Only a Buddha can directly understand all gross and subtle actions and their effects. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing full ripening of actions is a powerful, able, unobstructed exalted awareness that encompasses all objects of knowledge that are gross and subtle actions and effects of the three times and knows them directly and individually.

THE FORCE KNOWING THE VARIOUS DESIRES

[XI.33] Desires arising through the force of attachment and so forth –

A great variety of inferior, middling and especially superior desires –

The knower of these and others besides them,

Encompassing all living beings of the three times, is known as a ‘force’.

Living beings have many desires – desires that arise through the force of delusions such as attachment and hatred, desires that arise through the force of virtuous minds such as faith and compassion, desires that arise through the force of imprints in the mind and many others. Just one living being has countless desires. Some desires are inferior, others middling and others superior. Inferior desires are non-virtuous desires such as the wish to kill or steal. Middling desires are neutral desires such as the wish to eat or sleep. Superior desires are virtuous desires such as the wish to attain enlightenment, the wish to attain liberation or the wish to protect living beings. These arise through the force of Buddha’s blessings, through listening to correct teachings, through contemplation and meditation or through the force of virtuous imprints. Since desire is an internal, mental phenomenon it is difficult for an ordinary being to know others’ desires. Only a Buddha knows all the desires of living beings directly. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing the various desires is an unobstructed exalted awareness that encompasses all objects of knowledge that are the inferior, middling and superior desires of all living beings of the three times and knows them directly.

THE FORCE KNOWING THE VARIOUS ELEMENTS

[XI.34] Through their skill in perfectly distinguishing the elements

Buddhas say that whatever is the nature of eyes and so forth is an element.

The limitless knower of complete Buddhas

Realizing the distinctions of all types of element is said to be a force.

There are many divisions of elements such as the six powers, the eye sense power and so forth; the six objects, forms and so forth; and the six consciousnesses, eye consciousness and so forth. These and their ultimate nature, emptiness, have all been explained by the Buddhas. The divisions of all the gross and subtle elements are countless and only Buddhas can know them all directly. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing the various elements is an unobstructed exalted awareness that knows directly all objects of knowledge that are gross and subtle elements.

THE FORCE KNOWING SUPREME AND NON-SUPREME POWERS

[XI.35] Of conceptualization and so forth only the very sharp are accepted as supreme,

Middling types and the dull being explained as non-supreme.

The knower of all aspects free from attachment

That understands the eyes and so forth and their ability to support each other, is said to be a force.

Both supreme and non-supreme powers can be classified either from the point of view of minds or from the point of view of persons. Among minds, those such as faith and wisdom are supreme powers because they are the powers that prevent delusions, whereas conceptualizations such as inappropriate attention are inferior powers because they are the powers that generate delusions. Among persons there are some who have very sharp powers, some who have middling powers and some who have dull powers; and only those with very sharp powers are accepted as supreme.

From another point of view there are twenty-two types of power:

(1) Eye sense power

(2) Ear sense power

(3) Nose sense power

(4) Tongue sense power

(5) Body sense power

(6) Mental power

(7) The power of life

(8) Male power

(9) Female power

(10) The power of pleasant feeling

(11) The power of mental happiness

(12) The power of unpleasant feeling

(13) The power of mental unhappiness

(14) The power of neutral feeling

(15) The power of faith

(16) The power of effort

(17) The power of mindfulness

(18) The power of concentration

(19) The power of wisdom

(20) The power that causes knowledge of all

(21) The power that knows all

(22) The power that possesses all knowledge

The first six are powers that produce their own consciousnesses, the seventh is the power that sustains life, the eighth is the power that determines a person as male, the ninth is the power that determines a person as female, the tenth, which is bodily feeling and the eleventh, which is mental feeling, are the powers that generate attachment in ordinary beings, the twelfth, which is bodily feeling, and the thirteenth, which is mental feeling, are the powers that generate hatred in ordinary beings, the fourteenth is the power that generates confusion in ordinary beings, the fifteenth through to the nineteenth are the powers that generate the path of seeing, the twentieth, which is the path of seeing, is the power that generates the path of meditation, the twenty-first, which is the path of meditation, is the power that generates the Path of No More Learning, and the last, which is the Path of No More Learning, is the power that generates a nirvana without remainder.

Of these twenty-two powers, the first fourteen are inferior, or non-supreme, because they are causes of samsara and the last eight are supreme because they are causes of liberation and enlightenment. These are explained extensively in the commentaries to Treasury of Abhidharma by Vasubandhu. Only Buddhas can know directly all the powers such as the eye sense power as well as their ability to support each other. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing supreme and non-supreme powers is an unobstructed exalted awareness that knows directly all objects of knowledge that are gross and subtle supreme and non-supreme powers.

THE FORCE KNOWING ALL PATHS GOING EVERYWHERE

[XI.36] Some paths lead to the very state of a Conqueror,

Some to the enlightenment of a Solitary Realizer or the enlightenment of a Hearer,

Others to hungry ghosts, animals, hell beings, gods, humans and so forth;

The knower of these that is free from attachment is said to be the force going everywhere.

In general there are two types of path – external paths and internal paths. The paths that concern the spiritual practitioner are internal paths and these are more difficult to understand. Internal paths are either correct or incorrect. Correct internal paths lead to liberation or enlightenment. Some, such as the five Mahayana paths, lead to great enlightenment or Buddhahood and some, such as the five Hinayana paths, lead to the enlightenment of a Solitary Realizer or the enlightenment of a Hearer. Incorrect internal paths on the other hand lead not to liberation but to samsara. Some, such as the ten non-virtuous actions, lead to the hell realms, the hungry ghost realms, or the animal realms, and some, such as contaminated virtuous actions lead to the god realms or the human realms. Since there are so many different paths only a Buddha can know them all directly. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing all paths going everywhere is an unobstructed exalted awareness free from attachment that knows directly all correct and incorrect paths.

THE FORCE KNOWING THE MENTAL STABILIZATIONS, CONCENTRATIONS OF PERFECT LIBERATION, CONCENTRATIONS, ABSORPTIONS AND SO FORTH

[XI.37] The different types of Yogi throughout limitless worlds

Have the mental stabilizations, the eight [concentrations of] perfect liberation,

Those that are tranquil abidings and the nine that are absorptions;

The unobstructed knower of these is said to be a force.

There are many different types of Yogi and Yogini throughout limitless worlds, each of whom has attained different meditative concentrations such as the four mental stabilizations, the eight concentrations of perfect liberation, the various concentrations that are tranquil abidings and the absorptions of the nine successive abidings. Since there are countless different concentrations, some of which are mundane and some of which are supramundane, only a Buddha can know them all directly. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing the different mental stabilizations, concentrations of perfect liberation, concentrations of desire realm beings, absorptions and so forth is an unobstructed exalted awareness that knows directly all mundane and supramundane concentrations.

THE FORCE KNOWING RECOLLECTIONS OF PREVIOUS LIVES

[XI.38] For as long as there is confusion there is abiding in samsara.

Oneself and each and every living being of samsara now past,

However many there are, a limitless number, their origins and places of birth –

The knower of these is said to be a force.

For as long as they have confusion, living beings will remain in samsara. In the past, the countless samsaric beings including ourself have already taken countless rebirths in countless different places of birth, each in a different body with different characteristics, friends, possessions and so forth. Only a Buddha can know all these directly. The definition of a force that is a mind of a Buddha knowing recollections of previous lives is an unobstructed exalted awareness that knows directly all objects of knowledge that are the previous places of birth and so forth of oneself and all other living beings.

THE FORCE KNOWING DEATH AND BIRTH

[XI.39] The many varieties of death and birth of every single living being

Inhabiting the worlds as extensive as space –

The limitless knower without attachment and completely pure

That apprehends all aspects of these at one time is said to be a force.

Because the realms of all the worlds are as extensive as space, the living beings inhabiting them are countless. Each and every living being experiences uncontrolled death and birth one after the other without cessation as the effects of their accumulated actions. However, ordinary beings do not know how or where they died in the past, how or where they were born in the past, how or where they will die in this life or how and where they will be born and die in future lives. The many varieties of death and birth of each and every living being can be known directly only by a Buddha. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing death and birth is an unobstructed exalted awareness that is free from attachment and completely pure and that knows directly and at one time all aspects of the process of death and birth of every living being.

THE FORCE KNOWING THE CESSATION OF CONTAMINATIONS

[XI.40] The Conquerors’ swift destruction of delusions together with their imprints

Through the force of the knower of all aspects,

And the cessation of delusions by wisdom in the disciples and so forth –

The limitless knower of these that is free from attachment is said to be a force.

There are three types of enlightenment – great, middling and small. Buddhas attain a great enlightenment by abandoning all delusions together with their imprints, Solitary Realizers attain a middling enlightenment by abandoning all delusions and Hearers attain a small enlightenment also by abandoning all delusions. Each of these three enlightenments is known as a ‘cessation of contaminations’. Only a Buddha knows all these directly and reveals them to disciples. The definition of a force that is a Buddha’s mind knowing the cessation of contaminations is an unobstructed knower free from attachment that knows directly all objects of knowledge that are cessations of contaminations.

In the foregoing definitions, ‘free from attachment’ means ‘free from the delusion-obstructions’ and ‘unobstructed’ means ‘free from the obstructions to omniscience’. Delusion-obstructions are obstructions that principally obstruct the attainment of liberation. There are two types – manifest and non-manifest. The former are actual delusions and the latter are seeds of delusion. Delusion-obstructions can also be divided into intellectually-formed and innate. Intellectually-formed delusions are generated in dependence on incorrect reasoning or incomplete analysis. For example, the minds of proponents of non-Buddhist or lower Buddhist tenets that hold to inherently existent phenomena are intellectually-formed delusions. Innate delusions, on the other hand arise naturally from potentialities in the mind without depending on reasoning. All the delusions in the minds of animals and insects and most of the delusions in the minds of human beings are innate delusions. All intellectually-formed delusions and their seeds are abandoned by the path of seeing and all innate delusions and their seeds are abandoned by the path of meditation. Sometimes delusion-obstructions are divided into objects abandoned by the path of seeing and objects abandoned by the path of meditation. According to this system, intellectually-formed delusion-obstructions are objects abandoned by the path of seeing and innate delusion-obstructions are objects abandoned by the path of meditation.

Obstructions to omniscience are obstructions that principally obstruct the attainment of Buddhahood. They are so called because they obstruct simultaneous and direct knowledge of all phenomena. They are of two types – manifest and non-manifest, the latter being further divided into gross and subtle. A Bodhisattva begins to abandon obstructions to omniscience on the eighth ground but they are not finally abandoned until Buddhahood is attained.
