A Bodhisattva on the eighth ground has abandoned all delusions and their seeds but he still has the imprints of delusions in his mental continuum, rather as wet sand will retain a footprint even after the foot has moved on. These imprints of the delusions are obstructions to omniscience. They are not to be confused with the seeds of delusion. Seeds of delusion are causes of delusion and a Bodhisattva on the eighth ground has completely abandoned these. Imprints of delusion are effects of delusion but not causes of delusion. They are, however, causes of mistaken appearance. Thus although a Bodhisattva on the eighth ground has completely abandoned true-grasping and its seeds, the imprints of true-grasping that remain cause phenomena to appear as truly existent to his or her mind. These obstructions remain until Buddhahood is attained.

Only Buddhas are free from the imprints of delusion and the mistaken appearance of true existence to which they give rise. Hinayana Foe Destroyers still have the imprints of delusion even though they have abandoned all delusions and their seeds. There are many cases of Hinayana Foe Destroyers who manifest symptoms of anger or desirous attachment through the force of these imprints. Even though they have abandoned all delusions they occasionally manifest partiality because the imprints of desirous attachment and anger remain in their mental continuums. Similarly, although they have no true-grasping, phenomena still appear to their minds as truly existent through the force of the imprints of true-grasping that remain in their minds.

WHY ALL THE QUALITIES CANNOT BE DESCRIBED

[XI.41] Just as a bird does not turn back due to lack of space

But returns when its strength is consumed,

So the disciples and Sons of the Buddhas

Turn back when describing the good qualities of Buddha, which are as limitless as space.

[XI.42] So how could one such as I

Understand or explain your good qualities?

However, since they were explained by Superior Nagarjuna

I have overcome my apprehension and mentioned just a few.

The above description of Buddha’s good qualities is not exhaustive. In fact, it is impossible ever to finish describing the good qualities of a Buddha. For example, just as a bird flying in the sky does not turn back because it has run out of space but returns when its strength is consumed, so when Buddha’s Hinayana and Mahayana disciples describe the good qualities of a Buddha they stop not because they have described them all, for they are as limitless as space, but because the strength of their wisdom is consumed. Thus Chandrakirti humbly confesses, ‘How could one such as I understand or explain Buddha’s qualities?’ Nevertheless he continues, ‘Since they were explained by Superior Nagarjuna and have not been made up by me I have overcome my apprehension and mentioned just a few.’

THE BENEFITS OF UNDERSTANDING THE TWO GOOD QUALITIES

[XI.43] The profound is emptiness,

And the vast are the other good qualities.

Through understanding the ways of the profound and the vast

These good qualities will be attained.

Even though the good qualities of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are endless they are all included in two types – the good qualities of the profound and the good qualities of the vast. The good qualities of the profound are the wisdom realizing emptiness, the Truth Body and so forth, and the good qualities of the vast are all the other good qualities such as the ten grounds, the ten forces and the Form Body. If we understand the good qualities of the profound and the vast we will practise the stages of these two paths and eventually we will attain all these good qualities ourself.

EXPLAINING EMANATION BODIES

[XI.44] You who possess an immovable Body visit the three worlds again with your Emanations

And show descent, birth, enlightenment and the wheel of peace.

In this way, out of compassion, you lead to a state beyond sorrow

All worldly beings who have deceitful behaviour and who are bound by the many nooses of attachment.

It may be thought that whereas the Truth Body and the Enjoyment Body remain forever working for the benefit of living beings until samsara has ceased, the Emanation Bodies do not. To dispel such doubts Chandrakirti addresses the Enjoyment Body thus: ‘You who have attained an immovable Truth Body have manifested countless Emanation Bodies in the past and you will visit the three worlds again and again to display the twelve principal deeds – descent from Joyful Land, conception in a mother‘s womb, birth, mastery of the youthful skills and sports, enjoying a partner and retinue, ordination, the practice of asceticism, meditation beneath the Bodhi Tree, overcoming the demons, attaining enlightenment, turning the Wheel of Dharma and showing the manner of passing away. Your emanations will show these twelve deeds continuously, for as each emanation shows the manner of passing away in one world, it immediately shows descent into another. Out of compassion for all worldly beings who have deceitful behaviour and who are bound to samsara by the many nooses of attachment you display countless emanations to lead them temporarily to the happiness of humans and gods and finally to a state beyond sorrow.’

Here, ‘state beyond sorrow’ means liberation from the delusions, or nirvana. Thus, ‘sorrow’ means the delusions and ‘beyond’ means liberation. Generally there are two types of nirvana – a Hinayana liberation, which is the abandonment of only the delusion-obstructions and a Mahayana enlightenment, which is the abandonment of both the delusion-obstructions and the obstructions to omniscience. From another point of view there are three types of nirvana – nirvana with remainder, nirvana without remainder and non-abiding nirvana. The first two are possessed by Hinayanists. When a Hinayanist initially attains liberation he still possesses a body arisen from contaminated karma, which is a ‘remainder’ of samsara and so his true cessations at this time are called a ‘nirvana with remainder’. When he dies he is reborn in a Pure Land and takes on a pure body produced from uncontaminated causes. His true cessations are now a nirvana without remainder. The third type of nirvana is attained only by Bodhisattvas on the pure grounds and by Buddhas. It is a state of not abiding in either the extreme of samsara or the extreme of solitary peace. The supreme non-abiding nirvana is possessed only by Buddhas, who have attained true cessations of all obstructions.

PROVING THAT THERE IS ONE FINAL VEHICLE

[XI.45] Because, here, apart from understanding thatness, there is no principal eliminator of all stains,

Because phenomena do not depend on different types of thatness

And because there are not different wisdoms that are the object-possessors of thatness

You revealed to living beings an unequalled and undivided vehicle.

[XI.46] Because there are these impurities that give rise to faults in living beings

The worldly cannot engage in the extremely profound object experienced by Buddhas.

Therefore O Sugata, since you possess both wisdom and the methods of compassion,

And since you have promised, ‘I will liberate living beings’,

[XI.47] Just like the skilful one travelling to a jewel island

Who relieved the fatigue of his company by emanating a beautiful city on the way,

You presented this vehicle to the minds of disciples as a means of peace;

But you taught separately those who have attained isolation and trained minds.

Question Previously you said that the Enjoyment Bodies and the Emanation Bodies will ultimately lead all living beings to great complete enlightenment. Does this mean that there is only one final vehicle, the Mahayana, or Great Vehicle, and that the Hinayana, or Lesser Vehicle, is only a temporary vehicle?

Answer Yes it does. There are three reasons why there is only one final vehicle:

(1) Apart from the wisdom realizing emptiness there is no direct antidote that can remove the stains of the two obstructions.

(2) Phenomena do not depend on different types of emptiness because there are not different types of emptiness.

(3) There are not different wisdoms that realize emptiness.

Through these reasons we can know that the natural Buddha lineage of all living beings does not have different types and that they are all the same nature. Therefore there is no reason why all living beings will not finally attain the full enlightenment of Buddhahood. This is why Buddha Shakyamuni revealed to living beings only one final vehicle, which surpasses all other vehicles and is undivided in any way.

Objection In some Sutras, Buddha says that there are three final vehicles – the Hearers’ Vehicle, the Solitary Realizers’ Vehicle and the Great Vehicle. If it is Buddha’s intention that there is only one final vehicle, the Great Vehicle, why did he mention the other two?

Reply These present times are characterized by five impurities – the impurity of time, the impurity of living beings, the impurity of view, the impurity of delusions and the impurity of life span. These give rise to many faults in living beings and as a result they cannot easily engage in the profound final vehicle, which is the only object experienced by Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. Therefore, since Buddha is endowed with special qualities of both wisdom and method, and since when he was a Bodhisattva he promised to liberate all living beings from samsara, he revealed three final vehicles to some Hinayanists. This was not Buddha’s ultimate intention, but simply a device to bestow temporary happiness on his Hinayana disciples.

For example, there is a legend that long ago there was a skilful boatman endowed with miracle powers who sailed together with a large company of merchants to a jewel island where they hoped to gather a great treasure of jewels. Fearing that his companions might be reluctant to embark if the journey seemed too long and arduous, the skilful boatman used his miracle powers to manifest another island much closer to home on which was a beautiful city. When they reached this island the company put to shore and enjoyed the delights of the emanated island. Once they had rested and restored their strength the skilful boatman then took them on the remainder of the journey to the jewelled island and the marvellous treasure they had sought. In a similar way, Buddha, the Great Boatman endowed with supreme powers, finally leads all living beings across the vast ocean of samsara and solitary peace to the jewel island of great enlightenment. However, for his Hinayana disciples who weary at the prospect of such a long journey he presents the lower vehicles so that they can attain temporary peace. Thus he first leads them to the vehicles of a small and middling enlightenment whereby they can attain a complete abandonment of their delusions and the pacification of suffering and then, when their minds are trained, he leads them into the Mahayana path and thereby helps them to complete the journey to great enlightenment. To disciples with greater mental capacity, however, Buddha reveals the Mahayana path from the very beginning.

EXPLAINING THE DURATION OF ENLIGHTENMENT AND REMAINING

This section has two parts:

1 The duration of enlightenment

2 The duration of remaining

THE DURATION OF ENLIGHTENMENT

[XI.48] O Sugata, however many atoms there are among the tiniest atoms

In all the Buddha Lands in all directions,

For that many aeons you enter into the most supreme, holy enlightenment;

But these secrets of yours should not be explained.

Question Previously you said that Buddhas perform the twelve deeds, but is there a limit to how long they will do so?

Answer No there is no limit. Buddhas will perform the twelve deeds continuously until samsara has ceased. For example, Buddhas will show the manner of newly attaining the most supreme, holy enlightenment for as many aeons as there are atoms among the tiniest atoms in all the Buddha Lands in all the ten directions. However, these secrets of Buddha should not be explained to those with little wisdom or small virtuous roots lest they develop doubts or wrong views.

THE DURATION OF REMAINING

[XI.49] O Conqueror, for as long as all worldly beings have not gone to the most sublime peace

And for as long as space has not been destroyed,

You who are born from the mother of wisdom and nourished by compassion will perform your deeds,

So how could you have a solitary peace?

[XI.50] The distress of a mother for her child pained by eating poison

Does not compare to your mercy for your family,

The worldly beings who through the faults of confusion eat poisonous food.

Therefore, O Protector, you will never go to the most sublime peace.

[XI.51] Because the unskilled who have minds conceiving things and non-things

Experience suffering at the time of birth and death and when separated from the pleasant and meeting the unpleasant,

And because the evil experience rebirths, these worldly beings are objects of compassion.

Therefore, O Blessed One, out of compassion you have turned your mind away from peace and do not possess a nirvana.

Question For how long will Buddha’s emanations remain in this world?

Answer For as long as all worldly beings have not attained the most sublime peace of enlightenment and for as long as space remains Buddhas, who are born from the mother of the perfection of wisdom and nourished by great compassion, will remain in the world performing deeds to help living beings. How could they dwell in a solitary peace?

Objection Buddha Shakyamuni passed away when he was eighty-one. He did not remain until the end of space.

Reply A similar point is raised in Sutra of Holy Golden Light, where there is an extensive explanation of why Buddha showed the manner of passing away. It is true that Buddha Shakyamuni showed the manner of passing away at the age of eighty-one but this does not mean that he died like an ordinary being. Because Buddha Shakyamuni’s body is born from the perfection of wisdom, it is a deathless vajra body and it still remains to this day for those who have the pure karma to see it. Many practitioners, including Je Tsongkhapa when he was in retreat at Reting Monastery, have seen Buddha Shakyamuni’s body since he showed the manner of passing away. We should remember that what appears to the minds of ordinary beings is deceptive. It is not possible for ordinary beings who are bound by karmic obstructions to see directly holy beings who have attained a deathless state. If we want to understand how Buddha Shakyamuni’s body remains we need to think deeply about the nature of reality for a long time. And to understand the nature of a vajra body and how it is attained we need to study both Sutra and Secret Mantra extensively.

Some people refer to Sutra of the Fortunate Aeons where each of the thousand Buddhas is said to have a finite life span, but this Sutra was given according to the way things appear to ordinary beings. In reality, Buddhas have infinite life spans because they have attained a deathless state. How could someone who is not free from ordinary birth, death and intermediate state be a Buddha?

The distress of a mother for her child pained by eating poison does not compare to a Buddha’s compassion for living beings, all of whom he cherishes as if they were his very own family. Worldly beings, through the faults of the confusion in their minds, are strongly attracted to the poisonous food of the five contaminated objects of desire and to obtain them they repeatedly engage in negative actions. As a result they are tormented by the unceasing pains of samsara. Seeing this, out of their limitless compassion Buddhas will never go to a state of solitary peace but will remain in this world to help suffering beings.

Worldly beings are unskilled because they lack the wisdom realizing emptiness. Thus they conceive things and non-things to be truly existent. Through the force of this true-grasping they are bound to samsara where they repeatedly experience suffering from the moment of birth through to the moment of death, repeatedly having to part with what they like and encounter what they do not like. Furthermore, evil beings who deny actions and their effects take lower rebirths where they experience unbearable suffering for inconceivably long periods. Because of this, these worldly beings are objects of compassion for the Buddhas. Therefore the Blessed Ones have turned their minds away from solitary peace and do not possess a solitary nirvana.

Vajradhara Trijang Rinpoche

Conclusion

HOW THE TREATISE WAS COMPOSED

[XI.52] This system has been extracted from the treatises on the middle way

By the monk Chandrakirti

And has been presented exactly according to

The scriptures and the oral teachings.

[XI.53] A Dharma such as this is not found elsewhere.

Likewise the system presented here

Is not found elsewhere.

The wise should understand this clearly.

[XI.54] Frightened by the colour of the great ocean of Nagarjuna’s wisdom,

Some beings have kept this excellent system at a great distance.

Now, due to the nectar from the opening of the kumuta, which came from the unfolding of these verses,

The hopes of Chandrakirti have been completely fulfilled.

[XI.55] This profound and frightening thatness just explained will be realized by those with previous familiarity,

But it will not be comprehended by others, even though they may have listened extensively.

Therefore, having seen these other systems made up by one’s own mind,

You should abandon the mind that likes their treatises as you would systems that assert a self.

This treatise, Guide to the Middle Way, which reveals the uncommon Madhyamika system, was not simply made up by its author but has been extracted by the monk Chandrakirti from the various treatises on the middle way, such as Fundamental Wisdom. It has been presented exactly according to the scriptures of definitive meaning such as the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and the oral teachings that Chandrakirti received directly from Protector Nagarjuna. A Dharma such as this, that presents profound emptiness without error, is not found in other treatises that do not explain the middle way. Similarly the system presented here, which decisively refutes all other positions and conclusively establishes the uncommon view of the Madhyamika-Prasangika school by means of reasoning and scriptural citation, is not found in the Vaibhashika, Sautrantika, Chittamatra, or even the Madhyamika-Svatantrika systems. The wise should understand this clearly.

The Madhyamika system arose from the extremely vast and deep ocean of Nagarjuna’s wisdom. Frightened by this vastness and profundity, some beings have kept this excellent system at a great distance. In reality, however, Fundamental Wisdom is like a beautiful kumuta flower that grew from the ocean of Nagarjuna’s wisdom, but because its verses were not understood its petals remained folded keeping the nectar of emptiness within. Through the power of the sunlight of Chandrakirti’s wisdom these petals have now unfolded and the precious nectar of emptiness has flowed forth completely fulfilling the hopes of Madhyamika scholars such as Chandrakirti.

This profound thatness explained extensively in the sixth chapter is the foundation of real happiness for those who have wisdom, but it may appear frightening to those who do not. It will be realized by those who have previous familiarity with emptiness from their past lives and by those who have a great stock of wisdom, but it will not be comprehended by those who reject Nagarjuna’s system even though they may have listened extensively to teachings and studied many texts.

Some commentaries to the Guide take these lines to be a reference to scholars such as the Masters Dignaga and Vasubandhu because they presented systems outside Nagarjuna’s view. However, we cannot say that these scholars have not realized emptiness just because they presented other systems. These systems may not have been their final intention and they may have revealed them for some temporary purpose. Even so, many who are called Buddhist Masters have presented systems that are contrary to the Perfection of Wisdom Sutras and that are outside the view of Nagarjuna, and they have claimed these to be the highest systems. If we develop a mind that likes these treatises and teachings that are entirely made up without relying on Buddha’s teachings, it is similar to liking systems propounded by non-Buddhists that assert a permanent, partless, causeless self. Therefore, we should abandon any mind that likes to study or practise such incorrect treatises or teachings.

DEDICATING THE MERIT FROM COMPOSING THE TREATISE

[XI.56] Through the merit encompassing all directions that I have received from explaining the excellent system of Master Nagarjuna,

That is as white as autumn stars in the sky of my mind darkened by delusions,

And that is like a jewel on the hood of the snake of my mind,

May all worldly beings realize thatness and quickly attain the grounds of the Sugatas.

In dedicating the merit from composing Guide to the Middle Way, Chandrakirti is characteristically humble. He confesses that the sky of his mind is darkened by delusions and that through the presence of these delusions his mind is like a poisonous snake. Nevertheless, the merit that he has received from explaining clearly and without error the excellent system of Master Nagarjuna by relying on reasoning and scriptural citation will benefit living beings encompassing all directions until the end of time. Because his merit is not tainted by even the slightest bad motivation it is as white as a radiant moon surrounded by stars in an autumn sky illuminating the darkness of the mind, and because it will bring immeasurable benefit to others it is like a jewel on the hood of the snake of the mind. Therefore Chandrakirti dedicates all this merit to benefit all living beings, ‘May all worldly beings realize thatness and quickly attain the grounds of the Sugatas.’

THE MEANING OF THE CONCLUSION

The concluding section has two parts:

1 The Master who composed the treatise

2 The Pandits and translators who translated it

THE MASTER WHO COMPOSED THE TREATISE

This concludes Guide to the Middle Way, which makes clear the ways of the vast and the profound. It was composed by the Master Chandrakirti who, endowed with unassailable wisdom and compassion, sincerely practised the supreme vehicle, and who by drawing milk from a picture of a cow destroyed the conception of true existence.

THE PANDITS AND TRANSLATORS WHO TRANSLATED IT

The translation from Sanskrit into Tibetan was made according to a Kashmiri text by the Indian Abbot Tilaka and the Tibetan translator Venerable Patsab Nyimadrak at the Ratnagupta monastery in the Kashmiri town of Anuparna during the reign of Sri Aryadeva the king of Kashmir. Later at Ramoche in Lhasa it was thoroughly revised and authenticated by the Indian Abbot Kanakavarma and the same translator by comparing it to eastern texts.

The translation from Tibetan into English was made under the guidance of Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche at Manjushri Kadampa Meditation Centre, England, 1986.

Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche

Dedication

Through the virtues I have accumulated by composing this book, may all mother beings be released from the sufferings of humans and non-humans. May all poverty, disaster, conflict and war be eradicated and may pure Buddhadharma flourish throughout the world so that all living beings may attain the ultimate happiness of full enlightenment.

Appendix I: The Root Text: Guide to the Middle Way

by Chandrakirti

❖ The appearance of this symbol in the Root Text indicates a new outline in the Condensed Meaning of the Commentary.

The Root Text: Guide to the Middle Way

In Sanskrit, Madhyamakavatara

In Tibetan, Uma la jugpa

Homage to youthful Manjushri

(1) ❖ Hearers and Middling Buddhas (Solitary Realizers) are born from Buddhas, the Powerful Able Ones,

❖ Buddhas are born from Bodhisattvas,

❖ And the mind of compassion, the wisdom of non-duality

And bodhichitta are the causes of Conquerors’ Sons.

(2) ❖ Because for this bountiful harvest of the Conquerors

Compassion itself is like the seed, like water for growth

And like ripening remaining for long enjoyment,

At the beginning I praise compassion.

(3) ❖ I bow down to that compassion for living beings

Who from first conceiving ‘I’ with respect to the self,

Then thinking, ‘This is mine’ and generating attachment for things,

Are without self-control like the spinning of a well.

(4) ❖ Living beings are seen to be transient and empty of inherent existence

Like a moon in rippling water.

❖ The mind of this Conquerors’ Son,

Governed by compassion to liberate living beings completely,

(5) Thoroughly dedicated with Samantabhadra’s prayers

And always abiding in joy is called the ‘first’.

❖ From then on because he has attained this

He is addressed by the very name ‘Bodhisattva’.

(6) He is also born into the lineage of the Tathagatas

And has abandoned all three bonds.

This Bodhisattva possesses a supreme joy

And is able to cause a hundred worlds to shake.

(7) Mastering ground after ground, he advances higher.

At that time for him all paths to lower rebirths have ceased.

At that time for him all grounds of ordinary beings are exhausted.

❖ He is shown to be similar to an eighth Superior.

(8) ❖ Even when abiding on the first view of the mind of complete enlightenment

He defeats those born from the speech of the Powerful Able One and the Solitary Buddhas

Through the power of his greatly increased merit;

❖ And on Gone Afar he surpasses them in wisdom.

(9) ❖ At that time giving, the first cause of the enlightenment of complete Buddhahood,

Becomes surpassing for him.

That he acts gracefully even when giving his own flesh

Is a reason for inferring the non-apparent.

(10) ❖ All these beings strongly desire happiness

And humans cannot be happy without enjoyments.

Knowing that these enjoyments come from giving,

The Able One taught giving first.

(11) ❖ Even for those with little compassion and very rough minds

Who pursue only their own interests

Desired enjoyments that cause the alleviation of suffering

Arise from giving.

(12) ❖ Even they on some occasion of giving

Will soon come to meet a Superior being.

Then having severed the continuum of samsara completely

Those who possess this cause will go to peace.

(13) ❖ Those who hold in their mind a promise to help living beings

Immediately experience joy from giving.

❖ Therefore whether one is compassionate or not

The instructions on giving are fundamental.

(14) ❖ If from hearing and contemplating the word ‘Give’,

The Conquerors’ Son develops a bliss

The like of which is not aroused in the Able Ones through experiencing peace,

What can be said about giving everything?

(15) ❖ Through the pain from cutting and giving his body

He sees from his own experience

The suffering of others in the hells and elsewhere

And strives with great effort to eliminate it quickly.

(16) ❖ Giving with emptiness of giver, gift and receiver

Is called a ‘supramundane perfection’.

Where attachment to these three is generated

It is explained as a mundane perfection.

(17) ❖ Thus, abiding high in the mind of the Conquerors’ Son,

Beautifying with light this holy base,

This Joyful is like a water crystal jewel

For having dispelled all heavy darkness it is victorious.

This concludes the first ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ Because he possesses excellent moral discipline and pure qualities

He has abandoned the stains of degenerate discipline even in his dreams.

❖ Because his conduct of body, speech and mind is pure

He accumulates all ten paths of holy actions.

(2) ❖ For him all these ten virtuous paths

Are perfected and so extremely pure.

Like the autumn moon he is always completely pure.

Pacified and radiant, he is beautified by these.

(3) ❖ If we keep pure moral discipline with the view of inherent existence

Then because of that our moral discipline is not pure.

Therefore, he is always completely free from the wanderings

Of the dualistic mind towards the three.

(4) ❖ If enjoyments that result from giving arise in a lower rebirth

It is because that being broke his legs of moral discipline.

❖ If both the interest and the capital are spent

No enjoyments will arise for him in the future.

(5) ❖ If, when living in good conditions and acting with freedom,

We do not act to hold ourself back,

Once we have fallen into the abyss and lost our freedom

How will we raise ourself from there in the future?

(6) ❖ Therefore the Conqueror taught moral discipline

After he had taught giving.

When qualities grow in the field of moral discipline

The fruits will be enjoyed unceasingly.

(7) ❖ There is no cause other than moral discipline

For the high status and definite goodness

Of ordinary beings, those born from the speech,

Those definite in self-enlightenment and Conquerors’ Sons.

(8) ❖ As with an ocean and a corpse together,

And auspiciousness and misfortune together,

So too this great being controlled by moral discipline

Has no desire to remain with that which is degenerate.

(9) ❖ If there is observation of the three –

What is abandoned, by whom and with respect to whom –

That moral discipline is explained as a mundane perfection.

That which is empty of attachment to the three is supramundane.

(10) ❖ This Stainless, free from stains, arises from the moon, the Conquerors’ Son,

Who although not of samsara is the glory of samsara;

And just like the light of the autumn moon,

It relieves the mental torment of living beings.

This concludes the second ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ Because there arises the light of the fire

That consumes all the fuel of objects of knowledge, this third ground is Luminous.

At this time there arises for the Sugatas’ Son

A copper-like appearance similar to the sun.

(2) ❖ Even if someone inappropriately angered

Were to cut flesh and bone from his body

Piece by piece for a long time,

He would generate a superior patience towards the mutilator.

(3) Furthermore, for the Bodhisattva who has seen selflessness,

What is cut, by whom, at what time and in what manner –

All these phenomena are seen to be like reflections,

Therefore he is patient.

(4) ❖ If someone harms us and we become angry,

Does our anger undo what was done?

Thus getting angry is certainly senseless here

And contradictory with the world beyond.

(5) ❖ How can one who wants to assert that he is eradicating

The effects of non-virtuous actions committed in the past

Sow the seeds of future suffering

Through anger and harm towards others?

(6) ❖ Through getting angry with Conquerors’ Sons

Virtues accumulated from giving and moral discipline

Over a hundred aeons are destroyed in an instant,

Therefore there is no evil greater than anger.

(7) ❖ Impatience creates unattractive forms, leads to the unholy,

Robs us of our discrimination that knows right from wrong

And soon throws us into lower realms.

❖ Patience produces qualities opposite to what has been explained.

(8) From patience come beauty, closeness to holy beings,

Skill in knowing the suitable and unsuitable,

And after this, birth as a human or god,

And the eradication of negativity.

(9) ❖ Knowing the faults of anger and the good qualities of patience

In ordinary beings and Conquerors’ Sons,

We should quickly abandon impatience

And always rely on patience praised by Superior beings.

(10) ❖ Although dedicated to the enlightenment of complete Buddhahood,

If there is observation of the three it is mundane.

Buddha taught that if there is no observation

That is a supramundane perfection.

(11) ❖ The Conquerors’ Son on this ground

Has the mental stabilizations and clairvoyances.

Attachment and hatred are completely extinguished

And he is always able to overcome the desirous attachment of worldly beings.

(12) ❖ These three Dharmas, giving and so forth,

Are especially praised by the Sugatas for lay people.

They are known as the ‘collection of merit’,

The cause of a Buddha’s Body that is the nature of form.

(13) ❖ This Luminous, abiding in the sun, the Conquerors’ Son,

First completely removes the darkness within himself

And then strongly wishes to eliminate the darkness of living beings.

Being very sharp on this ground, he never gets angry.

This concludes the third ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ All good qualities follow from effort,

The cause of the two collections of merit and wisdom.

The ground on which effort blazes

Is the fourth, Radiant.

(2) ❖ There, for the Sugatas’ Son,

There arises an appearance superior to the copper light,

Which is produced from superior meditation on the realizations conducive to complete enlightenment;

❖ And what is related to the view of self is completely eradicated.

This concludes the fourth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ This great being on the ground Difficult to Overcome

Cannot be defeated even by all the maras.

❖ His mental stabilization is surpassing and he also attains great skill in realizing

The subtle nature of the truths of a good mind.

This concludes the fifth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ Abiding in a mind of meditative equipoise on Approaching

He approaches the state of complete Buddhahood.

He sees the thatness of dependent arising

And through abiding in wisdom attains cessation.

(2) ❖ Just as one person with sight can easily lead

A whole group of blind people to where they want to go,

Similarly, here, wisdom takes those qualities that lack sight

And goes to the state of a Conqueror.

(3) ❖ I will explain the very profound Dharma

According to the works of Superior Nagarjuna

Where it is presented through scripture and reasoning

Just as he realizes it.

(4) ❖ Even while an ordinary being, if on hearing of emptiness

Great joy arises within again and again,

The eyes moisten with tears of great joy

And the hairs of the body stand on end,

(5) Such a person has the seed of the mind of a complete Buddha.

He is a vessel for teachings on thatness

And ultimate truth should be taught to him.

❖ After that, good qualities will grow in him.

(6) He will take up and always maintain pure moral discipline,

Practise giving, rely on compassion,

Become acquainted with patience,

Fully dedicate all his virtues to enlightenment to liberate living beings

(7) And have respect for perfect Bodhisattvas.

❖ Since beings who are skilled in the ways of the profound and the vast

Gradually attain the ground Very Joyful

Those who seek that should listen to this path.

(8) ❖ It does not arise from itself; how can it come from other?

Also it is not from both; how can it be without a cause?

❖ There is no point in it arising from itself.

❖ Moreover, it is not reasonable that what has been produced is produced again.

(9) If you assert that what is already produced is produced again

Then the production of sprouts and so forth is not found here

And seeds will continue to be produced until the end of time.

❖ How can it destroy that?

(10) ❖ For you, the shape, colour, taste, potentiality and ripening of a sprout

Are not different from those of its cause, the seed.

❖ If its previous nature is destroyed and it becomes an entity other than that,

At that time how is it the nature of that?

(11) ❖ If, for you, the seed and the sprout are not different here

Then either the sprout is unapprehendable just like the seed

Or, since they are the same, that is also apprehendable just like the sprout.

Therefore you should not assert this.

(12) ❖ Because though a cause has disintegrated its effect is still seen,

Even the worldly do not assert that they are the same.

❖ Therefore this fabrication that things arise from self

Is unacceptable in thatness and in the world.

(13) ❖ If production from self is asserted,

Then product and producer, object and agent, are one.

Since they are not one, production from self should not be asserted

Because of the consequences extensively explained.

(14) ❖ If other arises in dependence on other

Then thick darkness arises even from flames.

Indeed everything arises from everything

Because all non-producers are similar in also being other.

(15) ❖ ‘Something that can be produced is definitely called an ‘‘effect’’,

And that which has the ability to produce it, though other, is a cause.

Thus, because it is produced from a producer of the same continuum

A rice sprout is not from barley or any other as they are.’

(16) ❖ If you say this, then just as barley, corollas, kengshuka and so forth

Are not called producers of a rice sprout, do not possess the ability,

Are not of the same continuum and are not similar,

So too the rice seed is not any of these because it is other.

(17) ❖ A sprout does not exist at the time of its seed,

So without otherness how can the seed be other?

Therefore, since production of a sprout from a seed is not established,

Give up this position of so-called ‘production from other’.

(18) ❖ ‘Just as the highness and lowness of the two arms of a balance

Are seen to be simultaneous,

So too are the producing of what is to be produced and the ceasing of the producer.’

If you say this, even though they are simultaneous, there is no simultaneity here; it does not exist.

(19) Since that being produced is approaching production, it does not exist,

And that ceasing, though existent, is said to be approaching cessation;

So how are they similar to a balance?

This production [of the sprout] without an agent [the sprout itself] is also an unacceptable entity.

(20) ❖ ‘An eye consciousness is other than its simultaneous producers,

The eyes and so forth and the discrimination and so forth that arise with it.’

If this is so, what need is there for an existent to arise?

If you say it does not exist, the faults in that have already been explained.

(21) ❖ If a producer producing a product that is other is a cause

Then what is produced, an existent, a non-existent, both, or neither?

If it is an existent, what need is there for a producer and what need is there if it is a non-existent?

What need is there for both and what need is there for neither?

(22) ❖ ‘Since they rely on their own views and assert the worldly to be valid

What is the point of stating reasons here?

Worldly people also realize that other arises from other

So production from other exists; what need for reasons here?’

(23) ❖ All things hold two entities –

Those that are found by seeing correctly and by seeing falsely.

It is said that the object of seeing correctly is thatness

And that of seeing falsely a conventional truth.

(24) ❖ Furthermore, it is said that seeing falsely is of two types –

With clear powers and with faulty powers.

Awareness with faulty powers is held to be incorrect

When compared with awareness with good powers.

(25) ❖ Whatever the worldly realize

By apprehending through the six powers without faults

Is true for the worldly.

The remainder are held by the worldly to be incorrect.

(26) ❖ A nature as projected by Tirthikas

Completely under the influence of the sleep of unknowing

And what is projected on illusions, mirages and so forth –

These are non-existent even for the worldly.

(27) ❖ Just as what is observed by eyes with floaters

Does not damage awareness without floaters,

So minds lacking stainless wisdom

Do not damage a mind without stains.

(28) ❖ Because confusion obstructs nature it is conventional.

Whatever is fabricated by it but appears as true

Is said by the Able One to be a conventional truth;

But fabricated things exist only conventionally.

(29) ❖ Whatever wrong entities such as floating hairs

May be projected due to floaters,

That which is the actual entity is seen by clear eyes.

You should understand thatness here in the same way.

(30) ❖ If the worldly are valid, then since the worldly see thatness

What need is there for other Superiors,

And what need is there for superior paths?

That the confused are valid cannot also be correct.

(31) In all cases the worldly are not valid;

Therefore, on the occasion of thatness, there is no damage by the worldly.

❖ If objects of the worldly are denied

There is damage from the worldly by worldly renown.

(32) ❖ From having only sown the seeds

The worldly claim, ‘I produced this child’

Or think, ‘I planted this tree’,

Therefore, there is no production from other even for the worldly.

(33) ❖ Because a sprout is not other than its seed

The seed is not destroyed at the time of the sprout,

And because they are not one

We do not say that the seed exists at the time of the sprout.

(34) ❖ If the dependent exist by way of their own characteristics

Then things are destroyed by being negated,

Therefore emptiness causes the destruction of things.

Since this is not reasonable, things do not exist.

(35) ❖ Since, if these things are analyzed,

No object is found on this side of things

Away from the nature of thatness,

Worldly nominal truths should not be analyzed.

(36) ❖ By the reasoning on the occasion of thatness

Production from self and other is inadmissible.

Since by that reasoning it is also inadmissible nominally,

By what is production established for you?

(37) ❖ Empty things such as reflections that depend on collections

Are also not unknown.

Just as, there, awareness of their aspects is generated

From empty reflections and so forth,

(38) So, although all things are empty,

They nevertheless generate from that emptiness.

❖ And since they lack inherent existence in both truths

They are neither permanent nor annihilated.

(39) ❖ Since it does not inherently cease

It has ability even though there is no basis-of-all.

Thus you should know that an appropriate effect will arise

Even though, in some cases, a long time elapses after an action has ceased.

(40) ❖ Having seen the observed object of a dream

A fool will generate attachment even when awake.

Likewise, there is still an effect from an action

Even though it lacks inherent existence and has ceased.

(41) ❖ Although the objects are similar in not existing,

Nevertheless one with floaters sees the appearance of floating hairs

But not the appearance of other things.

In the same way, you should understand that ripened actions cannot ripen again.

(42) Thus it is seen that non-virtuous ripening is from non-virtuous actions

And virtuous ripening is from virtuous actions.

Those who realize that virtue and non-virtue do not exist will be liberated.

However, analyzing actions and their effects is discouraged.

(43) ❖ ‘Basis-of-all exists’, ‘Person exists’,

‘These aggregates alone exist’ –

These teachings are for those

Who cannot understand this very profound meaning.

(44) ❖ Even though he is free from the view of the transitory collection

Buddha reveals ‘I’ and ‘mine’.

In the same way, even though things lack inherent existence

’Existence’ is revealed as an interpretative meaning.

(45) ❖ ’An apprehender is not seen without an apprehended.

By realizing the three realms as mere consciousness

The Bodhisattva abiding in wisdom

Realizes thatness in mere consciousness.

(46) Just as waves arise from a great ocean

When it is stirred by the wind,

Likewise, because of its potentials a mere consciousness arises

From the seed of all, which is called ‘basis-of-all’.

(47) Therefore whatever is an other-powered entity

Is the cause of imputedly existent things.

It arises without external objects, exists,

And has the nature of not being an object of any elaboration.’

(48) ❖ Where is there an example of a mind without an external object?

If you say it is like a dream then let us consider that.

For us, mind does not exist even when dreaming;

Therefore you do not have an example.

(49) If mind exists because we remember the dream when awake

Then it is the same with external objects.

Just as according to you we remember, thinking, ‘I saw’,

So, like that, external objects also exist.

(50) ❖ ‘Because eye awareness is impossible in sleep, it does not exist,

Only mental awareness exists;

Yet its aspect is conceived as external.

As it is in dreams, so it is here.’

(51) If you say this, then just as for you external objects are not produced in dreams,

So mind too is not produced.

The eyes, the visual object and the mind they generate –

All three are also false.

(52) And those three of the remainder, ears and so forth, are also not produced.

❖ Just as when dreaming, so here when awake, things are false.

That mind does not exist, objects of enjoyment do not exist

And the sense powers do not exist.

(53) Here, as when awake,

So when not awake these three exist;

And on waking all three no longer exist.

It is just the same when waking from the sleep of confusion.

(54) ❖ A mind of sense powers affected by floaters

And the hairs seen due to those floaters

Are both true with respect to that mind,

But both are false with respect to one who sees objects clearly.

(55) If mind exists without an object of knowledge

Then when his eyes focus on the place of those hairs

Even one without floaters will generate a mind of floating hairs.

Since this is not the case, it does not exist.

(56) ❖ ‘The observer does not have that mind

Because he does not have a ripened potential for it,

Not because of the absence of a thing existing as an object of knowledge.’

❖ If you say this, it cannot be proven because that potential does not exist.

(57) ❖ A potential for the produced is impossible.

❖ And there is also no potential for an unproduced entity.

Without characteristics there is no possessor of characteristics,

Otherwise it would exist for a child of a childless woman.

(58) If you want to state it in terms of what is to come,

Then without a potential it will never arise.

The holy ones have said

That whatever exists in mutual dependence does not exist.

(59) ❖ If it comes from the ripened potential of what has ceased,

Then other arises from the potential of other.

For you, possessors of continuums exist in mutual difference;

Therefore everything arises from everything.

(60) If you say that there, different possessors of continuums

Do not have different continuums and so there is no fault,

This cannot be proven;

For there is no possibility of a non-different continuum.

(61) Phenomena dependent on Maitreya and Upayagupta

Are not included in the same continuum because they are other.

Thus it is not reasonable that whatever are different by way of their own characteristics

Are included within the same continuum.

(62) ❖ ‘The production of an eye consciousness

Arises entirely from its immediate potential.

A potential that is the basis for its consciousness

Is called the ‘‘eye’’, a sense power possessing form.

(63) Here, when consciousness arises from a sense power,

Appearances such as blue arise from their seeds

Without there being external objects.

Not realizing this, beings think they are external objects.

(64) Just as when dreaming, without there being another form,

A mind with an aspect of that arises from the ripening of its potential,

Likewise, here, when awake,

Mind exists without there being external objects.’

(65) ❖ If, as you say, mental consciousness with appearances such as blue

Arises in dreams where there are no eyes,

Why is it not also generated from the ripening of potentials

In blind people here, where there is no eye sense power?

(66) If you say a potential for the sixth

Ripens in dreams but not when awake,

Then just as there is no ripening of a potential for the sixth here,

Why not say there is none during dreams?

(67) Just as lack of eyes is not the cause of this,

So too in dreams sleep is not the cause.

Therefore you should say that in dreams too

Things and eyes are the causes of false subjective realizers.

(68) Since any answer you may give

Is seen to be like an assertion,

You should abandon these arguments.

❖ Nowhere have Buddhas taught that things exist.

(69) ❖ Yogis following the instructions of their Spiritual Guide

Who see the ground covered with skeletons

Also see all three to be lacking production

Because it is taught to be a false attention.

(70) If, as you say, as it is with objects of sense consciousness

So it is with the objects of the mind of unattractiveness,

Then if someone else directs their mind to that place

They will also see; thus it is not false.

(71) As it is with a sense power affected by floaters and the like,

So it is with a hungry ghost’s mind seeing a flowing river as pus.

❖ In short, the meaning you should understand is this –

Just as objects of mind do not exist, mind also does not exist.

(72) ❖ If with no apprehended object and no apprehender

An other-powered thing exists empty of both,

By what is its existence known?

It is unsuitable to say that it exists without being apprehended.

(73) That it is experienced by itself is not proven.

❖ If you say it is proven by memory at a later time

The unproven that you assert as a proof

Does not prove anything.

(74) Even if self-cognizers are admitted,

It is impossible for memory to remember

Because, being other, it would be as if generated in an unknowing continuum.

Such distinctions are also destroyed by this reasoning.

(75) ❖ Because for us this memory is not other than

That by which the object was experienced,

Memory thinks, ‘I saw’.

This is also the way of worldly convention.

(76) ❖ Therefore, if there are no self-cognizers,

By what is your other-powered phenomenon apprehended?

Since agent, object and action are not identical,

It cannot apprehend itself.

(77) ❖ If there exists a thing that is an other-powered entity

Without production and with a nature not known,

By what would its existence be impossible?

Can a child of a childless woman harm others?

(78) ❖ Since not even the slightest other-powered phenomenon exists,

What is the cause of conventionalities?

Out of attachment to a substance in the other’s view

Even all the objects known to the world are forsaken.

(79) ❖ Those who are outside the path of Master Nagarjuna

Have no means of peace.

They depart from the truths of convention and thatness

And, because they depart from them, cannot attain liberation.

(80) Nominal truths are the method,

And ultimate truth arises from the method.

Those who do not know how these two are distinguished

Will enter mistaken paths due to wrong conceptions.

(81) ❖ We do not assert any conventionalities

The way you assert other-powered things.

However, even though they do not exist, for the sake of the result

We say to the worldly that they do.

(82) But if they did not exist as worldly

In the way that they are non-existent for Foe Destroyers

Who have abandoned their aggregates and entered peace,

Then we would not say that they exist even nominally.

(83) If you are not harmed by the worldly,

Then refute them in front of the worldly.

Thus you and the worldly should debate on this,

And afterwards we will rely on the stronger.

(84) ❖ It says that a Bodhisattva on Approaching

Realizes the three realms to be only consciousness

To realize the refutation of a permanent self as creator.

In fact, he realizes that only mind is creator.

(85) ❖ Therefore, to increase the wisdom of the intelligent,

In Gone to Lanka Sutra the All-Knowing One uttered

This vajra in the nature of speech that destroys the high mountains of the Tirthikas

To clarify the meaning.

(86) In their own treatises

Tirthikas speak of person and so forth,

But seeing that these are not the creator

The Conqueror said that only mind is the creator of the world.

(87) ❖ Just as ‘increase of thatness’ is said for ‘Buddha’,

So too, in Sutra, ‘only mind’ is said for

‘Only mind is principal in the world.’

The meaning of the Sutra here is not to deny forms.

(88) If the Great One knew that these are only mind

And if he denied forms there,

Why did he say again there

That mind arises from ignorance and karma?

(89) All the various worldly environments

And the living beings, the inhabitants, are created by mind.

It is said that all living beings are born from karma,

And if there is no mind there is no karma.

(90) Even though forms exist

They have no creator like mind.

Therefore a creator other than mind is rejected.

Forms, however, are not denied.

(91) ❖ For one who remains with the worldly,

All five aggregates exist as they are known by the worldly.

If a Yogi wishes to manifest the exalted awareness of thatness

Those five will not arise for him.

(92) If forms do not exist, do not hold to the existence of mind;

And if mind exists, do not hold to the non-existence of forms.

Buddha rejects them all equally in the Wisdom Sutras,

But they are taught in the Abhidharmas.

(93) You have destroyed these stages of the two truths.

However your substance does not exist because it has been refuted.

Therefore you should know that by these stages from the beginning

Things are not produced in thatness, but are produced for the worldly.

(94) ❖ In the Sutra that says

‘External objects do not exist, mind appears as various things’,

Forms are denied for those with strong attachment to forms;

But that is also of interpretative meaning.

(95) The Blessed One says that it is of interpretative meaning;

And it is also established by reasoning to be of interpretative meaning.

❖ This scripture makes it clear that other Sutras of this kind

Are also of interpretative meaning.

(96) ❖ The Buddhas have said that if objects of mind do not exist,

The absence of mind is easily realized.

Since if objects of mind do not exist the refutation of mind is established,

Objects of mind are refuted first.

(97) ❖ Thus, having understood this explanation of the scriptures,

You should realize that any Sutra whose meaning does not explain thatness

Is taught as interpretative, and you should interpret it.

You should know that those whose meaning is emptiness are of definitive meaning.

(98) ❖ Production from both is also not a suitable entity.

Why? Because all the faults already explained apply.

It does not exist for the worldly nor is it asserted in thatness

Because production from either is not established.

(99) ❖ If there is production entirely without causes

Then everything is produced from everything all the time,

And so to obtain fruit the people of this world

Do not have to gather seeds and so forth in a hundred ways.

(100) If living beings are empty of causes, they are unapprehendable

Like the fragrance and colour of an upala flower in the sky,

But a very colourful world is apprehended.

Therefore you should know that, like your mind, the world comes from causes.

(101) The nature of those elements that are the objects of your mind

Is not the nature of this.

How could one who has such thick mental darkness here

Correctly realize the world beyond?

(102) You should realize that when you deny the world beyond

You are conceptualizing the nature of objects of knowledge with a wrong view

Because you have a body that is a basis for developing such a view.

It is the same when you assert the nature of the elements to be existent.

(103) How these elements do not exist has already been explained.

How? Because production from self, other, both and no cause

Have already been refuted in general above.

Therefore, these unmentioned elements also do not exist.

(104) ❖ Since production from self, other, both, or without depending on a cause do not exist

Things are free from inherent existence.

❖ Because worldly beings have thick confusion like a mass of cloud

Objects appear incorrectly to them.

(105) Just as some, due to visual impairments, wrongly apprehend floating hairs,

Two moons, peacocks’ feathers, flies and so forth,

So too the unwise through the faults of confusion

See various produced phenomena with their minds.

(106) ‘Since actions arise in dependence on confusion, without confusion they will not arise.’

Certainly only the unwise conceptualize this.

The wise, who have completely eliminated thick darkness with the sun of their excellent minds,

Understand emptiness and are liberated.

(107) ‘If things did not exist in thatness

They would not exist even nominally,

Like a child of a childless woman;

Therefore, they must be inherently existent.’

(108) Whatever are the objects of those with floaters and so forth

Such as floating hairs are not produced.

Therefore, you should first examine these

And then apply this to the impairment of ignorance.

(109) If a dream, a city of smell-eaters, the water of a mirage,

Hallucinations, reflections and so forth are seen without production

Why for you is that unsuitable there,

For it is similarly non-existent?

(110) Thus, although they are not produced in thatness

They are not objects that are unseen by worldly beings

Like a child of a childless woman.

Therefore what you assert is not definite.

(111) ❖ The production from its own side of a child of a childless woman

Does not exist either in thatness or for the worldly.

In the same way, all these things

Have no production by their own entity either in thatness or for the worldly.

(112) Thus, with respect to this the Blessed One says

That from the beginning all phenomena are pacified, free from production,

And by nature completely beyond sorrow.

Therefore, production is always non-existent.

(113) Just as these pots and so forth do not exist in thatness

And yet exist well-known to the worldly,

So it is with all things.

Therefore, it does not follow that they are similar to a child of a childless woman.

(114) ❖ Because things are not produced without a cause,

Not from causes such as Ishvara and so forth,

And not from self, other or both,

They are produced completely dependently.

(115) Because things arise completely dependently

These conceptions cannot be sustained.

Therefore this reasoning of dependent arising

Cuts all nets of bad views.

(116) Conceptions arise if things exist,

But how things do not exist has already been thoroughly explained.

Without things they do not arise,

As, for example, without fuel there is no fire.

(117) ❖ Ordinary beings are bound by conceptions

Whereas Yogis without conceptions are liberated.

Therefore the wise say that whenever conceptions are eliminated

It is the result of correct analysis.

(118) The analyses in the treatises were not composed out of attachment to debate;

Rather, thatness is revealed for the sake of liberation.

If in correctly explaining thatness the works of others are discredited,

There is no fault.

(119) Attachment to one’s own view

And likewise anger at the views of others are mere conceptions.

Therefore, those who eliminate attachment and anger and analyse correctly

Swiftly attain liberation.

(120) ❖ Wisdom sees that all delusions and all faults

Arise from the view of the transitory collection.

Having understood that its object is the self,

Yogis negate the self.

(121) ❖ A self that is an experiencer, a permanent thing, a non-creator

And without qualities or activity is fabricated by the Tirthikas.

❖ Through finer and finer distinctions,

Different traditions of the Tirthikas have evolved.

(122) ❖ Since such a self is not born it does not exist,

Just like a child of a childless woman;

And since it is not even the basis of grasping at I

It cannot be asserted even conventionally.

(123) All the characteristics attributed to it by the Tirthikas

In this treatise and that treatise

Are damaged by the reason of its not being born, with which they are familiar;

Therefore, none of these characteristics exists.

(124) Thus there is no self that is other than the aggregates

Because it is not apprehended separately from the aggregates.

It cannot even be asserted as the basis of worldly I-grasping minds

Because though they do not cognize it, they have a view of self.

(125) Even those who have spent many aeons as animals

Do not see this unborn permanent,

And yet they too are seen to grasp at I.

Therefore, there is no self that is other than the aggregates.

(126) ❖ ‘Since a self that is other than the aggregates is not established,

The observed object of the view of self is only the aggregates.’

Some assert all five aggregates as the basis of the view of self

And some assert the mind alone.

(127) ❖ If the aggregates are the self, then since they are many

The self is also many.

The self is a substance

And the view of it is not wrong because it apprehends a substance.

(128) The self definitely ceases at the time of a nirvana;

And in the lives prior to a nirvana

Since an agent who is born and perishes does not exist,

There are no results and one experiences what another has accumulated.

(129) ❖ ‘Since there is a continuum in thatness there is no fault.’

But the faults of a continuum have already been explained in a previous analysis.

Therefore, neither the aggregates nor the mind is suitable to be the self

❖ Because the world has no end and so forth.

(130) ❖ According to you, when a Yogi sees selflessness

Things are definitely non-existent.

If it is a permanent self that is negated, then in that case

Neither your mind nor your aggregates is the self.

(131) According to you, a Yogi seeing selflessness

Does not realize the thatness of forms and so forth,

And because he observes forms and apprehends

He generates attachment and so forth from not having realized their nature.

(132) ❖ If you assert that the aggregates are the self

Because the Blessed One says that the aggregates are the self,

This is to refute a self other than the aggregates

Because in other Sutras it says that forms are not the self and so forth.

(133) Since other Sutras say that

Forms, feelings and discriminations are not the self,

Nor are compositional factors or consciousness,

The teaching in the Sutra does not say that the aggregates are the self.

(134) ❖ ‘When it says that the aggregates are the self

It means the collection of the aggregates, not their entities.’

It is not a protector, subduer or witness.

Since it does not exist that is not the collection.

(135) ❖ In that case, the collection of its parts remaining is a cart

Because self is similar to a cart.

❖ Sutra says that it is dependent on the aggregates.

Therefore, the mere collection of the aggregates is not the self.

(136) ❖ If you say it is the shape then since that belongs to form-possessors

They are the self according to you.

The collection of mind and so forth are not the self

Because they do not have shape.

(137) ❖ It is impossible for oneself the appropriator and what is appropriated to be identical,

Otherwise the agent and the [object of the] action would be identical.

If you think there is an [object of an] action without an agent

That is not so because there is no action without an agent.

(138) ❖ Since the Able One teaches that the self is dependent on

The six elements – earth, water, fire, wind,

Space and consciousness –

And on the six bases, eye contact and so forth,

(139) And since he says that it is dependent on

The phenomena of minds and mental factors,

It is not them, not any one of them and not the mere collection.

Therefore, the I-grasping mind does not observe them.

(140) ❖ ‘When selflessness is realized, a permanent self is negated’,

But this is not held to be the basis of grasping at I.

Therefore, it is amazing that you say that the view of self

Is eradicated through knowing the non-existence of self!

(141) It would be like someone who sees a snake in a hole in the wall of his house

Having his anxiety quelled and losing his fear of the snake

By someone saying, ‘There is no elephant here!’

Alas, he would be the laughing stock of others.

(142) ❖ The self is not within the aggregates

And the aggregates are not within the self.

Why not? If they were other, then there would be these conceptualizations,

But since they are not other, these are just conceptions.

(143) The self is not said to possess form because the self does not exist,

Therefore, there is no relationship with the meaning of possession.

Whether other, possessing cows, or not other, possessing form,

The self is neither one with nor other than form.

(144) ❖ Form is not the self, the self does not possess form,

The self is not within form and form is not within the self.

Thus all the aggregates should be known in these four ways,

Said to be the twenty views of the self.

(145) The vajra realizing selflessness destroys the mountain of views,

And these high peaks in the huge mountain range

Of the view of the transitory collection

Are destroyed along with the self.

(146) ❖ Some assert a substantially existent person who is indescribable

In terms of sameness, otherness, permanence, impermanence and so forth.

They say it is an object of knowledge of the six consciousnesses

And assert that it is the basis of grasping at I.

(147) ❖ Since you do not assert mind to be indescribable with respect to form

You should not assert existent things to be indescribable.

If self exists as a thing

Existent things, like mind, are not indescribable.

(148) According to you a pot, which is an entity not existing as a thing,

Is indescribable with respect to form and so forth.

Therefore, you should not assert a self indescribable with respect to its aggregates

Existing by itself.

(149) You do not assert that consciousness is other than its own nature

But you do assert it to be a thing that is other than form and so forth.

Since these two aspects are seen in things

The self does not exist because it lacks the characteristics of things.

(150) ❖ Therefore, the basis of grasping at I is not a thing.

It is not other than the aggregates and it is not the entity of the aggregates.

It does not depend on the aggregates and it does not possess them.

It exists in dependence on the aggregates.

(151) It is like a cart, which is not other than its parts,

Not non-other and does not possess them.

It is not within its parts and its parts are not within it.

It is not the mere collection and it is not the shape.

(152) ❖ If the mere collection is a cart

Then that cart exists in the pieces that remain.

Without a part-possessor there are no parts

Therefore, it is impossible for the mere shape to be the cart.

(153) ❖ According to you, the shape of each part is the same

When assembled into a cart as it was before.

Just as with those that were separate,

So too there is no cart even now.

(154) If the wheels and so forth have different shapes

Now at the time of the cart, they must be visible,

But they are not.

Therefore, the mere shape is not the cart.

(155) ❖ Since for you there is not the slightest collection

That shape is not of the collection of parts,

And since it does not depend on anything

How, in this case, can it be the shape?

(156) ❖ You should know that all things are produced

Just as you have asserted here,

With aspects of effects having untrue natures

Arising in dependence on untrue causes.

(157) Because of this, it is also unsuitable to say that a mind of a pot

Observes the forms and so forth that exist like that.

Since there is no production, forms and so forth do not exist.

Therefore, it is also unsuitable that their shape does.

(158) ❖ Indeed, it is not established by the seven ways

Either in thatness or for the worldly,

But from the point of view of the worldly without analysis

It is imputed here in dependence on its parts.

(159) ❖ It is a part-possessor and a component-possessor.

For living beings a cart is called an ‘agent’

And for beings it exists as a taker.

Do not destroy conventionalities known to the world.

(160) ❖ How can it be said that that which is non-existent in the seven ways exists

When its existence is not found by Yogis?

Since they realize thatness easily,

Its existence should be asserted in the same way here.

(161) ❖ If a cart does not exist then in that case,

Since there is no part-possessor, its parts also do not exist.

For example, if a cart is burned its parts no longer exist.

Likewise, when the part-possessor is consumed by the fire of wisdom, so too are the parts.

(162) ❖ In the same way, the self is held by worldly renown

To be an appropriator in dependence on the aggregates,

The elements and likewise the six sources.

The appropriated are the object and it is the agent.

(163) ❖ Because the thing does not exist it is not stable and not unstable,

It is not born and does not perish.

It also has no permanence and so forth

And it is without oneness or otherness.

(164) ❖ The self with respect to whom a mind grasping at I

Always arises strongly in living beings,

And with respect to whose possessions a mind grasping at mine arises,

That self exists uninvestigated and well-known to confusion.

(165) ❖ Since without an agent there is no [object of the] action,

Without a self there is no mine.

Therefore Yogis who see that self and mine are empty

Will attain liberation.

(166) ❖ Such things as pots, woollen cloth, canvas, armies, forests, rosaries, trees,

Houses, hand carts, guest houses and so forth

Should be realized in just the same way as they are spoken of,

Because the Able One would never argue with the worldly.

(167) Parts and part-possessors, qualities and quality-possessors, attachment and the attached,

Characteristics and bases of characteristics, firewood and fire and so forth –

Objects such as these do not exist in seven ways when analysed like a cart,

But otherwise do exist by way of worldly renown.

(168) ❖ If a cause produces a product it is a cause

And if no effect is produced then, lacking that, it is not a cause,

But if an effect has a cause it is produced.

Therefore, tell us what arises from what and what precedes what?

(169) If you say that a cause produces an effect through meeting

Then if they are the same potential, producer and effect are not different,

And if they are different, there is no distinction between cause and non-cause.

Having rejected these two, there is no other possibility.

(170) If you say that causes do not produce effects then so-called effects do not exist

And without an effect there is no reason for a cause, and they do not exist.

Since both of these are just like illusions, we are not at fault

And worldly people’s things exist.

(171) ❖ ‘Do these faults not apply to you as well,

For your refutation would refute what is to be refuted either by meeting it or by not meeting it?

When you say this you destroy only your own position.

Thus you are not able to refute what you seek to refute.

(172) And because without any reason you cast aspersions on everything

With false consequences that even in your own words turn back on yourselves,

You will not be accepted by the Holy Ones,

For, because you have no position of your own, you can only dispute by refuting.’

(173) ❖ The fault that you have stated here, that a refutation refutes what is to be refuted

Either by meeting or by not meeting,

Definitely applies to those who hold the position,

But since we do not hold that position the consequence does not follow.

(174) ❖ Just as for you at the time of an eclipse and so forth

The characteristics of the orb of the sun are seen even in a reflection,

And although the meeting or non-meeting of the sun and the reflection are certainly inappropriate,

Nevertheless it arises dependently and merely nominally.

(175) And although it is untrue, it is used to beautify the face.

Just as that exists, so too in the same way here,

Our reasons are seen to be effective in cleaning the wisdom face,

For although they are not suited, you should know that with them you can realize the object to be established.

(176) ❖ If the reasons that cause the objects they establish to be understood existed as things

And if the object established, that which is actually understood, were an existent entity,

You could apply the reasoning of meeting and so forth,

But since they do not exist, you can only despair.

(177) ❖ We can very easily induce the realization

That all things lack things,

But you cannot easily make others understand inherent existence in the same way.

So why confound the world with a net of bad views?

(178) ❖ Having understood the last refutation just taught,

You should use it here to answer the position of meeting and so forth.

We are not like disputants who only refute.

Any remainder from what has been explained should be understood by this position.

(179) ❖ To liberate living beings, the Blessed One said

That this selflessness has two types when divided by way of persons and phenomena;

And then again, according to disciples,

He explained many divisions of these.

(180) Having extensively explained

Sixteen emptinesses

He again explained four in brief,

And these are regarded as the Mahayana.

(181) ❖ Eyes are empty of eyes

Because that is their nature.

Ears, nose, tongue, body and mind

Should be understood in the same way.

(182) Because they do not remain constant

And do not disintegrate,

The lack of inherent existence

Of the six, eyes and so forth,

Is said to be the emptiness of the inner.

(183) ❖ Forms are empty of forms

Because that is their nature.

Sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects and phenomena

Are just the same.

(184) The lack of inherent existence of forms and so forth

Is said to be the emptiness of the outer.

❖ The lack of inherent existence of both

Is the emptiness of the inner and outer.

(185) The lack of inherent existence of phenomena

Is explained as emptiness by the wise.

❖ And that emptiness too is said to be

Empty of the entity of emptiness.

(186) The emptiness of what is called ‘emptiness’

Is said to be the emptiness of emptiness.

It was taught to overcome the mind

That apprehends emptiness as a thing.

(187) ❖ Because they pervade all environments

And their beings,

And because they are without end like the immeasurables,

The directions are great.

(188) That which is the emptiness

Of all these ten directions

Is the emptiness of the great.

It was taught to overcome grasping at the great.

(189) ❖ Because it is the supreme purpose,

The ultimate is nirvana.

That which is its emptiness

Is the emptiness of the ultimate.

(190) The Knower of the ultimate

Taught the emptiness of the ultimate

To overcome the mind

That apprehends nirvana as a thing.

(191) ❖ Because they arise from conditions,

The three realms are definitely explained as produced.

That which is their emptiness

Is said to be the emptiness of the produced.

(192) ❖ Whatever lacks production, abiding and impermanence

Is unproduced.

That which is its emptiness

Is the emptiness of the unproduced.

(193) ❖ Whatever is without extremes

Is described as beyond extremes.

The mere emptiness of that

Is explained as the emptiness of beyond extremes.

(194) ❖ Because samsara lacks both

A first beginning and a final end

It is described as beginningless and endless.

Because it is free from coming and going, it is like a dream.

(195) In the scriptures it clearly says that

That which is the isolation of this samsara

Is called the ‘emptiness

Of the beginningless and endless’.

(196) ❖ Rejected is clearly explained as

Cast aside or forsaken.

Not rejected, or not given up,

Is that which should not be rejected at any time.

(197) That which is the emptiness

Of the not rejected

Is therefore called

The ‘emptiness of the not rejected’.

(198) ❖ Because the very entity

Of the produced and so forth

Was not made by Hearers, Solitary Realizers,

Conquerors’ Sons, or Tathagatas,

(199) So the very entity of the produced and so forth

Is explained as their very nature.

That which is the emptiness of that

Is the emptiness of nature.

(200) ❖ The eighteen elements, the six contacts,

The six feelings that arise from them,

Likewise, those possessing form and those not possessing form

And produced and unproduced phenomena –

(201) That which is the isolation of all of these

Is the emptiness of all phenomena.

❖ That which is the non-thing of suitable to be form and so forth

Is the emptiness of definitions.

(202) ❖ Form has the definition, suitable to be form,

Feeling has the nature of experience,

Discrimination is apprehending signs,

And compositional factors are produced phenomena.

(203) The definition of consciousness

Is cognizing aspects of individual objects.

The definition of aggregate is suffering.

The nature of the elements is said to be a poisonous snake.

(204) The sources are said by Buddha

To be the doors for generation.

Within dependent relationship, that which arises

Is defined as coming together.

(205) ❖ The perfection of giving is giving away.

Moral discipline is defined as without torment.

Patience is defined as without anger.

Effort is defined as without non-virtue.

(206) Mental stabilization is defined as gathering.

Wisdom is defined as without attachment.

These are given as the definitions

Of the six perfections.

(207) The mental stabilizations, the immeasurables,

And likewise others that are formless

Are said by the Perfect Knower

To have the definition unperturbed.

(208) The thirty-seven realizations conducive to enlightenment

Are defined as causing definite emergence.

The definition of emptiness

Is complete isolation through not observing.

(209) Signlessness is pacification.

The definition of the third is the absence of suffering and confusion.

The [concentrations of] perfect liberation

Are defined as perfectly liberating.

(210) ❖ The forces are said to be the nature of

Utterly perfect decisiveness.

The fearlessnesses of the Protector

Are the nature of utter firmness.

(211) The correct, specific cognizers

Have the definition inexhaustible confidence and so on.

Accomplishing the benefit of living beings

Is called ‘great love’.

(212) Completely protecting those who suffer

Is great compassion.

Joy is defined as supreme joy,

And equanimity should be known by the definition unmixed.

(213) Whatever are asserted to be

The eighteen unshared qualities of a Buddha

Are defined as unsurpassed

Because the Blessed One is never surpassed by them.

(214) The exalted awareness knowing all aspects

Is said to have the definition direct perceiver.

Others, being limited,

Are not called ‘direct perceivers’.

(215) ❖ Whether they are definitions of produced phenomena

Or definitions of unproduced phenomena,

Their mere emptiness

Is the emptiness of definitions.

(216) ❖ The present does not remain

And past and future do not exist.

Because they are not observed anywhere

They are explained as unobservable.

(217) That which is the very isolation

Of the entities of these unobservables,

Because they neither remain constant nor disintegrate,

Is the emptiness of the unobservable.

(218) ❖ Because they arise from conditions

Things lack the entity of assembling.

The emptiness of assembling

Is the emptiness of no thing.

(219) ❖ The term ‘thing’

Indicates the five aggregates when condensed.

That which is their emptiness

Is explained as the emptiness of things.

(220) ❖ ‘Non-thing’

Indicates unproduced phenomena when condensed.

That which is the emptiness of non-things

Is the emptiness of non-things.

(221) ❖ Nature’s lack of entityness

Is called the ‘emptiness of nature’.

Thus, it is explained that because nature is not created

It is called ‘nature’.

(222) ❖ Whether Buddhas actually appear

Or do not appear

The emptiness of all things

Is explained as the other entity.

(223) The perfect end and thatness

Are the emptiness of other entities.

These explanations have been given

According to Perfection of Wisdom.

(224) ❖ Thus, with the rays of his wisdom he attains a clear appearance
