Just like an olive resting in the palm of his hand

And realizing that from the beginning all these three worlds have been without production

He enters into cessation through the power of nominal truth.

(225) Even though his thought is constantly directed towards cessation,

He still generates compassion for protectorless living beings.

After this, through his wisdom he will also defeat

All those born from the Sugata’s speech and all Middling Buddhas.

(226) This king of the geese, spreading his broad, white wings of convention and thatness,

Comes to the fore of the geese of living beings

And then, through the force of his powerful winds of virtue,

Goes to the supreme – the ocean of the Conquerors’ qualities.

This concludes the sixth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ Here, on Gone Afar, he can enter into cessation

Instant by instant,

And he has also attained a surpassing perfection of means.

This concludes the seventh ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ To attain virtues superior to those of before

This great being strives repeatedly for Immovable

On which they never return.

His prayers become extremely pure,

And he is raised from cessation by the Conquerors.

(2) ❖ Because his mind of non-attachment does not remain with faults

The eighth-grounder has thoroughly pacified those stains together with their roots,

But although his delusions are extinguished and he is the highest of the three grounds

He cannot yet attain all the qualities of the Buddhas, which are as endless as space.

(3) ❖ Although samsara has ceased, he attains the ten powers,

And with these causes his nature to be displayed as various beings within samsara.

This concludes the eighth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ On the ninth all his forces become completely pure.

Likewise he also attains the completely pure qualities of the correct cognizers of phenomena.

This concludes the ninth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ On the tenth ground, he receives holy empowerments from Buddhas in all directions,

And he also attains a supreme, surpassing exalted awareness.

Just as rain falls from rain clouds, so for the sake of living beings’ virtuous crops

A rain of Dharma spontaneously falls from the Conquerors’ Son.

This concludes the tenth ground in Guide to the Middle Way.

(1) ❖ At that time he can see a hundred Buddhas

And realize their blessings.

He remains alive for a hundred aeons

And engages perfectly in the ends of the former and the later.

(2) This Wise One can enter into and rise from the absorptions of a hundred concentrations.

He can cause a hundred worlds to shake and illuminate them.

Likewise, through his magical emanations he can cause a hundred living beings to ripen,

And visit a hundred Pure Lands.

(3) He can completely open the doors of Dharma, and this Son of the Powerful Able One

Can cause bodies to be displayed throughout his body,

Each body being endowed with and beautified by its retinue,

And revealing a hundred Conquerors’ Sons.

(4) ❖ These qualities are attained by the Wise One abiding on Very Joyful,

And in just the same way they are perfectly attained in thousands

By the abider on Stainless.

On the next five grounds, the Bodhisattva attains

(5) A hundred thousand of these, a hundred ten million, a thousand ten million,

Then a hundred, thousand ten million

And then ten million a hundred thousand million multiplied by a hundred and further multiplied by a thousand.

(6) ❖ Abiding on the ground, Immovable, free from conceptions,

He attains qualities equal in number

To however many atoms there are

In a hundred thousand of the three thousand worlds.

(7) The Bodhisattva abiding on the ground Good Intelligence

Attains the previously mentioned qualities

Equal in number to the atoms in a hundred thousand countless

Perfectly increased by ten.

(8) Briefly, the qualities of the tenth

Have passed beyond what can be expressed in words,

There being as many as there are atoms

In all the inexpressibles.

(9) Moment by moment he can display in his pores

Perfect Buddhas beyond number

Together with Bodhisattvas

And likewise gods, demi-gods and humans.

(10) ❖ Just as the moon in a stainless sky illuminates clearly,

Previously you strove again for the ground that generates the ten forces.

In Akanishta you accomplished the aim for which you strove –

All those unequalled, ultimate good qualities of the supreme state of pacification.

(11) Just as space has no divisions due to the divisions of vessels,

So thatness has no divisions made by things.

Therefore, perfectly realizing them to be of one taste,

O Good Knower, you realize all objects of knowledge in an instant.

(12) ❖ ‘If pacification is thatness, wisdom does not engage in it;

And with no mind engaging, certainly an object-possessor of the object of knowledge is not possible.

Without knowing anything, how can it be a knower? That is a contradiction.

If there is no one who knows, how can you teach others, “It is like this”? ‘

(13) ❖ Since non-production is thatness and the mind has freedom from production,

By depending on that aspect it realizes thatness.

For example, when a mind possesses any aspect it knows that object thoroughly.

In just the same way, this knows by depending on a nominality.

(14) ❖ Through the power of his Enjoyment Body maintained by merit

And of its Emanations,

Sounds that reveal the Dharma of thatness arise from space and others.

Due to these, worldly beings can also realize thatness.

(15) Just as here a potter with great strength

Expends much energy for a long time turning the wheel,

And then, while he is not generating effort,

It turns and is seen to be a cause of a pot,

(16) So like that, is he who resides in a body with the nature of Dharma.

Without generating any effort now

He engages in deeds that are completely beyond thought

Due to the special qualities of his prayers and the virtues of beings.

(17) ❖ That pacification that comes from the burning of all the dry tinder of objects of knowledge

Is the Truth Body of the Conquerors.

At that time there is no production and no disintegration.

Since minds have ceased, it is experienced directly by the body.

(18) ❖ This pacified body is resplendent like a wish-granting tree

And without conception like a wish-fulfilling jewel.

It will remain always until living beings are liberated for the fortune of the world,

And appear to those who are free from elaboration.

(19) ❖ The Powerful Able One, at one time, in one Form Body

Corresponding to that cause, clearly and without disorder

Makes a complete and exquisite display

Of everything that happened during his previous lives, now ceased.

(20) What the Buddha Lands and their Powerful Able Ones were like,

What their bodies, deeds and powers were like,

How many assemblies of Hearers there were and what they were like,

What forms the Bodhisattvas took there,

(21) What the Dharma was like and what he was like then,

What deeds were performed from listening to Dharma,

How much giving was practised towards them –

All these he displays in one body.

(22) Likewise what moral discipline, patience, effort, concentration and wisdom

He practised during previous lives

He displays clearly all these deeds without leaving anything out

In just one pore of his body.

(23) ❖ Buddhas who have passed away, those who are yet to come

And those of the present dwelling in the world

Revealing Dharma in a loud voice carrying to the ends of space

And bestowing breath on living beings tormented by suffering –

(24) All their deeds from first generating the mind

Through to the essence of enlightenment,

Knowing these things to be the nature of illusions

He displays them all clearly at one time in one pore.

(25) Likewise the deeds of all Superior Bodhisattvas,

Solitary Realizers and Hearers of the three times

And all the activities of the remaining beings –

He displays all of these at one time in one pore.

(26) ❖ This Pure One, by enacting his wishes,

Displays the worlds throughout space on a single atom

And an atom filling the directions of infinite worlds

Without the atom becoming larger or the worlds becoming smaller.

(27) Not being governed by conceptuality, you will show in each instant

Until the end of samsara

As many countless different deeds

As there are atoms in all the worlds.

(28) ❖ The force knowing source and non-source,

Likewise knowing full ripening of actions,

Understanding the various desires,

And the force knowing the various elements,

(29) Likewise knowing supreme and non-supreme powers,

Going everywhere,

And the force knowing the mental stabilizations,

[Concentrations of] perfect liberation, concentrations, absorptions and so forth,

(30) Knowing recollections of previous places,

Likewise knowing death and birth,

And the force knowing the cessation of contaminations –

These are the ten forces.

(31) ❖ Any cause from which something is definitely produced

Is said by the Omniscient Ones to be the source of that.

The opposite of what is explained is not a source.

The knower of infinite objects of knowledge that has abandoned obstructions is said to be a force.

(32) The desirable, the undesirable, the reverse of these, actions of abandonment

And their full ripening – a great variety –

The powerful, able, unobstructed knower engaging individually

That encompasses objects of knowledge of the three times is said to be a force.

(33) Desires arising through the force of attachment and so forth –

A great variety of inferior, middling and especially superior desires –

The knower of these and others besides them,

Encompassing all living beings of the three times, is known as a ‘force’.

(34) Through their skill in perfectly distinguishing the elements

Buddhas say that whatever is the nature of eyes and so forth is an element.

The limitless knower of complete Buddhas

Realizing the distinctions of all types of element is said to be a force.

(35) Of conceptualization and so forth only the very sharp are accepted as supreme,

Middling types and the dull being explained as non-supreme.

The knower of all aspects free from attachment

That understands the eyes and so forth and their ability to support each other is said to be a force.

(36) Some paths lead to the very state of a Conqueror,

Some to the enlightenment of a Solitary Realizer or the enlightenment of a Hearer,

Others to hungry ghosts, animals, hell beings, gods, humans and so forth;

The knower of these that is free from attachment is said to be the force going everywhere.

(37) The different types of Yogi throughout limitless worlds

Have the mental stabilizations, the eight [concentrations of] perfect liberation,

Those that are tranquil abidings and the nine that are absorptions;

The unobstructed knower of these is said to be a force.

(38) For as long as there is confusion there is abiding in samsara.

Oneself and each and every living being of samsara now past,

However many there are, a limitless number, their origins and places of birth –

The knower of these is said to be a force.

(39) The many varieties of death and birth of every single living being

Inhabiting the worlds as extensive as space –

The limitless knower without attachment and completely pure

That apprehends all aspects of these at one time is said to be a force.

(40) The Conquerors’ swift destruction of delusions together with their imprints

Through the force of the knower of all aspects,

And the cessation of delusions by wisdom in the disciples and so forth –

The limitless knower of these that is free from attachment is said to be a force.

(41) ❖ Just as a bird does not turn back due to lack of space

But returns when its strength is consumed,

So the disciples and Sons of the Buddhas

Turn back when describing the good qualities of Buddha, which are as limitless as space.

(42) So how could one such as I

Understand or explain your good qualities?

However, since they were explained by Superior Nagarjuna

I have overcome my apprehension and mentioned just a few.

(43) ❖ The profound is emptiness,

And the vast are the other good qualities.

Through understanding the ways of the profound and the vast

These good qualities will be attained.

(44) ❖ You who possess an immovable Body visit the three worlds again with your Emanations

And show descent, birth, enlightenment and the wheel of peace.

In this way, out of compassion, you lead to a state beyond sorrow

All worldly beings who have deceitful behaviour and who are bound by the many nooses of attachment.

(45) ❖ Because, here, apart from understanding thatness, there is no principal eliminator of all stains,

Because phenomena do not depend on different types of thatness

And because there are not different wisdoms that are the object-possessors of thatness

You revealed to living beings an unequalled and undivided vehicle.

(46) Because there are these impurities that give rise to faults in living beings

The worldly cannot engage in the extremely profound object experienced by Buddhas.

Therefore O Sugata, since you possess both wisdom and the methods of compassion,

And since you have promised, ‘I will liberate living beings’,

(47) Just like the skilful one travelling to a jewel island

Who relieved the fatigue of his company by emanating a beautiful city on the way,

You presented this vehicle to the minds of disciples as a means of peace;

But you taught separately those who have attained isolation and trained minds.

(48) ❖ O Sugata, however many atoms there are among the tiniest atoms

In all the Buddha Lands in all directions,

For that many aeons you enter into the most supreme, holy enlightenment;

But these secrets of yours should not be explained.

(49) ❖ O Conqueror, for as long as all worldly beings have not gone to the most sublime peace

And for as long as space has not been destroyed,

You who are born from the mother of wisdom and nourished by compassion will perform your deeds,

So how could you have a solitary peace?

(50) The distress of a mother for her child pained by eating poison

Does not compare to your mercy for your family,

The worldly beings who through the faults of confusion eat poisonous food.

Therefore, O Protector, you will never go to the most sublime peace.

(51) Because the unskilled who have minds conceiving things and non-things

Experience suffering at the time of birth and death and when separated from the pleasant and meeting the unpleasant,

And because the evil experience rebirths, these worldly beings are objects of compassion.

Therefore, O Blessed One, out of compassion you have turned your mind away from peace and do not possess a nirvana.

(52) ❖ This system has been extracted from the treatises on the middle way

By the monk Chandrakirti

And has been presented exactly according to

The scriptures and the oral teachings.

(53) A Dharma such as this is not found elsewhere.

Likewise the system presented here

Is not found elsewhere.

The wise should understand this clearly.

(54) Frightened by the colour of the great ocean of Nagarjuna’s wisdom,

Some beings have kept this excellent system at a great distance.

Now, due to the nectar from the opening of the kumuta, which came from the unfolding of these verses,

The hopes of Chandrakirti have been completely fulfilled.

(55) This profound and frightening thatness just explained will be realized by those with previous familiarity,

But it will not be comprehended by others, even though they may have listened extensively.

Therefore, having seen these other systems made up by one’s own mind,

You should abandon the mind that likes their treatises as you would systems that assert a self.

(56) ❖ Through the merit encompassing all directions that I have received from explaining the excellent system of Master Nagarjuna,

That is as white as autumn stars in the sky of my mind darkened by delusions,

And that is like a jewel on the hood of the snake of my mind,

May all worldly beings realize thatness and quickly attain the grounds of the Sugatas.

❖ This concludes Guide to the Middle Way, which makes clear the ways of the vast and the profound. It was composed by the Master Chandrakirti who, endowed with unassailable wisdom and compassion, sincerely practised the supreme vehicle, and who by drawing milk from a picture of a cow destroyed the conception of true existence.

❖ The translation from Sanskrit into Tibetan was made according to a Kashmiri text by the Indian Abbot Tilaka and the Tibetan translator Venerable Patsab Nyimadrak at the Ratnagupta monastery in the Kashmiri town of Anuparna during the reign of Sri Aryadeva the king of Kashmir. Later at Ramoche in Lhasa it was thoroughly revised and authenticated by the Indian Abbot Kanakavarma and the same translator by comparing it to eastern texts.

The translation from Tibetan into English was made under the guidance of Venerable Geshe Kelsang Gyatso Rinpoche at Manjushri Kadampa Meditation Centre, England, 1986.

Appendix II :  The Condensed Meaning of the Commentary

The Condensed Meaning of the Commentary

The commentary to Guide to the Middle Way has three parts:

1 Introduction

2 The actual commentary

3 Dedication

Introduction has two parts:

1 The origin of these instructions

2 The pre-eminent qualities of the author

The actual commentary has four parts:

1 The meaning of the title

2 The translators’ homage

3 The meaning of the text

4 The meaning of the conclusion

The meaning of the text has four parts:

1 The expression of worship, the means for engaging in the composition of the treatise

2 The actual body of the treatise

3 How the treatise was composed

4 Dedicating the merit from composing the treatise

The expression of worship, the means for engaging in the composition of the treatise, has two parts:

1 Praising great compassion without distinguishing its types

2 A homage to great compassion distinguishing its types

Praising great compassion without distinguishing its types has two parts:

1 Showing great compassion to be the principal cause of a Bodhisattva

2 Showing great compassion to be the root of the other two causes of a Bodhisattva

Showing great compassion to be the principal cause of a Bodhisattva has three parts:

1 How Hearers and Solitary Realizers are born from Buddhas

2 How Buddhas are born from Bodhisattvas

3 The three principal causes of a Bodhisattva

A homage to great compassion distinguishing its types has two parts:

1 A homage to compassion observing mere living beings

2 A homage to compassion observing phenomena and the unobservable

A homage to compassion observing mere living beings has four parts:

1 What causes living beings to wander in samsara

2 How living beings wander in samsara

3 How living beings experience suffering in samsara

4 Generating compassion by contemplating these points

The actual body of the treatise has two parts:

1 A presentation of causal grounds

2 A presentation of resultant grounds

A presentation of causal grounds has two parts:

1 A presentation of the individual grounds

2 The good qualities of the ten grounds

A presentation of the individual grounds has ten parts:

1 The first ground, Very Joyful

2 The second ground, Stainless

3 The third ground, Luminous

4 The fourth ground, Radiant

5 The fifth ground, Difficult to Overcome

6 The sixth ground, Approaching

7 The seventh ground, Gone Afar

8 The eighth ground, Immovable

9 The ninth ground, Good Intelligence

10 The tenth ground, Cloud of Dharma

The first ground, Very Joyful, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the first ground

2 Explanation of the first ground

Introduction to the first ground has four parts:

1 How the first ground is attained

2 Definition of the first ground

3 Divisions of the first ground

4 Etymology of the first ground

Divisions of the first ground has two parts:

1 The path of seeing

2 The path of meditation of the first ground

The path of seeing has three parts:

1 The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the path of seeing

2 The exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the path of seeing

3 The exalted awareness of the path of seeing that is neither of the two

The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the path of seeing has three parts:

1 The uninterrupted path of the path of seeing

2 The released path of the first ground

3 The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the path of seeing that is neither of the two

Explanation of the first ground has three parts:

1 Briefly showing the entity of the ground, the basis of characteristics

2 An extensive explanation of the good qualities that characterize the ground

3 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

An extensive explanation of the good qualities that characterize the ground has three parts:

1 The good qualities that beautify one’s own continuum

2 The good qualities that outshine others’ continuums

3 The surpassing good quality of the first ground

The good qualities that beautify one’s own continuum has two parts:

1 Enumerating the good qualities

2 Showing the good qualities in brief

Enumerating the good qualities has eight parts:

1 The good quality of attaining a meaningful name

2 The good quality of birth into Buddha’s family

3 The good quality of abandoning the three bonds

4 The good quality of abiding in great joy

5 The good quality of being able to cause a hundred worlds to shake

6 The good quality of mastering higher grounds

7 The good quality of destroying the causes of lower rebirth

8 The good quality of exhausting the grounds of ordinary beings

The good qualities that outshine others’ continuums has three parts:

1 Outshining Hearers and Solitary Realizers by way of lineage on this ground

2 Outshining Hearers and Solitary Realizers by way of wisdom on the seventh ground

3 An explanation of the meaning established by this teaching

An explanation of the meaning established by this teaching has three parts:

1 The teaching of Sutra on the Ten Grounds that Hearers and Solitary Realizers have the realization of the lack of inherent existence of all phenomena

2 The sources that prove this

3 Rejecting arguments against this teaching

The sources that prove this has two parts:

1 Mahayana Sutras that prove this

2 Treatises and Hinayana Sutras that prove this

The surpassing good quality of the first ground has four parts:

1 An explanation of the giving of one who abides on the first ground

2 An explanation of the giving of lower bases

3 An explanation of Bodhisattvas’ giving

4 The divisions of the perfection of giving

An explanation of the giving of lower bases has two parts:

1 Attaining samsaric happiness through giving

2 Attaining the happiness of nirvana through giving

An explanation of Bodhisattvas’ giving has four parts:

1 The uncommon benefits of Bodhisattvas’ giving

2 The instructions on giving are fundamental for both bases

3 The great joy a Bodhisattva obtains from giving

4 Whether a Bodhisattva experiences pain when giving away his body

The divisions of the perfection of giving has two parts:

1 The mundane perfection of giving

2 The supramundane perfection of giving

The second ground, Stainless, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the second ground

2 Explanation of the second ground

Introduction to the second ground has four parts:

1 How the second ground is attained

2 Definition of the second ground

3 Divisions of the second ground

4 Etymology of the second ground

Divisions of the second ground has three parts:

1 The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the second ground

2 The exalted awareness of subsequent attainment of the second ground

3 The exalted awareness of the second ground that is neither of the two

The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the second ground has three parts:

1 The released path of the second ground

2 The uninterrupted path of the second ground

3 The exalted awareness of meditative equipoise of the second ground that is neither of the two

Explanation of the second ground has five parts:

1 The completely pure moral discipline on this ground

2 A praise of moral discipline

3 An illustration of separation from that which is incompatible with moral discipline

4 The divisions of the perfection of moral discipline

5 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

The completely pure moral discipline on this ground has four parts:

1 The excellent moral discipline on this ground

2 The completely pure qualities that depend on this

3 This moral discipline surpasses that of the first ground

4 Another cause of completely pure moral discipline

A praise of moral discipline has five parts:

1 Enjoying the fruits of giving in fortunate realms depends on moral discipline

2 Enjoying the fruits of giving continuously depends on moral discipline

3 It is extremely difficult for those who lack moral discipline to escape from the lower realms

4 Why the instructions on moral discipline were given after the instructions on giving

5 Praising moral discipline as a cause of both high status and definite goodness

The divisions of the perfection of moral discipline has two parts:

1 The mundane perfection of moral discipline

2 The supramundane perfection of moral discipline

The third ground, Luminous, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the third ground

2 Explanation of the third ground

Introduction to the third ground has three parts:

1 How the third ground is attained

2 Definition of the third ground

3 Divisions of the third ground

Explanation of the third ground has four parts:

1 The etymology of the ground, the basis of characteristics

2 The good qualities that characterize this ground

3 The characteristics of the first three perfections

4 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

The good qualities that characterize this ground has four parts:

1 The surpassing patience on this ground

2 The way to rely on other patience

3 The divisions of the perfection of patience

4 The other pure qualities that arise on this ground

The way to rely on other patience has two parts:

1 The unsuitability of getting angry

2 The suitability of relying on patience

The unsuitability of getting angry has four parts:

1 Anger is unsuitable because it is unnecessary and very faulty

2 Not wishing future suffering and retaliating harmfully are contradictory

3 Anger is unsuitable because it destroys virtues previously accumulated over a long time

4 Stopping anger having contemplated the many faults of impatience

The suitability of relying on patience has two parts:

1 Contemplating the many benefits of patience

2 In summary, an exhortation to rely on patience

The divisions of the perfection of patience has two parts:

1 The mundane perfection of patience

2 The supramundane perfection of patience

The fourth ground, Radiant, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the fourth ground

2 Explanation of the fourth ground

Introduction to the fourth ground has three parts:

1 How the fourth ground is attained

2 Definition of the fourth ground

3 Divisions of the fourth ground

Explanation of the fourth ground has three parts:

1 The surpassing effort on this ground

2 The etymology of this ground

3 The characteristics of abandonment

The fifth ground, Difficult to Overcome, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the fifth ground

2 Explanation of the fifth ground

Introduction to the fifth ground has three parts:

1 How the fifth ground is attained

2 Definition of the fifth ground

3 Divisions of the fifth ground

Explanation of the fifth ground has two parts:

1 The etymology of the fifth ground

2 The surpassing mental stabilization and skill in the truths

The sixth ground, Approaching, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the sixth ground

2 Explanation of the sixth ground

Introduction to the sixth ground has three parts:

1 How the sixth ground is attained

2 Definition of the sixth ground

3 Divisions of the sixth ground

Explanation of the sixth ground has four parts:

1 The etymology of this ground and the surpassing perfection of wisdom

2 A praise of the perfection of wisdom

3 An explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising

4 Conclusion by way of expressing the good qualities of the ground

An explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising has five parts:

1 A promise to explain the profound meaning

2 Recognizing a suitable recipient for an explanation of the profound meaning

3 How good qualities arise when it is explained to such a person

4 Exhorting those who are suitable recipients to listen

5 The actual explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising

The actual explanation of the profound thatness of dependent arising has four parts:

1 How the correct meaning is revealed in the scriptures

2 Identifying the object of negation

3 Establishing the meaning of the scriptures by reasoning

4 An explanation of the divisions of emptiness

Identifying the object of negation has two parts:

1 Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school

2 Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school

Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Svatantrika school has three parts:

1 Identifying true existence and true-grasping

2 Explaining true and false with reference to worldly people by means of an analogy

3 Applying this analogy to the meaning

Identifying the object of negation according to the Madhyamika-Prasangika school has three parts:

1 Understanding mere imputation by means of scriptures

2 Understanding mere imputation by means of analogies

3 Understanding mere imputation by means of reasoning

Establishing the meaning of the scriptures by reasoning has two parts:

1 Establishing selflessness of phenomena by reasoning

2 Establishing selflessness of persons by reasoning

Establishing selflessness of phenomena by reasoning has four parts:

1 Refuting the four extremes of production within both truths

2 Rejecting arguments against this refutation

3 How dependently-arising production eliminates wrong conceptions that grasp at extremes

4 Identifying the result of logical analysis

Refuting the four extremes of production within both truths has three parts:

1 There is no inherently existent production

2 Proving this by reasoning

3 The meaning established by the refutation of the four extremes of production

Proving this by reasoning has four parts:

1 Refuting production from self

2 Refuting production from other

3 Refuting production from both

4 Refuting production without a cause

Refuting production from self has two parts:

1 Refuting production from self with the reasoning from Chandrakirti’s commentary

2 Refuting production from self with the reasoning from Fundamental Wisdom

Refuting production from self with the reasoning from Chandrakirti’s commentary has three parts:

1 Refuting the system of the Samkhya school

2 Even worldly people whose minds are not affected by tenets do not assert production from self

3 Conclusion from these refutations

Refuting the system of the Samkhya school has two parts:

1 Refuting production from a cause that is the same entity

2 Refuting that cause and effect are the same entity

Refuting production from a cause that is the same entity has three parts:

1 It follows that production from a cause that is the same entity is pointless

2 That things are produced from the same nature is contrary to reasoning

3 Refuting a denial of these faults

Refuting that cause and effect are the same entity has three parts:

1 It follows that the shape and so forth of the sprout are not different from those of the seed

2 Refuting a denial of this fault

3 It follows that both the seed and the sprout are similar in being either apprehendable or unapprehendable at any one time

Refuting production from other has two parts:

1 A description of the position asserting production from other

2 Refuting this system

Refuting this system has two parts:

1 A general refutation of production from other

2 A refutation of the Chittamatra system in particular

A general refutation of production from other has five parts:

1 The actual refutation of production from other

2 Denying that worldly people can damage this refutation

3 The good qualities of this refutation

4 There is no inherently existent production at any time

5 The good qualities of refuting inherently existent production within both truths

The actual refutation of production from other has three parts:

1 Refuting production from other in general

2 Refuting particular production from other

3 Refuting production from other having analyzed effects by way of four alternatives

Refuting production from other in general has two parts:

1 Refuting by means of the consequence of excess

2 Refuting a denial of this fault

Refuting a denial of this fault has two parts:

1 The denial of the fault

2 Refuting this denial

Refuting particular production from other has two parts:

1 Refuting production from other where a cause precedes its effect

2 Refuting production from other where a cause is simultaneous with its effect

Refuting production from other where a cause precedes its effect has two parts:

1 The actual refutation

2 Rejecting arguments against this refutation

Denying that worldly people can damage this refutation has two parts:

1 Denying damage by worldly people’s belief in production from other

2 Denying damage by worldly people because there is no production from other for the worldly, even nominally

Denying damage by worldly people’s belief in production from other has two parts:

1 The argument that there is damage by worldly people

2 Showing that there is no damage by worldly people

Showing that there is no damage by worldly people has five parts:

1 A general presentation of the two truths

2 Applying this to the present subject

3 An explanation of the respective natures of the two truths

4 How the charge of damage by worldly people is itself damaged

5 How there can be damage by worldly people

A general presentation of the two truths has three parts:

1 All phenomena have two natures

2 The divisions of conventional truths with respect to the awareness of worldly people

3 Mistaken conceived objects do not exist even nominally

The divisions of conventional truths with respect to the awareness of worldly people has two parts:

1 An explanation of correct and incorrect object-possessors with respect to the awareness of worldly people

2 An explanation of correct and incorrect objects with respect to the awareness of worldly people

An explanation of the respective natures of the two truths has two parts:

1 An explanation of conventional truths

2 An explanation of ultimate truth

There is no inherently existent production at any time has two parts:

1 Refuting the assertion of inherent existence

2 Rejecting an argument against this refutation

Refuting the assertion of inherent existence has three parts:

1 It follows that a Superior being’s meditative equipoise causes the destruction of things

2 It follows that nominal truths can withstand analysis

3 It follows that ultimate production is irrefutable

The good qualities of refuting inherently existent production within both truths has two parts:

1 The good quality of easily avoiding extreme views

2 The good quality of great consistency with cause and effect

The good quality of great consistency with cause and effect has three parts:

1 Not asserting inherent existence does not entail acceptance of a consciousness-basis-of-all and so forth

2 Showing by analogy how an effect arises after an action has ceased

3 Rejecting arguments against this

Rejecting arguments against this has two parts:

1 Rejecting the argument that the ripening of the effect would be endless

2 Rejecting the argument of contradiction with the scriptures that reveal a consciousness-basis-of-all

Rejecting the argument of contradiction with the scriptures that reveal a consciousness-basis-of-all has two parts:

1 The actual rejection of the argument of contradiction with the scriptures

2 An analogy of speech through the power of intention

A refutation of the Chittamatra system in particular has three parts:

1 Refuting an inherently existent consciousness without externals

2 Refuting the validity of the reason establishing other-powered phenomena as inherently existent

3 The word ‘only’ in ‘mind only’ does not exclude external objects

Refuting an inherently existent consciousness without externals has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

Refuting this system has two parts:

1 An extensive presentation of the refutation

2 The conclusion from this refutation

An extensive presentation of the refutation has three parts:

1 Refuting examples of a truly existent consciousness without external objects

2 Refuting a consciousness generated from its potential

3 This refutation and meditation on unattractiveness are not contradictory

Refuting examples of a truly existent consciousness without external objects has two parts:

1 Refuting the example of a dream

2 Refuting the example of seeing floating hairs

Refuting the example of a dream has three parts:

1 The example of a dream does not prove that consciousness is truly existent

2 The example of a dream does not prove that there are no external objects when awake

3 The example of a dream proves that all things are false

Refuting a consciousness generated from its potential has three parts:

1 Refuting that a consciousness to which an external object appears is generated or not generated from the ripening or non-ripening of imprints

2 Again refuting that consciousness exists without external objects

3 The refutation of the Chittamatra system is not damaged by the scriptures

Refuting that a consciousness to which an external object appears is generated or not generated from the ripening or non-ripening of imprints has two parts:

1 Stating the other position

2 Refuting this position

Refuting this position has three parts:

1 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the present

2 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the future

3 Refuting an inherently existent potential with respect to the past

Again refuting that consciousness exists without external objects has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

Refuting the validity of the reason establishing other-powered phenomena as inherently existent has four parts:

1 Refuting self-cognizers as a proof of other-powered phenomena

2 The Chittamatra system is deficient in both truths

3 Therefore it is advisable to follow only the system of Nagarjuna

4 Refuting other-powered phenomena is not the same as refuting worldly nominalities

Refuting self-cognizers as a proof of other-powered phenomena has four parts:

1 On investigation self-cognizers are unacceptable as a proof of other-powered phenomena

2 Refuting the other’s reply that they are acceptable

3 Self-cognizers are unacceptable by other reasoning too

4 An inherently existent other-powered phenomenon is similar to a child of a childless woman

Refuting the other’s reply that they are acceptable has two parts:

1 The actual refutation of the other system

2 How, according to our system, memory develops even though self-cognizers do not exist

The word ‘only’ in ‘mind only’ does not exclude external objects has three parts:

1 Explaining the intention of the statement in Sutra on the Ten Grounds that says that there is only mind

2 External objects and internal mind are the same in either being existent or being non-existent

3 Explaining the intention of the statement in Gone to Lanka Sutra that says that there is only mind

Explaining the intention of the statement in Sutra on the Ten Grounds that says that there is only mind has three parts:

1 The Sutra on the Ten Grounds proves that the word ‘only’ does not exclude external objects

2 This meaning is also established in other Sutras

3 The word ‘only’ establishes that mind is principal

Explaining the intention of the statement in Gone to Lanka Sutra that says that there is only mind has two parts:

1 The statement that there are no external objects but only mind is of interpretative meaning

2 A method for recognizing Sutras of interpretative and definitive meaning

The statement that there are no external objects but only mind is of interpretative meaning has two parts:

1 Showing by means of the scriptures that it is of interpretative meaning

2 Showing by means of reasoning that it is of interpretative meaning

Showing by means of the scriptures that it is of interpretative meaning has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Other Sutras like this are also of interpretative meaning

Rejecting arguments against this refutation has two parts:

1 The actual rejection of arguments

2 A summary

Establishing selflessness of persons by reasoning has three parts:

1 Those who desire liberation must first negate inherently existent self

2 The way to negate inherently existent self and mine

3 The analysis of the self and the cart also applies to other things

The way to negate inherently existent self and mine has two parts:

1 Negating inherently existent self

2 Negating inherently existent mine

Negating inherently existent self has six parts:

1 Negating a self that is a different entity from the aggregates as fabricated by other traditions

2 Refuting the assertion fabricated within our own tradition that the aggregates are the self

3 Refuting the three positions of dependent, basis and possession that remain after these two

4 Negating a substantially existent self that is neither identical nor different

5 Explaining with an analogy how the self is merely a dependent imputation

6 This presentation has the good quality of allowing us easily to abandon conceptions grasping at extremes

Negating a self that is a different entity from the aggregates as fabricated by other traditions has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

Stating the other system has two parts:

1 Stating the system of the Samkhyas

2 Stating the system of the Vaisheshikas and others

Refuting the assertion fabricated within our own tradition that the aggregates are the self has five parts:

1 Showing contradictions in the assertion that the aggregates are the self

2 Proving that assertion to be untenable

3 Showing other contradictions in the assertion that the aggregates are the self

4 Explaining the intention of the statement that the aggregates are the self

5 Showing that the other system is incoherent

Showing contradictions in the assertion that the aggregates are the self has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Refuting a denial of the fault

The actual meaning has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

Explaining the intention of the statement that the aggregates are the self has five parts:

1 Explaining the meaning of the statement that whatever is seen as the self is seen only in the aggregates

2 Explaining in dependence on other Sutras that the mere collection of the aggregates is not the self

3 Refuting that the shape of the arrangement of the mere collection of the aggregates is the self

4 Showing another contradiction in the assertion that the self is the mere collection of the aggregates

5 Buddha says that the self is imputed on the six elements and so forth

Explaining the meaning of the statement that whatever is seen as the self is seen only in the aggregates has three parts:

1 This teaching is given only from the standpoint of refutation

2 Even if it were given from the standpoint of establishment it still would not reveal that the aggregates are the self

3 Rejecting an argument against this

Refuting the three positions of dependent, basis and possession that remain after these two has two parts:

1 Refuting the positions of dependent, basis and possession

2 A summary of the refutations

Negating a substantially existent self that is neither identical nor different has two parts:

1 Stating the other system

2 Refuting this system

Explaining with an analogy how the self is merely a dependent imputation has four parts:

1 Even though the self does not exist in the seven extremes it is a dependent imputation like a cart

2 An extensive explanation of the two positions not previously explained

3 Rejecting an argument against this explanation

4 Showing that the nominal meaning of other names is also established

An extensive explanation of the two positions not previously explained has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Transferring this reason to others

The actual meaning has two parts:

1 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the mere collection of its parts

2 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the mere shape of its parts

Refuting the assertion that a cart is the mere shape of its parts has two parts:

1 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the shape of its individual parts

2 Refuting the assertion that a cart is the shape of the collection of its parts

This presentation has the good quality of allowing us easily to abandon conceptions grasping at extremes has five parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Rejecting an argument against this

3 Applying the analogy of the cart to the meaning of the nominal self

4 Showing other good qualities of asserting a self that is dependently imputed

5 Recognizing the self that is the basis both of the bondage of delusion and of liberation

The analysis of the self and the cart also applies to other things has three parts:

1 Applying it to things such as pots and woollen cloth

2 Applying it to cause and effect

3 Rejecting an argument against this

Rejecting an argument against this has two parts:

1 The argument that the refutation of inherently existent cause and effect has similar faults

2 Replying that it does not have similar faults

Replying that it does not have similar faults has four parts:

1 How refutation and proof are accepted within our position

2 An explanation clarifying the reason why the others’ consequence is not similar

3 Lack of inherent existence can be established but others cannot establish its opposite in the same way

4 How to understand the remaining refutations not explained here

How refutation and proof are accepted within our position has two parts:

1 How refutation of others’ positions is accepted nominally

2 How proofs within our own position are accepted

An explanation of the divisions of emptiness has two parts:

1 The divisions of emptiness in brief

2 An extensive explanation of the meaning of each division

An extensive explanation of the meaning of each division has two parts:

1 An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into sixteen

2 An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into four

An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into sixteen has four parts:

1 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the inner and so forth

2 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the great and so forth

3 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of beyond extremes and so forth

4 An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of all phenomena and so forth

An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the inner and so forth has four parts:

1 The emptiness of the inner

2 The emptiness of the outer

3 The emptiness of the inner and outer

4 The emptiness of emptiness

An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of the great and so forth has four parts:

1 The emptiness of the great

2 The emptiness of the ultimate

3 The emptiness of the produced

4 The emptiness of the unproduced

An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of beyond extremes and so forth has four parts:

1 The emptiness of beyond extremes

2 The emptiness of the beginningless and endless

3 The emptiness of the not rejected

4 The emptiness of nature

An explanation of the four emptinesses, the emptiness of all phenomena and so forth has four parts:

1 The emptiness of all phenomena

2 The emptiness of definitions

3 The emptiness of the unobservable

4 The emptiness of no thing

The emptiness of definitions has three parts:

1 A brief explanation

2 An extensive explanation

3 A summary

An extensive explanation has three parts:

1 The definitions of the phenomena of the base

2 The definitions of the phenomena of the path

3 The definitions of the phenomena of the result

An extensive explanation of the division of emptiness into four has four parts:

1 The emptiness of things

2 The emptiness of non-things

3 The emptiness of nature

4 The emptiness of other entities

The seventh ground, Gone Afar, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the seventh ground

2 The good qualities of the seventh ground

Introduction to the seventh ground has four parts:

1 How the seventh ground is attained

2 Definition of the seventh ground

3 Divisions of the seventh ground

4 Etymology of the seventh ground

The eighth ground, Immovable, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the eighth ground

2 The good qualities of the eighth ground

Introduction to the eighth ground has four parts:

1 How the eighth ground is attained

2 Definition of the eighth ground

3 Divisions of the eighth ground

4 Etymology of the eighth ground

The good qualities of the eighth ground has three parts:

1 The surpassing prayers on this ground and how he is raised from cessation

2 Showing that he has extinguished all delusions

3 Showing that he has attained the ten powers

The ninth ground, Good Intelligence, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the ninth ground

2 The good qualities of the ninth ground

Introduction to the ninth ground has four parts:

1 How the ninth ground is attained

2 Definition of the ninth ground

3 Divisions of the ninth ground

4 Etymology of the ninth ground

The tenth ground, Cloud of Dharma, has two parts:

1 Introduction to the tenth ground

2 The good qualities of the tenth ground

Introduction to the tenth ground has four parts:

1 How the tenth ground is attained

2 Definition of the tenth ground

3 Divisions of the tenth ground

4 Etymology of the tenth ground

The good qualities of the ten grounds has three parts:

1 The good qualities of the first ground

2 The good qualities of the second to the seventh grounds

3 The good qualities of the three pure grounds

A presentation of resultant grounds has five parts:

1 How Buddhahood is first attained

2 A presentation of Buddha’s bodies and good qualities

3 Explaining Emanation Bodies

4 Proving that there is one final vehicle

5 Explaining the duration of enlightenment and remaining

How Buddhahood is first attained has two parts:

1 The actual meaning

2 Rejecting an argument

Rejecting an argument has two parts:

1 Stating the other position

2 Refuting this position

Refuting this position has two parts:

1 Rejecting the argument that a knower of thatness is unacceptable

2 Rejecting the argument that a person knowing thatness is unacceptable

A presentation of Buddha’s bodies and good qualities has two parts:

1 A presentation of Buddha’s bodies

2 A presentation of the good qualities of the forces

A presentation of Buddha’s bodies has three parts:

1 An explanation of the Truth Body

2 An explanation of the Enjoyment Body

3 An explanation of the Body corresponding to its cause

An explanation of the Body corresponding to its cause has three parts:

1 How he displays all his deeds in one pore of his body

2 How he displays all the deeds of others there

3 An explanation of his completely excellent mastery of his wishes

A presentation of the good qualities of the forces has four parts:

1 Briefly presenting the ten forces

2 An extensive explanation

3 Why all the qualities cannot be described

4 The benefits of understanding the two good qualities

Explaining the duration of enlightenment and remaining has two parts:

1 The duration of enlightenment

2 The duration of remaining

The meaning of the conclusion has two parts:

1 The Master who composed the treatise

2 The Pandits and translators who translated it

Appendix III: A Brief Summary of Buddhist Tenets

From Presentation of Tenets

by Sera Jetsunpa Chokyi Gyaltsen

A Brief Summary of Buddhist Tenets

The explanation of Buddhist tenets has two parts:

1 Definition

2 Explanation of the different systems

DEFINITION

The definition of proponent of Buddhist tenets is a person propounding tenets who accepts the Three Jewels as perfect objects of refuge and who does not assert ultimate objects of refuge other than these.

Explanation of the different systems has four parts:

1 Explanation of the system of the Vaibhashikas

2 Explanation of the system of the Sautrantikas

3 Explanation of the system of the Chittamatrins

4 Explanation of the system of the Madhyamikas

EXPLANATION OF THE SYSTEM OF THE VAIBHASHIKAS

This has seven parts:

1 Definition

2 Divisions

3 Etymology

4 Way of asserting objects

5 Way of asserting object-possessors

6 Way of asserting selflessness

7 Presentation of grounds and paths

DEFINITION

The definition of Vaibhashika is a person propounding Hinayana tenets who does not assert self-cognizers.

DIVISIONS

There are many divisions, but they are all included within three:

1 Kashmiris

2 Aparantakas

3 Magadhas

ETYMOLOGY

‘Vaibhashika’ means ‘Particularist’. They are so called because they propound tenets following Great Treasury Explaining Particulars and also because they propound the three times to be particular substances.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECTS

The definition of thing is able to perform a function. Thing, existent and object of knowledge are synonyms. There are two types of thing: permanent things and impermanent things. Examples of the first are non-produced space, analytical cessations and non-analytical cessations. Examples of the second are product and impermanent.

There is another twofold division of thing: conventional truths and ultimate truths. The definition of conventional truth is a phenomenon that is such that if it is destroyed or mentally separated into individual parts the mind apprehending it ceases. Examples are a vase and a woollen cloth. If a vase is smashed with a hammer the mind apprehending it ceases, and if a woollen cloth is separated into individual threads the mind apprehending it ceases.

The definition of ultimate truth is a phenomenon that is such that if it is destroyed or mentally separated into individual parts, the mind apprehending it does not cease. Examples are directionally partless particles, temporally partless awareness and unproduced phenomena.

Furthermore, the Vaibhashikas assert that the three times are particular instances of one substance because a vase exists also at the time of the past of a vase, and at the time of the future of a vase.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECT-POSSESSORS

Some Vaibhashikas assert the mere collection of the five aggregates to be the person, and some assert the mental consciousness to be the person.

There are two types of mind: valid cognizers and non-valid cognizers. There are two types of valid cognizer: direct valid cognizers and subsequent valid cognizers. There are three types of direct valid cognizer: valid sense direct perceivers, valid mental direct perceivers and valid yogic direct perceivers. Valid sense direct perceivers are not necessarily awarenesses because the eye sense power, for example, is a valid direct perceiver.

There are two types of valid yogic direct perceiver: valid yogic direct perceivers realizing selflessness of persons and valid yogic direct perceivers realizing subtle impermanence. The first has two types: valid yogic direct perceivers realizing the lack of a permanent, partless, causeless person; and valid yogic direct perceivers realizing the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person.

WAY OF ASSERTING SELFLESSNESS

The Vaibhashikas assert that selflessness and subtle selflessness of persons are synonyms. They do not assert selflessness of phenomena because they say that all objects of knowledge are pervaded by self of phenomena.

The Samittiyas assert a selflessness of persons that is a lack of a permanent, partless, causeless person; but they do not assert a selflessness of persons that is a lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person because they say that there exists a self-supporting, substantially existent self that is indescribable in terms of being the same or different nature from the aggregates, or in terms of being permanent or impermanent.

PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

This has two parts:

1 Objects to be abandoned

2 Actual presentation of grounds and paths

OBJECTS TO BE ABANDONED

They assert two types of obstruction: delusion-obstructions and non-delusion-obstructions. Delusion-obstructions function principally to obstruct the attainment of liberation and non-delusion-obstructions function principally to obstruct the attainment of an all-knowing mind. However, they do not talk of ‘obstructions to omniscience’. Examples of the first are the mind conceiving a self-supporting, substantially existent person, and the three poisons together with their seeds that arise through its power. Examples of the second are the imprints of the mind conceiving a self-supporting, substantially existent person and the mental distortion that arises through their power.

ACTUAL PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

There are differences in the way in which the persons of the three vehicles progress on the paths. Those of the Hearer lineage meditate on the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person with a small collection of merit for three lives or more and attain a small enlightenment. Those of the Solitary Realizer lineage meditate on the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person with a middling collection of merit for a hundred aeons or more and attain a middling enlightenment. Bodhisattvas meditate on the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person with a great collection of merit for three countless great aeons or more and attain a great enlightenment.

There are differences in the way in which they accumulate merit. Bodhisattvas accumulate merit for three countless great aeons on the great stage of the path of accumulation and below, and then progress from the heat stage of the path of preparation through to the Path of No More Learning in one session. Those of the Solitary Realizer lineage accumulate merit for a hundred great aeons on the great stage of the path of accumulation and below, and then progress from the heat stage of the path of preparation through to the Path of No More Learning in one session. Those of the Hearer lineage accumulate merit while on all four learning paths; and they have to train on the learning paths for anything up to fourteen lifetimes even after they have attained superior paths.

The Vaibhashikas assert that the form aggregate of a Buddha is not Buddha because it is an object to be abandoned. This is because it is included within the same life as the body of the Bodhisattva on the path of preparation, and that body is an aggregate arisen from previous karma and delusion. They do not accept an Enjoyment Body, and they assert that when the Supreme Emanation Body, Buddha, attained nirvana without remainder his mental continuum ceased. Even though Buddhas have abandoned all delusions that observe true sufferings they still have true sufferings within their mental continuum.

The Vaibhashikas assert that Hearer and Solitary Realizer Foe Destroyers possess a nirvana with remainder from the attainment of the state of Foe Destroyer until they pass away, and that when they pass away they attain a nirvana without remainder. At the time of nirvana with remainder, even though they have abandoned all delusion-obstructions, they have not abandoned non-delusion-obstructions. Their non-delusion-obstructions cease at the time of nirvana without remainder, not because they are destroyed through the force of antidotes but because at that time the mental continuum that is their basis has ceased.

Proponents of things distinguish definitive and interpretative Sutras according to whether or not they can be taken literally. The two lower schools do not accept Mahayana Sutras to be the words of Buddha. Most Vaibhashikas believe that Sutras are necessarily Sutras of definitive meaning.

EXPLANATION OF THE SYSTEM OF THE SAUTRANTIKAS

This has seven parts:

1 Definition

2 Divisions

3 Etymology

4 Way of asserting objects

5 Way of asserting object-possessors

6 Way of asserting selflessness

7 Presentation of grounds and paths

DEFINITION

The definition of Sautrantika is a person propounding Hinayana tenets who asserts self-cognizers.

DIVISIONS

There are two divisions:

1 Sautrantikas following scripture, for example Sautrantikas who rely on Vasubandhu’s Treasury of Abhidharma

2 Sautrantikas following reasoning, for example Sautrantikas who rely on Dharmakirti’s Seven Treatises of Valid Cognition

ETYMOLOGY

‘Sautrantika’ means ‘Sutra Follower’. They are so called because they propound tenets following Buddha’s Hinayana Sutras.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECTS

The definition of existent is observed by a valid cognizer. There are two types: ultimate truths and conventional truths. The definition of ultimate truth is a phenomenon that is ultimately able to perform a function. Ultimate truth, truly existent, thing, product, impermanent, compounded phenomenon, substance and specifically characterized phenomenon are synonyms. The definition of conventional truth is a phenomenon that is not ultimately able to perform a function. Conventional truth, falsely existent, permanent and generally characterized phenomenon are synonyms.

There is another twofold division of existent: negative phenomena and affirmative phenomena. The definition of negative phenomenon is an object that is realized through the mind that apprehends it eliminating an object of negation. The definition of affirmative phenomenon is an object that is realized through the mind that apprehends it not eliminating an object of negation. There are two types of negative phenomenon: non-affirming negatives and affirming negatives. Examples of the first are unproduced space, true cessations and emptiness. Examples of the second are the opposite of non-thing and the appearance of the opposite of non-vase to a mind conceiving vase.

Furthermore, past and future are permanent; present and thing are synonyms.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECT-POSSESSORS

The Sautrantikas relying on Treasury of Abhidharma assert the continuum of the aggregates to be the person and the Sautrantikas relying on Seven Treatises of Valid Cognition assert the mental consciousness to be the person.

The definition of mind is that which is clarity and cognizing. There are two types of mind: valid cognizers and non-valid cognizers. The definition of valid cognizer is a freshly, non-deceptive cognizer. It is necessary to state the three, ‘freshly’, ‘non-deceptive’ and ‘cognizer’ as borders of the definition of valid cognizer because by stating ‘freshly’ re-cognizers are excluded from being valid cognizers, by stating ‘non-deceptive’ correct beliefs are excluded from being valid cognizers, and by stating ‘cognizer’ sense powers possessing form are excluded from being valid cognizers.

There are two types of valid cognizer: direct valid cognizers and subsequent valid cognizers. The definition of direct valid cognizer is a freshly, non-deceptive cognizer that is free from conceptuality. There are four types of direct valid cognizer: valid self-cognizing direct perceivers, valid sense direct perceivers, valid mental direct perceivers and valid yogic direct perceivers.

The definition of direct perceiver is a cognizer that is free from conceptuality and non-mistaken. The definition of self-cognizing direct perceiver is that part of an apprehender that only looks inwards. The definition of sense direct perceiver is a cognizer free from conceptuality that arises in dependence on its uncommon dominant condition, a sense power possessing form. The definition of mental direct perceiver is a cognizer free from conceptuality that arises in dependence on its uncommon dominant condition, a mental power. The definition of yogic direct perceiver is a direct perceiver that realizes a subtle object directly, in dependence on its uncommon dominant condition, a concentration that is a union of tranquil abiding and superior seeing. There are three types of yogic direct perceiver: yogic direct perceivers realizing subtle impermanence, yogic direct perceivers realizing gross selflessness of persons and yogic direct perceivers realizing subtle selflessness of persons.

The definition of subsequent cognizer is a conceiving cognizer whose object is realized in dependence on a conclusive reason. There are three types: subsequent cognizers through the power of fact, subsequent cognizers through belief and subsequent cognizers through renown. A subsequent cognizer through renown is necessarily a subsequent cognizer through the power of fact.

Direct perceivers are not necessarily direct valid cognizers and subsequent cognizers are not necessarily subsequent valid cognizers because both the second moment of a sense direct perceiver apprehending form and the second moment of a subsequent cognizer realizing impermanent sound are re-cognizers.

The definition of non-valid cognizer is a cognizer that is not freshly non-deceptive. There are five types:

1 Re-cognizers

2 Correct beliefs

3 Doubts

4 Non-ascertaining perceivers

5 Wrong awarenesses

The definition of re-cognizer is a cognizer that realizes what has already been realized through the force of a previous valid cognizer. There are two types: conceptual re-cognizers and non-conceptual re-cognizers.

The definition of correct belief is a factually concordant conceiving cognizer that is deceptive in conceiving its object. There are five types: correct beliefs that do not depend on a reason, correct beliefs contradicting reason, correct beliefs with an indefinite reason, correct beliefs with an unestablished reason and correct beliefs where a reason exists without being realized.

The definition of doubt is a mental factor that wavers with respect to its object. There are three types: doubts tending towards the truth, doubts tending away from the truth and balanced doubts.

The definition of non-ascertaining perceiver is a non-mistaken cognizer to which a phenomenon that is its engaged object appears clearly without being ascertained. There are three types: non-ascertaining sense direct perceivers, non-ascertaining mental direct perceivers and non-ascertaining self-cognizing direct perceivers.

The definition of wrong awareness is a cognizer that is mistaken with respect to its engaged object. There are two types: conceptual wrong awarenesses and non-conceptual wrong awarenesses.

WAY OF ASSERTING SELFLESSNESS

They assert the lack of a permanent, partless, causeless person to be gross selflessness of persons; and the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person to be subtle selflessness of persons. Like the Vaibhashikas they do not accept selflessness of phenomena.

PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

Members of all three lineages accumulate merit while on the four learning paths, therefore Buddha’s form aggregate is Buddha.

Their way of presenting obstructions, the way to progress through the grounds and paths and so forth, is similar to that of the Vaibhashikas.

EXPLANATION OF THE SYSTEM OF THE CHITTAMATRINS

This has seven parts:

1 Definition

2 Divisions

3 Etymology

4 Way of asserting objects

5 Way of asserting object-possessors

6 Way of asserting selflessness

7 Presentation of grounds and paths

DEFINITION

The definition of Chittamatrin is a person propounding Mahayana tenets who does not assert external objects and who asserts self-cognizers to be truly existent.

DIVISIONS

There are two divisions:

1 True Aspectarian Chittamatrins

2 False Aspectarian Chittamatrins

The True Aspectarians assert that although the five objects, form and so forth, are not external objects, they are gross objects. The False Aspectarians assert that they are not gross objects because if they were they would be external objects.

ETYMOLOGY

‘Chittamatrin’ means ‘Proponent of Mind Only’. They are so called because they assert that all phenomena are merely the nature of mind. Thus they assert that the five objects, form and so forth, are generated from the substance of inner consciousness in dependence on imprints of common and uncommon actions placed on the consciousness-basis-of-all, and so they are not external objects.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECTS

There are two types of object of knowledge: ultimate truths and conventional truths. The definition of ultimate truth is an object realized by a valid cognizer that realizes it directly by means of dualistic appearance subsiding. Ultimate truth, nature of reality, sphere of phenomena and final condition are synonyms. There are two types of ultimate truth: subtle selflessness of phenomena and subtle selflessness of persons.

There are twenty types of subtle selflessness of phenomena by way of bases of emptiness. When these are condensed there are eighteen. When these are condensed there are sixteen. When these are condensed there are four emptinesses and so on.

Examples of subtle selflessness of phenomena are the emptiness that is a form and a form-apprehending valid cognizer’s lack of being other substances, and the emptiness that is a form’s lack of existing by way of its own characteristics as a basis for applying the name ‘form’. An example of subtle selflessness of persons is the emptiness that is the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person.

The definition of conventional truth is an object realized by a valid cognizer that realizes it directly with dualistic appearance. There are two types: other-powered phenomena and uncompounded phenomena other than ultimate truths.

They refer to impermanent phenomena as ‘other-powered phenomena’ and assert them to be truly existent but false. They refer to emptinesses as ‘natures of reality’ and assert them to be truly existent and true. They refer to uncompounded phenomena other than emptiness as ‘imaginaries’ and assert them to be falsely existent and false. They say that all natures of reality are non-affirming negatives. They explain other non-affirming negatives in the same way as the Sautrantikas.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECT-POSSESSORS

The True Aspectarians assert a collection of eight consciousnesses: the six consciousnesses asserted by the other proponents of tenets, together with a consciousness-basis-of-all and a deluded mentality. The consciousness-basis-of-all is a seventh consciousness that is other than the six consciousnesses. They assert that the consciousness-basis-of-all is the person who is the basis of actions and effects.

The False Aspectarians assert a collection of six consciousnesses and they say that the mental consciousness is the person who is the basis of actions and effects.

The Chittamatrins assert two types of mind: valid cognizers and non-valid cognizers. They assert two types of valid cognizer: direct valid cognizers and subsequent valid cognizers. There are four types of direct valid cognizer: valid sense direct perceivers, valid mental direct perceivers, valid self-cognizing direct perceivers and valid yogic direct perceivers.

Self-cognizing direct perceivers and yogic direct perceivers are necessarily non-mistaken awareness. Sense direct perceivers in the continuums of ordinary beings are necessarily mistaken awareness. Mental direct perceivers in the continuums of ordinary beings can be either mistaken or non-mistaken.

There are four types of yogic direct perceiver: yogic direct perceivers directly realizing subtle impermanence, subtle selflessness of persons, gross selflessness of persons, and subtle selflessness of phenomena.

WAY OF ASSERTING SELFLESSNESS

They assert gross and subtle selflessness of persons in the same way as the Sautrantikas. They assert the emptiness that is a form and a form-apprehending valid cognizer’s lack of being other substances as an instance of subtle selflessness of phenomena.

PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

This has two parts:

1 Objects to be abandoned

2 Actual presentation of grounds and paths

OBJECTS TO BE ABANDONED

They assert delusion-obstructions to be self-grasping of persons together with its seeds, and the three poisons together with their seeds that arise through their power. They assert obstructions to omniscience to be self-grasping of phenomena together with its seeds, its imprints, and all the mistaken dualistic appearance that arises through their power.

ACTUAL PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

Their assertions regarding the way members of the Hearer and Solitary Realizer lineages progress on the paths is the same as the assertions of the Vaibhashikas and Sautrantikas. They say that Bodhisattvas take as their object of meditation the emptiness that is apprehender and apprehended’s lack of being other substances. By meditating on this for three countless great aeons for the sake of others they attain great enlightenment.

The True Aspectarians assert that when Hearer and Solitary Realizer Foe Destroyers pass beyond sorrow without remainder, their mental continuums cease. They assert that it is not possible for the mental continuum of a Buddha to cease because Bodhisattvas first attain Buddhahood in an Enjoyment Body in Akanishta and that Enjoyment Body, with an uninterrupted continuum of the same aspect, works for the welfare of others through various emanations according to the fortune of disciples until samsara ceases. They assert that the three vehicles are definite in their own final lineages because since beginningless time living beings have had three different lineages or dispositions; and due to these, three different inclinations; and due to these, three different practices; and due to these they attain three different final results.

The False Aspectarians do not assert that when Hearers and Solitary Realizer Foe Destroyers pass beyond sorrow without remainder their mental continuums cease. They assert that at that time the continuum of only the consciousness that is the nature of true suffering and true origins ceases. However a mere consciousness does go to the ground of Buddhahood, and therefore they assert the existence of one final vehicle.

EXPLANATION OF THE SYSTEM OF THE MADHYAMIKAS

This has three parts:

1 Definition

2 Divisions

3 Explanation of each division

DEFINITION

The definition of Madhyamika is a person propounding Mahayana tenets who does not assert true existence even nominally.

DIVISIONS

There are two divisions:

1 Madhyamika-Svatantrikas

2 Madhyamika-Prasangikas

EXPLANATION OF EACH DIVISION

This has two parts:

1 Explanation of the system of the Madhyamika-Svatantrikas

2 Explanation of the system of the Madhyamika-Prasangikas

EXPLANATION OF THE SYSTEM OF THE MADHYAMIKA-SVATANTRIKAS

This has seven parts:

1 Definition

2 Divisions

3 Etymology

4 Way of asserting objects

5 Way of asserting object-possessors

6 Way of asserting selflessness

7 Presentation of grounds and paths

DEFINITION

The definition of Madhyamika-Svatantrika is a proponent of Madhyamika tenets who asserts inherent existence.

DIVISIONS

There are two divisions:

1 Sautrantika-Madhyamika-Svatantrika

2 Yogachara-Madhyamika-Svatantrika

The definition of the first is a proponent of Madhyamika tenets who asserts nominalities mostly in accordance with the Sautrantikas. The definition of the second is a proponent of Madhyamika tenets who asserts nominalities mostly in accordance with the Chittamatrins. Examples of the first are Bhavaviveka and Gyanagarbha; and examples of the second are Shantirakshita, Haribhadra and Kamalashila.

ETYMOLOGY

‘Svatantrika’ means ‘Autonomist’. They are so called because they assert autonomous syllogisms and autonomous conclusive reasons possessing the three modes.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECTS

Existing by way of its own characteristics, existing from its own side and existing inherently are synonyms. They assert that all phenomena exist in these three ways. They assert unproduced space, true cessations, past, future, and subtle selflessness of persons to be both non-affirming negatives and conventional truths. Ultimate truth, nature of reality and subtle selflessness of phenomena are synonyms.

The Sautrantika-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert that the five objects, form and so forth, are different entities from awareness and are gross external objects composed of partless particles. The Yogachara-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert that they are the same entity as the awareness apprehending them.

WAY OF ASSERTING OBJECT-POSSESSORS

They assert a collection of six consciousnesses, and that the mental consciousness is the person.

There are two types of mind: valid cognizers and non-valid cognizers. There are two types of valid cognizer: direct valid cognizers and subsequent valid cognizers. The Sautrantika-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas do not assert self-cognizing direct perceivers. The Yogachara-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert all four types of direct perceiver. They say that self-cognizing direct perceivers and yogic direct perceivers are necessarily non-mistaken awareness; the other two can be either mistaken or non-mistaken.

The Sautrantikas, Chittamatrins and Svatantrikas all assert that direct perceivers are necessarily non-conceptual awareness, that re-cognizers are necessarily non-valid awareness, that an awareness mistaken with respect to its conceived object is necessarily a wrong awareness, that an awareness that is mistaken with respect to a particular phenomenon is necessarily a non-valid cognizer with respect to that phenomenon, and that subsequent cognizers are necessarily non-valid cognizers with respect to their appearing objects.

WAY OF ASSERTING SELFLESSNESS

They assert the lack of a permanent, partless, causeless person to be gross selflessness of persons; and the lack of a self-supporting, substantially existent person to be subtle selflessness of persons. The Yogachara-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas assert a form and a form-apprehending valid cognizer’s lack of being other substances to be gross selflessness of phenomena; and all phenomena’s lack of true existence to be subtle selflessness of phenomena.

The two selflessnesses are distinguished by way of their object of negation, not by way of their bases of emptiness. Thus the negation of true existence on the basis of a person is subtle selflessness of phenomena; and the negation of self-supporting, substantial existence on the basis of a person is subtle selflessness of persons.

The two self-graspings are distinguished by way of the manner of grasping, not by way of their observed object. Thus grasping at true existence observing the basis person is self-grasping of phenomena, and grasping at self-supporting, substantial existence observing the basis person is self-grasping of persons.

PRESENTATION OF GROUNDS AND PATHS

The Yogachara-Madhyamika-Svatantrikas posit the differences between the persons of the three vehicles in terms of three different obstructions that are the principal objects to be abandoned, and three different views that are the principal objects of meditation. They say that members of the Hearer lineage take the mind conceiving a self-supporting, substantially existent person as their principal object to be abandoned.
